incidents.content: A joint investigation by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) and the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ), found that, since 2015, the Chinese government had conducted coordinated campaigns against diaspora dissidents living in Canada. Tactics included digital surveillance, hacking, harassment, intimidation of families in China, and smear campaigns. The investigation exposed systematic efforts by PRC authorities and their proxies to silence critics abroad using both online and offline methods. Canadian lawmakers from multiple parties urged the newly elected government to enforce the recently passed Countering Foreign Interference Act and to take immediate steps to protect targeted individuals. Adopted in June 2024, the Bill is supposed to “counter the rising threat of transnational repression and foreign interference in Canada by giving government departments and agencies more powers to fight it and by creating a foreign agent registry and a foreign interference transparency commissioner”.
incidents.title: Investigation sheds light on PRC targeting of dissidents in Canada

incidents.content: In June 2025, Canada’s Centre for Cyber Security  (Cyber Centre) and the United States’ FBI jointly stated that PRC-linked cyberespionage group Salt Typhoon had conducted malicious operations targeting Canada’s telecommunications infrastructure. According to the joint advisory, at least one Canadian telecommunications provider was breached in mid-February 2025. The attackers exploited vulnerabilities in network edge infrastructure, specifically older Cisco routers, to gain access and collect sensitive data. The Cyber Centre warned that Salt Typhoon was still targeting Canadian entities and was likely to persist in doing so over the next two years. In a separate advisory from April 2025, the Cyber Centre had already singled out Salt Typhoon as “ targeting network edge routers across critical infrastructure sectors”.
incidents.title: PRC state-affiliated hackers target Canadian telecommunications sector

incidents.content: In April 2025, Canada’s Security and Intelligence Threats to Elections(SITE) Task Force reported that a coordinated information operation linked to the PRC government targeted Prime Minister and Liberal Party leader Mark Carney during the 45th general election. The campaign originated on WeChat through the anonymous account Youli‑Youmian, which Canadian intelligence links to the CCP’s Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission. The operation amplified both positive and negative narratives about Carney, including his stance on relations with the United States and his qualifications for office. Analysts observed coordinated posting activity on March 10 and again during the writ period on March 25. Approximately 30 WeChat accounts reposted content in close sequence, a tactic identified as inauthentic amplification. The operation generated between 85,000 and 130,000 interactions and potentially reached 1 to 3 million users. Despite its scale, Canadian officials determined the campaign did not compromise the integrity of the election. A Liberal Party representative was briefed on the findings, and the SITE Task Force raised the issue with Tencent, WeChat’s developer. Canada describes the SITE Task Force as the country’s “principal mechanism to monitor the threat from hostile state interference during elections”.
incidents.title: PRC-linked WeChat operation targeted Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney

incidents.content: In early February 2025, Canada’s Security and Intelligence Threats to Elections (SITE) Task Force detected a coordinated online information operation targeting Liberal Party leadership candidate Chrystia Freeland. The campaign originated from a popular anonymous WeChat news account linked to the PRC government, and involved over 30 WeChat news accounts publishing derogatory content about Freeland. SITE reported that the operation generated substantial engagement, with over 140,000 interactions between January 29 and February 3, and was visible to an estimated 2 to 3 million WeChat users worldwide. The goal was to undermine confidence in Freeland’s candidacy as she vied to replace Prime Minister Trudeau. SITE briefed Freeland’s campaign team and Liberal Party executives on February 7. Canada describes the SITE Task Force as the country’s “principal mechanism to monitor the threat from hostile state interference during elections”.
incidents.title: Canada detects China‑linked information operation targeting Chrystia Freeland

incidents.content: In the lead-up to Canda’s April 2025 federal election, the country’s Security and Intelligence Threats to Elections (SITE) Task Force determined that PRC authorities targeted Joe Tay, a Conservative Party candidate for Parliament known for his opposition to Beijing’s policies. In December 2024, Hong Kong police issued a warrant and placed a bounty on Tay as one of six overseas democracy activists accused of violating Hong Kong’s national security law. In addition, Canadian intelligence identified a coordinated online repression campaign designed to discredit Tay and suppress information about his candidacy. The campaign involved amplification of narratives about the arrest warrant and his political competence across platforms including Facebook, WeChat, TikTok, RedNote, and Douyin. Intelligence officials also observed keyword filtering of Tay’s name in Chinese characters on PRC-based platforms. Canadian authorities classified the effort as a transnational repression operation, noting that one Facebook account involved was historically linked to PRC authorities in Hong Kong. While the campaign had limited engagement, officials flagged it as a deliberate and persistent attempt to manipulate voter perceptions in a diaspora-rich riding with a history of foreign interference. Canada describes the SITE Task Force as the country’s “principal mechanism to monitor the threat from hostile state interference during elections”.
incidents.title: PRC-linked repression campaign targets Canadian candidate Joe Tay

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On September 12, 2019, former local lawmaker Han Dong won the Liberal Party of Canada’s (LPC) nomination in Don Valley North—an electoral district in the Greater Toronto Area—for that year’s federal elections. According to the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians’ report, between 175 and 200 Chinese international students arrived at the nomination contest on buses arranged by the PRC Consulate. PRC officials gave these students falsified documentation, breaking the LPC’s requirement that only a district’s residents can vote in nomination contests there. PRC officials also told students that their student visas would be jeopardized if they did not vote for Dong and reportedly looked to physically intimidate other voters. The Canadian Security Intelligence Service assessed that this played a “significant role” in Dong’s narrow victory. Dong maintains that his campaign was not involved in busing in international students from outside the district.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: 2019 Elections: PRC Buses in Chinese International Students to Vote in Toronto-Area Party Nomination Contest

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In February 2021, Michael Chong, a member of parliament (MP) from the Conservative Party of Canada (CPC) sponsored a parliamentary motion to label the PRC’s treatment of Uighurs in Xinjiang Province a genocide. Soon thereafter, the Canadian Security Intelligence Service found that PRC officials were collecting data on Chong’s relatives in Hong Kong and concluded that the PRC intended to make an example of him to deter other MPs from taking similar “anti-China” positions. In May 2023, Canada expelled PRC diplomat Zhao Wei for his role in targeting Chong and his family. Chong also reported a disinformation campaign directed at him in the summer of 2023. While Canadian intelligence confirmed that a campaign directed at Chong had several hallmarks of a PRC-directed operation, such as a coordinated network on popular Chinese messaging app WeChat, it could not definitively attribute the activity to the PRC.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: 2021 Elections: PRC Diplomat targets Canadian MP and his family

incidents.content: In 2021, a confidential Canadian intelligence report revealed that Chinese diplomat Zhao Wei had sought to gather information about the family of Conservative Member of Parliament Michael Chong. Beijing had previously hit Chong with sanctions after he sponsored a Canadian parliamentary motion saying China’s treatment of the Uighur Muslim minority in the Xinjiang region constitutes genocide. The Canadian agency said that Zhao had sought information on Chong’s relatives “who may be located in the PRC, for further potential sanctions” and that China wanted “to make an example of this MP and deter others from taking anti-PRC positions”. Following the Globe and Mail’s publication of the report in May 2023, Canada expelled Zhao Wei.
incidents.title: Chinese diplomat gathers information on Canadian MP’s family

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In January 2022, a Federal Canadian court upheld a decision identifying the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office (OCAO), an administration that is part of the CCP’s United Front Work Department (UFWD), as an entity that engages in espionage acts “contrary to Canada’s interests.” The ruling upheld a Canadian official’s denial of permanent Canadian residence to a Chinese citizen owing to their more than 20-year employment with the OCAO. Officially, the OCAO manages overseas issues related to China, including liaising with the Chinese diaspora. However, in court, Canadian Immigration argued “that the nature of OCAO’s interactions with the overseas Chinese communities, the information gathered, and the intended use of the gathered information is surreptitious,” — an assertation the judge upheld. UFWD is the CCP agency responsible for ensuring Party control of PRC society, including Chinese businesspeople and members of the Chinese diaspora such as Huang, and has been linked to cases of political interference around the world.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Canadian court rules PRC’s Overseas Chinese Affairs Office conducts espionage, gathers information on diaspora

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In November 2016, Chinese state-affiliated hacker group Panda Emissary, also known as APT27, launched a cyberattack against the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), a UN agency responsible for standard setting in the global civilian aviation industry based in Montreal, Canada. The hackers compromised ICAO’s servers and website, and used them as a springboard to access employee data and other information at other organizations. However, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation revealed in 2019 that ICAO, headed by Secretary General Fang Liu, a former Chinese government official, obstructed investigations into the attack. James Wan, ICAO’s deputy director of information management and general administration, dismissed findings from New York-based UN IT analysts and, in December 2016, the ICT team he headed was formally accused of “acting with intent to disguise the source, nature and impact of a breach of the ICAO network.” According to Canadian media, the team was escorted out of the ICAO building on December 21, 2016 before being re-instated six weeks later after “pressure from higher up the United Nations chain.” According to the same media report, ICAO Secretary General Fang Liu “shelved internal recommendations to investigate the four ICT team members and James Wan.”

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese state-affiliated hackers infiltrate UN civil aviation body's servers

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Starting at least in 2010, cyberattacks originating in China targeted three bodies of the Canadian government: the Canadian Finance Department, the Treasury Board, as well as Defence Research and Development Canada. The attacks on the two economic agencies were detected in January 2010 and forced them to disconnect from the internet as a result of the attack. CBC reports that Defence Research and Development had to shut down access to one of its servers for two months as a result of “an earlier attack.” While the Canadian government never officially attributed the attacks to the Chinese state, Canadian media reported at the time that “Chinese government hackers” were behind the attack.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Canadian government targeted by cyber-attack originating in China

incidents.content: In July 2014, China’s state-sponsored hackers attacked the Canadian National Research Council’s computer systems through phishing messages containing malicious links. The Council works with private businesses to fund and develop technological innovation. The Canadian Cyber Incident Response Centre reported that the hackers were after intellectual property, trade secrets, and other sensitive information. Canadian federal documents revealed that the cyber intrusion involving multiple departments cost Canada hundreds of millions of dollars. While the Canadian government had previously been targeted by actors seemingly based in China, this was the first time that they publicly blamed the Chinese state for a cyber-attack.
incidents.title: Chinese state-affiliated hackers attack Canada National Research Council

incidents.content: In June 2020, remarks by an official from the Chinese Foreign Ministry made an explicit connection between Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, two Canadians detained in China, and the extradition proceedings of Huawei CFO, Meng Wanzhou. His remarks implied that a prisoner swap between the two nations is feasible. The Chinese, up and to this point, have repeatedly refuted claims that the detention and indictment of the two Canadians on espionage charges were retaliation for the legal proceedings against Meng Wanzhou. Additionally, the Chinese government has demanded the Canadian government put an end to extradition proceedings. The Canadian Prime Minister, Justin Trudeau, responded that the judicial system in Canada is independent and the federal government cannot intercede. Trudeau faces contradictory pressures from some parts of the Canadian political spectrum to be tougher on China, and from others to release Meng altogether.
incidents.title: Chinese official explicitly states that two Canadian prisoners could be released if the Canadian government stops the extradition of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou

incidents.content: Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, two Canadians initially detained by Chinese authorities in December 2018 on allegations of endangering Chinese national security, were formally indicted on charges of espionage in June 2020. Unlike Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou, arrested in Vancouver in December 2018, the Canadian citizens have not had access to legal consul and have been subject to what some have labeled as torture in the form of solitary confinement as well as being kept awake through constant exposure to light for multiple days. The indictments occurred a month after a Canadian court ruled that the legal requirements had been met for Ms. Wanzhou to be extradited to the United States. Western governments view the indictments as retaliation for Ms. Wanzhou's continued detention, and without legal merit.
incidents.title: Two Canadian citizens indicted for espionage in China in what many see as retaliation for the arrest of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou

incidents.content: In June 2019, China announced a suspension of Canadian pork and beef imports. Officially, the ban was justified by the discovery of a banned additive and by falsified export certificates for some products. However, the move has more commonly been viewed as retaliation for Canada's 2018 arrest of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou. In November 2019, China allowed sales to resume, but estimates of the loss for Canadian industry have ranged from $100 million to nearly $500 million.
incidents.title: China suspends Canadian pork imports in move seen as ongoing retaliation for arrest of Huawei CFO

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

At McMaster University, Uighur activist Rukiye Turdush had several Chinese students shout to disrupt her speech about Xinjiang, and students apparently contacted the Chinese consulate in Toronto about the event. According to screenshots of messages between the students and consulate officials, the consulate reportedly told students to observe whether school officials attended the event. Subsequently, the university's student assembly voted to de-certify the Chinese Students and Scholars Association for hiding "connections to the Chinese government" and "intimidating students on campus who speak out against the Chinese government".

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese students, allegedly with backing of government-supported association, harass speaker discussing Xinjiang

incidents.content: In January 2019, China's Foreign Ministry issued a travel advisory concerning Canada, citing risks of "arbitrary detention." The advisory was part of the CCP's retaliation over the arrest of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou. As of 2018, Chinese tourism in Canada represented approximately $1.6 billion in revenue from nearly 700,000 annual visitors. Visa requests from Chinese tourists declined in 2019, and the Canadian tourist industry had seen significant declines in business even before the travel limitations resulting from the coronavirus pandemic. On July 6, 2020, a new travel advisory from the Chinese government cautioned against visiting Canada and cited "frequent violent actions" by Canadian law enforcement," while a government spokesman said that Canada "grossly interfered in China's internal affairs," referencing Canada's statements about Hong Kong's loss of autonomy under Beijing's new national security law.
incidents.title: Beijing issues travel warnings in retaliation for the arrest of Huawei's CFO, damaging Canada's tourism sector

incidents.content: The Canadian province of New Brunswick removed Confucius Institutes from all its schools after receiving several complaints from students stating that certain topics within Chinese history were deemed inappropriate during classes organized by the Institute. Confucius Institutes are language and culture centers run by the People’s Republic of China’s Ministry of Education, which are hosted in more than 500 universities around the world. Critics have raised concerns about incidents of infringement upon intellectual freedom at some Confucius Institutes, whose terms of agreement are often hidden. A former head of propaganda for the Chinese Communist Party has called them "an important part of China’s overseas propaganda set-up." The province is phasing out programs provided by the Confucius Institute for elementary and middle school students as of August 2019. Select programs will continue to be available for high school students to comply with the contract between the school district and the Institute which extends out to 2022. Canadian media reports add that the province will continue to comply with the contract out of fear of potential financial repercussions given that the China is New Brunswick's third-largest export market.
incidents.title: Students in New Brunswick complain that certain Chinese historical topics were 'off limits' in Confucius Institute cultural programs

incidents.content: In November 2018, the NDP and Liberal parties formally requested the Canadian Federal Election Commission probe the relationship between the Conservative Party and 10 non-profit organizations set-up by a Toronto real-estate developer, Ted Jiancheng Zhou, who emigrated from China in 2013. Mr. Jiancheng set up Chinese-Canadian conservative groups in British Columbia, Alberta, and Ontario as well as created a national organization called the Federation of Chinese Canadian Conservatives. The probe will focus on collusion between the Conservative party and the Chinese Canadian organizations to circumvent donation caps in Canadian election law. According to a Globe and Mail article, Mr. Jiancheng has close ties to members of the CCP, and has been a prominent donor to the Liberal party in the past. The Conservative party has denied the allegations of collusion.
incidents.title: Canadian political parties ask that Canadian Election Commission investigate political donor with connections to the CCP over potential collusion with the Conservative party to circumvent donation caps

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In December 2018, nine days after Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou was arrested in Vancouver by Canadian authorities, two Canadian citizens, Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, were arrested in China for allegedly endangering Chinese national security. One of the Canadians detained is a former diplomat. The Wall Street Journal reported days after the arrests that several former and current ambassadors familiar with the inner workings of the CCP saw the detention of the Canadian citizens as retaliation for the arrest of Ms. Wanzhou. Shortly after the arrest of Ms. Wanzhou, the Chinese Foreign Ministry threatened the Canadian government with severe consequences if she was not released. In June 2020, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stated that there was a direct link between the cases of Ms. Wanzhou and of the detained Canadians in China.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Two Canadian citizens arrested for "endangering China's National Security," current and former Canadian officials call the arrests retaliation

incidents.content: According to an Amnesty International report submitted to the Canadian government in 2018, a Canadian activist of Chinese descent faced harassment from Chinese security services for several weeks when he went to visit his family in China. Prior to returning to Canada, the activist was confronted by officials from the Chinese security service and was told that if he did not stop his criticism of the Chinese government his family would face consequences. The report notes that the Canadian activist has stopped his criticism out of fear for his family’s safety.
incidents.title: Amnesty International reports that Chinese dissidents living in Canada face harassment and threats to stop criticizing the Chinese government

incidents.content: Meng Wanzhou, CFO of Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei, was arrested by Canadian authorities in December 2018. The Chinese Embassy in Canada released a statement refuting any wrongdoing and demanded Ms. Meng’s immediate release. Canadian officials stated that she was sought for extradition to the United States. Charges released in January 2019 confirmed that the United States was indicting Huawei with stealing technology and violating economic sanctions against Iran. Ms. Meng is the daughter of the CEO of the firm and is also deputy chairwoman of the board. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Huawei CFO, Meng Wanzhou, arrested in Canada over sanctions skirting

incidents.content: In October 2017, The New York Times reported that the Russian Congress of Canada (RPC), a Canada-based non-profit group reportedly tied to the Russian government, strongly opposed a Canadian bill that bars corporations from dealing with foreigners who have committed human rights violations. Canadian lawmakers claimed that the Russian government orchestrated the group’s unsuccessful attempt to derail the law as a part of a broader lobbying effort against similar sanctions bills. Although the RPC denies having any ties to the Kremlin, according to the New York Times, "lawmakers say the push fits a pattern of Moscow-backed interference in the West."
incidents.title: Russian government uses Canada-based NGO as proxy to attempt to derail sanctions law, according to Canadian lawmakers

incidents.content: A statement posted by Canadian lawmaker Jenny Kwan, which praised the pro-democracy Umbrella Movement in Hong Kong, was removed from Chinese social media and messaging app WeChat. Kwan told the Human Rights Watch that the post had garnered a handful of views, likes, and comments before being quietly removed. WeChat's content, which attracts around 100 million users outside of China, is censored by the Chinese government, with posts that criticize the regime being subject to removal. The removal of Kwan's post, according to the Human Rights Watch, is an instance where the Chinese regime has "interfered with communications between elected officials and constituents" in a Western democracy through censorship on WeChat.
incidents.title: Canadian MP's statement on Hong Kong protests removed from WeChat due to CCP censorship

incidents.content: Starting in January 2017, pro-Russian news sites began to spread narratives that the grandfather of newly-appointed Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister, Chrystia Freeland, served as a Nazi propagandist in Nazi-occupied Poland. Freeland argued that the articles were part of a Kremlin-orchestrated smear campaign designed to delegitimize her office. In 2014, the Russian government issued Freeland a travel ban in repsponse to her advocacy for sanctions against Russian entities in the wake of the Crimean annexation and for her tough stance on Russian corruption. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau expelled four Russian diplomats in March 2018 at least in part for using "their diplomatic status to undermine Canada’s security or interfere in [its] democracy” by participating in the smear campaign.
incidents.title: Canadian foreign minister accuses Russian government of orchestrating smear campaign

incidents.content: In November 2016, after a cash-for-access fundraiser for the Liberal party that was attended by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, the head of the China Cultural Industry Organization in Canada and Senior CCP member, Zhang Bin, donated $1 million to various Canadian organizations. $750,000 of the donation funded scholarships for the University of Montreal Faculty of Law and grants for Canadian students to visit China. Another $200,000 went to the Trudeau Foundation, and the remaining $50,000 went to funding for a statue of Pierre Trudeau. The fundraiser was held at the private residence of a Chinese Canadian businessman, and hosted other Chinese businessman and political elites. Prime Minister Trudeau has denied all accusations of impropriety and stated that it was an effort to attract Chinese investment in Canada.
incidents.title: Senior CCP member makes substantial donation to the Pierre Trudeau Foundation.

incidents.content: On September 13, 2016, the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), headquartered in Canada, announced that the Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacker group Fancy Bear, or APT28, had stolen confidential medical information about U.S. Olympic athletes and released it on the Internet. WADA Director General Olivier Niggli denounced the attacks as "an attempt to undermine WADA and the global anti-doping system."
incidents.title: Russian government-backed hackers steal confidential medical information from the World Anti-Doping Agency

incidents.content: In June 2016, Gao Bingchen, a journalist at a Vancouver-based Chinese-language newspaper, was forced to end his periodic column after criticizing Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi’s interaction with a reporter during a joint press conference with Canadian Foreign Minister Stephane Dion. At the press conference, Wang berated a reporter due to a question that framed China’s human rights record negatively. Gao's piece that criticized Wang was published via Gao’s social media account and did not appear in the Chinese-language newspaper for which he is a columnist. His editor informed him that the decision to end his column was the result of outside pressure. Similarly, another Canadian journalist, Xin Feng, received death threats after publishing a critical piece on Wang to the Canadian based Chinese-language website, 51.ca. Both of these incidents highlight the CCP's efforts to control China’s image globally and suppress criticism regardless of borders and local laws.
incidents.title: Chinese-Canadian journalists face pressure over criticism of the Chinese Foreign Minister's reaction during a press conference in Canada

incidents.content: In July 2015, Helen Wang, the editor of the Chinese Canadian Post, claimed she was fired after the Chinese Consulate and the paper's owner - who Canadian press reported had "close ties to the consulate" - complained to the paper over an article about Ontario MP Michael Chan. The article criticized Chan's strong reaction to reports that Canadian intelligence thought he was under undue influence from the CCP. Wang claims that the publisher received complaints from the Chinese consulate in Toronto, and other pro-Chinese government organizations based in Canada. NGO Canadian Journalists for Free Expression stated that Helen Wang's case was "a perfect example of the dubious ties between Beijing and supposedly "independent" Canadian media sources."
incidents.title: Editor of a Chinese-language Canadian newspaper claims she was fired as a result of Chinese pressure

incidents.content: Local school district officials in British Columbia have run into questions about potential conflicts of interest amid reporting that Hanban, the Chinese government entity responsible for administering the Confucius Institutes, paid as much as $8,000/person in grants for trips to China. School officials including a district superintendent defended the trips as promoting educational exchange, while critics have called for more scrutiny into the themes and activities of the trips. Confucius Institutes are language and culture centers run by the People’s Republic of China’s Ministry of Education, which are hosted in more than 500 universities around the world. Critics have raised concerns about incidents of infringement upon intellectual freedom at some Confucius Institutes, whose terms of agreement are often hidden. A former head of propaganda for the Chinese Communist Party has called them "an important part of China’s overseas propaganda set-up."
incidents.title: Confucius Institute's Hanban governing body raises conflict of interest questions in paying for school officials' trips to China

incidents.content: In 2012, Sonia Zhao, a Chinese instructor and practitioner of the Falun Gong movement, filed a human rights challenge before the Ontario Human Rights Tribunal, saying that the Confucius Institute at McMaster University had language in its hiring contract that forbade her from practicing Falun Gong. She had been hired in 2010, and left her job the following year, seeking asylum in Canada. She also says that she received training on how to promote government themes on controversial topics such as Tibet. The university ended its contract with the Confucius Institute in 2013. Confucius Institutes are language and culture centers run by the People’s Republic of China’s Ministry of Education, which are hosted in more than 500 universities around the world. Critics have raised concerns about incidents of infringement upon intellectual freedom at some Confucius Institutes, whose terms of agreement are often hidden. A former head of propaganda for the Chinese Communist Party has called them "an important part of China’s overseas propaganda set-up."
incidents.title: Chinese instructor files human rights challenge against Confucius Institute hiring practices

incidents.content: A training manual for the United Front Work Department (UFWD) encouraged employees to establish and build relationships with young Canadian politicians who were ethnically Chinese. The UFWD is the CCP agency responsible for ensuring Party control of PRC society, including Chinese businesspeople and members of the Chinese diaspora, and has been linked to cases of political interference around the world. The UFWD would invest in promising Canadian politicians in the hopes of increasing the CCP’s influence in the Canadian political system as these individuals advanced through the Canadian bureaucracy.
incidents.title: United Front manual encourages relationship building with Ethnic Chinese Canadian Politicians to gain political influence in the west

incidents.content: According to the Dutch Military Intelligence and Security Service (MIVD), Russia conducted multiple cyber operations against the Netherlands in 2024, including espionage, sabotage, and influence campaigns. One attack involved a Russian state-backed group attempting to sabotage the digital control system of a public facility in the Netherlands, the first such incident confirmed by Dutch authorities. While the impact was limited, the MIVD expressed concern over the increasing capabilities and intent of Russian cyber actors. The MIVD also identified GRU Unit 29155 as actively seeking intelligence on Western arms transfers to Ukraine and pre-positioning for possible physical sabotage. Additional operations targeted the Dutch government and critical infrastructure, particularly by stealing sensitive data like the personal details of public officials and company employees.
incidents.title: Russia targets Dutch government and infrastructure with cyber operations

incidents.content: In June 2024, pro-Kremlin hackers targeted the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg, the websites of several Dutch political parties, as well as various Irish institutions on the first day of the European elections. In the Netherlands, the parties affected by the attack were center-right Christian Democratic Appeal, far-right Forum for Democracy, and Geert Wilders’ Party for Freedom. The Irish Parliament, voter registration portal and transportation network were all affected by the attack. Hacker group HackNet later assumed responsibility for the cyber-attack on its Telegram channel. HackNet is a pro-Russian hacktivist group, considered to work in coordination with Russian intelligence services. An analyst at cyber-security firm warned that the attack was “superficial” and mainly aimed to “raise doubts in the security of the election”.
incidents.title: Pro-Kremlin hackers seek to sow doubt at start of EP elections

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On June 4, 2024, the investigative journalism platform Follow The Money and RTL Nieuws reported on a new Dutch political party receiving donations from several Chinese-Dutch associations with links to the CCP, notably from an organization affiliated with the Chinese United Front Work Department (UFWD). “Nederland met een plan” (NL PLAN) was founded in 2022 by Amsterdam-born entrepreneur Kok Kuen Chan. The party promotes strong ties between the EU and the PRC and aims to push back on alleged anti-Chinese rhetoric. Among its donors was the China Council for the Promotion of Peaceful National Reunification, an organization founded by the UFWD to promote Taiwan’s unification with mainland China. The PRC uses “United Front” work to co-opt and neutralize sources of potential opposition to the policies and authority of the CCP. The CCP’s UFWD—the agency responsible for coordinating these kinds of influence operations—mostly focuses on the management of potential opposition groups inside China, but it also has an important foreign influence mission.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: CCP-linked associations make political donations to a new Dutch party

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In January 2022, Dutch public broadcaster NOS revealed that a research center at the Free University of Amsterdam was conducting research into human rights issues, most notably on Xinjiang, with the financial support of the Chinese state. According to an agreement between the Dutch institution and a publicly funded Chinese university in Chongqing, the center received approximately 300,000 euros per year in 2018, 2019, and 2020. NOS documented many pro-CCP statements made by members of the research center in Chinese state media and online. For instance, one of the researchers there wrote on LinkedIn that stories about labor camps in Xinjiang were “rumours” and decried “whatever lies the western media comes up with” about the region. As a result of NOS’ reporting, the Free University of Amsterdam announced it would be closing the research center in July 2022. The incident was highlighted as an example of Chinese interference in Europe during Ursula von der Leyen’s 2022 State of the European Union speech.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese state funds Dutch university's human rights research into Xinjiang

incidents.content: In July 2015, Chinese state-affiliated hackers performed a cyberattack against the Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) in The Hague. The Philippines had asked the court to rule on their territorial dispute in the South China Sea and on the validity of Chinese territorial claims in the region. The hackers implanted a malicious Adobe Flash file on the PCA’s website, using it as a springboard from which to infect other machines. The malware allowed the hackers to track the website visitors’ computers and access their confidential documents. The Diplomat reports that Chinese cyber units could have used their access to the computers of journalists, diplomats, lawyers, and others to gather information on the arguments they intended to use against China in the South China Sea arbitration. The attackers’ methodology was similar to that of the Naikon Chinese state-affiliated hacker group, also known as APT unit 78020, who had previously targeted several Southeast Asian countries.
incidents.title: Chinese state-affiliated hackers attack Permanent Court of Arbitration

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

After leaking Chinese government documents exposing human rights abuses in Xinjiang in June 2019, Asiye Abdulaheb, an Uyghur woman living in the Netherlands, started receiving death threats. According to Dutch media, the documents’ release coincided with the hacking of her email account, threatening messages on social media, and harassment of her acquaintances. In particular, her ex-husband claims to have been lured to Dubai where a Chinese man saying he worked for state intelligence told him to hack into his ex-wife’s computer, showing him videos of his mother being questioned by Chinese authorities. While reporters were unable to independently verify the ex-husband’s claims, his and Ms. Abdulaheb’s accounts are consistent with Chinese authorities’ harassment of Uyghurs in other European countries.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Uyghur Dutch woman harassed after revealing details of Chinese camps

incidents.content: On April 17, 2021, Dutch newspaper de Volkskrant reported that Chinese tech giant "may have eavesdropped on Dutch mobile network's calls." Dutch telecom operator KPN started using Huawei technology in 2009 and requested a risk assessment the following year. The assessment, which was kept confidential, found that Huawei could evesdrop on all conversations on KPN's network, which included those of the Prime Minister. Huawei also knew which numbers were monitored by Dutch police and intelligence services. Finally, the report also said that the Chinese company accessed the network core from China. KPN responded to the April 2021 article by saying it had never observed Huawei taking client information and that it conducted maintenance of the core network itself. But de Volkskrant reported the next day that management of KPN's 4G network is in fact still outsourced to Huawei. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Huawei was able to monitor all calls made on one of the largest Dutch mobile phone networks

incidents.content: In April 2020, media reports suggested that far-right Dutch politician Thierry Baudet received funding from Russia. Baudet led a campaign against the Netherlands' potential support of an association agreement with Ukraine in 2016. Baudet's methods included a think tank which criticized the proposal, and a referendum campaign that thwarted the deal. The think-tank since morphed into a political party, and Baudet became a member of the Dutch parliament who has regularly espoused pro-Russian views. The 2016 WhatsApp messages in which Baudet references payments involved Vladimir Kornilov, who reportedly worked for Russian president Vladimir Putin.
incidents.title: Russian funding supported far-right Dutch politician's campaign against Ukraine agreement

incidents.content: According to Dutch intelligence services, on April 10, 2018, four Russian military intelligence agency (GRU) agents entered the Netherlands under diplomatic passports with the intention of hacking into the offices of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the organization investigating the attack on Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in the UK, as well as a chemical weapons attack in Douma, Syria. On April 13, Dutch authorities apprehended the four men outside of the OPCW offices in a car that contained sophisticated electronic equipment used for hacking. Dutch intelligence services found sufficient evidence to prove that the GRU agents intended to compromise the building’s wireless network using an antenna hidden in their car. Because they entered the country with diplomatic passports, Dutch authorities expelled the four men rather than charge them with a crime. Russian state-sponsored media outlets such as Sputnik and RT claimed the event was staged.
incidents.title: Netherlands expels four Russian military intelligence agents (GRU) for attempting to hack into the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons' (OPCW)

incidents.content: In the run-up to the April 2016 Dutch referendum on the association agreement between the EU and Ukraine, opponents of the agreement used fake reports, headlines, and photographs from Russian state-sponsored media outlets to influence the vote. For example, according to The New York Times, a prominent campaigner against the agreement shared a false report from a Russian state-sponsored TV channel falsely claiming “Ukrainian soldiers had crucified a 3-year-old Russian-speaking boy in eastern Ukraine.” The report proved to be a hoax, and the supposed Ukrainian witness turned out to be a Russian actress. The agreement, which was ratified and implemented the following year despite the referendum's failure, established a deep and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA) between Ukraine and the EU and strengthened both political and economic ties between the two entities.
incidents.title: Disinformation from Russian state-sponsored media outlets contributes to campaigns against EU-Ukraine Association Agreement

incidents.content: On January 18, 2016, trolls linked to the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) published a fabricated video showing the Ukrainian Azov Battalion threatening terrorist attacks in the Netherlands. The soldiers in the video were shown to be burning a Dutch flag and threatening to attack the Netherlands if Dutch voters rejected an association agreement with Ukraine in an April 16, 2016 referendum. A Bellingcat investigation linked the falsified video to the Internet Research Agency (IRA), describing it as an attempt to influence the referendum. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Trolls from the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) release fake video of Ukrainian soldiers threatening to conduct terrorist attacks in the Netherlands

incidents.content: In October 2015, hackers of Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, attempted to gain access to the Dutch Safety Board’s (DSB) website, according to Trend Micro. The campaign involved setting up fake servers and conducting phishing attacks to collect credentials and gain access to the DSB's servers. The DSB was investigating the downing of Malaysia Air Flight 17 (MH17), which it concluded was shot down by Russian-backed Ukrainian separatists with a Russian-made missile. The hack is suspected to have been part of an attempt to gain information regarding the investigation.
incidents.title: GRU-connected cyber group attempts to hack website of Dutch Safety Board

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In January 2018, the University of Groningen announced the cancellation of a proposed branch campus in Yantai, China, in part over concerns about limits to academic freedom. Proposed contractual language included a provision that a member of the CCP would sit on the Yantai campus governing board. In addition, a memorandum of understanding included a clause stipulating that the campus would operate "in accordance with the higher education laws and regulations of China and the Netherlands." Chinese state policies, including on education, are subject to Party approval and revision. One Dutch student representative on the university council that voted not to proceed said that "a university which is run by a party secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, is just too far."

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Concerns over academic freedom lead to cancellation of Dutch university campus in China

incidents.content: Since the July 17, 2014 downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17), which killed all 283 passengers and 15 crew on board, Russian officials and state-sponsored media outlets have pushed a wide variety of false claims and conspiracy theories to attempt to deflect blame for the downing of the commercial jetliner. Debunked narratives promoted by Russian state-sponsored media outlets and government officials often attempt to blame Ukraine for the downing. As illustrated by Bellingcat, the Russian government's various narratives have shifted often, and are contradictory and conflicting. On September 28, 2016, the international team that investigated the incident concluded that the missile that destroyed the plane had come from Russia and that it had been fired from an area controlled by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. On May 24, 2018, the investigators attributed the attack to a specific missile system belonging to a Russian military brigade.
incidents.title: Russian government officials and state-sponsored media outlets promote disinformation and conspiracy theories regarding the downing of Malaysian Airlines Flight 17 (MH17)

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On May 12, 2024, a fire at the Marywilska 44 shopping center in Warsaw destroyed one of the largest shopping centers in the city, displacing approximately 1,400 small businesses. Following a months-long investigation, Poland's Internal Security Agency (ABW) determined that the arson was part of a broader Russian intelligence-directed sabotage campaign. Several individuals were arrested in connection with the attack, and Polish officials claim that orders were issued from within Russian territory. On May 12, 2025, Poland announced the closure of the Russian consulate in Kraków in response to the previous year’s fire. Poland's foreign ministry described the consulate closure as a proportional response to hostile actions by the Russian state.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Poland ties Russian intelligence to 2024 Warsaw shopping center arson

incidents.content: On 15 January 2025, Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk announced that Russian had been planning “acts of terrorism in the air”. This statement was connected to a device at a transport company in Jablonow,  Poland, catching fire, as well as to DHL packages catching fire at warehouses in Birmingham, United Kingdom, and at Leipzig airport in Germany prior to being loaded onto a flight in July 2024. Western intelligence officials believe that the incendiary packages were test runs for future operations in the United States. US intelligence intercepted Russian communications planning to place similar incendiary devices on American flights. The type of fire created were magnesium-based, greatly complicating the extinguishing processes. Magnesium fires are made worse when water is applied and require special powder-based extinguishers.
incidents.title: Polish PM accuses Russia of targeting civilian aircraft with incendiary parcels

incidents.content: On May 31, 2024, the Polish government reported that the Polish Press Agency was hit by a cyberattack most likely perpetrated by a Kremlin-affiliated actor. The cyberattack resulted in the publication of a fake article on the Polish Press Agency’s website, announcing that Prime Minister Donald Tusk was calling for the mobilization of 200,000 Poles, “both ex-military and regular civilians”, to join the fight in Ukraine by July 1. The article was removed 8 minutes later, before being released and removed a second time. The attack took place ahead of a NATO foreign ministers meeting in Prague to discuss the long-term war effort in support of Ukraine, and Polish officials linked it to a wider attempt to influence voters heading into the 2024 European Parliament elections.
incidents.title: Russian hack leads to false news agency story about Polish mobilization

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On October 14, 2022, Microsoft’s Threat Intelligence Center assessed that a hacking group linked to Russia’s military intelligence agency conducted a ransomware attack on transportation and logistics companies in Ukraine and Poland. The attack, which was dubbed “Prestige” and targeted computer infrastructure in Poland, is perceived to be a retaliatory move against Ukraine’s logistics partners and an attempt to interfere with the flow of goods into Ukraine. Microsoft warned that this attack indicates an increased risk to organizations that directly supply or transport humanitarian or military assistance to Ukraine. The hacking group known as “Sandworm” was responsible for the ransomware attack. Microsoft tracks that group under the name “Seashell Blizzard”.  

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian hackers target organizations in Poland and Ukraine with ransomware

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In June 2022, a hacking group tied to Russian interests pushed fabricated Ukrainian government correspondence that claimed Ukrainian refugees in Poland would be apprehended and sent back to Ukraine for military service, according to the cybersecurity firm Mandiant. The hacking and disinformation group, known as Ghostwriter, used two hacktivist personas to spread the message on Telegram. On June 16, one of the hacktivist groups, Beregini, posted a fake document from Ukrainian Minister of Defense Oleksiy Reznikov to Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba that laid out plans to send male Ukrainian refugees to the frontline. On June 17, the hacktivist persona JokerDPR claimed on Telegram to have documents showing Kuleba asking Polish officials to help with deportations. That same day, a Polish politician’s dormant social media account posted images purporting to show official correspondence that laid out the deportation program. JokerDPR then used those posts to validate its earlier claims. Multiple Russian state media outlets reported the assertions as fact. The Polish government said that at least one of the letters being pushed by the hacktivists was fake. Warsaw also noted that the falsified letters were sent to an undisclosed number of emails.  

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian-linked hackers spread disinformation about Poland deporting Ukrainian refugees

incidents.content:

The Russian energy giant Gazprom said on April 27 that it would be cutting off natural gas exports to Poland and Bulgaria, citing both countries’ refusal to pay for gas in rubles. Russia President Vladimir Putin had previous ordered “unfriendly” nations to pay for gas in rubles, a move meant to stabilize Russia’s currency in the wake of sanctions sparked by Russia’s war in Ukraine. Poland and Bulgaria rely heavily on Russian gas exports, with Bulgaria getting more than 90 percent of its gas from Russia. Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, said that Russia was using “gas as an instrument of blackmail.” Hours after Russia cut gas to Warsaw and Sofia, prices for natural gas in Europe spiked by more than 23 percent.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia halts gas supplies to Poland and Bulgaria

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

The head of Russia’s foreign intelligence service, Sergei Naryshkin, claimed that the United States and Poland were plotting to restore Polish control over parts of western Ukraine under the guise of combatting Russian aggression. According to Russian officials, Polish intelligence had attempted to co-opt members of the Ukrainian elite to go along with the landgrab. The site NewsFront, which has been tied to Russian intelligence, argued that Poland is famous for “its hysterically expansive behavior” and is now rushing to “seize a piece of the collapsing Ukraine.” Other Moscow-funded outlets pushed similar lines. The General Command of the Polish Armed Forces denied that Poland has any plans to invade Ukraine. 

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia spreads false narrative that Poland plans to invade Ukraine

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

A Russian government-aligned hacking group “leveraged compromised assets” to spread disinformation about a criminal ring in Poland that was harvesting organs from Ukrainian refugees to illegally traffic in the European Union, the cybersecurity firm Mandiant said in a report. The information operation included claims that “high-ranking Polish officials” were involved in the organ trafficking program and that Poland’s Internal Security Agency had launched an investigation into the criminal ring. Mandiant linked the hacking collective behind the disinformation campaign, known as Ghostwriter, to Belarus, but the German government has said the group is tied to Russia’s military intelligence service, known as the GRU.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia-backed hackers spread disinformation about Polish organ trafficking

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Russian officials and state media launched a coordinated messaging campaign to falsely blame Western countries for causing a migrant crisis on the Polish-Belarusian border that was manufactured by Belarusian dictator Alexander Lukashenko. Russian officials insisted that Belarus was not responsible for the crisis, despite evidence that Lukashenko eased entry into Belarus for migrants who bought packages that included visas, flights, hotels, and transportation to the Polish border. Russian state media amplified President Vladimir Putin’s lie that Belarusian airlines had not carried migrants. Russian diplomats claimed that “Western nations’ policies towards the Middle East & North Africa” prompted the migrant surge. Moscow-linked Twitter accounts also highlighted instances of Polish forces violently pushing back asylum seekers and framed the European Union as hypocritical on human rights.  

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian propaganda campaign blames the West for Belarusian-manufactured migrant crisis
