In March 2021, Facebook announced that it had found a hacking operation targeting “activists, journalists and dissidents predominantly among Uyghurs from Xinjiang in China primarily living abroad.” The hackers behind the operation belonged to a group known as Earth Empusa or Evil Eye based in China. They attempted to gain access to the victims’ computers and phones by creating fake Facebook accounts, as well as websites and apps intended to appeal to a Uyghur audience. In some cases, the hackers created lookalike websites almost identical to legitimate news sites popular with Uyghurs. Facebook did not directly attribute the operation to the Chinese state but said that it was “well-resourced and persistent,” hinting at nation-state backing. In addition, Evil Eye’s long track-record of going after diaspora groups of interest to the CCP, notably Uyghurs and Tibetans, strongly suggests Chinese state involvement.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Facebook stops Chinese hacking operation targeting Uyghurs living abroad

incidents.content: On May 25, hackers linked to Russia’s Foreign Intelligence Service, or SVR, leveraged access to the U.S. Agency for International Development’s (USAID) mass emailing service in a spear-phishing campaign that targeted 3,000 individuals tied to international development, humanitarian work, human rights groups, and government organizations, according to Microsoft. The SVR hacking group, known as APT 29, gained access to the email service, Constant Contact, to send emails that appeared to be a USAID special alert about new evidence of fraud in the 2020 election. The emails contained links to malware that would give the Russian operatives access to the recipient’s computer network. Targets included anti-corruption groups, research organizations investigating Russian disinformation, and entities outspoken about the Kremlin’s treatment of Russian activist Alexei Navalny, such as the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE). Most of the spear-phishing emails were blocked by threat detection systems, though some may have successfully reached their targets, Microsoft said.
incidents.title: Russian government-linked hackers compromise USAID email system to launch phishing attack against government agencies, civil society organizations

incidents.content: In March 2020, cybersecurity firm FireEye reported that Chinese state affiliated hacker unit APT41 had waged a cyber campaign affecting 75 organizations in over 20 countries. The intrusions affected government agencies, non-profits, media organizations, and companies in sectors including finance, high tech, and energy. Using a vulnerability in software distributed by companies including Cisco and Citrix, APT41 launched a remarkably broad cyber action. FireEye described the attacks as "one of the broadest campaigns by a Chinese cyber espionage actor (...) in recent years."
incidents.title: Chinese state-affiliated hacker group targets 75 organizations in several economic sectors

incidents.content: In June 2020, Google announced that Chinese state-affiliated hacker group APT 31 was targeting the personal email accounts of campaign staffers on both sides of the U.S. presidential race. The APT31 campaign emailed links to staffers enticing them to download legitimate software from the Github software download platform. Malware allowing the attacker to upload and download files would then be silently installed to the systems. One of the examples provided by Google was APT31 impersonating the popular McAfee antivirus software.
incidents.title: Chinese state-affiliated cyber unit targets Biden and Trump campaign staffers

incidents.content: In April 2021, cybersecurity firm FireEye revealed that Chinese state-affiliated hackers were conducting a cyber-campaign targeting U.S. government agencies, defense contractors, and financial institutions. Using a vulnerability in American virtual private networking (VPN) devices, at least two groups broke into the systems of several public and private institutions. While FireEye was unable to attribute all of the attacks to specific actors, they ascertained that at least part of the campaign was run by hackers with ties to APT5, a Chinese state-affiliated group active since at least 2007. The Washington Post reported that the attacks allowed "theft of intellectual property, project data" and that the full extent of data theft caused by the intrusions may never be known.
incidents.title: Chinese state-affiliated APT5 steal data from many institutions in the United States

incidents.content: In November 2019, the messaging app WeChat took down the account of Chinese American users who wrote messages criticizing the Chinese government. The banned accounts were all based in the United States. A statement by WeChat owner Tencent explained that cross-platform messages between Wechat and its Chinese “sister app” Weixin caused the ban. People with Chinese phone numbers sign up to Weixin, while people with international phone numbers register to WeChat. The two Tencent apps are interoperable but use different servers and store user data in different locations. However, Weixin is ubiquitous in China, meaning that Chinese Americans who are banned from WeChat risk losing contact with their friends and relatives in China. So while Tencent argues that only Weixin users inside China are subjected to Chinese law, WeChat users abroad are de facto subjected to Chinese censorship if they want to keep in touch with friends and family.
incidents.title: Chinese app WeChat bans U.S.-based accounts criticizing Chinese authorities

incidents.content: In May and early June 2020, at the request of Chinese government, video-conferencing company Zoom suspended meetings and accounts of U.S.-based Chinese activists for publicizing the commemoration of the Tiananmen Square massacre. The suspended meetings had a "significant number of mainland China participants" but also included hosts and participants based in the United States or Hong Kong. A statement by Zoom explained that the suspension took place in response to a demand from Chinese authorities, who deemed the meetings illegal under Chinese law. According to the Guardian, the company also suggested it would block any further meetings that Beijing deemed illegal.
incidents.title: Zoom suspends activists' accounts at the request of the Chinese government

incidents.content: For about four months starting in September 2012, Chinese hackers launched continuous cyberattacks on the New York Times’ computer systems. The hackers accessed the newspaper’s internal system and accessed the personal computers of over 50 employees, including those of the Beijing and Shanghai bureau chiefs. The New York Times reported that the hacking campaign coincided with the release of a report, authored by the newspaper’s Shanghai bureau chief, exposing the wealth of then Chinese premier Wen Jiabao. The Chinese government had warned that the New York Times’ report would “have consequences.” Cybersecurity experts that helped the newspaper found that the attacks had been routed through American university computers previously used by the Chinese military “to attack United States military contractors.”
incidents.title: New York Times hacked as it releases report on Chinese premier’s wealth

On 19 July 2021, NATO, the European Union, Australia, New Zealand and Japan all issued public statements officially attributing an attack on Microsoft to Chinese state-sponsored actors. In March 2021, suspected China-backed cyber espionage groups carried out a cyberattack on Microsoft’s email software, leading to hundreds of thousands of businesses and organizations’ data and credentials being compromised. Microsoft said the hacking took advantage of a previously undetected vulnerability to remotely enter the email boxes. Microsoft's Threat Intelligence Centre blamed the cyber-attack on Hafnium, a state-sponsored group operating out of China. According to the Diplomat, the cyberattack initially targeted U.S. think tanks. 

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: NATO, EU, and allies attribute email intrusion to Chinese state-backed hackers

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Bugra Arkin, the owner of a Uyghur restaurant in California, claims to have received direct threats from Chinese secret police at his restaurant. California media reports that his parents, still in Xinjiang, are monitored by the authorities. His father was detained in Xinjiang and Arkin says Chinese officials told him to stop promoting Uyghur identity and culture if he wanted his father to be released. His mother had an app installed on her phone that monitors their conversations and she never answers Arkin’s questions about his father.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese officials threaten Uyghur restaurant owner in California

incidents.content: In November 2018, Russian foreign intelligence agency (SVR)-connected hacking group APT29 launched a large spear-phishing operation directed at multiple sectors of the U.S. economy and government, according to cybersecurity firms Crowdstrike and FireEye. The attacks, which were the first notable actions by the hacking group in over a year, targeted government and law enforcement agencies, think tanks/NGOs, pharmaceutical companies, and transportation infrastructure. APT29 gained notoriety for its hacking of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) in 2016 and hacks of the Norwegian and French governments in 2017.
incidents.title: Russian state-backed hackers target government, non-profits, critical infrastructure, and private sector

incidents.content:

In December 2018, Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacking group APT28 targeted the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a Washington D.C. based think tank, according to court filings. The Daily Beast reported that APT28 hackers set up an array of fake websites mimicking CSIS internal cyberinfrastructure, designed to fool CSIS staffers into inputting their credentials, and a mail server mimicking CSIS systems. Microsoft, which initially identified the activity, also announced that APT28 hackers had set up a fake domain that seemed to mimic an internal login site for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, a U.S. government-funded independent media outlet. Earlier in 2018, Microsoft identified a similar campaign linked to APT28 that targeted other U.S. think tanks and NGOs.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian state-backed hackers target U.S. think tank

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In February 2021, the National Counterintelligence and Security Center issued a public report warning that the Chinese state was working to acquire American health data, particularly pertaining to U.S. citizens' DNA. The report states that through targeted acquisitions, "aggressive marketing" of Chinese COVID-19 testing kits, and cyber operations, Chinese authorities had already gained access healthcare information of "much of the U.S. population." The document explains that this information is being used to advance Chinese medical research and expresses concerns about the potential for blackmail.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese state targets American genomic and other healthcare data

incidents.content: Russian military intelligence-sponsored APT28, or Fancy Bear, was flagged by Microsoft for targeting email accounts of democratic state parties in California and Indiana as well as election-related organizations in Washington D.C. and New York. According to an ABC News report, APT28 successfully entered systems containing voter registration information from two counties, but the counties involved were not disclosed. The related organizations included the Center for American Progress, the Council on Foreign Relations, and the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, according to a Reuters report.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored APT28 targeted Democratic state parties in California and Indiana and other organizations connected with the 2020 election.

incidents.content: The Department of the Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) issued sanctions against the Kremlin after attributing the destructive Triton malware to a Russian government research institution. Russia’s Central Scientific Research Institute of Chemistry and Mechanics (CNIIHM) designed Triton, also known as TRISIS and HatMan, to target a specific industrial control systems (ICS) controller used in critical infrastructure facilities to initiate immediate shutdown procedures in case of an emergency. Depending on how the malware is deployed, it can have lethal effects by allowing machinery to work in an unsafe state, creating a risk of explosions. It was reported that the malware was scanning at least 20 electrical utilities in the United States for vulnerabilities.
incidents.title: The US Treasury Department attributed the creation of highly destructive “Triton” malware to the Russian government

incidents.content: Cybercriminals based in Moscow and St. Petersburg are responsible for launching cyberattacks on nearly 400 U.S. hospitals, and as of October 2020, about 30 hospitals were successfully infected. Cybersecurity professionals speculate that the attacks are retribution for Microsoft’s TrickBot takedown over the summer, which took offline more than 90% of TrickBot servers. Hackers had previously agreed not to target hospitals due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. In some ransomware attacks, hackers held hospital administrators hostage for $5 million in cryptocurrency.
incidents.title: Russia-based cybercriminals have targeted more than 400 U.S. hospitals in cyber operations

incidents.content: A joint advisory from CISA and the FBI warns that Russian state-sponsored APT Havex, or Energetic Bear, has been targeting dozens of state, local, territorial, and tribal (SLTT) government networks. The APT successfully compromised network infrastructure and were able to harvest passwords, IT instructions, vendor and purchasing information, and printable access badges. The advisory notes that there is no evidence that elections data had been compromised in the attack, but the group may seek to use the data to delegitimize SLTT entities in the future.
incidents.title: CISA, FBI issued an advisory that a Russian state-sponsored APT has targeted state and local systems.

incidents.content: American, British, and Canadian officials accuse Kremlin intelligence-connected hackers from group APT29, or Cozy Bear, of attempting to steal COVID-19 vaccine research by targeting biotech companies. The National Security Agency (NSA) noted that the hackers were not looking to sabotage vaccine research efforts, but to expedite Russian vaccine development. APT29 deployed malware and sent fraudulent emails to harvest log-in credentials. Officials suggested that the attacks have not been hugely successful, but were prolific enough to warrant an international advisory.
incidents.title: Officials accuse the Kremlin of cyberattacks on COVID-19 vaccine-related targets.

incidents.content: Russian intelligence-linked APT28, or Fancy Bear, is responsible for launching cyberattacks that have targeted online accounts at seven companies researching COVID-19 vaccines and related medication. Microsoft published information about the attacks in the company’s official blog, but did not specify the targeted companies. Microsoft noted that APT28 deployed thousands of rapid login attempts, using password spray and brute force login attempts to steal credentials.
incidents.title: Microsoft announced that Russia-linked APT28 launched cyberattacks on COVID-19 vaccine makers.

incidents.content: In September 2020, Facebook removed several accounts based in Romania that were run by people associated with the Russian government. The network was connected to the IRA gravitating around the news website Peacedata.net and targeted "left-leaning communities" posting stories about social and racial justice issues in the US and UK, NATO and EU politics, alleging Western war crimes, corruption and environmental issues. Facebook identified 13 accounts and two Facebook pages with a following of 14,000 that made up the network stating that it was in the "early stage" of building a wider audience. The campaign largely targeted audiences in the US, UK, Algeria and Egypt, in addition to other English-speaking countries and countries in the Middle East and North Africa.
incidents.title: Facebook Removes Russian Propaganda Network ‘Based in Romania’

incidents.content: Over the course of six years, Russian government operatives conducted an expansive information operation relying on forgeries and fake posts on 300 platforms. Objectives of the information operation included; (1) displaying Ukraine as a failed state or unreliable partner, (2) the United States and NATO as aggressive and interfering in other countries, (3) Europe as weak and divided, (4) Critics of the Russian government as morally corrupt, alcoholic, or otherwise mentally unstable, (5) Muslims as aggressive invaders, (6) The Russian government as the victim of Western hypocrisy or plots, (7) Western elections as rigged and candidates who criticized the Kremlin as unelectable, (8) Turkey as an aggressive and destabilizing state, (9) World sporting bodies and competitions as unfair, unprofessional, and Russophobic. The title "Secondary Infektion is a reference to the Soviet Era "Operation Infektion," which spread the false claim that the United States created the virus that causes AIDS. Secondary Infektion was not as effective as other well-known operations, like the IRAs divisive social media campaign targeting the 2016 election, due in large to its extreme stealth.
incidents.title: Secondary Infektion - Russian disinformation operation relied on forgeries, fake posts on 300 platforms, new report says

incidents.content: In April, Recorded Future published a report detailing a Russian disinformation operation, dubbed Operation Pinball. A continuation of an earlier disinformation operation known as Secondary Infektion, Operation Pinball forged diplomatic emails and planted articles on a number of social media sites in an attempt to undermine multiple governments and impersonate U.S. lawmakers. Operation Pinball used multiple social media platforms, including Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, and LiveJournal. Recorded Future attributed the operation with high confidence to coordinated activity.
incidents.title: Operation Pinball - Suspected Russian operatives tried using forged diplomatic documents, social media to create divisions

incidents.content: Omelas, a Washington based firm that tracks online extremism, identified 14 Russian-backed Youtube channels that were not labelled as state-sponsored. These accounts ran in direct contradiction to YouTube's service policy that was introduced in February of 2018 required labels on all news items that are wholly or partly funded by national governments. Disinformation ranged from a U.S. politician covering up a human organ harvesting ring and the economic collapse of Scandinavian countries. These accounts generated billions of views and millions of dollars in advertising revenue. Omelas researchers noted 12 additional Russia-sponsored channels spreading disinformation however, these sites were labelled.
incidents.title: Russian disinformation on YouTube draws ads, lacks warning labels according to researchers

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Russian disinformation networks appear to have acted to promote the Bernie Sanders campaign during the 2020 presidential primaries, while criticizing Joe Biden both during and after the primary season. U.S. officials briefed Senator Sanders on the operation, and assessed that Russia aimed to sow division more than seek a victor for any one candidate. Some social media posts boosting Sanders may have purported to originate from American voters but instead came from accounts linked to the Internet Research Agency. The Department of Justice describes the IRA as "a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes," and Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin," provides funding and support for the IRA.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian disinformation campaign aimed to promote Bernie Sanders, denigrate Joe Biden

incidents.content: In April 2020, Facebook announced the removal of two likely Russian disinformation networks for coordinated inauthentic behavior, including 91 accounts, 46 pages, two groups and one Instagram page. Media coverage suggests that at least one outlet had originally functioned as a state news agency with FSB funding, and both may have relied on Kremlin inputs for content to publicize. The networks frequently propagated false narratives concerning U.S. elections, NATO, the COVID-19 pandemic, and other subjects.
incidents.title: Facebook removed Russian propaganda network

incidents.content: A right-wing news site known as the Newsroom for American and European Based Citizens, or NAEBC, appears to be another Russian disinformation campaign. In an evolution of tactics first employed to influence the 2016 election, the site's organizers appears to have paid genuine journalists to write stories fitting their narratives of social disruption and political polarization. Contributers reportedly received $50 to $75 per article, with the money transferred online. NAEBC staff also reportedly provided detailed instructions for the articles they commissioned and how they should be framed. Twitter and LinkedIn accounts have activity associated with NAEBC dating from June 2020, though content reportedly generated greater traction on Parler and Gab. U.S. government officials and civil society researchers assess the NAEBC setup as a new method by which Russian actors attempted to influence the U.S. electoral process.
incidents.title: Russian disinformation campaign seemingly behind right-wing news site targeting American voters

incidents.content: Microsoft announced on September 10, 2020 that it has detected ongoing attacks from Russian military intelligence connected Fancy Bear, or APT 28. The group, also responsible for attacks on the Democratic National Convention in 2016, launched a series of attacks from September 2019 to September 2020. Microsoft’s Threat Intelligence Center (MSTIC) observed campaigns launched on U.S. organizations that were directly or indirectly affiliated with the November 2020 elections which aimed to harvest log-in credentials for intelligence-gathering or disruption purposes. Targets included U.S.-based political consultants, think tanks, national and state political party organizations, and businesses in entertainment, manufacturing, financial services, and physical security.
incidents.title: Microsoft identified cyberattacks on more than 200 organizations ahead of the November 2020 election conducted by GRU-connected APT 28

incidents.content: On September 1, 2020, Facebook announced that it had removed "13 accounts and 2 pages, which had nearly 14,000 followers," affiliated with the Internet Research Agency. The accounts and pages promoted a variety of disinformation narratives, including false claims about the coronavirus pandemic, Joe Biden, and the QAnon conspiracy theory. IRA members in some instances appeared to pose as editors seeking freelance journalists to write about polarizing topics. IRA activity also employed a website, "Peace Data," including photos of purported staff that were generated using artificial intelligence software. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is "a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes." Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin," provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Facebook removes suspected Internet Research Agency accounts for coordinated inauthentic behavior

incidents.content: A network of approximately 350 accounts across Facebook, Instagram, and other social media platforms appears to have conducted a Russian disinformation campaign aiming to sway Black voters and criticize Joe Biden ahead of the November 2020 presidential election. Some of the relevant accounts were created as far as two years in advance before beginning to spread misleading content. Narratives included false characterizations of the COVID-19 pandemic response, U.S. civil unrest, and other divisive topics. Facebook and civil society researchers assessed the network as likely another outgrowth of the Internet Research Agency, which U.S. prosecutors previously described as ""a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes." Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin," provides funding and support for the IRA. This network appeared to combine fake accounts purporting to be individuals, with false news sites and even think tanks that fabricated reports and stories.
incidents.title: Russian disinformation network sought to influence Black voters, attack Joe Biden

incidents.content: An outlet known as InfoRos, including sites InfoRos.ru, Infobrics.org, and OneWorld.press, has reportedly been publishing disinformation surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic with influence from Russian intelligence services. Multiple individuals affiliated with the outlet, including Denis Valeryevich Tyurin and Aleksandr Gennadyevich Starunskiy, appear to have previously worked in a GRU unit specializing in psyschological intelligence and operations. Between May and July 2020, the outlet reportedly published approximately 150 articles with coverage criticizing U.S. response efforts or praising Russian efforts. U.S. officials warned that the narratives demonstrate sophisticated efforts to mask the disinformation within more reputable content, usually in English and often by leveraging external sources.
incidents.title: Websites publishing COVID-19 disinformation reportedly connected to Russian intelligence services

incidents.content: In May 2020, the FBI and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) said in a statement that U.S. groups researching vaccines were being targeted by China-linked hackers who were attempting to identify and obtain valuable intellectual property and public health data. The security agencies said that PRC-affiliated "cyber actors and non-traditional collectors" were attempting to get ahold of COVID-19-related research.
incidents.title: PRC-affiliated cyber actors target COVID-19 research organizations.

incidents.content: Russian state-backed hacking group Energetic Bear, also known as Dragonfly, hacked into the San Francisco International Airport (SFO) Wi-Fi systems and two SFO-operated websites starting March 17, 2020, according to cybersecurity firm ESET. Officials believe that the group was searching for one specific, unidentified traveler. Hackers injected code into two Wi-Fi portals that stole usernames to "fingerprint" visitors, and upon detecting a device using an older version of Internet Explorer, they would infect the laptop. Only ten devices were impacted, and the hundreds of thousands of devices that used other browsers were left alone. After about two weeks, officials at two other West Coast airports had also discovered that they had been compromised.
incidents.title: Russian state-backed group Energetic Bear hacked into San Francisco airport Wi-Fi systems

incidents.content: Starting on March 12, 2020, Chinese Foreign Ministry official Zhao Lijian posted several tweets alleging that the coronavirus had in fact originated in the U.S. On March 13, he shared a link to conspiracy website that tied the virus' apparition to the US Army biological defense laboratory at Fort Detrick in Maryland. Over the course of following months and as recently as December 2020, other officials, including Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hua Chunying, and Chinese state media repeatedly returned to these baseless allegations.
incidents.title: Chinese officials claim that COVID-19 originated in US biological defense laboratory

incidents.content: On March 12, 2020, Facebook announced that it had removed "49 Facebook accounts, 69 Pages and 85 Instagram accounts for participating in foreign interference online," likely tied to the Internet Research Agency, though this time the network appeared to have operated out of Ghana and Nigeria. The accounts mainly referenced "black history, black fashion, black excellence, celebrity gossip, historical figures, and LGBTQ issues," aiming to inflame social divisions and possibly avoid detection in contrast to accounts posting only about specific political candidates. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is "a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes." Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin," provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Russian government-backed Internet Research Agency continues information operations meant to divide Americans

incidents.content: A U.S. Department of Homeland Security report has accused Russian actors of launching a disinformation campaign amplifying attacks on U.S. mail-in voting ahead of the November elections. The alleged culprits are not precisely identified but are said to encompass proxies and state-affiliated media, possibly including RT and Sputnik. The disinformation narratives claimed that mail-in voting lacks integrity and transparency, and also attempted to heighten racial divisions with additional misleading claims.
incidents.title: Russian disinformation campaign attacks U.S. mail-in voting

incidents.content: On February 12, 2020, Facebook announced that it had removed accounts determined to be operating on behalf of foreign governments, including pages tied to Russian intelligence services. Researchers found a network of "78 accounts, 11 Pages, 29 groups, and four Instagram pages" that often posted about news such as Russia’s involvement in Syria and the downing of the Malaysian airliner MH17, and also "had links to Russian military intelligence services," the company said.
incidents.title: Facebook removes accounts reportedly linked to Russian intelligence services

incidents.content: In an October 2020 report, DHS reports that foreign governments—principally China—seek to cultivate influence with state and local leaders directly and indirectly, often via economic carrots and sticks such as informal and legal or social agreements that seek to promote cultural and commercial ties. The report states that "Chinese officials calculate that U.S. state- and local-level officials enjoy a degree of diplomatic independence from Washington and may leverage these relationships to advance policies that are in China’s interest during times of strained relations." Examples of problematic instances of Chinese outreach include Chinese officials leveraging local and state official relationships to push pro-Chinese narratives in Chicago, and a Chinese official emailing a Midwestern state legislator to ask that the legislative body of which he was a member pass a resolution recognizing that China has taken heroic steps to fight the virus..
incidents.title: The US Department for Homeland Security is preoccupied by China's cultivation of relationships with American local officials.

incidents.content: Outlets affiliated with the Russian government, incuding RT and Sputnik News, published content starting as early as January 2020 that circulated false and misleading narratives about the coronavirus. Laura Cooper, U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Russia, Ukraine, and Eurasia, said that by publicizing false information, Russian accounts were "undermining the efforts of governments, of health agencies and of organizations that are in charge of disseminating accurate information about the virus to the public." Among other false claims, the Russian campaign included stories that suggested U.S. pharmaceutical companies inflated rumors about the virus as part of a plan to increase sales, reports that Eastern European countries’ economies would collapse, reports that Russia would close key trade routes, and has reports that the Baltic states were feuding over quarantine measures.
incidents.title: Russian outlets spread false information about coronavirus to hinder U.S. public health response

incidents.content: A group of fake accounts on Facebook, Reddit, and Medium appear to have targeted former U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovich to spread disinformation, including about Joe Biden's role in U.S.-Ukraine policy. Accounts published false and misleading narratives supposedly concerning a "do not prosecute" list of individuals that Yovanovich is alleged to have provided to Ukrainian officials, though she has denied any such list existed. The network included Russian-language content as well as imperfectly translated English content, and leveraged some existing Russian-affiliated sites to publicize claims. Other false narratives that the Russian network spread included misleading descriptions of U.S.-U.K. relations under the Trump administration and of details relating to investigations of Trump campaign ties to Russia.
incidents.title: Russian disinformation campaign targets U.S. role in Ukraine

incidents.content: On October 22, 2019, Facebook announced that it had removed 50 fake accounts from Instagram due to suspected impersonation of American voters in swing states that "bore all the hallmarks of the Internet Research Agency." Per an analysis from Graphika, the accounts posted content in support of Bernie Sanders or Donald Trump, while attacking Joe Biden's candidacy from both sides of the political spectrum, and occasionally also attacking Elizabeth Warren or Kamala Harris. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is "a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes." Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin," provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Facebook removes Instagram accounts posing as American voters in suspected Internet Research Agency disinformation campaign

incidents.content: NBA commissioner Adam Silver reported that the Chinese government asked him to fire Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey, after Morey tweeted his support of the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. The tweet, which Morey deleted, read "Fight for freedom, stand with Hong Kong" according to CNN. While the Chinese government denied the claim, and Silver stated that Morey would not be fired, the tweet did spark backlash against the NBA by Chinese companies and state media. The New York Times reports that several companies based in China cut ties with the Rockets, the most popular team in the country, and that the Beijing-controlled China Central Television network canceled its broadcasts of NBA games. The league was additionally criticized by American government officials as being too beholden to Beijing after it released an initial statement expressing regret over Morey's tweet. 10% of the NBA's 2019 revenue originates from the Chinese market, and according to CNN, that revenue could grow to 20% by 2030.
incidents.title: Chinese regime asks NBA commissioner to fire executive over tweets supporting Hong Kong protests

incidents.content: Since August 2019, more than 10,000 suspected fake Twitter accounts have been involved in a coordinated influence campaign with suspected ties to the Chinese Government. Among these are hacked accounts from users around the world that post messaging and disinformation about the COVID-19 pandemic and other topics of interest to China. Experts Jessica Brandt and Bret Schafer explain in an October 2020 piece that "China’s diplomats have routinely engaged with accounts bearing multiple hallmarks of inauthenticity."
incidents.title: Twitter takes down accounts coordinating to spread Chinese government-backed disinformation

incidents.content: According to an NSA advisory issued May 28, 2020, Russian military-backed Sandworm operatives, part of GRU Unit 74455, have been exploiting a vulnerability in Exim mail transfer agent (MTA) software since at least August 2019. Nearly half of internet email servers run Exim, a software that runs on Linux-based email servers to deliver emails from senders to recipients. The vulnerability was initially discovered in June 2019 and Microsoft issued an advisory to Azure customers a few weeks later, but as of May 1, 2020, half of these Exim servers were still operating on a version that was vulnerable to attack. The NSA advisory explains Sandworm’s exploitation as "any attacker’s dream access," as the vulnerability has allowed hackers to remotely execute commands and code of their choosing.
incidents.title: Hacking group Sandworm, linked with Russian military intelligence, has exploited an Exim mail transfer agent

incidents.content: In July 2019, according to researchers from cybersecurity firm Proofpoint, "several spear phishing emails were identified targeting three US companies in the utilities sector", aiming to infect employees with LookBack, a remote access Trojan. The experts found that the attack presented "similarities" with one that took place in July 2018, where Chinese state-affiliated group APT10 targeted Japanese entities. Forbes ' cybersecurity correspondent explains that this makes APT10 "the most likely culprit behind [the] cyber campaign targeting U.S. utility companies."
incidents.title: Hacker group uses tactics similar to those of Chinese state-affiliated group APT10 to target American utility companies

incidents.content: In July 2019, a former University of California professor was convicted for his involvement in a scheme "to illegally obtain integrated circuits with military applications that later were exported to China without the required export license". According to evidence, Yi-Chi Shih gained access to sensitive semi-conductor technology and transferred it to Chengdu GaStone Technology Company, a Chinese firm placed on the U.S. Department of Commerce's entity list due to national security concerns. The investigators also found that Shih had received payments from a Beijing-based company also on the entity list.
incidents.title: Engineer convicted for conspiring to sell military technology to sanctioned Chinese company

incidents.content: On June 13, 2019, Twitter announced that it had removed accounts "reliably" linked with state-backed organizations including the Internet Research Agency. Malicious activity included "the amplification of political propaganda and the impersonation of American politicians, among other terms of service violations." According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is "a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes." Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin," provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Twitter removes malicious accounts associated with suspected Russian government-backed Internet Research Agency

incidents.content: Eliminating Barriers for the Liberation of Africa (EBLA) is a small non-profit group renting a compound for near Accra, Ghana. It housed 16 Ghanaians pretending to be Americans stoking racial division on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. The trolls were hired in the second half of 2019, and late in the year EBLA expanded to Nigeria. In January 2020, EBLA advertised a position in Charleston, South Carolina. Ghanaian security services determined that all of EBLA's funding had secretly come from Russia. Facebook took down the accounts, which they determined were operating "on behalf of individuals in Russia ... Although the people behind this activity attempted to conceal their purpose and coordination, our investigation found links to EBLA, an NGO in Ghana, and individuals associated with past activity by the Russian Internet Research Agency (IRA)."
incidents.title: Russia-funded troll farm targeting Americans runs out of Africa as a non-profit front group

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text columns="" column_min_width="" column_spacing="" rule_style="" rule_size="" rule_color="" hue="" saturation="" lightness="" alpha="" content_alignment_medium="" content_alignment_small="" content_alignment="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" sticky_display="normal,sticky" class="" id="" margin_top="" margin_right="" margin_bottom="" margin_left="" fusion_font_family_text_font="" fusion_font_variant_text_font="" font_size="" line_height="" letter_spacing="" text_transform="" text_color="" animation_type="" animation_direction="left" animation_color="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_delay="0" animation_offset=""]

Ferkat Jawdat, a Uyghur American living in Virginia, claims that Beijing transferred his aunt and uncle to an internment camp after Jawdat spoke out against the treatment of his relatives still living in the Chinese province of Xinjiang. Jawdat, along with three other Uyghur men and women, met with U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in March 2019 to discuss Beijing's mass surveillance campaign targeting Uyghur Muslims. Jawdat's mother, aunt, and uncle had all been sent to internment camps in 2018, which the Chinese government says are used for vocational and educational purposes. After the meeting, Jawdat learned that his aunt and uncle had been transferred to another camp for a term of eight years, which he says was done in retaliation for his public advocacy. According to Buzzfeed, Pompeo made an apparent reference to the retaliatory jailing in an interview with Fox Business, saying "this is the kind of thing [Chinese officials] do to impact [Jawdat's] behavior here in America. It's unacceptable". It is estimated that more than a million Uyghurs and other Turkic ethnic groups are being held in internment camps.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Uyghur American's family interned in Xinjiang reeducation camp over activism abroad

incidents.content: In January 2019, the U.S. Department of Justice charged Huawei with conspiring to steal trade secrets, wire fraud and obstruction of justice. According to prosecutors, the Chinese telecommunications company conspired to steal trade secrets and valuable intellectual property, notably from T-Mobile, "to gain an unfair advantage in the global marketplace". The indictment stated that Huawei engineers "violated confidentiality and non-disclosure agreements" with T-Mobile by secretly taking photos of company's phone-robot "Tappy" in an attempt to replicate the robot. The FBI also claimed that Huawei offered bonuses to workers based on the information stolen from other companies. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Chinese telecoms giant Huawei charged in Washington State with theft of trade secrets, wire fraud, and obstruction of justice.

incidents.content: In February 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice charged Chinese telecommunications company Huawei with stealing trade secrets, and violating the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The new indictment represents an escalation of the cases initiated in January 2019. According to the 16 count indictment, Huawei and its subsidiaries breached confidentiality agreements with six U.S. tech companies and gained access to their intellectual property. Investigators also claim that Huawei developed a bonus program through which the employees were encouraged to obtain confidential information from competitors. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Additional charges of racketeering conspiracy and conspiracy to steal trade secrets brought against Chinese telecoms giant Huawei in New York.

incidents.content: In January 2019, the U.S. Department of Justice charged Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei with financial fraud, bank fraud, wire fraud and conspiracy. According to the 13-count indictment, Huawei CFO, Meng Wanzhou was charged with committing wire fraud and other violations of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), thereby contravening U.S. trade sanctions against Iran. The charges accused Huawei for engaging in a decade-long fraudulent financial scheme through a subsidiary from Iran, called Skycom. The investigators claimed that when finding about the investigation, Huawei tried to "move witnesses with knowledge about Huawei’s Iran-based business to the PRC." As part of the proceedings, Huawei's chief financial officer was arrested in Canada in December 2018 at the request of the United States. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Chinese telecoms giant Huawei charged in New York with money laundering, bank fraud, wire fraud, conspiracy, and conspiring to obstruct justice.

incidents.content: Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman were indicted in October 2019 for making political contributions secretly and illegally funded an individual who is known as "Foreign National-1" in the federal indictment against the group, who "is a foreign national Russian citizen and businessman who, at all relevant times, was not a citizen or lawful permanent resident of the United States." Foreign National-1 wired Parnas and Fruman two $500,000 transfers in Sept.-Oct. 2018 from overseas accounts, part of $1-2 million contemplated in a spreadsheet used by Parnas and his associates. Foreign National-1 also funded a marijuana startup that never came to fruition, leading some investigative journalists to suggest that it may be Andrey Muraview. In some cases, when Parnas and Fruman wanted to conceal the true source of their political donations, they incorporated an anonymous shell company called Global Energy Producers LLC (GEP), which had "no income or significant assets."   While they made some donations directly in their own names, they falsely identified GEP as the contributor for some other donations (including the $325,000 contribution to America First Action on May 17, 2018), when in fact "the funds came from a private lending transaction between Fruman and third parties, and never passed through a GEP account."
incidents.title: U.S. associates of Rudy Giuliani and President Trump funnel Russian money in the effort to acquire dirt on a leading 2020 candidate

incidents.content: Dmytro Firtash (a Ukrainian oligarch with top-level ties to the Kremlin and the Russian mob) paid Lev Parnas $200,000 between August and October of 2019 (purportedly for translation services, as part of the legal team that included Victoria Toensing and Joseph diGenova) and another $1 million in September 2019 (for unknown purposes). Parnas and Fruman used this money to buy access to President Trump (starting in October 2016), a lawmaker willing to help advocate for the firing of Ambassador Yovanovich (in May-June 2018), and Rudy Giuliani (in September-October 2018).
incidents.title: U.S. associates of Rudolph Giuliani and President Trump receive funding from Kremlin-linked Ukrainian oligarch

incidents.content: Russian actors have continued to purchase ads on Facebook - at times circumventing the platform's terms of service - such as in early 2019 when accounts linked to Russian state broadcaster Sputnik purchased $135,000 worth of ads targeted at users primarily in Eastern and Central Europe. Entities in other countries have also begun imitating this method of interference.
incidents.title: Russia and others buy advertisements on Facebook to influence Western discourse after the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election

incidents.content: Ukrainian authorities open an investigation into hacks by APT 28 (a.k.a. "Fancy Bear"), affiliated with the Russian GRU, Russian military intelligence, into Ukrainian energy company Burisma. Burisma, with which former U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden’s son Hunter Biden was once affiliated, has been the subject of political questions in the United States in the 2020 Democratic presidential primary. APT 28 has a history of using cyber operations to interfere in U.S. elections, having hacked the U.S. Democratic National Committee (DNC)’s servers in 2016.
incidents.title: APT 28 Russia-affiliated cyber group hacks into Ukrainian energy company Burisma

incidents.content: From mid-2019 to 2020, Andrii Derkach, a member of the Ukrainian parliament who is according to the U.S. Treasury also an agent of Russian intelligence, waged a covert influence campaign to encourage bogus corruption investigations against U.S. political figures, mainly relatives of then-Democratic Party presidential candidate Joe Biden, designed to culminate around the time of the U.S. 2020 election. Derkach, conspiring with domestic actors such as former New York City mayor Rudolph Giuliani, rendered further assistance of value to then-President Donald Trump’s campaign by releasing doctored audio tapes and other false information designed to harm U.S. elected officials. Former Ukrainian government officials Konstantin Kulyk, Oleksandr Onyshchenko, and Andriy Telizhenko also took part in Derkatch’s scheme and have been sanctioned by the United States.
incidents.title: Russian Agent Andrii Derkach and Associates Sanctioned for Covert Influence Campaign Targeting 2020 U.S. Election

incidents.content: In June 2020, an officer of China’s People’s Liberation Army (PLA) was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport under charges of visa fraud. According to investigators, researcher Xin Wang made fraudulent statements about his military service in his visa application to increase his chances of receiving a J1 visa. In fact, he was still employed by the PLA while conducting research at the University of California (UCSF) and received orders from "the director of his military university lab in the PRC to observe the layout of the UCSF lab and bring back information on how to replicate it in China."
incidents.title: Chinese military officer conducts visa fraud to gather information on University of California lab.

incidents.content: On November 5, 2018, Facebook announced that, following a tip from U.S. law enforcement, it had removed 115 accounts on Facebook and Instagram that were engaged in inauthentic coordinated behavior. The following day a website claiming to be affiliated with the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency took credit for the removed accounts and published a list of Instagram accounts that it claimed it was using to influence the U.S. midterm elections. According to ThinkProgress, several of the Instagram accounts were targeted at American citizens on both sides of the political spectrum. Other accounts targeted minority groups, social movements, and celebrity fan groups. According to ThinkProgress, many of the accounts were established in 2017, and some had gained followings in the tens of thousands (with one account garnering over 100,000 followers). According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Facebook reveals information operation targeting U.S. midterm elections potentially linked to Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency

incidents.content: Ohio Secretary of State Frank LaRose told the Columbus Dispatch in November 2019 that the state’s elections infrastructure had been the subject of an "unsophisticated" attack by a Russian-owned company, although the hack itself originated in Panama. LaRose indicated that the hackers were searching for vulnerabilities in the state’s cyber protections but were foiled by an anti-intrusion system.
incidents.title: Russian-owned company attempts Ohio election hack.

incidents.content: In June 2020, a Taiwanese court ruled that engineers from United Microelectronics Corp (UMC) stole trade secrets from U.S. company Micron Technology. According to the court, the operation conducted by Taiwanese engineers was backed by the PRC government, and the information stolen was shared with a government-backed Chinese company. The district court in Taiching fined UMC $3.4 million, with the engineers jailed for periods between four to seven years. In November 2018, the U.S Department of Justice had already indicted UMC, the Chinese state-backed company and three engineers for conspiring to steal trade secrets from Micron. The FBI’s evidence was used by the Taiwanese court when issuing their sentence. According to the U.S. investigators, the PRC-state owned company was able to jumpstart China’s dynamic random-access memory industry thanks to Chinese espionage in the United States.
incidents.title: Engineers convicted of stealing trade secrets for the benefit of a Chinese state-backed company.

incidents.content: On August 20, 2018, Microsoft announced it identified an attempt to steal data from NGOs and think tanks in the United States, including the International Republican Institute (IRI) and the Hudson Institute. Microsoft traced the attack to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28. The group was apparently laying the groundwork for a spear phishing campaign by mimicking the targets’ websites to obtain user login information. In addition to the think tanks, Microsoft identified and seized spoofed domains “associated with several Senate offices and services.”
incidents.title: Microsoft thwarts Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear attack against U.S. NGOs, think tanks, and Senate offices

incidents.content: On August 7, 2018, The Times of Israel reported that Russian government-connected Twitter accounts were trying to influence relations between the United States and Israel according to researchers from Clemson University. The discovery came after FiveThirtyEight and Clemson University released nearly 3 million tweets from thousands of accounts linked to the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency. Thousands of those tweets concerned Israel, with the majority supporting U.S. President Donald Trump’s relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and criticizing former U.S. President Barack Obama. However, some tweets were critical of Mr. Netanyahu. The accounts intended to influence the conversation about Israel in the United States rather than in Israel itself. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Researchers uncover Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency tried to influence U.S.-Israeli relations

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On July 31, 2018, Facebook announced that it had removed the page “Resisters,” created by the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) as part of a sweep removing eight inauthentic Facebook pages, 17 inauthentic Facebook profiles, and seven inauthentic Instagram accounts linked to the IRA. Removing the Resisters page resulted in removing an event, ‘No Unite the Right 2 DC’, which the page had created and recruited five unwitting legitimate grassroots organizations to co-host. The event was a counter protest to the Unite the Right 2 protest scheduled for August 10-12. According to the Washington Post, the removal launched a heated debate about freedom of speech and how to combat Russian government disinformation campaigns without censoring legitimate organizations and viewpoints. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Facebook removes "No Unite the Right 2 - DC" event co-organized by Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency

incidents.content: American Airlines, Delta Airlines, and United Airlines stopped listing Taipei as a city located in Taiwan on their websites, in response to Beijing's efforts to prevent carriers from referencing Taiwan as an autonomous nation. American had listed Taipei's airport as the traveler destination, while Delta listed the city name and its country code instead, stopping short of naming Taipei has being part of mainland China. An April 2019 letter sent by the Civil Aviation Administration of China to foreign airlines called for website changes if Hong Kong, Macau, or Taiwan were categorized as countries. The letter cited a series of penalties to be implemented if the carriers did not make the desired changes, and several airlines including British Airways, Lufthansa, and Qantas, chose to comply. After the letter's release, the White House described the demands as "Orwellian nonsense". According to the New York Times, China is on course to becoming the largest global aviation market, with American companies vying to gain footholds. American, Delta, and United all own stakes in Chinese-based carriers.
incidents.title: U.S. airlines change Taipei listings following CCP pressure

incidents.content: On July 19, 2018, Microsoft executive Tom Burt announced that Russian hackers had registered a fake website for use in a phishing campaign against three candidates in the 2018 U.S. midterm elections. The next week, on July 26, The Daily Beast reported that Democratic Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri, who was at the time seeking reelection in a closely contested race, was one of the three targeted candidates. The Daily Beast identified Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers as the perpetrators of the August 2017 attack.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers target three candidates in the 2018 midterm elections

incidents.content: PRC consulate officials used ties with Chinese Students and Scholars Associations ("CSSA") at universities to instill the CCP’s core interests and propaganda throughout the Chinese student community studying abroad in the United States. Local Chinese consulates provided guidance to CSSA members on how to deter events occurring on university campuses that opposed the CCP's interests. Consulates also funded CSSAs and paid members to participate in rallies and show support for Chinese dignitaries visiting the United States.
incidents.title: Chinese consulates pressure CSSA members to carry out Chinese government directives

incidents.content: In the months leading up to the 2018 U.S. midterms, Russian state-sponsored media outlet RT promoted heavily one-sided coverage of the upcoming vote, according to the Atlantic Council's Digital Forensic Research Lab. Of 31 RT articles covering the midterms, 19 included strongly negative depictions of the Democratic party and its candidates, and six of the articles included links to Republican campaign ads. According to the Atlantic Council, over the same period, no RT articles were critical of the Republican party or shared Democratic campaign ads.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media promotes one-sided coverage of midterm elections

incidents.content: On May 25, 2018, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) warned Americans that Russian military intelligence (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, “had compromised hundreds of thousands of… routers and could collect user information or shut down network traffic,” according to Reuters. The FBI added that the difficult-to-detect malware had been found in over 50 countries, Ukraine being the suspected “primary target for further actions.”
incidents.title: FBI warns of Russian government-linked group's router-hacking

incidents.content: On March 1, 2018, the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Science, Space, and Technology released a majority staff report highlighting a concerted campaign by social media accounts run by the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) to influence discussion around energy and environmental issues in the United States. According to the report, "more than four percent of all IRA tweets were related to energy or environmental issues," with accounts targeting "pipelines, fossil fuels, climate change, and other divisive issues to influence public policy." In January 2017, the U.S. intelligence community similarly exposed efforts by Russian state-sponsored media outlets to influence U.S. energy policy through anti-fracking programming. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: U.S. Congressional Committee exposes Russian information operation to influence U.S. energy policy

incidents.content: In May 2018, a journalist reported that a Confucius Institute sponsoring a conference and award at Savannah State University removed any mention of Taiwan from her bio listed on the printed program material. The journalist had reported from Taiwan and had covered issues including Hong Kong pro-democracy protests, repression of Uighurs and Tibetans, and Chinese President Xi Jinping’s crackdown on news outlets and the internet. After the journalist's remarks, the Chinese co-director of the Confucius Institute criticized her for discussing negative developments in China rather than emphasizing positive stories. The co-director had told university officials she would boycott the event unless the Taiwan references were removed from the speaker's biography. Confucius Institutes are language and culture centers run by the People’s Republic of China’s Ministry of Education, which are hosted in more than 500 universities around the world. Critics have raised concerns about incidents of infringement upon intellectual freedom at some Confucius Institutes, whose terms of agreement are often hidden. A former head of propaganda for the Chinese Communist Party has called them "an important part of China’s overseas propaganda set-up.
incidents.title: Confucius Institute officials attempt to censor materials on Taiwan at U.S. academic conference

incidents.content: PRC intelligence officials have been recruiting overseas students to spy on dissident and activist groups abroad. Radio Free Asia (RFA) spoke with a Chinese student at the University of Georgia , Sulaiman Gu, who told the outlet that state officers had contacted him in the United States to request that he write a secret report on the status of pro-democracy groups. Another student, Wu Labao, told RFA that he had also been harassed by PRC officers for information, and that they were "particularly interested in the activities of Uighurs and Tibetans". Gu additionally speculated that anyone abroad who participated in open signature campaigns directed to President Xi Jinping might be at risk of coercion.
incidents.title: PRC intelligence coerces overseas student into spying on overseas Chinese dissidents

incidents.content: In January and February 2018, PRC government hackers infiltrated computers of a Navy contractor and stole sensitive data related to naval warfare. American officials that the data obtained by PRC hackers was unclassified. However, the 614 gigabytes of information available on the contractor’s unclassified network was of a highly sensitive nature, related to the underwater project known as Sea Dragon. According to experts in the field, this kind of operation aims to develop own PRC capabilities, while challenging those of the United States. The U.S. Navy and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are investigating the case.
incidents.title: Chinese intelligence agency hack into U.S. Navy contractor

incidents.content: On November 14, 2017, the Russian Ministry of Defense posted on social media "'irrefutable evidence'" of United States cooperation with ISIS. As skeptics soon discovered, the purported evidence was misrepresented; it actually consisted of a video game screenshot and footage from videos of the Iraqi Air Force bombing ISIS.
incidents.title: Russian Ministry of Defense presents falsified "evidence" of American-ISIS cooperation

incidents.content: In August 2017, fake Twitter accounts run by the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) spread divisive messaging during the Unite the Right rally in Charlottesville, VA. A BuzzFeed News analysis of the nearly 3 million tweets released by FiveThirtyEight on July 31, 2018 showed that more than 100 accounts posing as supporters of Donald Trump sent out thousands of tweets per day in the days surrounding the riots, typically blaming the violence on "antifa" and Black Lives Matter and supporting right-wing narratives of the events. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) sows discord on Twitter during Charlottesville riots

incidents.content: On June 30, 2017, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik Radio began broadcasting in Washington, DC. In June 2019, a Florida-based broadcasting company, RM Broadcasting LLC, was forced to register as a foreign agent under the Foreign Agents Registration Act after receiving more than $1.4 million from Rossiya Segodnya to air Sputnik programming in DC from November 2017-June 2019. According to the Center for European Policy Analysis, the Russian government uses Sputnik "to promote the Kremlin's chosen messages of disinformation."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik Radio begins broadcasting in Washington, DC

incidents.content: On June 29, 2017, the Chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Science, Space, and Technology and Chairman of the Subcommittee on Energy submitted a letter to the Treasury Department outlining an alleged Russian government campaign to covertly fund environmental groups in the United States to influence U.S. energy policy. According to the letter, the Russian government actively funneled "millions of dollars through various non-profit entities to influence the U.S. energy market." Specifically, "the Russian government and complicit parties" allegedly utilized shell companies to launder money to environmental groups to "execute a political agenda" beneficial to Moscow's interests.
incidents.title: U.S. Congressional Committee alleges Russian campaign to covertly fund activist groups to influence U.S. energy policy

incidents.content: Following the June 2017 NotPetya ransomware attack, numerous international companies, including American multinational conglomerates Merck, Mondelez International, FedEx, and New Jersey-based law firm DLA, confirmed significant losses due to disruptions. In addition, several Pennsylvania hospitals temporarily suspended services after their systems became infected by the virus. U.S. intelligence services attributed the attack to Russian government-backed cyber actors. Experts describe NotPetya as the most costly and disruptive known cyberattack to date, and estimate that the virus cost the international financial sector $1.3 billion.
incidents.title: NotPetya malware traced to Russian government-backed cyber actors paralyzes operations at international companies and hospitals

incidents.content: In November 2019, Haitao Xiang, a former Monsanto researcher was indicted in the United States for stealing predictive algorithms with the intention of handing them over to a Chinese government research institute. The Department of Justice explained that, through its "Thousand Talents Plan," the Chinese government was encouraging "employees to steal intellectual property from their U.S. employers." According to DoJ, within a year of being enrolled in the "Talents" program, Xiang "quit his job, bought a one-way ticket to China, and was caught at the airport with a copy of the company's proprietary algorithm." In response to the indictment, Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Geng Shuang denied that Beijing had nothing to do with the case, calling it an "ordinary, isolated incident" and a pretext for the United States to criticize China.
incidents.title: Chinese national recruited into a PRC talents' program indicted on economic espionage charges.

incidents.content: On May 25, 2017, the University of Toronto's Citizen Lab published a report detailing a large phishing and disinformation campaign directed at over 200 targets in 39 countries, including senior U.S. government and military officials. The operation sought to steal emails from high-profile targets and selectively leak them to the public after tampering with their content. Citizen Lab was able to circumstantially link the attacks to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, but was unable to conclusively attribute the attacks using open source information.
incidents.title: Think tank identifies phishing and disinformation campaign potentially linked to Kremlin-affiliated hacking group

incidents.content: In May 2017, the Russian government and state-sponsored media began pushing a now-debunked conspiracy theory claiming that DNC employee Seth Rich was murdered for leaking internal documents to WikiLeaks. On May 16, RT (Russia Today) published a story repeating the discredited claims; on May 19, the Russian Embassy in Britain tweeted that Rich, not Russian hackers, had provided the material to WikiLeaks. On June 2, Sputnik published another "conspiratorial" piece featuring fringe allegations that "Rich's death could have been part of a massive conspiracy" to elect Hillary Clinton in 2016. Later reporting revealed that Russian military intelligence (GRU) officers manipulated metadata in stolen DNC files before releasing them, in order to corroborate the conspiracy theory.
incidents.title: Russian government and state-sponsored media promote debunked conspiracy theory

incidents.content:
