[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text columns="" column_min_width="" column_spacing="" rule_style="default" rule_size="" rule_color="" content_alignment_medium="" content_alignment_small="" content_alignment="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" sticky_display="normal,sticky" class="" id="" font_size="" fusion_font_family_text_font="" fusion_font_variant_text_font="" line_height="" letter_spacing="" text_color="" animation_type="" animation_direction="left" animation_speed="0.3" animation_offset=""]

Beginning in 2017 and lasting through 2018, Russian state-sponsored hackers "targeted government entities and the energy, water, aviation, nuclear, and critical manufacturing sectors" in the United States, according to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Using techniques such as spear phishing and watering holes, the government-backed hackers sought to reconnoiter and breach smaller and less-secure systems "to gain access and move laterally to networks of major, high value" energy targets. The hackers reportedly gained access to the control rooms of U.S. electric utilities by breaching the networks of key vendors that had trusted relationships with the companies, according to the Wall Street Journal.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored hackers target the United States' critical infrastructure and energy sectors

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text columns="" column_min_width="" column_spacing="" rule_style="" rule_size="" rule_color="" hue="" saturation="" lightness="" alpha="" content_alignment_medium="" content_alignment_small="" content_alignment="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" sticky_display="normal,sticky" class="" id="" margin_top="" margin_right="" margin_bottom="" margin_left="" fusion_font_family_text_font="" fusion_font_variant_text_font="" font_size="" line_height="" letter_spacing="" text_transform="" text_color="" animation_type="" animation_direction="left" animation_color="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_delay="0" animation_offset=""]

The PRC detained family members of four US-based ethnic Uyghur journalists working for Radio Free Asia (RFA) to deter reporting on events in the Xinjiang region. The family members received jail sentences or were sent to reeducation camps. Many of the reporters were told by family members and friends living in Xinjiang that the authorities had asked them to stop the reporters from communicating with individuals and reporting on events in the region. One of the RFA reporters suspected the PRC of using voice recognition software to impede the reporters’ attempts to contact individuals in Xinjiang.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: PRC detains relatives of RFA reporters for reporting on Xinjiang

incidents.content: On July 31, 2018, Facebook announced that the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) ran about 150 ads for approximately $11,000 on Instagram and Facebook from April 2017 to June 2018. During this round of social media influence, the IRA used heightened techniques to avoid detection, including VPNs, internet phone services, paying third parties to run the ads, and paying for the ads in U.S. and Canadian dollars. The ads played mostly on racial and political divides in the United States, including ads targeting African Americans and Native Americans, as well as anti-Trump ads. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency continues to buy political ads on Facebook and Instagram

incidents.content: In February 2019, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) indicted You Xiaorong and Liu Xiangchen for the theft and transfer of trade secrets valued at almost $120 million. According to the investigators, stole trade secrets from an American company "for the economic benefit of the Chinese company that Liu managed." The indictment highlighted the role of Beijing’s official "Thousand Talents" program that "solicit[s] and reward[s]" the theft of U.S. trade secrets and intellectual property. DOJ emphasized that this case confirmed that the PRC encouraged industrial espionage on U.S. companies by offering conspirators financial incentives based on the information they stole.
incidents.title: Chinese-born engineer incentivized by PRC’s "Thousand Talent" program to steal trade secrets in the United States.

incidents.content: On March 15, 2017, a federal grand jury indicted two Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) officers and two hackers for conspiring to hack Yahoo and breach the email accounts of "Russian journalists, U.S. and Russian government officials and private-sector employees of financial, transportation and other companies." The defendants were accused of stealing information on "at least 500 million Yahoo accounts and... us[ing] some of that stolen information to obtain unauthorized access to other accounts." Other targets included "a foreign intelligence and law enforcement service... [and] employees of a prominent Russian cybersecurity company..." According to the indictment, "The FSB officer defendants... protected, directed, facilitated and paid criminal hackers to collect information..." The Federal Bureau of Investigation featured hacker defendant Alexsey Belan on its list of most-wanted cyber-criminals. In March 2017, hacker defendant Karim Baratov was arrested in Canada, and pled guilty in November over his work for the FSB.
incidents.title: United States indicts hackers for colluding with FSB officers to hack Yahoo accounts

incidents.content: According to the Department of Justice, since 2017 the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) has continued its campaign “to sow division and discord in the U.S. political system, including by creating social and political polarization” and by “undermining faith in democratic institutions.”Using inauthentic social media accounts, the IRA actively works to promote controversial perspectives from both sides of the political spectrum. Among other subjects, trolls from the IRA have seized on the Roseanne Barr controversy, the NFL #TakeAKnee debate, the #MeToo movement, and the Trump administration, often playing both sides of the issues to inflame discourse. The IRA has also targeted specific politicians and media outlets, including Marco Rubio, Paul Ryan, John McCain, and CNN. To direct its operations, the IRA provides its workers with specific instructions on how to target narratives toward particular audiences and minority groups, even specifying the best times of day for social media activity. The IRA also uses inauthentic accounts posing as American citizens to communicate with activists and promote protests. One such IRA Twitter account, @wokeluisa, gained over 55,000 followers after its creation in March 2017. The account was erroneously cited numerous times by major U.S. media outlets, lending it further reach and legitimacy. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency continues information operation to "to sow division and discord in the U.S. political system"

incidents.content: On December 31, 2016, U.S. officials reported that cyber actors utilized a code associated with Russian state-sponsored hacking group Grizzly Steppe to target Burlington Electric systems in Vermont. Officials said that the hackers failed to penetrate the utility company’s networks, but emphasized that the attack highlighted Russian interest in compromising the American electric grid. The Department of Homeland Security and the Federal Bureau of Investigation later released a report confirming Grizzly Steppe’s involvement in the attempted hack and alerting the public to the dangers of the ongoing Russian cyber campaign against the United States.
incidents.title: Actors associated with the Russian government-linked hacking group Grizzly Steppe target Vermont utility

incidents.content: Within hours of the November 8, 2016, election, Russian hacking group Cozy Bear, or APT 29, which is connected to Russia’s Federal Security Service (FSB) and Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR), conducted spear phishing campaigns against U.S.-based think tanks specializing in security studies, including the Council on Foreign Relations and the Brookings Institution. Hackers used email accounts resembling those of Harvard University faculty or Clinton Foundation staff, with some using the subject line “Why American Elections are Flawed” in an attempt to trick think tank staff into downloading the malware. The hacking attempts were unsuccessful.
incidents.title: Russian government-backed hacking group conducts spear phishing campaign against Washington-based think tanks

incidents.content: On the night of the 2016 U.S. presidential election, accounts linked to the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) on Twitter began pushing for California's secession from the United States, according to BBC News. Early on November 9, #Calexit was among Twitter's top hashtags, in part thanks to IRA trolls. In the past, Yes California, a pro-secessionist group, has received substantial positive press and coverage from Kremlin state-controlled media outlets. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency promotes Californian secession from the United States on social media

incidents.content: On October 5, 2016, David Satter, a "prominent journalist and critic of the Russian government," was successfully spear phished; his emails "were selectively modified, and then 'leaked' on the blog of CyberBerkut, a self-described pro-Russian hacktivist group." The emails were edited to make Satter's work appear sinister and clandestine. Russian state-sponsored media outlets, including RIA Novosti and Sputnik Radio, amplified the misleading story. The University of Toronto's Citizen Lab concluded that based on the hackers' tactics and focus, "there is strong—but not conclusive—evidence for Russian government sponsorship of the phishing campaign, and the tainted leaks." An Associated Press investigation has detailed Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacking group Fancy Bear’s targeting of “at least 200 journalists, publishers, and bloggers… [since] mid-2014," across multiple countries.
incidents.title: Journalist David Satter targeted in hacking and disinformation campaign

incidents.content: In October and November 2016, WikiLeaks released more than 58,000 emails stolen from Hillary Clinton campaign chair John Podesta by hackers linked to the Russian military intelligence agency (GRU). Concurrently, GRU officers used the persona DCLeaks to publish a large batch of documents stolen from former campaign advisor Capricia Marshall. The leaked emails were intended to undermine Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. U.S. media outlets and publications significantly amplified the effect of the leaks through extensive coverage.
incidents.title: WikiLeaks releases Clinton campaign emails stolen by Russian government hackers

incidents.content: On August 12, 2016, Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-created DCLeaks published hundreds of emails belonging to Republican Senators John McCain and Lindsey Graham, as well as Republican ex-Congresswoman Michele Bachmann. The same day, GRU proxy Guccifer 2.0 released personal information, including phone numbers, of "over 200 Democratic lawmakers," allegedly stolen from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-created DCLeaks and its proxy Guccifer 2.0 release material stolen from Republicans and Democrats

incidents.content: In August 2016, Russian hacking group Cozy Bear, or APT 29, which is connected to Russia’s Federal Security Service (FSB) and Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR), launched sophisticated spear phishing attacks against several U.S.-based think tanks and NGOs. The group designed the emails to appear as though the senders were well-known individuals from influential think tanks and consultancies, such as the Center for a New American Security (CNAS), the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), the Eurasia Group, and others.
incidents.title: FSB- and SVR-connected APT 29 targets Washington-based NGOs

incidents.content: On July 22, 2016, WikiLeaks released nearly 20,000 emails stolen from the Democratic National Committee (DNC) server by hackers linked to Russia's military intelligence agency (GRU). GRU Officers used the online persona Guccifer 2.0 to pass the emails to WikiLeaks for public distribution. The leak was intended to create division within the Democratic Party in the months leading up to the 2016 election.
incidents.title: WikiLeaks publishes 20,000 emails stolen from the DNC by Russian government hackers

incidents.content: On June 8, 2016, Russian military intelligence officers (GRU) used the front site DCLeaks to publish stolen files and emails belonging to George Soros' Open Society Foundation and former NATO supreme commander Philip Breedlove. GRU officers published more Soros documents on August 15, 2016, seeking to smear the philanthropist and emphasize his support for Hillary Clinton. In September 2016, officers used DCleaks to publish the stolen emails of former Secretary of State and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Colin Powell.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence (GRU) proxy site, DCLeaks, releases hacked documents

incidents.content: In January 2018, the cybersecurity firm Trend Micro published its findings that Russian military intelligency agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, had been targeting the United States Senate since June 2016. According to the firm’s research, Fancy Bear was employing phishing techniques involving fake websites that mirror the Senate’s login server, in an attempt to trick Senate staffers into entering their login credentials onto the bogus site.
incidents.title: Russian government-backed hacking group targets the United States Senate

incidents.content: Following the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) hack on April 6, 2016, during which Russian hackers stole thousands of pages of internal Democratic Party documents, Russian military intelligence officers (GRU) used the false persona Guccifer 2.0 to release DCCC documents containing internal criticisms of Democratic House candidates. The leaked documents were intended to influence competitive 2016 House races in Florida, Illinois, New Hampshire, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, and Pennsylvania, among others.
incidents.title: GRU leaks stolen information on Democratic House candidates

incidents.content: In the months leading up to the 2016 election, the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) used inauthentic social media personas to orchestrate rallies, demonstrations, and protests on politically divisive issues in New York, Pennsylvania, Georgia, Texas, and across Florida. The trolls employed fake email accounts, Facebook ads, Facebook events, and inauthentic Instagram accounts to promote the events. According to The New York Times, the efforts included organizing the rallies, coordinating with grassroots efforts, soliciting promotion from activists, requesting rally signs directly from campaigns, and monetarily supporting protests. The rallies spanned the political spectrum and focused on divisive issues, such as race and immigration. In some cases, the IRA organized both protests and corresponding counter protests with the goal of stoking anger and confrontation. Beyond organizing the rallies, IRA social media accounts also contributed by funding advertising, flyers, and rally supplies. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency utilizes fake social media accounts to mobilize rallies across the United States

incidents.content: Beginning in April 2016, Russian military intelligence officers (GRU) began planning and establishing false personas impersonating Americans on social media to promote and spread leaked documents ahead of the 2016 presidential election. One such persona, Alice Donovan, was used to create the DC Leaks Facebook account, which released numerous documents and emails stolen from the Democratic Party and from individuals affiliated with the Republican Party. Other false personas on Facebook and Twitter amplified the spread of stolen information, steered traffic to the GRU-run DCLeaks website, promoted protests, and amplified divisive political opinions. The accounts were intended to sow division within the Democratic Party, to undermine the campaign of candidate Hillary Clinton, to promote the campaign of Donald Trump, and to reduce Americans' faith in democratic institutions.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence officers (GRU) use social media personas to leak and amplify stolen information

incidents.content: Since at least March 2016, according to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Federal Bureau of Investigation, Russian state-backed hackers known as Energetic Bear, or Dragonfly, penetrated the secure systems of U.S. ritical infrastructure in a multistage intrusion campaign. The hackers reportedly breached hundreds of victims by compromising their vendors through spear phishing and watering-hole tactics. According to a DHS official, the Russians "got to the point where they could have thrown switches" and caused power outages.
incidents.title: Russian state-backed hackers continue attacks on American critical infrastructure, gaining access to secure networks

incidents.content: In April 2019, the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) charged Xiaoqing Zheng of Niskayuna, New York and Zhaoxi Zhang of Liaoning Province, China for conspiring to steal General Electric’s (GE) trade secrets for the benefit of PRC. According to prosecutors, Zheng used "elaborate and sophisticated means to remove electronic files" from GE, related to gas and steam turbine, and sent them afterwards to Zhang in the PRC. During an interview with the prosecutors, Zheng admitted that he "have received grant money and funding from the government of China" for the information stolen.
incidents.title: General Electric engineer and Chinese businessman charged with stealing trade secrets for the PRC government

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text columns="" column_min_width="" column_spacing="" rule_style="default" rule_size="" rule_color="" content_alignment_medium="" content_alignment_small="" content_alignment="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" sticky_display="normal,sticky" class="" id="" font_size="" fusion_font_family_text_font="" fusion_font_variant_text_font="" line_height="" letter_spacing="" text_color="" animation_type="" animation_direction="left" animation_speed="0.3" animation_offset=""]

In the lead up to the 2016 election, Russian government-linked hackers probed the election infrastructure of all 50 U.S. states, successfully breaching election systems in two of them, according to the Senate Intelligence Committee. Hackers linked to Russia's military intelligence agency (GRU) began probing and targeting states in the summer of 2016. Federal authorities initially identified 21 states that had been probed ahead of the election, though post-election investigations revealed more widespread efforts. Hackers successfully gained access to election infrastructure systems and extracted voter data in two states, which were publicly identified as Illinois and Arizona. Hackers also gained access to the networks of a Florida county government through a spearphishing campaign targeting election officials in that state. Both the Senate Intelligence Committee and the U.S. Intelligence Community reported that the hackers did not gain access to any systems involved in vote tallying. 

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian state-backed hackers probe the election infrastructure of all 50 U.S. states, successfully breaching two

incidents.content: In 2015, a Russian gun enthusiast and aspiring foreign agent named Maria Butina pitched an espionage proposal to Alexander Torshin, who is a senior Russian government official and close Putin ally: Because official diplomatic channels under the Obama administration were not succeeding at altering U.S. foreign policy, Russia should instead pursue the same objectives via a back channel that Torshin and Butina would develop through the NRA to the Republican party and a future Trump administration. Torshin agreed and funded the secret operation. Butina brought into the conspiracy a longtime Republican operative she was dating named Paul Erickson. She met one presidential candidate at an NRA convention, used her FSB connections to facilitate a trip to Moscow meant to cultivate top NRA officials, hosted multiple large "friendship dinners" for prominent Republicans, publicly asked then-candidate Donald Trump a question about Russia sanctions at a 2015 rally, and brought a Russian delegation to the 2017 National Prayer Breakfast (where the Russians sought to establish the back channel and report back directly to Putin). Between 2012 and 2016, Torshin met every NRA president and attended all NRA annual meetings. At the 2016 annual meeting, Torshin was trying to arrange a Trump-Putin summit and met privately with Donald Trump Jr. In 2018, Butina was arrested and pled guilty to conspiring "to establish unofficial lines of communication with Americans having power and influence in U.S. politics" for the "benefit of the Russian Federation." Separately, the FBI investigated whether Torshin funneled secret campaign donations to Trump through the National Rifle Association, but it's not clear what came of the inquiry, if anything, and the NRA was not mentioned in the unredacted Mueller report. Spanish authorities have sought to arrest Torshin as they consider him the investor atop an elaborate money laundering scheme. In 2016, the NRA spent triple the amount of money supporting Trump as it devoted to the 2012 election, with most of the money coming from the NRA's 501(c)(4) that doesn't have to disclose its donors. The NRA has said it only received $2,513 "from people associated with Russian addresses" or known Russian nationals living in the United States and that it didn't spend Russian-linked money on politics, but the NRA has not disclosed its donor identifies, methods of vetting shell companies, or systems of segregating foreign money.
incidents.title: Russia cultivates ties to US political leaders through the National Rifle Association (NRA)

incidents.content: In 2015, fake Twitter accounts run by the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) amplified conspiracy theories surrounding the Jade Helm military exercise in the southwestern United States. These theories claimed that the exercise was a smokescreen for the Obama administration to impose martial law. Former CIA director Michael Hayden stated on May 3, 2018 that IRA accounts helped to spread these false messages. Those claims were confirmed following the release of nearly 3 million IRA tweets by FiveThirtyEight on July 31, 2018. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency accounts push Jade Helm conspiracy theories on Twitter

incidents.content: On September 6, 2017, Facebook announced that the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) operated around 470 accounts and spent $100,000 on advertising on the site in the lead up to the 2016 election, reaching as many as 126 million Americans. Over the next few weeks, Facebook received substantial public, media, and governmental criticism over its perceived lack of transparency regarding the manipulation of its platform, culminating in the release of over 3,000 Russian-linked ads to Congress. While some ads were targeted to support specific candidates, including Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders, and Jill Stein, other ads focused on specific hot-button issues such as immigration and racism. The IRA also used falsified American accounts to purchase at least $6,000 worth of ads on Instagram, including ads promoting Jill Stein and “Florida Goes Trump” rallies. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency runs extensive social media influence campaign involving targeted advertisements

incidents.content: In advance of the 2016 U.S. presidential election, Russian state-sponsored hacking groups Cozy Bear and Fancy Bear targeted political parties, organizations, and presidential campaigns. In July 2015, hackers from Russian intelligence-connected Cozy Bear, or APT29, infiltrated the Democratic National Committee's (DNC) computer network using spear phishing tactics. According to cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike, the hackers "monitor[ed] the DNC’s email and chat communications." A January 2017 report from the Director of National Intelligence states that Cozy Bear "maintained that access until at least June 2016." On March 19, 2016, Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta opened a phishing email disguised as a Google security alert, giving Russian military intelligence-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, access to Podesta’s account and the Clinton campaign network. On April 6, 2016, Russian hackers successfully spear phished an employee of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC). Just days later, the hackers breached the DCCC, stealing thousands of pages of internal party documents. On April 18, 2016, Fancy Bear leveraged its DCCC access to further infiltrate the DNC. The GRU officers installed malware to steal data, such as opposition research, from the DNC. By June, the hackers had compromised 33 DNC computers. In January 2017, U.S. intelligence officials revealed that Russian hackers also accessed Republican computer systems prior to the 2016 election, including old Republican National Committee domains that were no longer in use. However, the hackers elected not to leak most of the documents belonging to Republican lawmakers. The revelation indicates that Russian actors targeted both major American political parties in their attempts to influence the 2016 presidential election, but primarily released Democrats' documents.
incidents.title: Russian government-backed hackers target American political parties, organizations, and campaigns in the 2016 presidential election

incidents.content: In April 2014, the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) established a team - known as the "translator project" - that "focused on the U.S. population and conducted operations on social media platforms," according to the Department of Justice. By May, "the [IRA's] strategy included interfering with the 2016 U.S. presidential election, with the stated goal of 'spread[ing] distrust towards the candidates and the political system in general.'" The IRA received funding for its interference operations from companies tied to Yevgeny Prigozhin, a Kremlin insider known as "Putin's chef." Russian trolls created accounts impersonating Americans to influence domestic American debate over divisive issues, such as energy and climate policy, race, gun control, LGBT issues, and immigration, as well as to drum up support for candidates, including Jill Stein, Donald Trump, and Bernie Sanders. The IRA also published and amplified derogatory information targeted at candidates, including Hillary Clinton, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio, throughout the presidential and primary campaigns. The IRA funded political advertisements, related expenses such as “buttons, flags, and banners for rallies,” as well as rally leaders (usually Americans) through PayPal accounts and occasionally through use of cryptocurrency. The IRA also purchased false identification documents to create accounts at PayPal and online cryptocurrency exchanges. Since the election, Facebook alone has found over 470 accounts, which generated 80,000 posts reaching as many as 126 million Americans. The IRA also infiltrated Twitter, Instagram, Reddit, Tumblr, and the meme site 9Gag.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency targets the United States and the 2016 primaries and presidential election on social media

incidents.content: On January 26, 2015, hackers from Russian military intelligency agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, targeted three popular YouTubers with phishing attacks four days after the trio interviewed President Obama at the White House. Analysts believe this was an attempt to employ the island hopping technique, by which a hacker probes individuals or companies with weaker security that have interacted with a target, in order to ultimately gain access to their target - in this case, the White House.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored hacking group targets popular YouTubers after interview with President Obama

incidents.content: On December 13, 2014, Russian trolls from the Internet Research Agency (IRA) disseminated fake reports of Atlanta police shooting an unarmed black woman alongside a fake video and the hashtag #shockingmurderinAtlanta. Russian trolls utilized the report to exploit public anxiety regarding concerns of police brutality after the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, in August 2014. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Trolls from Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency circulate false reports of Atlanta police shooting an unarmed black woman

incidents.content: On December 13, 2014, Russian trolls linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA) publicized false reports of a supposed Ebola outbreak in Atlanta, using the hashtag #EbolaInAtlanta. The hoax came amidst media panic regarding a handful of Ebola cases in the United States. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Trolls from Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency circulate fabricated reports of an Ebola outbreak in Atlanta, Georgia

incidents.content: On September 11, 2014, trolls tied to the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA) cloned the websites of local news stations, CNN, and YouTube and used bots to circulate fake reports of a chemical disaster at the Columbia Chemicals factory in Centerville, Louisiana. The bogus reports attributed the disaster to ISIS, and bots targeted "Dozens of journalists, media outlets and politicians" with the disinformation. According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, “a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Trolls from Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency disseminate bogus reports of a chemical explosion in Centerville, Louisiana

incidents.content: On February 4, 2014, a phone call between then-Assistant Secretary of State for European and Eurasian Affairs Victoria Nuland and the American Ambassador to Ukraine, Geoffrey Pyatt, was published on YouTube. State-sponsored actors tapped Nuland’s phone line and leaked the audio. The call prompted significant backlash from Nuland’s European counterparts over her critical commentary regarding European involvement in Ukrainian politics. The White House and the State Department attributed the leak to the Russian government.
incidents.title: Russian government leaks recording of conversation between American officials to undermine U.S.-European relations

incidents.content: In fall 2013, New Eastern Outlook, "a geopolitical journal published by the government-chartered Russian Academy of Sciences" began a partnership with a homegrown "fringe American news site" Veterans Today. Since then, Veterans Today has published Russian propaganda narratives targeted at veterans, including articles depicting Ukraine as being run by neo-Nazis, blaming the 2013 Ghouta chemical attack on Turkey, and alleging American support for terrorists. According to an interview with the site's managing editor in 2012, "about 30% of what’s written on Veterans Today, is patently false. About 40% of what I write, is at least purposely, partially false...”
incidents.title: Russian government-connected journal partners with U.S. website to target veterans with disinformation

incidents.content: A 2019 FireEye report explained that Chinese-sponsored hacking groups are conducting cyber operations against the healthcare sector in the United States. The report claims that the aim of these operations’ data extraction has two purposes: to siphon research back to China (particularly related to cancer treatment), and to pave the way for Chinese intelligence operations. Hacker group APT 41 features particularly prominently in the report, having conducted several cyber-attacks against various American healthcare actors between 2013 and 2018. In addition, a FireEye blog post explained that, over the course of several years, APT41 targeted a variety of U.S. industries such as healthcare, high-tech, higher education or telecommunications. The blog post also posits that Chinese authorities turn a blind eye to the group’s for-profit cyber-activities against videogame companies in exchange for their cooperation on operations in the state's interests.
incidents.title: PRC-affiliated Chinese hacker groups target healthcare sector in the United States

incidents.content: In January 2018, cyber experts at Symantec uncovered a wide-ranging espionage operation conducted by "computers within China", targeting multiple organizations in the United States and Southeast Asia. Symantec monitored the group, dubbed "Thrip" since 2013, and noticed in 2018 that it was releasing "powerful malware" targeting satellite operators, telecommunication companies and defense contractors. Remarkably, Symantec determined that the type of systems targeted by the group indicated that its objectives went beyond data-collection and could include disruption.
incidents.title: Chinese-based espionage group hits satellite, defense and telecom companies

incidents.content: In April 2020, BlackBerry researchers detailed the operation of five related Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) groups "operating in the interest of the Chinese government" targeted Linux servers, Windows systems and Android mobile devices while remaining undetected for nearly a decade. The targeting of Linux systems was particularly noteworthy because the platform "runs nearly all of the top 1 million websites online, 75% of all web servers, 98% of the world’s supercomputers and 75% of major cloud service providers." The researchers highlighted that a key factor behind the operation’s success was the fact that the five APT groups were composed of Chinese civilian sub-contractors who worked collaboratively among themselves, as well as with their government counterparts. BlackBerry tied the launch of the report to the U.S. Department of Justice’s announcement of "several high-profile indictments from over 1,000 open FBI investigations into economic espionage."
incidents.title: Hackers operating in the interest of the Chinese government systematically target critical systems while remaining undetected for nearly a decade.

incidents.content: In 2018, cybersecurity firm Cybereason uncovered a complex worldwide campaign against telecom providers conducted by PRC-backed hackers since at least 2012. Their cyber operations compromised companies from more than 30 countries and "aimed to gather information on individuals in government, law-enforcement and politics." One the attack’s particularity was that it was conducted in multiple waves, allowing the hackers to pursue their operations over a long period of time. Analyzing all the evidence gathered, the cyber experts concluded "with a high level of certainty that the threat actor is affiliated with China and is likely state sponsored". The report did not mention who the affected companies were, but Reuters reported that many of them are likely located in Western Europe.
incidents.title: PRC-affiliated hackers target global telecommunications providers

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Beginning in 2011, Russian government-linked hackers began targeting U.S. critical infrastructure companies with malware attacks that eventually compromised several targets, according to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). DHS, which published a warning in 2014 that the attacks had compromised "numerous industrial control systems environments," reported that the hackers used a variant of the BlackEnergy malware, which Russian government-linked hackers previously used to target critical infrastructure in Ukraine. Analysts attributed the attacks to a group linked to Russia's military intelligence agency (GRU). The hacking campaign reportedly affected over 1,000 organizations in over 84 countries. The goal of the attacks may have been industrial espionage; however, according to The New York Times, researchers reported that the hackers could hijack "industrial control systems from afar" if they so desired.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian government-linked hackers target U.S. critical infrastructure

incidents.content: In the spring of 2010, Russian state-sponsored media outlet RT launched RT America. US intelligence agencies have described RT as “Russia’s state-run propaganda machine.” RT is available in English, Russian, German, French, Spanish, and Arabic languages.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet Russia Today launches RT America in Washington, DC

incidents.content: In October 2018, the Department of Justice (DoJ) indicted two Chinese intelligence officers, as well as hackers and company insiders "working under their direction" for stealing technology from U.S. and French aviation companies. According to the prosecutors, the conspirators conducted a five-year long scheme, hacking into private companies’ computer systems to steal "technology underlying a turbofan engine used in U.S. and European commercial airliners". The Federal Bureau Investigation highlights that the operation conducted by the two Chinese intelligence officers who worked for Jiangsu Province Ministry of State Security was a "Chinese government-sponsored hacking activity".
incidents.title: Chinese intelligence officers build team of hackers and company insiders to steal sensitive aerospace technology

incidents.content: In June 2020, a federal judge convicted Chinese citizen Hao Zhang of economic espionage, theft of trade secrets, and conspiracy. According to the investigators, between 2010 and 2015, Zhang "plotted with Tianjin University to take trade secrets from two U.S. companies, including his own employer, to China for the benefit of the Chinese Government." Zhang’s sentencing hearing is scheduled for 31 August 2020. Investigators insist that Tianjin University in China is "an instrumentality of the Chinese government" and that Zhang’s economic espionage helped Tianjin University and another Chinese company to unfairly compete in the market.
incidents.title: Chinese national convicted of economic espionage for the benefit of the Chinese government.

incidents.content: In 2007, Russian government officials embezzled from the Russian Treasury $230 million.[DS1]   The scheme was uncovered by a lawyer named Sergei Magnitsky, who was murdered in a Russian prison. The U.S. sanctioned Russian officials responsible for the killing through the Magnitsky Act in 2012. In retaliation, the Kremlin banned Americans from adopting Russian orphans. In 2015, the U.S. Justice Department was prosecuting a company owned by Russian businessman Denis Katsyv as a beneficiary of some of the stolen $230 million, which had allegedly been laundered and invested in New York real estate. Katsyv sought help from U.S. lawyers and lobbyists, who recommended setting up a non-profit foundation in Delaware. They called it the Human Rights Accountability Global Initiative Foundation, purportedly for American families wanting to adopt Russian orphans. By legally organizing as a U.S. nonprofit, the foundation effectively concealed its sources of funding, which if revealed might have required registering as a foreign agent. The $500,000 of contributions turned out to have come from Katsyv and other Moscow elites asked to support him. The foundation held an account at Bank of America, which alerted the U.S. Treasury after investigating and suspecting that the transaction activity was evidence of corruption and bribery in Russia's bid to overturn the Magnitsky Act. The influence operation employed lobbyists and consultants led by Natalia Veselnitskaya, a lawyer who was later indicted in a related case proving her ties to the Kremlin. Non-profits have similarly been used in other countries such as Canada to lobby against Russia sanctions.
incidents.title: Russia uses a U.S. non-profit to hide funding of covert lobbying operation against Russia sanctions.

incidents.content: In July 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) indicted two Chinese nationals for a cyber-campaign aimed at stealing intellectual property and other confidential information, notably COVID-19 research. According to the indictment, "the hackers operated from China both for their own gain and with the assistance and for the benefit of the Chinese government’s Ministry of State Security". During a decade-long campaign, the two Chinese nationals, Li Xiaoyu and Dong Jiazhi hacked trade secrets and intellectual property from all over the world, totaling "hundreds of millions of dollars." The two hackers are considered to be "one of the most prolific group of hackers" ever investigated by U.S. prosecutors.
incidents.title: Two Chinese nationals charged in the United States for conducting a decade-long cyber campaign, partly for the benefit of the Chinese state.

incidents.content: Maxim Yakubets, a Russian citizen with familial ties to the FSB, has since 2009 led a hacker group calling itself "Evil Corps" that has used a malware known as "Dridex" to attack the personal information of customers of over 300 banks in 40 countries. Yakubets’ crime spree began in 2009 when he and an accomplice stole $415,000 from the treasury of Bullitt County, KY. He has outstanding indictments against him in Nebraska and Pennsylvania, and the U.S. Treasury Department has announced that his group has worked to steal confidential documents on behalf of the FSB. Investigation by Meduza indicate a quid pro quo relationship between "Evil Corps" and the FSB, where the FSB allows "Evil Corps" to commit cybercrime unhindered and Yakubets’ operation in turn helps the FSB with intelligence gathering.
incidents.title: "Evil Corps," a Russian hacker collective with FSB ties, uses malware to target personal information of customers of over 300 banks in 40 countries, and also provides material assistance to the FSB in hacking attacks against overseas targets.

incidents.content: Chinese intelligence officials flew to San Francisco in order to surveil and disrupt pro-democracy, Tibet, Uighur, and Falon Gong protests during the 2008 Olympic torch relay. Three former intelligence officials told Politico that Chinese MSS and Ministry of Public Security officers filmed the demonstrations and directed 6,000-8,000 Chinese students, some pro-PRC and some faced with the revoking of their funding should they not participate, to intimidate and overwhelm anti-Beijing protestors. U.S. officials reportedly shared the identities of the Chinese intelligence officers involved with Australia in order to prevent them from obtaining Australian visas, but did not notify the wider American public or media at the time.
incidents.title: Chinese intelligence officials coordinate Olympic torch counter-protests in San Francisco

incidents.content: The CCP has several recruitment programs, which seek to acquire technology and intellectual property, often through illegal or non-transparent means. Researchers targeted by these programs often continue their work outside of China, remunerated by their institution, supplemented by Chinese payments. By employing scientists in laboratories around the world, the CCP benefits from the structural, financial, and technological resources of those laboratories. However, host institutions’ ignorance of these programs means that they are unwittingly using their resources to fund a foreign government. Additionally, the CCP’s emphasis acquiring dual use technology, means that much of the research conducted in institutions abroad is eventually used by the PLA or enables the repression of minorities in China. Many of the talent recruitment agencies also work with the United Front and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology’s State Administration of Foreign Experts Affairs. China uses "United Front" work to co-opt and neutralize sources of potential opposition to the policies and authority of its ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP). The CCP’s United Front Work Department (UFWD)—the agency responsible for coordinating these kinds of influence operations—mostly focuses on the management of potential opposition groups inside China, but it also has an important foreign influence mission.
incidents.title: Chinese state programs incentivize intellectual property theft globally

incidents.content: In December 2018, the U.S. Department of Justice indicted two Chinese hackers associated to Chinese state-backed hacking group APT10 for intrusion campaigns targeting intellectual property and confidential business information. According to the indictment, Zhu Hua and Zhang Shilong took part in a 12-year hacking campaign conducted by PRC and breached computer systems belonging to the U.S. Navy, as well as to other government and businesses. According to the court documents, the hackers of APT10 group compromised dozens of computer systems and stole sensitive information from more than 100,000 Navy personnel. This intrusion was part of the ‘Cloud Hopper’ campaign during which APT10 hacked into at least eight of the world’s biggest technology service providers, such as Hewlett Packard Enterprise and IBM, gaining unfettered access to their clients' data.
incidents.title: Two hackers affiliated to Chinese state-backed APT10 accused of breaching U.S. military computer systems.

incidents.content: In December 2018, the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) announced charges against two Chinese nationals who worked for the Chinese cyber group APT-10. The prosecutors accused the hackers of infiltrating corporate and government technology, including a major Department of Energy laboratory. The charges highlight PRC efforts to steal commercial data from U.S. companies, including "banking and finance, telecommunications and consumer electronics, medical equipment, packaging, manufacturing, consulting, healthcare, biotechnology, automotive, oil and gas exploration, and mining."
incidents.title: U.S. charges two hackers affiliated with the PRC

incidents.content:

In early June 2024, French counterterrorism authorities arrested a 26-year-old dual Ukrainian-Russian national after an explosion in his hotel room in Roissy-en-France. The suspect, who sustained facial and upper body burns, was found in possession of materials used to manufacture explosive devices, including ammonium nitrate, as well as firearms and forged passports. Investigators discovered that he had been preparing a bomb intended for a Bricorama store, aiming to cause property damage without casualties. The individual, identified as originating from the Donbass region and having previously fought with pro-Russian separatists, was charged with participation in a terrorist criminal association and possession of explosives in connection with a terrorist enterprise. French authorities suspect that he was acting under foreign direction, with communications on encrypted messaging platforms suggesting coordination from abroad. This incident is considered part of a broader campaign of sabotage orchestrated from Moscow targeting multiple European countries.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: France arrests Ukraine-Russia national with explosives on terror charges

incidents.content:

In November 2023, around one month after the October 7 attacks by Hamas in Israel, French authorities arrested four people suspected of painting almost 250 blue Stars of David across Paris. The subsequent investigation revealed that the graffiti was part of a Russian destabilization attempt to raise tensions between the large Jewish and Muslim communities in the city. The French governmental agency Viginum, which is tasked with monitoring foreign information manipulation attempts, found that bots affiliated with the Russian network Doppelganger were using the platform X, formerly known as Twitter, to fuel controversy regarding the paintings. In February 2024, France’s domestic intelligence agency assessed that the FSB’s fifth division that focuses on international operations was behind the destabilization attempt. Media reports also commented that the operation echoed a 1950s KGB operation that posted antisemitic slogans and swastikas throughout West Germany to mimic Nazi sentiment.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia orchestrates the spray painting of stars of David in Paris

incidents.content: In a June 2024 report, the French governmental agency Viginum, which is tasked with monitoring foreign information manipulation attempts, exposed “Matriochka”, a Russian disinformation campaign active since September 2023. The campaign aimed at discrediting governments, public officials, media and fact-checking agencies in more than 60 countries, France being a “prime target”. Propagated narratives criticized French support for Ukraine, specific French political figures, and the 2024 Paris Olympics. The campaign posted deepfake content, reports and images on online platforms, primarily on X, in the comment section of public figures, media outlets and fact-checking sites. Matrioshka operators then asked those influential accounts to investigate their false claims. Most content was traced back to Russian-language Telegram channels. Viginum assessed that “the criteria for foreign digital interference have been satisfied”.
incidents.title: French security agency reveals Russian propaganda campaign

incidents.content: In a February 2024 report, the French governmental agency Viginum, which is tasked with monitoring foreign information manipulation attempts, revealed a pro-Russian propaganda network that it dubbed “Portal Kombat”. The network originally covered Russian and Ukrainian news for Russian-speaking audiences, but shifted its focus to Ukrainian and Western audiences, particularly in France, after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. They did not produce any original content but rather used automation and search engine optimization to amplify posts from pro-Russian public figures in Europe, Russian news agencies, and official communications of the Russian government. Portal Kombat promoted false or misleading information about Russia’s war in Ukraine, denigrated Ukrainian leadership, and criticized Western governments supporting Kyiv. The Viginum report highlighted the central role of Crimea-based, Russian web development company TigerWeb in the creation and administration of the network sites. According to Viginum, Portal Kombat met “the criteria for foreign digital interference” and shared significant technical similarities to the Inforos network, which is under EU sanctions and assessed by the United States to be under GRU administration.
incidents.title: French security agency reveals Russian propaganda network

incidents.content: On April 16, 2024, the French governmental agency Viginum, which is tasked with monitoring foreign information manipulation attempts, made public that Rafaël Glucksmann, Socialist Party candidate for the June 2024 European parliamentary elections, was targeted by a mass disinformation campaign on social media. According to the agency, accounts linked to the PRC disseminated accusations that Glucksman was a trojan horse for the CIA in Europe, a rumor that had previously circulated in French far-right and -left circles. The PRC had issued sanctions against Glucksmann in 2021 for his vocal and repeated criticism of the PRC’s treatment towards Uyghurs. Following this incident, Viginum issued a warning to all political parties running in the June 2024 European elections.
incidents.title: PRC behind campaign denigrating European elections candidate

incidents.content: On June 2, 2024, Microsoft published an intelligence report highlighting disinformation campaigns by “Russian influence actors” Storm-1679 and Storm-1099 dating back to June 2023 and aiming to discredit the 2024 Olympic Games in Paris. In the first campaign, Storm-1679 created a faux Netflix documentary, narrated by an AI-generated Tom Cruise voice and titled “Olympics Has Fallen”, which they promoted across social media using AI-edited Cameo videos of American celebrities delivering anti-Ukraine messages and encouraging viewers to watch the documentary. Both Storm-1679 and Storm-1099’s main disinformation tactic, however, was to replicate reputable media outlets and democratic governments to disseminate Kremlin-talking points under the guise of authoritative sources. In one case, Storm-1679 released press releases supposedly emanating from the CIA and French General Directorate for Internal Security discouraging people from attending the Olympics, citing terrorist attack concerns. Similarly, Storm-1099’s versions of French outlets Le Parisien and Le Point propagated criticisms against Macron’s “showmanship” and his disregard of socio-economic issues in France.
incidents.title: Russian disinformation group targets the Paris Olympics

incidents.content:

On June 13, 2023, France accused Russia of carrying out a long-running disinformation campaign that leveraged websites impersonating French media and government agencies. The French outlets Le Monde and Le Figaro had their websites spoofed. The French Foreign Ministry also had its website impersonated and used to spread false information. In particular, VIGINUM, the French agency responsible for fighting online interference, said the fake websites were designed to sow confusion about Paris’s support for Ukraine. VIGINUM identified more than 350 fake domains targeting countries around Europe. The French agency assessed that the network of false websites was connected to a sprawling Russian disinformation campaign that Meta identified in 2022 but which continues to push false content.   

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia spoofs French media and government websites

On October 20, 2022, French media revealed two investigations that the Paris Judicial Court had initiated in September 2021 on two French politicians who stood accused of corruption, influence peddling, breach of trust and money laundering in connection with the French-Russian Dialogue Association. The French politicians, Thierry Mariani, from the National Rally Party, and Yves Pozzo di Borgo, former Senator and Paris counsellor, are the most active members of the association and have repeatedly defended the Kremlin’s foreign policy. The association is one of the most influential Russian political relays in France and seeks to deepen cooperation between politicians and businessmen from both countries. The French Ministry of Economy’s anti-money laundering unit identified suspicious financial transactions that transited through YPDB Conseil, a consulting company created by Pozzo di Borgo a few weeks after his 2017 Senate departure. According to the trade register, this company grew exponentially in 2018 and 2020, which granted the French politician generous dividends worth 103,838 euros in 2020. The Ministry’s investigations showed that YPDB Conseil made 85% of its turnover with the Russian bus manufacturer Bakulin Motors Group, believed to be connected to a Kremlin-linked oligarch.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: French politicians corrupted by French-Russian association

In July 2021, French cybersecurity agency ANSSI issued an alert identifying APT31, a Chinese state-affiliated hacker group, as the threat actor responsible for breaching an array of French entities. APT31 also operates under the aliases Zirconium and Judgment Panda and specializes in the theft of highly competitive organizations’ intellectual property. While the effected institutions were not named, ANSSI noted that the campaign utilized “a network of compromised home routers as operational relay boxes” to conduct reconnaissance and attacks. A December update of the ANSSI alert notes that, while the attack is still ongoing, APT31 has ceased its use of infected home routers.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese state-affiliated threat actor targets French organizations’ routers

Uyghurs living in several democratic countries in Europe and North America claim to be the target of harassment by Chinese authorities. Callers purporting to work for the Chinese state would ask Uyghurs living abroad to send extensive documentation and personal information, frequently making veiled threats concerning family members who still live in China. RFA reported in May 2017 that France was among the countries in which Chinese authorities ordered all Uyghurs students to return to their hometowns in China. Various media outlets reporting on this harassment explained that WeChat is a essential to Chinese authorities' monitoring and harassment of the Uyghur diaspora.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese authorities track and monitor Uyghurs living abroad

incidents.content: Aviazapchast, a Russian company that manufactures aircraft parts, filed suit in the Moscow City Court of Arbitration on December 4, 2019 against Marine Le Pen’s National Rally, to recover the $10.8 million its predecessor lent the party during France’s 2017 presidential election. The company is wholly owned by Valery Zakharchenkov, who is allegedly linked to Russian intelligence. The lawsuit is a further attempt by Russian proxies to inject chaos into the French political system following the 2017 presidential election.
incidents.title: Obscure Russian aircraft parts company sues France’s National Rally to recover $10.8 million it lent in 2014.

incidents.content: Up to 600 accounts known to be affiliated with the Russian government, as well as state media outlets such as RT and Sputnik, heavily promoted the 2018-19 anti-tax and anti-immigrant Yellow Vest (“gilets jaunes”) protest movement in France. The coordinated inauthentic behavior focused heavily on violent or provocative incidents during the protests, as is common with information manipulation campaigns by Russia to showcase instability in Western democracies.
incidents.title: Russian state media, including RT and Sputnik, amplify and heavily promote the Yellow Vest protest movement in France on social media.

incidents.content: In December 2020, Huawei announced it intended to build a network equipment factory in Brumath, on the French side of the Franco-German border, its first outside of China. Despite local authorities' enthusiasm at the prospect of new jobs in the region, French media also highlights that Brumath is located in the middle of several key military units specializing in various aspects of French military intelligence. Within a half hour drive of Brumath are located, among others, one unit specialized in human intelligence, one unit specialized in electronic warfare, as well as the headquarters for the French land forces' intelligence. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Huawei announces its intention to build a factory close to key French military intelligence installations.

incidents.content: The Chinese ambassador in Paris was summoned by the French ministry of foreign affairs after a text published on the embassy's website accused French authorities of leaving old people to die in their retirement homes. The Guardian quotes the Chinese text as saying that "Residents of retirement homes were made to sign certificates of ‘waiver of emergency care’; the nursing staff of the Ehpad abandoned their posts overnight, deserted collectively, leaving their residents to die of hunger and disease."
incidents.title: Chinese embassy in Paris accuses French authorities of abandoning old people during the COVID crisis

incidents.content: On October 12, 2020, a French museum announced that it would be delaying an exhibition on Genghis Khan and the Mongol empire following pressures from Beijing. The Chinese authorities asked the museum to remove certain words from the exhibition (such as "Khan", "empire", and "Mongol"). In addition, the museum explains that Beijing asked for control over all the elements that would accompany the exhibited pieces (maps, texts, etc.) The Chinese authorities proposed a new synopsis "aiming to make the Mongol culture and history disappear completely in favor of a new national narrative."
incidents.title: French museum cancels exhibition following pressures from Beijing
