[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On July 11, 2024, Western intelligence agencies exposed a Russian assassination plot targeting German defense company Rheinmetall’s CEO Armin Papperger after the US informed Germany of the imminent threat. Germany is the second largest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its defense against the Russian invasion and Rheinmetall plays a significant role in that military support. The German weapons’ manufacturer notably provides Leopard 1 main battle tanks, Marder infantry fighting vehicles, and 155mm artillery shells to Kyiv. A month before the assassination attempt, it had opened an armored vehicle maintenance facility in the Western part of Ukraine. In January 2025, NATO's deputy assistant Secretary-General for innovation, hybrid and cyber, James Appathurai, implied that the assassination attempt was only one of several such plots planned by Russia in countries supporting Ukraine.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia attempts to assassinate German CEO

incidents.content: In April 2022, the regional parliament of German regional state Mecklenburg-Vorpommern launched a parliamentary inquiry into the “Climate and Environment Protection Foundation MV”. The state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern had backed the foundation’s creation in January 2021, ostensibly to promote climate protection, nature preservation and the role of renewables and gas as bridge technologies. However, the foundation also aimed to ensure the completion of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, potentially circumventing US sanctions. The foundation was mostly funded by the Nord-Stream 2 AG, a Swiss company itself fully funded by Gazprom. Nord Stream 2 AG also participated in the drafting of the foundation’s charter. Mecklenburg-Vorpommern’s leadership denounced the foundation in 2022 but, as of fall 2024, legal obstacles were still preventing authorities from shutting it down.
incidents.title: German region investigates Gazprom-funded foundation over sanctions’ circumvention

incidents.content:
In April 2023, the Washington Post reported on the Kremlin’s attempts to interfere in German domestic politics, mostly through a manifesto drawn for the German far-right party Alternative für Deutschland (AfD) and an attempt to unite the far-right and the far-left in an anti-war coalition to curb support for Ukraine. One year later, the German weekly Der Spiegel reported additional details about the manifesto. They explained that, in July 2022, the Kremlin commissioned Tatyana Matveyeva, the deputy to the Kremlin’s first deputy chief of staff Sergei Kiriyenko, to draw up a new concept for AfD, aiming at boosting support for the party and reaching majorities at the local, regional, and federal level, notably through cooperation between the far-right and far-left. The documents suggested rebranding AfD under the name of “United Germany” or “German Unity” and promoting the end of discrimination against Russian Germans.

Whether the document reached AfD is unclear. However, interviews with officials and affiliates from both AfD and the new far-left party BSW suggest that at least one member of each party has been in contact with Kremlin officials when the plans were being drawn up.
incidents.title: Kremlin strategic paper aims to build anti-war coalition with far-right and far-left

incidents.content: On March 1, 2024, editor-in-chief of Russian state-run channel RT, Margarita Simonyan, shared a 38-minute recording of an internal German military call about Ukraine. In the clip posted to Telegram and other platforms, four senior German military officers, including the chief of the German air force, discussed whether German Taurus cruise missiles would be capable of destroying the Kerch bridge connecting mainland Russia to occupied and illegally annexed Crimea. At the time, German Chancellor Scholz had repeatedly refused to deliver such missiles to Ukaine. The Kremlin used the recording to allege that Western powers were planning to strike Russian territory and place British troops in Ukraine. These claims caused panic in NATO countries, particularly in the UK. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and Defense Minister Boris Pistorius promised a swift investigation into the “very serious matter” of this “hybrid attack of disinformation”. The investigation concluded that a Russian spy had dialed into the Webex-call without being noticed due to “individual errors”.
incidents.title: Russia leaks German military audio to the press

incidents.content: On June 1, 2024, one week before European parliamentary elections, Germany’s largest opposition party was forced to temporarily take part of its IT infrastructure offline after it fell victim to a “serious” cyberattack. In response, the German Federal Office for Information Security (BSI) and the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution (BfV) increased protective measures to prevent further damage, issued warnings to all other political parties, and launched an investigation. Officials eventually attributed the attack to APT28, a hacking unit also known as Fancy Bear directed by Russia’s military intelligence service (GRU). Authorities refused to provide details regarding the extent of the breach but later confirmed that party head Friedrich Merz was amongst those affected. The hackers apparently took advantage of vulnerabilities in the security software “Check Point”.
incidents.title: Russia hacks Germany’s largest opposition party (CDU)

incidents.content: Vladimir Sergienko, a Ukrainian-born staffer to German Member of the European Parliament Eugen Schmidt (a representative of the Alternative für Deutschland [AfD] party), is accused of colluding with Russia. He is currently facing the revocation of his German citizenship, after having lied about his double citizenship of Ukraine and Russia. His unrestricted access to the German federal parliament and national legislation have been suspended. In August 2023, news outlets Spiegel and The Insider first reported on the incident, based on leaked conversations between Sergienko and an unknown person called ‘Alexei’. The conversations from March 2023 indicate that Sergienko was asking for Russian financial and media support to prepare a legal complaint against German military support for Ukraine, aiming to prevent or at least delay the delivery of arms and non-lethal goods. In April 2023, he also asked for a money transfer to a German NGO with pro-Kremlin positions. ‘Alexei’ was later identified as Ilya Vechtomov, an officer of the Fifth Service of Russia’s Federal Security Service. In July 2023, the AfD initiated legal procedure  2 BvE 5/23, in which it claimed the German Parliament had not been sufficiently involved and consulted in the executive’s decision to supply military equipment to Ukraine.
incidents.title: Staffer to German far-right MEP colludes with Russian agent to delay military aid to Ukraine

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Petr Bystron, a German MP for far-right Alternative für Deutschland (AfD) and second on the party’s list for the 2024 European Parliament elections was accused of having connections to the pro-Russian Voice of Europe platform, potentially also receiving money from it. Czech newspaper Denik N first reported on those allegations in early April 2024. The newspaper explained that Czech intelligence was investigating claims against Bystron based on audio recordings, indicating that he received 20,000 Euro in cash from oligarch Artem Marchevsky. German public prosecutors started investigating Bystron for and money laundering. Bystron’s immunity was lifted, and his office and private rooms were searched by the police on May 17th.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: German far-right MP investigated for payments from Kremlin-friendly media

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On April 23, 2024, German authorities arrested Jian G., the parliamentary aide to Maximilian Krah, a Member of the European Parliament for Alternative für Deutschland (AfD), for “alleged intelligence activity”. Jian is accused of repeatedly forwarding internal information from the European Parliament to the Chinese secret service and of spying on Chinese dissidents living in Germany. He was one of the first assistants employed by Krah when he entered the European Parliament in July 2019. Reports concerning Jian started appearing in 2023, when German outlet t-online shared another AfD MEP’s doubts about the sincerity of the aide’s commitment to the parties’ parliamentary work. Krah, the party’s top candidate in the 2024 European parliament elections, said that he did not have any knowledge about the activities of his assistant, but that he would terminate the employment if allegations proved to be true. The European Parliament suspended Jian G. immediately due to the severity of the allegations.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Assistant to Member of European Parliament arrested for espionage on behalf of PRC

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On December 25, 2020 Chinese state-owned publisher China International Publishing Group had pressured a small German publishing house to alter the German translation of a Chinese book or have a book tour by the author canceled. After the books had already been printed, the Chinese publisher requested that the German publisher make edits to portray the Cultural Revolution more favorably. They also asked that the book, which the Chinese foreword presents as based on the memories of someone the author met, be presented as fiction in the German translation. The German publisher refused the changes, resulting in the partial cancellation of the book tour. In a related story, Thalia, a large German bookstore chain, had its Chinese literature section emptied of content critical of the CCP. According to DW, Thalia’s shelves instead had “speeches by Xi Jinping front and center.” It turned out the displays were curated by a German subsidiary of China International Publishing Group.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese state-owned publishing group advances pro-CCP worldview in Germany

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On October 22, 2021 two German journalists were to present their new book: Xi Jinping: The Most Powerful Man in the World, at the Confucius Institutes of Hannover and of the University of Duisburg-Essen but the presentations were cancelled last minute due to pressure from Chinese diplomats. After the cancellation, Aust, one of the authors, quoted an institute employee as saying “you cannot talk about Xi Jinping as a normal person, he is supposed to be untouchable and unmentionable now.” Authors Aust and Adrian stated that this incident confirmed the thesis of their book: “Not only is a dictatorship trying to overtake the west in economic terms but it is also trying to push its values internationally — values which are aimed at our freedom,” German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas summoned the Chinese ambassador but there was no public remonstrance over the cancellations.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Confucius Institute shuts down presentation critical of Xi Jinping at German University

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On September 6, German Foreign Ministry officials said that a hacking group affiliated with Russia’s military intelligence service was targeting German politicians with phishing attacks ahead of the country’s elections on September 26. German intelligence agencies warned in July that the Russian hacking collective, known as Ghostwriter, was attempting to steal data from German officials, potentially to use in a hack-and-leak operation designed to disrupt the German elections. Days before the polls opened, the European Union’s top diplomat attributed Ghostwriter’s campaign to Russia and called the group’s actions a threat to “the core functioning of our democracies.” No significant hack-and-leak operation surfaced prior to Germany’s election.   

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia-linked hacking group Ghostwriter targets German politicians ahead of elections

incidents.content: On March 26, 2021, hackers likely affiliated with Russia’s military intelligence service (GRU) targeted seven members of the German federal parliament, the Bundestag, and 31 state legislators with phishing emails, according to German authorities. The credential theft activity targeted politicians belonging to the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), the political party of Chancellor Angela Merkel, and the Social Democratic Party (SDP). FireEye reports that UNC1151, a state-sponsored cyber actor that uses malware and credential theft tactics, is likely behind the attack. Additionally, FireEye concluded that the attack was a part of a broader influence campaign called Ghostwriter, which has involved attacks in Lithuania, Latvia, and Poland since 2017 and is aligned with Russian security interests. Historically, the campaign has utilized fake email accounts and junk news sites to spread anti-NATO sentiment and false narratives.
incidents.title: Russian government-linked hackers target German lawmakers

incidents.content: In December 2019, Wu Ken, the Chinese ambassador to Germany, was quoted as threatening the German auto manufacturing industry to restrict its access to the Chinese market should Chinese tech giant Huawei be excluded from participating in contracts to build Germany's 5G networks. Chinese consumers purchased approximately 28 million cars in 2018 of which 25% were German brands. Despite warnings from Germany's intelligence community, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, supported by several German telecommunications companies, remains opposed to banning any particular company outright.
incidents.title: Chinese ambassador to Berlin warns of "consequences" for the German car industry should Huawei be banned from Germany's 5G network

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text columns="" column_min_width="" column_spacing="" rule_style="" rule_size="" rule_color="" hue="" saturation="" lightness="" alpha="" content_alignment_medium="" content_alignment_small="" content_alignment="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" sticky_display="normal,sticky" class="" id="" margin_top="" margin_right="" margin_bottom="" margin_left="" fusion_font_family_text_font="" fusion_font_variant_text_font="" font_size="" line_height="" letter_spacing="" text_transform="" text_color="" animation_type="" animation_direction="left" animation_color="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_delay="0" animation_offset=""]

Abdujelil Emet, a Uyghur man and naturalized citizen of Germany, told the Guardian that a Chinese official made threats against his family over the phone after he sat in the public gallery of a parliamentary hearing on human rights. Following the hearing, Emet received a phone call from his sister still living in the Chinese province of Xinjiang for the first time in three years. Towards the end of the call, a Chinese official warned Emet that he needed "to think of [his] family while [he's] running around doing [his] activism work in Germany." Emet, who has lived in Germany for over two decades, volunteers for the World Uyghur Congress, a global organization of exiled Uyghurs that promotes "democracy, human rights, and freedom" for the Uyghur people. According to the Guardian, the warning made to Emet is part of a campaign by Beijing to quell criticism of the CCP policies that have led to the detainment of more than a million ethnic Uyghurs, and other Turkic Muslim minorities, within internment camps.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Uyghur man living in Germany has family threatened by Chinese officials due to his activism abroad

incidents.content: Outgoing Chinese ambassador to Germany Shi Mingde asked German corporations to help establish a new media outlet that would favorably represent Beijing to the German people. The "China Reporter" project, which never came to fruition, was conceptualized by Mr. Shi and two German journalists who he could trust "to permanently influence the image of China in Germany and shape it more objectively", as explained in the letter. The German reporters, Georg Blume of Die Zeit and Spiegel, and Wolfgang Hirn of Manager Magazine, had "decades of experience in China and in the best German media", again according to the letter. Mr. Shi estimated that the project would cost an annual budget of 250,000 euros, and he wrote to major German companies belonging to the DAX stock index asking for financial support. While the project was not successful, German news site Süddeutsche Zeitung reports that the letter gives insight into Beijing's efforts to influence public opinion in Germany.
incidents.title: Outgoing Chinese ambassador writes letter to German companies soliciting funds for pro-Beijing media project

incidents.content: Alongside more innocuous services for academic or social assistance, Chinese student associations in Germany appear to promote more problematic conduct as well. For instance, reports allege that at least one leader of a Chinese student association at a German university was explicitly asked by Chinese embassy officials to act as a spy. Additionally, publications from such groups have included political exhortations to support CCP efforts, such as reminding students that "you can take to the streets and shout for the motherland." Similarly, remarks from Chinese Ambassador Shi Mingde at an event sponsored by Chinese student associations included a call to "turn patriotic feelings into patriotic deeds … tightly tie your own ideals to the destiny of the motherland," before continuing with a directive to "bring science and technology back home, to push forward China’s economic and social development." Members of Chinese student groups have noted that requests to transfer economic or research data can come with both financial inducements and appeals to national loyalty.
incidents.title: Chinese student and scholar groups promote CCP values and ideology in Germany

incidents.content: In July 2018, Chinese state-owned China State Grid bid to purchase a 20% stake in 50Hertz, a German transmission system operator for electricity. In response, The German finance and economy ministers issued a joint statement clearly outlining their position that the government viewed China State Grid's purchase of a 20% stake in 50Hertz as a threat to national security and critical infrastructure. To block the purchase by china State Grid, the German federal government had KfW, a German state-owned development bank buy the stake instead. The German government could not directly interfere with the transaction as the law only allowed involvement by the government when ownership stakes in question are 25% or greater.
incidents.title: Chinese state-owned operator tried to purchase a 20% stake in the regional transmission system operator, 50Hertz

incidents.content: Daimler, a German auto manufacturer, issued an apologize for an Instagram post for its Mercedes-Benz brand that utilized a quote from the Dalai Lama. Instagram is banned in China, but some Chinese citizens can access the content through virtual private networks. Chinese citizens and state media attacked the company for their insensitivity to Chinese values. Daimler's apology was posted on Chinese social media platform Weibo, and the Mercedes-Benz brand deleted the post from their Instagram account. The Chinese market accounts for nearly 30% of all Mercedes-Benz cars sold in 2019.
incidents.title: German auto manufacturer, Daimler, publicly apologizes to China for a corporate Instagram post that utilized a quote from the Dalai Lama

incidents.content: An auto-parts business in Berlin owned by Russians and Ukrainians provides financial support in the form of advertising revenue to extremist websites in Sweden, Germany, Hungary, Austria, and elsewhere in Europe.
incidents.title: An auto-parts business in Berlin owned by Russians and Ukrainians provides financial support in the form of advertising revenue to extremist websites in Sweden, Germany, Hungary, Austria, and elsewhere in Europe

incidents.content: On September 29, 2017, former German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was elected to the board of directors of Russian state-controlled oil giant Rosneft. Already chairman of the controversial Russian state-controlled Nord Stream 2 project, Schröder came under heavy criticism from all major German political parties, including his own Social Democrats, for apparently gaining financially from his previous role as chancellor and helping Russia extend its energy dominance over European energy supplies.
incidents.title: Former German Chancellor Schröder elected to the board of Russian state-controlled Rosneft

incidents.content: On June 13, 2017, Germany's Federal Office for Information Security, BSI, revealed that Russian hackers launched a widespread attack on German energy providers. According to BSI, the attackt dubbed "Berserk Bear" only breached the computers of a few companies. BSI did not reveal the total number of targets. A week later, Germany's intelligence agency pointed to Russia as the perpetrator. As reported by Reuters, Hans-Georg Maassen, former President of the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, stated, “The modus operandi is in fact one of multiple indications that point to Russian control of the attack campaign.”
incidents.title: Berserk Bear - Germany implicates Russian hackers in attacks on German energy companies

incidents.content: On April 24, 2017, Russian state-controlled Gazprom signed a financing deal for the controversial Nord Stream 2 project. The new pipeline would double Russia's capacity to export natural gas directly to Germany through the Baltic Sea, deepening Europe's reliance on Russian gas and increasing Europe's vulnerability to Russian influence. The pipeline is also viewed as a Russian attempt to divide Europe, as the project has caused divisions among member states of the European Union and NATO.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Gazprom signs financing deal for Nord Stream 2 pipeline

incidents.content: In April 2017, Russian nationals and associates of the Russian government conspired to offer support to the election campaign of a prominent member of the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party. Russian government strategy papers reviewed by European news outlets, including the BBC show that Russia provided political support to far-right German MP Markus Frohnmaier during his 2017 Bundestag election campaign. One document suggests the goal of the operation was to deliver to the Kremlin its "own absolutely controlled MP in the Bundestag." A separate document obtained from an unnamed EU state intelligence agency detailed the overarching aim of Russian support for Frohnmaier - to see him take an influential role in shaping AfD foreign policy on the expectation that he would promote closer ties to Russia and insert Russian-friendly planks into the party platform. Since Frohnmaier's election in 2017, Russian state-sponsored media has featured the young parliamentarian prominently in its coverage, focusing heavily on his pro-Russian positions, including his public acceptance of Russia's annexation of Crimea and his personal validation of the 2018 Russian presidential election, which he deemed to be free and fair. German officials from across the political spectrum have called for Frohnmaier to resign.
incidents.title: Russian government officials and associates conspire to support the election of pro-Russian Bundestag member

incidents.content: In March 2017, according to cybersecurity firm Trend Micro, hackers from Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected group Fancy Bear, or APT28, hacked the systems of two think tanks tied to the parties of the German coalition government. The Christian Democratic Union’s (CDU) Konrad Adenauer Foundation and the Social Democratic Party’s (SDP) Friedrich Ebert Foundation fell victim to a spear phishing operation that attempted to install malicious software. It is suspected that the attacks were targeting Chancellor Angela Merkel, from the CDU party, who was seeking reelection at the time.
incidents.title: German political think tanks hacked by Russian GRU-connected Fancy Bear

incidents.content: On February 14, 2017, Lithuanian politicians and media outlets recieved emails alleging the rape of an underage Lithuanian girl by German NATO soldiers. Lithuanian authorities found no evidence of the alleged rape. NATO officials stated that the email campaign was an attempt to undermine NATO presence in Eastern Europe, and that the Russian government likely perpetrated the operation. The false accusations resembled the fake rape "Liza case" in Germany that was widely spread by Russian state-sponsored media outlets.
incidents.title: NATO officials allege Russian government is behind false rape accusations against German soldiers

incidents.content: On February 6, 2017, hackers set up a website imitating the official website of German Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democratic Union (CDU). According to Germany's domestic intelligence service, BfV, the website was likely preparation for a phishing attack against the political party. BfV linked the website to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacker group Fancy Bear, or APT28.
incidents.title: GRU-connected Fancy Bear sets up copy of official German conservatives' website

incidents.content: The Freie Universität of Berlin signed in 2017 establishing an endowed professorship by partnering with the Chinese state body governing Confucius Institutes. The agreement sets aside approximately 500,000 euros over a five-year period to fund a teaching degree in Chinese, with provision for 20 students annually. However, language within the contract raises potentially problematic leverage on the part of the Chinese state, including allowing "corrective measures" against the university, requiring the program to obey Chinese laws that have been used to silence critics, and multiple mechanisms to halt funding, from yearly evaluations to holding any mediation in a Chinese setting. A former head of propaganda for the Chinese Communist Party has called Confucius Institutes "an important part of China’s overseas propaganda set-up," and multiple other contracts between Chinese state-run educational establishments and western universities have run into issues of academic freedom and censorship.
incidents.title: Teaching contract at German university raises concerns over Chinese state influence

incidents.content: German companies, especially those specializing in advanced manufacturing, engineering, and other high-tech industries remain targets of Chinese hacking operations, allegedly with Chinese government support. U.S. Department of Justice indictments have accused Chinese intelligence personnel of participating in industrial espionage campaigns, including some Advanced Persistent Threat groups active against Germany. Germany's information security agency has urged companies to improve defensive measures and warned of continuous efforts to steal economic and technical data. Besides the tech and manufacturing sector, the targeting of pharmaceutical conglomerate Bayer in 2019 suggests that the medical sector also faces vulnerabilities. German companies have suffered from hacks of allegedly Chinese origin since at least 2009, with estimates of damages in the billions of euros annually.
incidents.title: Chinese hackers, allegedly with state backing, continue to target German firms

incidents.content: Some German officials at sub-national levels have increasingly advocated pro-Beijing positions and expressed support for Chinese activity in Europe. For example, Helga Zepp-LaRouche, a founder of fringe political party Bürgerrechtsbewegung Solidarität (BüSo), was invited to attend the official Belt and Road Initiative Forum in 2017, and her party has adopted some official Chinese political language in its electoral campaigning, including ads in Berlin claiming that "the future of Germany is the Silk Road!" Elsewhere, Wolfgang Tiefensee, a former transportation minister now active in regional politics, praised Chinese investments as a "completely new form of cooperation," and traveled to China to make personal pitches for new projects. Similarly, the mayor of Arnstadt, where Chinese firm Contemporary Amperex Technology Ltd. has decided to invest $2 billion in a new factory, has said that "It’s not my job to talk about" human rights violations and other problematic Chinese activity. Chinese investment in places like Duisburg, where almost 100 Chinese companies have established a presence, even extend influence to educational settings, with one local principal saying that new Chinese language instruction will "portray a realistic image [of China]. By learning Chinese, students will be able to see things as they are." The focus on economic relations over political concerns likely carries additional weight in struggling locales like Duisburg, where the unemployment rate is more than triple the national average
incidents.title: Friendly - and economically dependent - local officials boost Chinese rhetoric and objectives in Germany

incidents.content: In October 2016, German authorities blocked a potential sale of semiconductor manufacturer Aixtron to a Chinese company, Fujian Grand Chip Investment Fund (FGC). The proposed deal valued at nearly $732 million reportedly drew U.S. and German concerns that the company's technology could be adapted for military purposes by the People's Liberation Army, given CCP laws requiring companies to cooperate with security interests. Additional concern came from suggestions of improper dealing in advance of the decision to sell. Specifically, San’an Optoelectronics, a different Chinese entity but one under the control of the same state-run semiconductor fund, canceled an order from Aixtron, which caused its value to plummet and gave FGC an opening to negotiate advantageously.
incidents.title: Sale of German semiconductor firm to Chinese entity blocked over national security concerns

incidents.content: On August 15 and 24, 2016, hackers targeted Germany's Social Democratic Party (SDP), Die Linke, and Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) with phishing attacks. The perpetrators, who imitated NATO officials, were reportedly unsuccessful. The German cyber-security agency BSI indicated that Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacking group Fancy Bear, or APT28, was responsible for the attack.
incidents.title: Suspected Russian hackers target German political parties

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On July 29, 2016, former German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder became the chairman of the board of the Russian state-controlled Nord Stream 2 company (a subsidiary of Gazprom), although it was not officially announced until October 5, 2016. The position accompanies his post as chairman of the shareholder committee for the project as a whole, which he has held since 2005. With his new position, Schröder took on an even greater role with the controversial project, which many Central and Eastern European states strongly oppose due to the potentially destabilizing geopolitical consequences. Nord Stream 2 would double Russia's capacity to export natural gas directly to Germany through the Baltic Sea, increasing energy dependence on Russia.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Gerhard Schröder becomes chairman of Nord Stream 2 Board of Directors

incidents.content: In July 2016, Russian government-connected oligarch Vladimir Yakunin launched the Dialogue of Civilizations Research Institute (DOC) in Berlin. According to Deutsche Welle, there were "rumors that the Berlin center is to be the headquarters of a worldwide network of such institutions, aimed at making 'Russia's view of the world popular.'" Although the funding of the organization is not public, DOC denies receiving any Russian government funding. The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung reported that Yakunin was planning to invest 25 million euros over five years, and it was suspected that several other Russian businessmen had invested in DOC. The U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned Vladimir Yakunin in 2014 for “involvement in the situation in Ukraine” due to his position as a high-ranking government official and as a member of Russian President Vladimir Putin’s inner circle. The U.S. Treasury Department described Yakunin as a "close confidant" of Vladimir Putin.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected oligarch Vladimir Yakunin launches think tank in Berlin to present pro-Russian perspective

incidents.content: In April 2016, approximately a year after hacking the German Parliament, Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacker group Fancy Bear, or APT28, conducted a cyber-operation against Germany's Christian Democratic Union (CDU), the party of German Chancellor Angela Merkel and the largest party in Parliament. According to Trend Micro, Fancy Bear's attack mainly consisted of coordinated credential phishing in an attempt to gain access to sensitive computer systems and email accounts. According to Germany's domestic intelligence agency (BfV), the attempts were detected early by a cybersecurity firm and by BfV, so they were unsuccessful.
incidents.title: Russia's GRU-connected Fancy Bear hacks Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democratic Union (CDU)

incidents.content: In January 2016, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Channel One reported a story about the alleged rape of a German girl of Russian origin named Liza by migrants from the Middle East. Although the story was debunked by local authorities, other Russian outlets – both in traditional and social media - seized on the story and amplified its reach, stirring anti-immigrant sentiment throughout Germany and even leading to demonstrations involving “representatives of the German-Russian minority (Deutschlandrussen) as well as neo-Nazi groups.” Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov also commented on the story in order to criticize Germany's immigration policies and stoke tensions.
incidents.title: Russian domestic and foreign news outlets spread disinformation to stir up anti-migrant sentiment

incidents.content: In spring 2015, the Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacker group known as Fancy Bear, or APT28, carried out a cyberattack on the German Parliament, according a 2018 minority staff report by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Initially German officials could not confirm where the attack originated from, but in 2016, a senior security agent stated that the cyberattack was "clearly attributable to a Russian military intelligence service."
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacker group Fancy Bear attacks German Parliament

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Chinese "friendship associations" and student groups in Germany have developed extensive networks promoting Beijing's rhetoric and positions to an at times unsuspecting European audience. For example, the Chinese People’s Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries (CPAFFC) has multiple agreements with German cultural and social organizations and, according to one German interlocutor, "avoids politics." However, the CPAFFC has substantial ties to the United Front Work Department, a CCP entity responsible for responsible for ensuring Party control of PRC society, including Chinese business people and members of the Chinese diaspora, and has been linked to cases of political interference around the world. The CPAFFC's president is the daughter of a high-ranking official who used to run the People’s Political Consultative Conference, and she herself is said to have a rank equivalent to a minister in Chinese bureaucratic circles. The Chinese organizations have sought to soften perceptions of China and the CCP in Germany, in part by emphasizing culture and trade over political and security concerns.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese-German "friendship associations" and educational groups appear to launder CCP soft power propaganda, cultivate political influence

incidents.content: On March 3, 2014, members of the Russian government-connected Night Wolves biker gang entered Germany as part of a victory ride around Europe to commemorate the Soviet victory over Nazi Germany in World War II. According to the Telegraph, the group has been accused of attempting to intimidate European countries with the tour. The Polish and German governments attempted to block the Night Wolves’ from entering their countries, with the Polish government stopping them at the border and the German government revoking visas from known members. In 2014, the U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned the Night Wolves due to their support for Russia-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. The Treasury Department described the group as "closely connected to the Russian special services."
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Night Wolves visit Germany on WWII victory ride

incidents.content: On April 4, 2013, Russian state-sponsored media outlet RT launched Ruptly, a "full-service global video news agency,", in Berlin. According to RT, Ruptly was designed to become the "go-to alternative resource" in the region, providing alternative coverage to major news stories. U.S. intelligence agencies have described RT as “Russia’s state-run propaganda machine.”
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet RT launches visual news agency "Ruptly" in Berlin

incidents.content: On December 14, 2011, four employees of one of Germany's biggest banks, Commerzbank, were charged for helping launder money from Russian telecommunications companies, as well as a Danish lawyer who facilitated the activities. They are alleged to have illegally transferred $150 million in Russian telecom assets on behalf of former Russian Telecoms Minister Leonid Reiman between 1995 and 2008. Commerzbank was fined €7.3 million by the Frankfurt civil court. In 2012, four of the defendants settled the charges, while the charges against the fifth were dropped due to the expiration of the statute of limitations.
incidents.title: Four Commerzbank employees charged in Russian money-laundering case

incidents.content: On November 8, 2011, German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Russian President Dmitry Medvedev officially inaugurated the Nord Stream pipeline. The pipeline was marketed as an attempt to reduce Russian dependence on transit pipelines through Belarus and Ukraine, and drew heavy criticism from governments of transit countries, such as Poland and Ukraine. In October 2012, the second section of the Nord Stream gas pipeline was officially inaugurated. New Russian gas pipelines to Europe increase dependence on Russian energy supplies.
incidents.title: Inauguration of the first section of Nord Stream pipeline

incidents.content: Chinese media entities, usually with connections to state organizations and espousing Communist Party narratives, have increasingly entered into agreements with German media that have the effect of laundering propaganda. For instance, German outlets including Handelsblatt and Süddeutsche Zeitung publish China Watch, a paid media placement prepared by the China Daily, over which the CCP exercises financial and editorial control. Similarly, a newsletter from DPA, Germany's largest press agency, now carries content from Xinhua, including materials promoting the Belt and Road Initiative, Beijing's effort to fuse infrastructure and economic investments with geopolitical influence. Hamburg-based Europe Times is owned by a company touting "excellent connections to companies, officials, ministries and associations in China," with scarce detail publicly available on what these connections entail. Though proponents of the media collaboration efforts note that such content is usually listed as paid advertising, critics still contend that Chinese state media are piggybacking off of the greater trust citizens place in their local news outlets, and that standalone content from a foreign authoritarian government would not be very persuasive.
incidents.title: Chinese state media bolster CCP narratives to potentially unaware audiences in Germany

incidents.content: In November 2005, just weeks before stepping down as Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder signed the controversial North European Gas Pipeline deal (later renamed "Nord Stream") with Russia. Directly after leaving office, Schröder accepted the nomination as chairman of the Russian state-controlled company (a subsidiary of Gazprom) responsible for the project, leading to allegations of corruption and cronyism. Members on both sides of the aisle in Germany denounced Mr. Schröder's actions.
incidents.title: Former German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder becomes chairman of Russian state-controlled Nord Stream pipeline company directly after leaving office

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In March 2025, the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP) and iStories revealed that RT, a Kremlin-controlled media outlet banned in the EU and sanctioned by the United States, secretly funded a network of “independent” influencers to promote anti-Ukrainian content and portray Russia as a defender of “traditional values.” Among them is Martin Held, an Austrian-born content creator who runs the YouTube and TikTok channel “Russian Road.” The account features videos of foreigners praising life in Russia and frames the West as morally decaying. Financial records show Held received nearly half a million euros from RT’s parent company, TV Novosti, through a firm he controls in Russia. Though previously blocked under the name “Russian Code,” Held’s rebranded channel continues to grow across TikTok, Instagram, and YouTube. Other influencers reportedly backed by RT include “Sasha Meets Russia” and German Russian commentator Alina Lipp.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian state media bypasses sanctions by backing Western content creators

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Jan Marsalek, an Austrian citizen working for the Russian military intelligence agency GRU, fed false information to the far-right FPÖ while they were in Austria’s governing coalition, leading to a police raid on the Austrian domestic intelligence service BVT. Marsalek conveyed allegations that the BVT was investigating the FPÖ via an anonymous dossier distributed by two BVT double agents. He then promoted the documents via the Austro-Russian Friendship society, actively targeting Russophile far-right politician Johann Gudenus to nurture his mistrust of the intelligence unit. As a result, on 28 February 2018, the premises of Austrian intelligence service were raided by local policemen looking for evidence of corruption and mishandling of sensitive data. The raid was ultimately signed off by the FPÖ-led ministry of interior. Evidence suggests that the Kremlin intended the operation to lay the groundwork for a rebuilding of the intelligence service under a new leadership more favorable to Moscow.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian agent manipulates Austrian far-right into raiding intelligence service

incidents.content: A1 Telekom, Austria's largest internet service provider was hacked in November 2019. In December, A1's cybersecurity team noticed the intrusion, but it wasn’t until May 22, 2020 that they were able to remove the malware and boot the hackers from the system. The delay came from the team's maneuvers to avoid alerting the hackers to A1’s awareness of their presence in the system, and from several unfortunate postponements caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The main suspect for this attack is the PLA hacking group called Gallium. The fact that the attackers did not use ransomware or encrypt any data points to a state-controlled group, Gallium targeted many telecom companies in 2018 and 2019 to steal their data, and the attack pattern fit their usual modus operandi. However, there was no official attribution of the attack on A1 Telekom.
incidents.title: Chinese state-affiliated hacker group prime suspect in cyberattack against Austrian internet provider

incidents.content: On June 5, 2018, Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom and Austrian energy company OMV signed an agreement to supply Austria with Russian gas through 2040. No other details of the deal were made public. According to a European Parliament study, long-term supply contracts between Russian energy companies, in particular Gazprom, and European importers increase the purchasing country's dependence on Russian energy supplies by locking in energy purchases for the duration of the contract.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Gazprom and Austrian energy giant sign long-term gas supply deal

incidents.content: On November 6, 2017, two members of the far-right Freedom Party of Austria (FPÖ) Hans-Jörg Jenewein and Detlef Wimmer participated in the founding of a "Friends of Crimea" group to promote international recognition of Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea. Jenewein and Wimmer had recently returned from a controversial visit to Crimea, which was funded in part by unidentified Russian organizers. In the past, other FPÖ members also visited Crimea to observe the annexation referendum organized by Russian authorities and to recognize the region as part of Russia, according to Deutsche Welle.
incidents.title: Austrian far-right politicians encourage international recognition of Crimean annexation following Russian-sponsored trip

incidents.content: On December 27, 2016, the Organization for Security and Co-Operation in Europe (OSCE) confirmed that there was a cyberattack on its headquarters in Vienna, Austria that gained access to emails, folders, passwords, and sensitive information. At the time of the attack, the OSCE was monitoring a ceasefire agreement between Ukrainian troops and Russian-backed separatists in Eastern Ukraine. According to Le Monde, a Western intelligence service attributed the attack to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28.
incidents.title: The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), based in Vienna, confirms cyber hack attributed to GRU-connected Fancy Bear

incidents.content: In 2002, Russian government-connected oligarch Vladimir Yakunin founded the World Public Forum - Dialogue of Civilizations in Vienna, Austria. According to the Foreign Policy Centre, the foundation is part of a network of organizations promoting an authoritarian and Eurasianist model of thought to counter the current liberal-democratic world order. The U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned Vladimir Yakunin in 2014 for “involvement in the situation in Ukraine” due to his position as a high-ranking government official and as a member of Russian President Vladimir Putin’s inner circle. The U.S. Treasury Department described Yakunin as a "close confidant" of Vladimir Putin.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected oligarch Vladimir Yakunin launches NGO in Vienna

incidents.content: In October 2024, Moldovan authorities uncovered a Russian-backed destabilization operation ahead of the country's presidential election and concurrent EU accession referendum. The plot, orchestrated by fugitive oligarch Ilan Shor, funneled over USD $15 million from Russian banks into the accounts of more than 130,000 Moldovans, amounting to 5% of all Moldovan residents, with the aim of influencing the vote against pro-European policies. Shor had previously led protests against President Maia Sandu’s pro-Western government. The Stockholm Centre for Eastern European Studies suggested that Shor was behind attacks on official buildings such as the Moldovan Ministry of Labor, the Government Building and the Central Election Commission. The Swedish non-profit also reported that Moldovan police had arrested several suspects who were trained outside Moscow and paid to carry out vandalism and violent protests. In addition, Moldova’s national security adviser, Stanislav Secrieru, accused the Kremlin of “flooding the political landscape with clone parties and candidates, from pro-Russian to phony pro-European.”
incidents.title: Russia interferes in 2024 Moldovan election

incidents.content: Ahead of Moldovan local elections in October 2023, pro-Russian propagandists hired US celebrities to record videos of themselves calling for the overthrow of Moldova’s pro-European President Maia Sandu on Cameo, a video platform that allows users to pay celebrities to create personalized videos. The Digital Forensic Research Lab found that the celebrities were paid to read a script in Russian, a language most of them likely did not understand. The individual clips were then edited into a video compilation that was first shared on TikTok. The account has since been deleted. The longer edit was later reposted in prominent Telegram channels and reproduced in Russian media and on various other platforms. While researchers could not establish a direct link to the Kremlin with complete certainty, the smear of Sandu followed the modus operandi of a similar Russian-sponsored operation from July 2023. There, Russian operatives had hired celebrities on Cameo to record videos calling for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to seek treatment for alleged substance abuse.
incidents.title: US celebrities hired to call for Moldovan president’s resignation

incidents.content: Russia’s state-funded private military company Wagner Group – and specifically its former head, the now-deceased Yevgeny Prigozhin – plotted a coup attempt that aimed to depose Moldova’s pro-European president Maia Sandu and destabilize the country. The attempt was thwarted thanks to information released on February 9, 2023, by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. While Ukrainian authorities simply spoke of plans “by the Russian intelligence”, the Moldovan President attributed the operation to Wagner Group’s since-deceased leader Yevgeny Prigozhin. The coup was part of a larger strategy to destabilize the country politically. Russian forces intended to support the coup with various tactics including provoking societal unrest, encouraging anti-government protests to turn violent by hiring aggressive rioters, and bribing voters with money smuggled into the country through cash mules and bank cards issued in Dubai. According to Moldovan intelligence, Russia illegally channeled more than $55 million into the country for political purposes in 2023.
incidents.title: Russia’s Wagner Group plotted attempted coup in Moldova

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In October 2022, the US Treasury Department sanctioned multiple organizations and individuals for being part of Russia’s malign influence operations targeting Moldova. The sanctions froze assets and property interests of nine individuals and twelve entities. Sanctioned individuals included the Moldavian populist leader Ilan Shor, who, according to the Treasury Department, collaborated with Russia ahead of the 2021 Moldovan elections, aiming to control the parliament and support legislation favorable to Russia. Another sanctioned individual was Vladimir Plahotniuc, a former Moldovan member of parliament who directed law enforcement to investigate political opponents ahead of 2018 elections. A company called the National Engineering Corporation (NIK) was also sanctioned. Igor Yuryevich Chayka, a son of a member of Russia’s Security Council, invested millions of dollars to set up NIK, which seemingly operated as an engineering firm for Russian business technology projects.  

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: US sanctions Russian organizations and individuals for malign influence campaigns targeting Moldova

incidents.content: In November 2022, Moldovan officials said Russian state-linked hackers were behind a website called “Moldova Leaks,” which published Telegram conversations of Sergiu Litvinenco, Moldova's Minister of Justice, and Dorin Recean, the Defense and National Security Advisor to the President. Moldova's pro-Russian opposition spread allegations based on the leaks, arguing that the messages proved corruption and vote rigging. Additional leaks targeted anti-corruption officials. The Moldovan Justice Ministry stated that the leaked data was stolen and that some of it has been manipulated. Moldovan officials called the operation a part of Russia's “hybrid war to destabilize the pro-European government.” Several experts allege that this is the work of Russia’s military intelligence service.
incidents.title: Russian hack-and-leak operation targets Moldovan officials

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Russian state gas company Gazprom increased the price and limited the supply of gas shipped to Moldova to pressure the former Soviet republic into distancing itself from the European Union, the Financial Times reports. Gazprom raised the cost of gas deliveries to Moldova from $550 to $790 per cubic meters, while cutting its gas supply by one-third, after the two parties’ contract expired in September 2021. Gazprom told Moldovan officials that gas prices would be lowered if the country amended its tariff-free trade deal with the EU and delayed the implementation of EU rules that would increase competition in the gas market. Moldova declared a state of emergency in October, and the European Union’s top diplomat Josep Borrell accused Russia of weaponizing its gas supply. On October 28, Gazprom and Moldova announced a five-year deal that will provide the country with gas at almost half of the current market price. Moldovan President Maia Sandu subsequently declared the end of her country’s energy crisis.  

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia attempts to use gas supply to gain concessions from Moldova

incidents.content: An investigation conducted by the Dossier Center and Rise Moldova detailed how Russian advisers with close ties to the Kremlin were working with pro-Russian Igor Dodon in his reelection campaign. The advisors worked at the the headquarters of Moldova's Socialist Party (PSRM) and at the presidency. The investigation also implicates Igor Dodon and his inner circle in connection to the Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) of the Russian Federation. The report claims that the SVR has considerable influence over Moldovan foreign policy.
incidents.title: Russian Advisers ‘Working for Moldovan President’s Re-Election Campaign’

incidents.content: According to Balkan Insight, on August 3, 2017, Russia banned the import of Moldovan plums in response to Moldova’s August 2 decision to declare Russian Deputy Prime Minister and Special Representative to Transnistria Dmitry Rogozin persona non grata. The Moldovan government reportedly labeled Rogozin, who was known for his inflammatory remarks targeted at the Moldovan government, persona non grata for “brutal interference in the domestic affairs of our state.” Russia continues to support Transnistrian separatists despite Moldovan claims that Russian involvement violates Moldovan sovereignty. According to the Irish Times, Russian officials deemed the Moldovan declaration "provocations."
incidents.title: Russia bans Moldovan plums after Moldova labels Russian Deputy Prime Minister persona non grata

incidents.content: On March 15, 2017, Moldova’s Deputy General Prosecutor and his staff told Reuters that Russian officials harassed them in an effort to derail an investigation into potential Russian money laundering activities in Moldova. The Moldovan officials said that Moldovan intelligence had determined that Russian intelligence officers (FSB) and Russian businessmen managed the global money laundering scheme known as the Russian Laundromat, which laundered an estimated $20 billion from Russia via banks in Moldova and Latvia. The Russian government denied harassing Moldova’s Deputy General Prosecutor and his staff.
incidents.title: Russian authorities harass Moldovan officials in an attempt to derail money laundering probe
