On February 10, 2017, Moldova’s Audiovisual Coordinating Council (CCA) fined NTV Moldova, a regional office of Russian state-sponsored media outlet NTV, for broadcasting disinformation targeting Moldovan pro-Western presidential candidate Maia Sandu. The CCA cited programs in which NTV Moldova, and another channel titled Accent TV, misrepresented Sandu as a Western puppet and an enemy of the church. The channels also ran several stories claiming that Sandu had promised Western leaders that Moldova would welcome a large influx of Syrian refugees. The two channels are owned by pro-Russian Socialist Party MP Corneliu Furculi??. According to Moldovan media, Furculita has been linked to mysterious Russian off-shore accounts. A 2016 investigative report by RISE Moldova, alleged that Furculita acted as an intermediary between Russian financiers and the Socialist Party of Moldova.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored TV channel affiliate fined for disinformation about pro-Western Moldovan presidential candidate

incidents.content: On September 28, 2016, journalists from RISE Moldova released an investigative report connecting Moldovan Socialist Party MP and media mogul, Corneliu Furculi??, to the transfer of a $1.5 million loan from a Russian offshore company to the pro-Russian Socialist Party in the run up to the 2016 Moldovan presidential election. In the report, RISE journalists said Westerby Ltd, a Russian shell company located in the Bahamas, sent 30 million lei to Farculita’s media company, Exclusiv Media. Exclusiv Media then sent the money to Socialist Party MPs. The loan agreement states it follows all the rules of the Russian Federation, but the loan is from a Bahamas-registered firm transferred from its Swiss account.
incidents.title: Moldovan MP funnels money from Russian offshore accounts to finance campaign

incidents.content: From 2012 to 2013, offshore companies and individuals linked to Moldovan businessman Ilan Shor took control of Moldovan banks Banca de Economii, Banca Sociala, and Unibank. In November 2014, these banks then lent about $1 billion – about 15% of Moldovan GDP – to Shor-linked companies in Britain and Hong Kong. When the government bailed out the banks, the Moldovan currency (lei) and economy were devastated. According to a confidential report from U.S. investigative firm Kroll, the loans were “‘enabled by deposits from external financial institutions, including [three Russian banks] Gazprombank, Interprombank, and Alef Bank.’” Shor was arrested in 2015 for money laundering and embezzlement, although he was released from house arrest in June to compete in Orhei’s mayoral elections, which he won. Massive protests erupted, and the EU, IMF, and World Bank all “[froze] their financial assistance to Moldova.” On October 19, 2015, Moldova’s central bank revoked the banks’ licenses and initiated their liquidation. When the government resigned under pressure from protesters, “Pro-Kremlin parties rushed to exploit the crisis.” Further investigation revealed that some of Shor’s shell companies were also involved in the $20.8 billion money laundering scheme known as the Russian Laundromat.
incidents.title: Ilan Shor uses  shell companies to drain three Moldovan banks of $1 billion

incidents.content: On August 31, 2014, Russia suspended its duty-free trade policy with Moldova, adopted when the two countries signed the Russia-Moldova CIS Free Trade Agreement in October 2011. The Russian government did not provide an official justification for the decision, though it came in the months following the conclusion of Moldova’s Association Agreement with the European Union. In July 2014, Russia banned the import of Moldovan meats and fruits, likely in response to the Association Agreement as well.
incidents.title: Russia suspends its tariff-free trade preferences with Moldova for political purposes

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On December 8, 2023, the Estonian Interior Minister Lauri Laanemets and his wife found out that their car had been vandalized. A few hours later, the Estonian Internal Security Service (KAPO) arrested Allan Hantsom, a pro-Russian activist living in Estonia, over the incident. KAPO found that Hantsom was part of a long chain of command, which eventually traced back to the GRU, Russia’s military intelligence agency. He also belonged to a political party in Estonia that supported Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and was a contributor on Kremlin-sponsored propaganda outlet Sputnik Estonia. Estonian security services found a list of targets that included prominent politicians and journalists who had exposed Kremlin propaganda on the war in Ukraine with Estonia’s Russian-speaking population. KAPO also arrested many more vandals tied to organized crime who did not know that the GRU was their ultimate sponsor.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia behind vandalism campaign in Estonia

incidents.content: In April 2023, a consortium of European media outlets, together with the “Dossier Center,” reported on a 2021 strategic paper by the Kremlin that outlined the “Strategic Goals of the Russian Federation in the Estonian, Latvian, and Lithuanian Directions”. (Disclosure: The Dossier Center is an NGO funded by leading Russian opposition figure Mikhail Khodorkovsky.) The strategic paper was drafted by the Russian Presidential Administration’s Directorate for Cross-Border Cooperation, a body staffed by Russian intelligence officers from the FSB (State Security), SVR (Foreign Intelligence Service) and GRU (Military Intelligence Service), and presented Moscow’s long-term strategy to exert influence over the politics of the three Baltic states. The strategy included the cultivation of local businessmen to advocate for pro-Russian policies, attempts to weaponize legacy energy arrangements dating back from the USSR, as well as information manipulation campaigns to strengthen anti-NATO and anti-EU sentiment.
incidents.title: Kremlin strategic document aims to influence Baltic states

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Published in February 2022, the Estonian Foreign Intelligence Service’s annual report highlighted the Chinese Embassy in Tallinn’s collection of Estonian citizen’s personal email addresses to be used “when it deems necessary.” According to the report, the embassy emailed unsolicited Chinese propaganda from China Watch — a think tank and publication underwritten by China Daily and financed by the Chinese Communist Party — to private citizens. Following the report’s publication, the embassy issued a condemnation describing it as “cold war mentality” that “maliciously speculates on China's goodwill and is completely irresponsible.”

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese embassy collected Estonian citizens’ personal emails, sent unsolicited propaganda

incidents.content: In the fall of 2019, partly in response to the objections raised by U.S. and European security officials, Estonia looked set to ban Huawei from participating in its 5G rollout over surveillance, sabotage, and privacy risks. In response to these plans, Huawei employed a PR firm counting multiple former Estonian ministers among its members, raising additional concerns about indirect influence. Media reports suggest that the former ministers brokered numerous meetings between Huawei and current lawmakers or officials in an effort to reverse the planned regulation, though, in the absence of any lobbying regulation in Estonia, what was discussed in those meetings and who attended them was not logged in any official record. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Huawei conducts opaque lobbying with Estonian government to reverse 5G ban

incidents.content: A Chinese proposal to fund and build a massive undersea rail tunnel between Tallinn, Estonia and Helsinki, Finland has been shelved after the Estonian government raised concerns. Contracts would have been awarded to state-linked firms including China Railway International Group, China Railway Engineering Company, and the China Communications Construction Company, but a July 31, 2020 statement from Estonian Minister of Public Administration Jaak Aab mentioned "environmental, economic, and security reasons" to doubt the project's viability. Among the government's expressed concerns included additional costs for "developing and maintaining national defense capabilities," likely relating to securing transit access in any crisis. More broadly, however, the government appears wary of having an important piece of the country's infrastructure dependent on Chinese financing. A Chinese-owned company, Touchstone Capital Partners, had nominally pledged up to 15 billion euros for the tunnel project in partnership with Finnish private company FinEst Bay Area Development, but a UK report in 2019 found that Touchstone only had assets of £1. The planned tunnel, some 100km in length, potentially would have formed a portion of China's Belt and Road Initiative, especially if it could eventually link to other projects in the Arctic or the Balkans. An Estonian think tank report raised concerns of the project inviting more Chinese political and strategic presence in the country, potentially blurring economic and military aims with dual-use investments.
incidents.title: Estonia rejects China's proposed support for Tallinn-Helsinki tunnel over security and economic concerns

incidents.content: In April 2017, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Baltnews circulated a narrative that NATO forces were seeking Russian speaking volunteers to function as test subjects for a hybrid warfare experiment during the Summer Shield XVI military exercises. Russian Lieutenant General Yuri Netkachev, who has commanded forces in Transnistria and the Caucasus, claimed that Russian speakers would be the subjects of physical, biological, and psychological experiments by NATO forces. Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik declared Summer Shield XVI to be a propaganda tool in order to build anti-Russian sentiment. NATO StratCom reports that Summer Shield XVI was a major focus of Russian-language bots on social media. According to an investigation by Re:Baltica, despite trying to hide its origins, Baltnews is "funded and directed" by Russian state-sponsored multimedia conglomerate Rossiya Segodnya.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet Baltnews spreads anti-NATO disinformation

incidents.content: In September 2016, the Russian government's Fund for the Legal Protection and Support of Russian Federation Compatriots Living Abroad paid representatives from Estonian NGOs to criticize the Estonian government’s treatment of ethnic Russians residing in Estonia at an annual meeting organized by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE). According to the Estonian Internal Security Service, the two organizations in question - the Legal Information Centre for Human Rights and the Russian School in Estonia - submitted statements which “painted a picture of Estonia that completely met the expectation of the sponsor – Estonia violates the rights of Russian children to be educated in their mother tongue and has a 'massive' issue with people without citizenship, and so on.”
incidents.title: Russian government-connected fund supports pro-Russian NGOs in Estonia in order to promote messaging critical of the Estonian government

incidents.content: In 2016, according to Estonia's Internal Security Service (ISS), the Russian government sent Russian resident Aleksei Maksimov to Estonia to masquerade as a local Nazi enthusiast at an event commemorating Estonian veterans who fought against Nazi Germany. Estonia’s intelligence service KAPO reported that Maksimov protested in front of waiting Russian film crews so that pro-Russian media could stage reports of a growing Estonian fascist movement.
incidents.title: Russia government plants fake protester in Estonia to stage story on fascist protest

incidents.content: Around the end of 2015, suspected Russian state-backed hackers targeted energy grids in Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania with cyber operations. The hackers used Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks to disrupt the operations of an Internet gateway controlling a Baltic electricity grid, network communication devices, and a Baltic petrol-distribution system. The attacks caused disruptions but no energy outages. As reported by Reuters, "Interviews with more than a dozen law-enforcement and private investigators, insiders and utility officials show hackers have quietly made incursions into Baltic networks ... They say Russian state organizations are suspected of being behind the campaigns."
incidents.title: Russia suspected in cyberattacks on Baltic energy grids

incidents.content: From 2012-2015, the Russian government's Fund for the Legal Protection and Support of Russian Federation Compatriots Living Abroad provided 710,000 euros to NGOs in Estonia. According to Re:Baltica, the largest recipient of grant money was the Legal Information Centre for Human Rights, which Estonian security services describe as a "Russian agent." The second largest recipient of grant funding was Andrey Zarenkov, a pro-Russian activist who publishes a magazine distributed by the Russian embassy. Additionally the fund also contributes monetary support to Altmedia, a media organization which the Estonian security service (KAPO) alleges is controlled by actors related to Russia’s state-sponsored media giant Rossiya Segodnya. According to Re:Baltica, the funding is intended to support "key executors of the Russian foreign policy" in Estonia to "influence the public debate and the society" toward Russian interests.
incidents.title: Russian government-linked fund provides support to NGOs to spread pro-Russian narratives

incidents.content: A 2011 meeting between Estonian president Toomas Ilves and exiled Tibetan leader the Dalai Lama caused China to retaliate against a trade delegation and Estonian exports while criticizing the event to local media. A statement from the Chinese embassy requested that Estonia "stop interfering in China's internal affairs," and that Estonia's actions "seriously violate the basic principles of international relations," among other critiques. After the meeting occurred, China halted a planned visit from Estonian Agriculture Minister Helir-Valdor Seeder, and effectively cut off access to Chinese markets for Estonian dairy exporters, an industry exporting more than 200 million euros of products annually. Minister for Foreign Trade and Entrepreneurship Anne Sulling acknowledged the connection, admitting that "we have not been successful in the Chinese market since the Estonian officials welcomed the Dalai Lama here." Estonian milk producers did not receive full access until 2016, though higher-level diplomatic relations normalized in 2014.
incidents.title: China retaliates against Estonia after Estonian officials meet with Dalai Lama

incidents.content: In spring 2010, declassified documents from Estonia's counterintelligence agency KAPO exposed that Russian government-connected oligarch Vladimir Yakunin promised to finance Tallinn Mayor and Chairman of the Centre Party Edgar Savisaar. According to news outlet ERR, the deal included "1.5 million euros to support his political party in Estonia's parliamentary elections." Savisaar's party signed a cooperation agreement with United Russia in 2004 and has publicly supported the Russian annexation of Crimea. The U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned Vladimir Yakunin in 2014 for “involvement in the situation in Ukraine” due to his position as a high-ranking government official and as a member of Russian President Vladimir Putin’s inner circle. The U.S. Treasury Department described Yakunin as a "close confidant" of Vladimir Putin.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected oligarch Vladimir Yakunin finances pro-Russian Estonian political party

incidents.content: In May 2007, following the relocation of the controversial Soviet "Bronze Soldier" war memorial from Tallinn’s city center, Russian state-controlled company Russian Railways stopped deliveries of Russian crude oil and gas to Estonia, citing planned track repairs. Russian transit good deliveries to Estonia decreased by 60 percent, temporarily damaging Estonia’s economy.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Russian Railways halts deliveries of gas and goods

incidents.content: In 2007, according to the Carnegie Endowment, Russia-aligned hackers launched a coordinated, large-scale Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) cyberattack against Estonia in response to the Estonian government’s decision to relocate a Soviet war memorial known as the Bronze Soldier from the center of Tallinn. The cyberattack targeted Estonian media websites, banks, telecommunications infrastructure, and government agencies for a period of three weeks. Botnets accompanied the attack with waves of spam and automated online requests designed to crash servers. In addition to the cyberattack, the Russian government directed a smear campaign at the Estonian government, likening the Estonian government’s decision to remove the Soviet-era statue to glorifying Nazism.
incidents.title: Russia-aligned hackers launch "Bronze Soldier" DDoS attack

incidents.content: As part of an ongoing investigation, Estonian Finance Minister Martin Helme revealed that Russia's security services had moved money through his country to finance intelligence operations overseas. Helme also indicated that Estonian authorities are investigating whether individuals sanctioned by the U.S. had moved money through Estonia, where the Danske Bank money laundering operation transferred $220 billion in suspect transactions between 2007 and 2015.
incidents.title: Russian security services and sanctioned entities used Estonia as a transit point for money laundering and funding intelligence operations overseas.

incidents.content: On February 13, 2024, Spanish authorities found Maksim Kuzminov dead with six bullet wounds in the parking garage of this apartment complex in the Spanish town of Villajoyosa. Kuzminov, a Russian helicopter pilot, defected to Ukraine in 2023 and had been living in Spain under the name of Ihor Schevchenko. He had started communications with Ukrainian intelligence regarding his anticipated defection around a year after the Russian invasion of Ukraine began. On August 9, 2023, Kuzminov flew his Mi-8 transport helicopter towards the Ukrainian border, where he defected. Ukrainian authorities paid him USD $500,000 for defecting. Although Spain’s Civil Guard never officially confirmed that the body found in Villajoyosa was Kuzimov’s, they identified a Russian former KGB officer a Russian police colonel present in the country at the time of the killing as “persons of interest” in the case. Spanish media reported at the time of the killing that Spanish intelligence thought that the Kremlin was behind the assassination.
incidents.title: Spain accuses Russia of gunning down defector

incidents.content: Between March 2019 and February 2020, Josep Lluis Alay, a senior advisor to former Catalan President Carles Puigdemont, travelled to Moscow three times to meet with several people connected to the Russian government and intelligence community. According to a European intelligence report reviewed by the New York Times, the aim of these meetings was to secure the Kremlin’s support for the independence movement in Catalonia. Both Alay and Puigdemont confirmed that the trips occurred. In March 2019, accompanied by Alexander Dmitrenko, who was refused Spanish citizenship due to his ties to Russian intelligence, Alya met Sergei Sumin, a colonel of Putin's personal security detail. Alay also met Edvard Chesnokov, deputy editor of the international section of Komsomolskaya Pravda, Russia's second largest daily newspaper who Spanish outlet El Confidencial describes as “a key player in the Kremlin's propaganda during the invasion of Ukraine”. In June 2019, Alay and Dmitrenko met with Andrei Bezrukov, a former officer of the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Alay also met with Evgeni Primakov, a former member of the State Duma for Putin’s party and the grandson of a former head of the SVR. In June 2020, Primakov was appointed by Putin as head of Rossotrudnichestvo, a government agency under Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov tied to Russia's global influence campaigns. In the months that followed, Puigdemont was interviewed by state media outlets Russia 24, Russia Today, and Sputnik. According to El Confidencial, Alay also met with Arkady Seregin, an advisor to the Russian Ministry of Energy linked to the SVR.
incidents.title: Catalonian independentist leader meets Kremlin allies in Moscow

incidents.content: On April 27, 2023, Spain’s Minister of Foreign Affairs, Jose Manuel Albares Bueno, summoned Russian Ambassador Yuri Klimenko regarding a video released from the Russian Embassy’s official X account (formerly known as Twitter). The video showed two soldiers speaking in Spanish in Ukraine next to statements by Spain’s Minister of Defense denying the presence of Spanish troops in the country. The Spanish military has no formal presence in Ukraine and the soldiers were likely from the International Legion, a unit of volunteers from around the world who fight under the supervision of Ukrainian intelligence. Published just days after the new ambassador had presented his credentials to the Spanish King, the video was promptly removed before Klimenko’s meeting at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
incidents.title: Spain Summons Russian Ambassador Over Video Alleging Spanish Troops in Ukraine

incidents.content: In 2017, right before the independence referendum, a group identifying themselves as envoys of the Russian government met with Catalonian independence leaders, including former Catalonia President Carles Puigdemont. The Russians reportedly offered $500 billion and 10,000 armed soldiers to facilitate Catalonia’s bid for independence in exchange for favorable cryptocurrency legislation. According to Christopher Nehring, a lecturer in intelligence history at the University of Potsdam, the proposal combined “a covert, intelligence-backed support for a separatist movement with a scam or fraud component on the side”. A member of this group, Nikolai Sadovnikov, was flagged by a Western intelligence agency as having a direct line to Vladimir Putin. A 2012 report from that agency assessed as a “credible hypothesis” that Sadovnikov worked for Russian intelligence agent. In 2020, a Spanish judge investigating the diversion of public funds for the independence movement confirmed that a Russian offer was indeed made to Puigdemont, but that the Catalonian leader had rejected it.
incidents.title: Russia-affiliated envoys offer to assist Catalonian independentists

On September 18, 2020, Spanish newspaper El Pais reported that Chinese hackers had stolen information from research centers working on a Covid-19 vaccine. The head of Spain’s National Intelligence Center said that “sensitive sectors such as health and pharmaceutics” had been targeted, and that there has been “a particularly virulent campaign, and not just in Spain, against laboratories working on a vaccine for Covid-19.” Sources interviewed by the newspaper explained that Chinese and Russian state agencies were behind a wave of cyberattacks targeting research institutions globally but that the cyberattacks aimed at Spain came from China.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese hackers target Spanish Covid-19 vaccine research

incidents.content: The Spanish Foreign Ministry admitted in 2018 that it had long suspected Russian interference in the 2016-present unrest around Catalonian independence, and had received information from British and U.S. intelligence services that Russia had committed various destabilization operations across Europe, which in Spain focused on Catalonia. In December 2019 investigation by Bellingcat revealed that Denis Sergeev, Alexey Kalinin, and Mikhail Opryshko, suspected members of the GRU’s elite Unit 29155, had traveled to Barcelona at various times during the unrest. There is currently a sealed investigation by the Spanish High Court into Unit 29155’s operations in Spain. The Kremlin has denied any involvement and accused Spanish media of perpetrating an “anti-Russia campaign.”
incidents.title: Members of elite GRU unit found to have traveled to Catalonia during independence referendum unrest in 2016-17.

incidents.content: Between September 29 and October 5, 2017, in advance of the Catalan independence referendum, social media accounts traced to Russia and Venezuela spread a wealth of disinformation, according to analysis by Javier Lesaca, a visiting scholar at George Washington University. An analysis of more than 5 million messages about Catalonia posted on social networks during this time period showed that 32 percent of the messages investigated came from Venezuela, and 30 percent were born from anonymous accounts "exclusively dedicated" to promoting content from Russian state-sponsored media outlets RT and Sputnik, according to the Daily Beast. Additionally, messages from RT and Sputnik's official social media presence accounted for ten percent of the messages. Articles from RT and Sputnik reportedly sought to inflame tensions and spread exaggerated claims of violence ahead of the referendum.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets and social media accounts spread disinformation ahead of Catalan independence referendum

incidents.content: On September 28, 2016, Russian state-sponsored media outlets reported that Catalonia was planning to recognize the annexed Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea as part of Russia, according to StopFake. StopFake noted that the original Russian report cited the spokesman of a Catalonian party which "is not even in the Catalonian parliament and therefore does not represent any official position."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outelts falsely report that Catalonia plans to recognize Crimea as part of Russia

incidents.content: On December 11, 2014, Russian-state sponsored media outlet Sputnik opened a Spanish-language news service including a website and a radio station. The new multimedia service in Spanish, Sputnik Mundo, integrates its new website, mundo.sputniknews.com, together with the news service Sputnik Novosti and the broadcasts of Radio Sputnik, the subsidiary of the old radio station La Voz de Rusia. According to the Center for European Policy Analysis, the Russian government uses Sputnik "to promote the Kremlin’s chosen messages of disinformation."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik launches Servicio Español Sputnik website

incidents.content: In mid-October 2006, defected Russian intelligence official Alexander Litvinenko was poisoned by drinking tea that was laced with Polonium-20, a radioactive compound. He died on November 23, 2006 as a result of this poisoning. Right before his death, Litvinenko claimed that it was Putin himself who had ordered his assassination. The European Court of Human Rights determined that two Russian intelligence officers, Andrei Lugovoi and Dmitry Kovtun, were responsible for the assassination. British authorities agreed that the Kremlin orchestrated the poisoning and that former head of the FSB, Nikolai Patrushev, had approved the assassination alongside President Putin. The Polonium was traced back to a nuclear reactor in the Urals and went through production in the Russian town of Sarov. From there, an FSB laboratory was able to create a drinkable substance containing the radioactive compound.
incidents.title: Russian intelligence poisons former spy and Kremlin critic in London

incidents.content:

In March 2018, former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia were victims of a nerve agent attack in Salisbury in the United Kingdom. The nerve agent, identified as Novichok, caused significant bodily harm to both Skripal and his daughter, as well as to Detective Sergeant Nick Bailey. The police believed that two Russian nationals going by the aliases Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov were responsible for the Novichok attacks. The men claimed that they were in Salisbury as tourists, but the Bellingcat investigation team produced several in-depth reports tying them conclusively to the GRU, Russian military intelligence. In response to the incident, British Prime Minister Theresa May announced the expulsion of 23 Russian diplomats from the United Kingdom, triggering similar actions from other European allies. In August 2018, the United States imposed its own sanctions on Russia as a result of the Novichok attack.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian agents release nerve agent in Salisbury

In January 2023, a hacking group believed to be affiliated with Russia’s intelligence services stole emails from a member of parliament in the United Kingdom, Stewart McDonald, who has expressed fears that the exfiltrated messages could be publicly released. The hackers accessed McDonald’s messages when he opened an email disguised as a military update about Ukraine from a member of his staff. The National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) was already on alert about the Russian hacking group, which is known as “Seaborgium.” NCSC alleged the group is responsible for a highly targeted campaign against individual politicians, activists, and journalists. Previously, Seaborgium is said to have published hacked emails from former head of MI6 Sir Richard Dearlove and journalist Paul Mason.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Hacking group tied to Russian intelligence stole UK lawmaker’s emails

British news outlet Sky News reported on October 18, 2022 that the Chinese military air force had hired former British army officers to accelerate its pilots and soldiers’ training. On October 21, 2022, French newspaper Le Figaro reported that French instructors had also been retained, in exchange for three-year lucrative contracts of 20,000 euros per month. Sky News alleged that British instructors were more numerous than the French and estimated around 30 Royal Air Force former pilots were involved in trainings provided at the “Test Flying Academy of South Africa”, a company with no connection to the South African government. The objective of the hires was to develop Chinese military air force capabilities, notably their ability to land on aircraft carriers, and to teach pilots how to best counter NATO capabilities. The UK government has since sought to pass legislation to prevent former UK military personnel from getting involved in such contracts with rivals and US authorities are seeking the extradition of a former Marine corps pilot over trainings he provided to Chinese military pilots at the “Academy”.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese air force employed former officers to counter NATO capabilities

On October 16, 2022, Chinese consul-general in Manchester Zheng Xiyuan was filmed assaulting pro-democracy protesters in front of the consulate. Videos posted on social media showed the consul and several men come out of the consulate to pull down banners before dragging a protester on the consulate’s grounds and beating them up. As a result of the outrage that followed the revelations, British authorities summoned China’s charge d’affaires to London, Yang Xiaoguang, for an explanation. The same week, the Manchester consul gave a TV interview in which he justified his actions by saying that it was his “duty” to attack the protester after the man had “abused my country, my leader”. In December 2022, as the Manchester police asked to question six officials, including the consul, over the incident, Chinese authorities moved them out of the United Kingdom.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese consul in Manchester assaults protesters
