A Russian government-linked troll farm is working to build and guide a wider network of online supporters to target international politicians and media outlets with content meant to promote Russian President Vladimir Putin, advance Russia’s narratives around the war in Ukraine, and disparage critics of the Kremlin, according to the UK government. The information operation has links to Yevgeniy Prigozhin, who founded the infamous Internet Research Agency troll farm and has been sanctioned by multiple Western countries. The new troll farm pushes disinformation across eight social media platforms, including Telegram, Twitter, Facebook, and TikTok. Directors of the troll farm called on supporters to target specific Kremlin critics, politicians, and media. They also asked individuals aligned with the information operation to turn on VPNs and flood comment sections rather than post original content in order to make it more difficult for social media platforms to identify their campaign. 

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian troll factory spreads disinformation on social media

incidents.content: On 15 December 2019, China's state broadcaster CCTV removed an Arsenal-Manchester City football match from its schedule after Arsenal player Mesut Özil tweeted in support of Uyghur Muslims in China. Two days before the match, Özil criticized the Chinese government and the silence of the global Muslim community in the face of ongoing human rights abuses in Xinjiang. Chinese state media described Özil’s action as “false” and expressed the “disappointment” of Chinese fans and football authorities. A Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesperson further denounced Ozil, saying he was “deceived by false news reports.” Arsenal rapidly distanced itself from the player, insisting that the tweet constituted Özil’s personal views. For the English Premier League, China had become a major overseas market, with the signature of a three-year TV rights deal worth $700 million in 2019.
incidents.title: Chinese state TV pulls match after football star Mesut Özil criticizes Muslim detention camps

incidents.content: Dmytro Firtash’s companies fund Scythian Ltd., a U.K.-registered corporate entity owned by his man in London, Robert Shetler-Jones. Scythian and Shetler-Jones have made donations to the Conservatives central office, Pauline Neville-Jones (payments that were reportedly presented by MI5 as evidence of why she should not be appointed National Security Advisor), and MP Robert Halfon. Richard Spring, a Conservative MP who is known as Lord Risby and chairs the Firtash-funded British Ukrainian Society, has accepted advisory fees from a Cyprus company called Spadi Trading Ltd., which is owned by a British Virgin Islands entity called Interbean Ltd., which in turn is controlled by Shetler-Jones. Firtash is acknowledged by the United States to have connections to Russian organized crime, as well as to the Russian government and the pro-Russian former president of Ukraine, Viktor Yanukovych.
incidents.title: Ukrainian oligarch funds British shell companies that donate to a handful of Conservative Party politicians.

incidents.content: Aquind Ltd is a U.K.-registered company seeking to build a controversial £1.2 billion undersea electricity grid connector between Britain and France. Its three named directors are Richard Glasspool (former partner at KPMG Russia and former executive at a Russian bank run by Putin-friendly oligarch Roman Avdeev), Kirill Glukhovskoy (former senior lawyer with major Russian energy companies), and oligarch Alexander Temerko (former Russian arms tycoon who supported his “friend” Boris Johnson’s campaign to take Britain out of the E.U. and is reportedly one of nine donors named in the ISC Russia report). It emerged in 2020 that a still-unidentified fourth backer with control over Aquind had been granted anonymity by Companies House under a rare exemption for people who could be at risk of “serious violence or intimidation” should their name become public. Luxembourg public records related to Aquind’s holding company revealed that the secret beneficial owner is Viktor Fedotov, a Russian-born tycoon, who U.K. security and law enforcement agencies say is not genuinely at risk of violence or intimidation. Aquind has given £242,000 to the U.K. Conservative Party since 2018, including £8,000 to John Whittingdale (Boris Johnson’s minister responsible for defending Britain from disinformation) and £5,000 donation from Mark Pritchard (an MP who sits on the ISC). It has also employed multiple British lords as directors or paid advisers.
incidents.title: Former Russian arms tycoon and other wealthy Russians donate to U.K. Conservative Party through an obscure energy company.

incidents.content: Huawei and London School of Economic (LSE) are in talks to begin a three-year study into the technology company's "leadership" in 5G development. The project, funded by Huawei's £105,000 donation, is a proposed "three year consultancy" intended "to provide a comprehensive study on how Huawei has internally supported innovation and product development in the past 20 years," according to internal documents obtained by OpenDemocracy. LSE's ethics committee approved the project, despite concerns from academics over Huawei's links to the Chinese state. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: LSE under scrutiny over proposed program financed by Huawei

incidents.content: Professor Stephen Tsang, of SOAS University London, testified in a report commissioned by Parliament that he knew of an instance where a university pro-vice chancellor "was spoken to by someone in the Chinese embassy and as a result he stood a speaker who was already invited down", and that he was also aware of "a vice-chancellor again under pressure from the Chinese embassy asking one of his senior academics not to make political comments on China at a specified period of time". Tsang's testimony, which does not specify the names of the universities nor of those involved, comes amidst increased government concern about Chinese Communist Party interference in British academia. The Parliamentary report states that the Foreign Affairs committee heard "alarming evidence" about the degree of CCP interference in UK universities.
incidents.title: UK professor testifies to Parliament on pressuring of university academics by Chinese state officials

incidents.content: Professor Christopher Hughes of the London School of Economics told Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee he was aware of "Confucius Institute officials confiscating papers which mention Taiwan at an academic conference". Hughes stated that a Beijing official seized papers and brochures in order to remove the pages that mentioned Taiwan at the European Association of Chinese Studies' biannual conference in Portugal. The testimony was one of many published in a report commissioned by Parliament to explore reported Chinese government interference in British academia.
incidents.title: London School of Economics professor testimony to Parliament details confiscation of papers by Confucius Institute officials at academic conference

incidents.content: In May 2020, British regulator Ofcom ruled that CGTN had breached its impartiality rules when covering the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. The regulator stated that the Chinese network was guilty of a "serious failure of compliance" for which Ofcom was "minded to consider these breaches for the imposition of a statutory sanction."
incidents.title: British regulator finds CGTN's coverage of Hong Kong protests biased

incidents.content: Following a complaint made by British citizen Peter Humphrey that "CCTV had collaborated with police to extract, record and broadcast a confession" before his trial in China, British regulator Ofcom launched a formal investigation into whether CGTN, the international news channel of CCTV, had aired that confession. In July 2020, Ofcom ruled that CGTN aired forced confessions, as a result of which the channel faces statutory sanctions.
incidents.title: British regulator finds CGTN guilty of airing forced confessions

incidents.content: In December 2018 and January 2019, Russian state-sponsored media outlets Sputnik and RT disseminated documents hacked from a British think tank in dozens of online articles.  The think tank, the Integrity Initiative, works to identify Russian government influence campaigns. According to BuzzFeed News, hackers breached the Integrity Initiative's servers some time in 2018.  Tranches of the stolen documents appeared on hacktivist website CyberGuerilla in four separate releases from November 2018 through January 2019.   Russian state-sponsored media amplified the hacked materials, including screenshots and quotes of sensitive internal documents, in an attempt to discredit the think tank and undermine its work in exposing Russian interference efforts. In response, the Integrity Initiative temporarily moved its public materials offline, replacing its website with a description of the hack that indicated that some disseminated documents had been doctored.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets publish and amplify stolen documents in attempt to discredit British think tank

incidents.content: Since July 2018, according to experts at the Henry Jackson Society (HJS), entities operating through a Turkish server farm with ties to Russia's military intelligence agency (GRU) targeted the think tank with more than 2,400 unsuccessful hacking attempts. According to the Daily Express, HJS is known for its "scepticism towards Vladimir Putin" and its cooperation with other prominent critics of the Kremlin, including Marina Litvinenko, Bill Browder, and Vladimir Kara-Murza. Hackers also targeted the email account of Dr. Andrew Foxall, the director of the Russia and Eurasia Studies Centre at HJS.
incidents.title: Cyber Operations potentially linked to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers target U.K. think tank with repeated hacking attempts

incidents.content: On June 10, 2018, The Times of London reported on British businessman and Brexit supporter Arron Banks' undisclosed meetings with Russian officials, including the Russian ambassador to the United Kingdom, who offered him investment opportunities. Banks, the largest funder of the Leave.EU campaign, was placed under investigation by the British Electoral Commission, which found that Banks' loans to Leave.EU had been misreported. According to emails cited by the press, before the Brexit referendum, "Banks was offered the chance to invest in several Russian businesses," including gold mines and a Russian state-owned diamond mining firm. On November 11, 2018, The Guardian reported that Banks’ insurance company and Leave.EU were fined £60,000 for “serious breaches of the law that governs electronic marketing.”
incidents.title: News reports reveal contacts between Russian officials and major pro-Brexit donor

incidents.content: Following the poisoning of former Russian intelligence officer Sergei Skripal and his daughter in March 2018, the Russian government and its state-sponsored media outlets have attempted to sow doubt and suspicion of the British government’s explanation of the event. The New York Times writes that "English-language Russian outlets flooded social media with more than a dozen alternative theories," from a British false-flag attack to an inside job. According to a report by the Atlantic Council, these unfounded narratives may have paid off, as "four of the six most-shared English-language articles on the case came from Kremlin media outlets." Additionally, the Alliance for Securing Democracy reported in June 2018 that Russian state-sponsored media outlets successfully dominated the search results for Google queries related to the poisoning.
incidents.title: Russian disinformation seeds doubt over the poisoning of Sergei Skripal

incidents.content: On November 20, 2017, The Times reported that "almost 400,000 Twitter messages about Scottish independence were posted by fake accounts, most believed to be Russian." Moreover, these accounts' activity "coincided with major Scottish events," including the proposed second Scottish independence referendum. Of the nearly 400,000 tweets, nearly all of them were pro-independence. On December 13, the Atlantic Council’s Ben Nimmo similarly reported that "pro-Russian internet trolls" that operated with behavior consistent with the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency conducted a disinformation campaign after the Scottish referendum. Nimmo claimed that the trolls utilized Twitter, YouTube, and Facebook accounts to claim that the election was manipulated. Nimmo stated that "'the allegations of fraud demonstrably had an impact; pro-Kremlin accounts demonstrably boosted those allegations. The anger and disappointment felt by many yes voters were entirely sincere [and] those sentiments were fanned by pro-Kremlin trolls, in a manner characteristic of Russian influence operations.'"
incidents.title: Research suggests Russian government-connected bots and trolls sought to sway Scotland referendum

incidents.content: Cambridge University Press (CUP) removed approximately 300 articles deemed politically sensitive by the Chinese Communist Party to ensure that other academic materials remained accessible to researchers and academics in China. The blocked articles, all published in Chinese-studies journal China Quarterly, focused primarily on topics such as the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong and cultural tension in Tibet and Xinjiang. In a statement from CUP, the publisher announced that the removal came after it "received instruction from a Chinese import agency to block individual articles," and that it had been "troubled by the recent increase in requests of this nature" from Beijing. The articles have since been restored following fierce global backlash from academics.
incidents.title: Cambridge University Press restricts access to China Quarterly articles at behest of CCP

incidents.content: During May 2016, British energy companies and other critical infrastructure were targeted, reportedly by hackers with the Russian military intelligency agency (GRU). The attack targeted energy networks running the national grid in the Republic of Ireland, which also covers Northern Ireland. Security analysts believe the hackers intended to access control systems using a massive spear phishing operation. Emails disguised as job applications and complaints were sent to engineers who had access to the control systems. While no disruption was caused, according to British media, "a number of Industrial Control System engineering and services organisations are likely to have been compromised."
incidents.title: Russian GRU-connected hackers target British critical energy infrastructure

incidents.content: On June 8, 2017, the same day as the United Kingdom's post-Brexit snap elections, hackers suspected to be working on behalf of the Russian government targeted energy companies in the United Kingdom, according to the Telegraph. The United Kingdom's National Cyber Security Centre warned companies that it had detected "advanced state-sponsored hostile threat actors, who are known to target the energy and manufacturing sectors." Although the report does not name the state responsible, the Telegraph reported that experts believe the Russian government was behind the attack.
incidents.title: Hacking attempts target U.K. energy companies on the same day as snap elections

incidents.content: The Justice Department indicted four Chinese military-sponsored hackers on charges related to a 2017 cyberattack that scraped the personal data of 150 million customers across the United States and United Kingdom. Personal data belonging to nearly half of the American population, and of approximately 15 million British citizens, were stolen by the group. BBC reported that the Equifax attack is one of many large data breaches in the United States and elsewhere, including those on healthcare providers and government institutions. According to the New York Times, the charges indicated that the Equifax breach was one in a series of data thefts by Chinese intelligence officials.
incidents.title: Chinese state-sponsored hackers indicted for 2017 Equifax cyber-attack targeting Britain and United States

incidents.content: In July 2016, Prime Minister Theresa May postponed final approval of the Hinkley Point C nuclear reactor amidst growing concerns over the Chinese state's financial involvement. State-owned China General Nuclear Power (CGN) holds a 33% stake in the £20bn Hinkley reactor, a project which is a part of a broader UK program aimed at curbing the country's net carbon emissions. According to the Guardian, May decided to delay the signing of a subsidy deal due to the Chinese government's proprietorship of sensitive infrastructure within Britain. Nick Timothy, May's joint chief of staff and aide said that officials were worried that the Chinese government might "use their role to build weaknesses into computer systems, which will allow them to shut down Britain's energy production at will." Nevertheless, days after announcing the review, Downing Street approved continuation of the project with "a new legal framework for future foreign investment in Britain's critical infrastructure." According to the Washington Post, "Hinkley Point may have been too far along in the planning by the time she took office for her to cancel the project."
incidents.title: Rocky development for British nuclear reactor partly funded by Chinese state-owned company

incidents.content: According to a January 2018 U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee minority staff report, in the months leading up to the U.K. Brexit referendum, Russian state-sponsored media outlets RT and Sputnik promoted coverage that was "'systematically'" biased towards the Leave movement. According to Atlantic Council analyst Ben Nimmo, RT and Sputnik used slanted language, quotes, and commentators that favored Brexit. On November 15, 2017, new research from the University of California at Berkeley and Swansea University concluded that Russian bots were active in disseminating pro-leave messages on Twitter in the lead-up to the referendum.
incidents.title: Russia utilizes state-sponsored media outlet and social media disinformation campaigns to promote Leave EU campaigners

incidents.content: Between July and August 2015, officers from Russia's military intelligence agency (GRU) hacked into the email accounts of UK TV station Islam Channel's executives, stealing information and eventually seizing control of the outlet's entire IT infrastructure. The station is marketed to the UK's Muslim population and also reportedly reaches a significant audience in Russia and Central Asia. The UK Government's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) exposed the operation in an October 2018 report providing evidence of four Russian government Cyber Operations against targets in the United Kingdom, the United States, and Ukraine. The NCSC assessed with "high confidence" that GRU officers were behind the attacks, and that the actors likely belonged to the same group as the suspects in the March 2018 Salisbury chemical attack.  According to the NCSC, the hackers deployed phishing campaigns and ransomware attacks, among other tactics. The hackers' motivation for targeting Islam Channel remains unclear, although experts theorize the attack may have been a training exercise or part of a larger campaign to infiltrate European media organizations in 2015.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence officers target UK-based Islam Channel with Cyber Operations

incidents.content: On September 17, 2014, Russia sent election observers to the United Kingdom in order to observe the Scottish Independence Referendum. According to the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project, “Reporters found that the Russian election observers were far from objective, and that Russia had provided a Scottish independence group with legal assistance.” The Russian election observers were part of a non-governmental organization, but they reportedly had contracts with the Russian government. The Russian observers declared the vote “[did] not conform to generally accepted international principles of referendums.” They claimed that ballot boxes were unwatched and polling tables lacked transparency. These allegations were not substantiated by any other observers, but were reiterated Russian media outlets in the aftermath of the referendum.
incidents.title: Russian "election observers" from the Russian Public Institute of Electoral Law cast doubt on validity of Scottish referendum vote

incidents.content: The Chinese embassy allegedly recruited groups of people to drown out anti-CCP protestors in London, who gathered during a visit to the UK by government official Li Keqiang. The protests, attended by practitioners of Falun Gong as well as others, sought to call attention to the Chinese government's human rights record and were countered by dozens of pro-CCP demonstrators organized by Chinese officials. Protestors claimed that the counter-demonstration was the result of the CCP "wanting to stamp out dissent."
incidents.title: Chinese embassy accused of recruiting protestors to counter demonstrations during visit of Chinese state official

incidents.content: In December 2018, the UK government and its allies attributed, "with the highest level of probability", a complex cyber campaign to cyber group APT 10 "acting on behalf of the Chinese Ministry of State Security." The National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) assessed that APT 10 targeted a range of global companies "seeking to gain access to commercial secrets". In addition, NCSC assessed that, since at least 2016, APT10 was behind a cyber-operation known as ‘Cloud Hopper.’ Following a Reuters investigation, the ‘Cloud Hopper’ operation, which was the subject of a U.S. indictment in 2018, hacked into at least eight of the world's biggest technology service providers, such as Hewlett Packard Enterprise and IBM.
incidents.title: British government determines Chinese Ministry of State Security behind cyber-attacks targeting commercial data

incidents.content: The 50-page report on Russian malign activity in Britain was prepared over 18 months by the nation's parliamentary intelligence and security committee with input from the intelligence agencies. The Sunday Times reported that this report on Russian threats posed to U.K. democracy identifies nine oligarchs and other wealthy Tory donors.   Noting that some Russian donors are personally close to Prime Minister Boris Johnson, the Times points to former Russian defense ministry official and arms tycoon Alexander Temerko who has given £1.2 million to the Conservatives since becoming a British citizen in 2011. The Times also identifies "the largest Russian Tory donor" to be Lubov Chernukhin, the wife a former ally of Putin who became a U.K. citizen in or around 2009. The Conservative Party treasurer, Ehud Sheleg, began donating millions to the Tories after his art gallery business struck a deal with a Cypriot company owned by two powerful Russian businessmen in 2015.   In 2016, a Labour MP raised concerns that a £400,000 donation to the Tories came from Gérard Lopez, the chairman of a private investment fund that had recently signed infrastructure deals worth billions with Russia and whose managing partner is understood to be close to Putin.   While these individuals' ties to Russia have been discussed in British media, there is no suggestion that they are among the nine businesspeople reportedly named in the parliamentary report, which Prime Minister Johnson prevented from becoming public before the 2019 general election.
incidents.title: Secret U.K. government report on threats to U.K. democracy names nine Russian businesspeople who donated to the Conservative Party

incidents.content: Dmytro Firtash's companies fund Scythian Ltd., a shell company owned by Robert Shetler-Jones. Robert Shetler-Jones is a U.K. businessman described as "quite clearly Firtash's man in London" or "one of the people closest to Firtash." In 2005, Shetler-Jones lived in Ukraine and told the Kyiv Post "I have met Mr. Firtash on several occasions and we are acquainted." Shetler-Jones's association with Firtash has included working for his companies, claiming to own assets that later turn out to be part of Firtash's business empire, and introducing Firtash to key members of the London establishment. Scythian and Shetler-Jones have made donations to the Conservatives central office, Baroness Pauline Neville-Jones (payments that were reportedly presented by MI5 as evidence of why she shouldn't be appointed National Security Advisor), and MP Robert Halfon. Richard Spring, a Conservative MP who is known as Lord Risby and chairs the Firtash-funded British Ukrainian Society, has accepted advisory fees from a Cyprus company called Spadi Trading Ltd., which is owned by a British Virgin Islands entity called Interbean Ltd., which in turn is controlled by Shetler-Jones. Firtash also uses a network of charitable foundations working alongside his shell companies to buy influence in London. He established and funds the British Ukrainian Society, which employs former U.K. spies and lawmakers and pays for current members of parliament to visit Ukraine and meet associates of Firtash. His company's charitable fund bankrolled an influential London festival focused on Ukraine. And his DF Foundation donated £4.3 million to Cambridge University's Ukraine studies program.
incidents.title: Ukrainian oligarch funds British shell companies that donate to a handful of Conservative Party politicians, with additional support from his foundations and employee in London.

incidents.content: On November 1, 2006, Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian intelligence officer (FSB) living in the United Kingdom fell suddenly ill from polonium-210 poisoning and died three weeks later. On his deathbed, Litvinenko accused President Putin of ordering his assassination. This claim was later corroborated by U.K. and U.S. intelligence services and by a U.K. investigation. Since the assassination, the Russian government and its state-sponsored media outlets have carried out coordinated efforts to deflect blame for Litvinenko’s murder, including suggesting Litvinenko was secretly dealing polonium, claiming Litvinenko poisoned himself, accusing the U.K. government of assassinating Litvinenko, and other widespread efforts to cast doubt on the U.K. investigation. Following the March 2018 Skripal poisoning, Russian state-sponsored media began attempting to pin the murder on Alex Goldfarb, a close friend of Litvinenko, who is currently suing Russian state-sponsored media for libel in U.S. courts.
incidents.title: Russian disinformation campaign seeks to deflect blame for Litvinenko murder

incidents.content: In mid-May 2024, Tibor Eliot Rostas, editor in chief of Zem&Vek (Earth and Age) magazine travelled to China in an attempt to foster ties with the PRC’s propaganda apparatus. Slovak media watchdog Košpirátori.sk ranked Zem&Vek among the least reliable outlets in the country. According to Rostas’ social media channels, he met with the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Wenbin, participated in discussions with state-owned broadcaster CCTV, and was interviewed by the People’s Daily about “conditions in the collapsing European Union”. Visegradinsight reports that Zem&Vek helps improve “visibility of the Chinese embassy in Slovakia” and that, in 2023, the magazine contributed some of the most visible content discussing China in the Slovak language. At the time of his trip, Rostas was also a candidate in the 2024 European Parliament elections where he ran for the far-right Republika party.
incidents.title: Editor of Slovak disinformation outlet travels to Beijing

incidents.content: On June 23, 2018, the Russian government-connected Night Wolves biker gang established a European headquarters in Dolna Krupa, Slovakia, according to Yahoo News. An official from the Russian embassy in Slovakia attended the opening event. According to Slovak security analyst Jaroslav Nad, the headquarters is "almost a military base" for the group, which he describes as a paramilitary group funded by the Russian government. The Slovak foreign ministry called the news "disturbing," and said that the group would need to be "carefully monitored." In 2014, the U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned the Night Wolves due to their support for Russia-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. The Treasury Department described the group as "closely connected to the Russian special services."
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Night Wolves set up European headquarters in Slovakia

incidents.content: On May 24, 2018, the European Commission imposed obligations on Russian energy giant Gazprom for violations of antitrust laws. The Commission found that Gazprom attempted to partition gas markets along national borders in eight different EU member states, including Slovakia. The legally-binding obligations sought to ensure that gas prices remained competitive throughout the European Union in order to prevent Gazprom from leveraging its dominance in the European energy market.
incidents.title: European Commission imposes obligations on Gazprom in response to breaches of antitrust rules in eight member states

incidents.content: On November 21, 2017, EU vs Disinfo reported that the Russian state-sponsored media outlet Zvezda published an article on its website titled: “Czechoslovakia should be grateful to the USSR for 1968: The history of ‘the Prague Spring.’” The article claimed that the Prague Spring was actually a NATO-organized coup d’etat, and that Soviet troops rescued Czechoslovakia. The article was edited and later removed after protests from Czech officials.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet publishes article promoting false history of Prague Spring

incidents.content: In October 2017, Slovak news outlet The Slovak Spectator reported that the Nové Zámky branch of the Sme Rodina political party shared a story on its Facebook page claiming that EU lawyers stated that the Russian annexation of Crimea was legal. Czech fact-checking site manipulatori.cz revealed that the story was based on an analysis authored by a "lobbyist group connected to the Kremlin," rather than that of “EU lawyers”.
incidents.title: Slovak political party spreads propaganda originating from Russian government-linked lobbyist group

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In May 2017, Eerik-Niiles Kross, former head of Estonia's intelligence services, stated that Russian military intelligence officers (GRU) provided training to Slovak paramilitary groups, according to EUobserver. The groups mentioned are the Slovak Conscripts and the Slovak Revival Movement. The Slovak Conscripts are a far-right, pro-Russia paramilitary organization. According to Political Capital, the Slovak Revival Movement is a nationalist, right-wing political movement organization with ties to Russian nationalist and paramilitary organizations.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Slovak paramilitary groups reportedly receive combat training from Russian intelligence officers

incidents.content: In March 2017, the head of Slovakia's largest public news agency, TASR, revealed that the company has a news sharing agreement with major Russian state-sponsored media outlet, TASS. Jaroslav Reznik, the head of TASR, mentioned the agreement while attempting to defend a new agreement with Russian state-sponsored outlet Sputnik. According to the National Endowment for Democracy, "TASR does not noticeably differentiate foreign reports from its own," meaning that "Russian state news can be inadvertently packaged as being from TASR and distributed by Slovak media." Sputnik News Agency signed the agreement to exchange English language content and develop “joint projects aiming to strengthen the relations between Russia and Slovakia.” The National Endowment for Democracy reported that "the pressure from civil society, independent media, and some opposition figures was so strong that TASR cancelled its contract with Sputnik days after its initial announcement."
incidents.title: Slovakia's largest public news agency reveals news-sharing agreements with Russian state-sponsored news outlets TASS and Sputnik

incidents.content: On February 22, 2017, emails revealed that Russian government-connected oligarch Konstantin Malofeyev was funding the efforts of Russian nationalist Alexander Usovsky to organize anti-Western protests in Central and East European countries. According to The New York Times, Usovsky funded political organizations and facilitated media coverage from Russian state-sponsored media outlets for his Slovak affiliates. Malofeyev, who is under EU and U.S. sanctions for support of pro-Russian separatists in Ukraine, allegedly demanded that Usovsky supply “a clear, concrete and realistic plan for the coming to power of pro-Russian forces” to secure further funding.
incidents.title: Emails reveal that Russian government-connected oligarch is indirectly funding anti-Western protests in Central and Eastern Europe

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In July 2015, the Slovak Spectator reported that Slovak paramilitary group Slovenski branci, trained by former Russian Spetsnaz, performs military training and spreads pro-Russia narratives through its 12 branches in Slovakia. Members of Slovenski branci traveled to fight with Russian forces in eastern Ukraine; the group also spreads sentiments against NATO as a “terrorist organization.”

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Members of Slovak paramilitary organization connected with Russian spetsnaz travel to fight in Ukraine

incidents.content: On June 4, 2015, at the initiative of the Russian Embassy in Slovakia, Tibor Rostas and Dušan Budzák, editors of the conspiratorial pro-Russian media outlet "Zem a Vek," traveled to Moscow to meet with the editor and representatives of the "International Life" journal, a publication officially linked to the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Rostas and Budzák proposed the establishment of a pro-Russian media holding in Slovakia to counter pro-U.S. and pro-NATO narratives. Earlier, in May 2015, Rostas and Budzák met with then-Russian Ambassador to Slovakia Pavel Kuznecov to request support.
incidents.title: Slovakian editors of pro-Russian media outlet meet with the editor of a Russian government-linked magazine to discuss establishing a pro-Kremlin media holding in Slovakia

incidents.content: On May 23, 2015, a Russian state-sponsored TV channel broadcasted a documentary detailing the Russian invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. The documentary, titled "Warsaw Pact: Pages Declassified," painted the invasion as a defensive response to NATO aggression. According to European Values think tank, the release deeply angered Czechs and Slovaks who viewed it as an attempt to rewrite history. Both the Czech and Slovak foreign ministries issued complaints about the broadcast.
incidents.title: Russian state media muddy facts about 1968 Russian invasion of Czechoslovakia

incidents.content: In 2019, the Chinese embassy in Slovakia reportedly offered to fund a special, China-focused issue of the journal published by the Slovak Foreign Policy Association, but the association declined amid concerns about editorial independence and risks of censorship. In 2015, the embassy had already contributed funds for a similar issue, but had not made any editorial demands, with several of the 2018 issue's articles addressing issues such as human rights violations in China and Chinese influence in Europe. When the embassy made the 2019 offer, it requested editorial control, and made its grant conditional on the Slovak association ceding that authority. The association then declined the funding to preserve its academic integrity.
incidents.title: Chinese embassy demands editorial control in exchange for funds to Slovak foreign policy journal series

incidents.content: In October 2014, Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom cut natural gas supplies to Slovakia by 50 percent, nominally due to technical issues. Slovak officials believe the reduction was in response to Slovakia assisting Ukraine in building up gas supplies before winter. Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico stated that the Kremlin was "playing with gas supplies as an instrument of political posturing." According to the Congressional Research Service, Slovakia depends on Russia for 98 percent of the natural gas it consumes, accounting for over 27 percent of the country’s primary energy supply. Although a technical issue was used as justification for the cuts, Gazprom has regularly used similar reasons when disrupting energy flows for political purposes.
incidents.title: Russia cuts gas supplies to Slovakia by 50% in response to Slovak assistance to Ukraine

incidents.content: In 2012, Political Capital think tank reported that the Slovak Conscripts, a far-right paramilitary organization, received training from ex-Spetsnaz instructors, and that the group's leader, Peter Švr?ek, received personal training from the ultranationalist Stiag (or flag) paramilitary group and from the Russian Cossacks in 2012. One former member of the Slovak Conscripts, Martin Keprta, left the group to fight in Eastern Ukraine. According to EUObserver, former head of Estonian intelligence Eerik-Niiles Kross alleged in 2017 that the Slovak Conscripts recieved training from Russian military intelligence officers (GRU). The Slovak Conscripts also reportedly maintain connections to the Russian government-connected Night Wolves biker gang. In 2014, the U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned the Night Wolves due to their support for Russia-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. The Treasury Department described the group as "closely connected to the Russian special services."
incidents.title: Slovak paramilitary organization receives training from ex-Spetsnaz instructors

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

During Chinese President Hu Jintao's 2009 visit to Slovakia, a group of pro-CCP protestors clashed with Slovak activists rallying to demand that Slovakia's president raise human rights issues during the bilateral meeting. Reporting suggests that Xingmin Ji, the Vice-President of the Union of Chinese Entrepreneurs in Slovakia, had convened the pro-Chinese group attending the rally, and some accounts even allege that members of Hu's security team were involved in the physical altercations. Multiple people, including a Slovak university rector, human rights activists, and journalists, sustained injuries, and several Chinese nationals were detained by police.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese protestors clash with Slovak human rights activists during Hu Jintao presidential visit

incidents.content: On September 1, 2007, Political Capital think tank reported that the "Private Secondary Professional School for the Protection of Persons and Properties," an accredited secondary school for security professionals in Bratislava, "spreads anti-Western, anti-NATO and pro-Russian views among its students." According to Political Capital, the school's founder, Štefan Kurilla, is a certified Spetsnaz instructor with close ties to Russian intelligence and the school "co-operates with several leading institutions in the security structures of the state" to prepare students for jobs in the police and security services.
incidents.title: Think tank alleges Russian intelligence-connected instructor founded school for Slovak security professionals

incidents.content: On January 17, 2024, a cyberattack temporarily disrupted access to multiple Swiss government websites. The pro-Russian group NoName claimed responsibility for the distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack, initiated in response to Ukrainian President Zelenskiy’s visit to the World Economic Forum taking place at the time of the hacking in Davos, Switzerland. According to Switzerland’s National Cyber Security Center (NCSC), “an attack of this kind had been expected, and appropriate security measures were in place”, which allowed officials to restore the websites in a timely manner.
incidents.title: Swiss government hit by pro-Russian hackers

incidents.content: Switzerland’s most powerful law enforcement and investigatory official, Michael Lauber, resigned amid impeachment proceedings over his mishandling of high-profile corruption and money-launder cases. He held secret, un-minuted meetings with the president of FIFA while leading a what has become a slow and problematic investigation into corruption at FIFA. Lauber’s top Russia expert (“Viktor K”, whose real identity cannot be revealed but has “fluid” links between Swiss federal prosecutors and Russian officials) accepted gifts from Russia, such as a bear hunting trip to Siberia. Russian officials lobbied Swiss prosecutors on sensitive cases such as the Magnitsky affair during a series of off-the-book meetings in expensive restaurants and during elaborate vacations and day-trips. Viktor K told the court the lavish trip could have been funded by one of several Russian oligarchs. A key Russian official on the trip was Putin ally deputy state prosecutor Saak Karapetyan, who died in a helicopter crash in October 2018.
incidents.title: Russia gives lavish gifts to a top Swiss law enforcement official for leniency on cases

incidents.content: The National Security Law was implemented in Hong Kong in June 30, 2020 imposes strict penalties, including seizure of assets, for "secession," "subversion," "terrorism," and "collusion with foreign forces." The law, created after months of intense pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, prompted foreign banks, including Credit Suisse and UBS, to carefully scrutinize clients for links to the Hong Kong democracy movement. Wealth managers in Hong Kong have now been told to look at their customers’ public and social media comments as far back as 2014 to find even moderate support for democracy. The end goal of this exercise would be to designate democracy supporters as "politically exposed persons" (PEPs). The designation, used to prevent money laundering by government officials and politicians, means that activists in Hong Kong may have difficulties accessing banking services or be prevented from doing so entirely.
incidents.title: National security law in Hong Kong prompts banks to scrutinize clients in search of pro-democracy ties

incidents.content: Ten municipalities in Vaud, Switzerland were asked not to participate in Tibetan Uprising Day, an event organized by Swiss Tibetan Friendship Society (GSTF) on March 10th every year. The event commemorates a Tibetan popular uprising in 1959 in which tens of thousands of Tibetans were killed. Swiss municipalities have commemorated the event yearly by raising the Tibetan flag. However, in 2020, the Vaud authorities sent a letter to ten municipalities requesting that they not participate in the demonstration because it violates Switzerland’s One China Policy. In fact, the Chinese ambassador had written to the Vaud government and asked them to stop the demonstration. The GSTF president, Thomas Büchli, stated that such an action from Chinese officials was not unusual, but the response of the Swiss government was. Ralph Weber, an expert in Chinese intervention, stated that this move was common in United Front work. China uses "United Front" work to co-opt and neutralize sources of potential opposition to the policies and authority of its ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP). The CCP’s United Front Work Department (UFWD)—the agency responsible for coordinating these kinds of influence operations—mostly focuses on the management of potential opposition groups inside China, but it also has an important foreign influence mission.
incidents.title: Swiss local government gives in to pressures from Chinese ambassador about Tibet-related anniversary

incidents.content: On July 30, 2018, The Local.ch reported that Russian state-connected hacker group known as Sandworm targeted the Swiss Spiez Laboratory. The Spiez Laboratory analyzed the Novichok nerve agent used in the assassination attempt of former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in the town of Salisbury, U.K. According to the Federal Office for Civil Protection, which oversees the lab, the hack caused limited damage. The targeted lab provides a variety of services to national and international agencies in "implementing and developing arms control and non-proliferation agreements."
incidents.title: Russian state-connected hacker group Sandworm hacks Swiss laboratory analyzing nerve agent used in Skripal attacks

incidents.content: On February 1, 2018, Switzerland’s financial regulator, FINMA, banned Gazprombank Switzerland from taking on new private clients in response to its lack of appropriate anti-money laundering measures. FINMA’s investigation was triggered by the 2016 Panama Papers: leaked documents on elites’ use of offshore corporations. Gazprombank Switzerland – a subsidiary of a Kremlin-controlled bank – “was in serious breach of its anti-money laundering due diligence requirements” between 2006 and 2016, according to FINMA. FINMA found Gazprombank Switzerland’s risk categorization, record-keeping, and reporting inadequate.
incidents.title: Gazprombank Switzerland sanctioned over money laundering concerns

incidents.content: On January 10, 2018, as reported by The New York Times, Russian military intelligency agency (GRU)-connected hacker group Fancy Bear, or APT28, leaked reportedly stolen correspondence from 2016 and 2017 between International Olympic Committee (IOC) and World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) officials regarding the decision to ban Russia from the 2018 Winter Olympics. A post on Fancy Bear's website read “the genuine intentions of the coalition headed by the Anglo-Saxons are much less noble than a war against doping."
incidents.title: Russian GRU-connected Fancy Bear hacking group targets International Olympic Committee

incidents.content: The Swiss Federal Intelligence Service has confirmed knowledge of Chinese intelligence operations targeting key personnel via LinkedIn and other similar professional social media services. Several LinkedIn profiles have been determined to be fake profiles, set up by the Chinese intelligence service. These profiles are used to contact researchers, decision makers, parliamentarians, civil servants, army personnel, bank employees, and academics. Once contact has been made with Swiss citizens, the fake profile users ask for information and facilitate knowledge transfers to the PRC. Those who comply are rewarded with monetary bribes as well as invitations and free entry to conferences in China.
incidents.title: Chinese intelligence services use LinkedIn to extract intelligence from Swiss citizens

incidents.content: In 2015, an agreement between the Swiss State Secretariat for Migration (SEM) and the CCP established a system by which Chinese officials could investigate illegal immigrants in Switzerland. These officials could enter Switzerland for two weeks at a time, unofficially, and work to determine if the illegal immigrants were of Chinese nationality, even having the right to interrogate them. If it was determined that the illegal immigrants were Chinese, the officials would work in concert with the SEM to deport them back to China. The agreement was never officially published, and some members of Parliament had never heard of it. It garnered attention in Autumn 2020, because it was set to expire in December of the same year. The excuse given for the secrecy surrounding the agreement was that it is an administrative agreement and thus not legally required to be published. In September 2020, the SEM began talks with CCP officials over renewing the agreement. However, while the SEM has expressed a desire to renew the agreement, other Swiss officials are staunchly against it. While Tibetans and Uyghurs are excluded from the illegal immigrants subject to this agreement, other rejected asylum seekers are not, and there is no information available about what happens to the irregular migrants after they return to China.
incidents.title: Swiss government signs secret deal allowing Chinese officials to investigate Chinese immigrants in Switzerland

incidents.content: In June 2013, Russian government-connected oligarch Vladimir Yakunin launched the Endowment for St. Andrew the First-Called Foundation in Geneva. According to the Foreign Policy Centre, the foundation is part of a network of organizations promoting an authoritarian and Eurasianist model of thought to counter the current liberal-democratic world order. Yakunin is the deputy chairperson of the organization, and his wife is the chairperson. The U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned Vladimir Yakunin in 2014 for “involvement in the situation in Ukraine” due to his position as a high-ranking government official and as a member of Russian President Vladimir Putin’s inner circle. The U.S. Treasury Department described Yakunin as a "close confidant" of Vladimir Putin.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected oligarch Vladimir Yakunin launches foundation in Geneva

incidents.content: On 29 May 2024, the Georgian government announced that a consortium of Chinese state-owned companies would build the country’s first deep-sea port in Anaklia, a strategic position on Georgia’s Black Sea coast. The project intends to increase traffic, efficiency, and trade volume, while also presenting an alternative trading route to Russia. China Communications Construction Company (CCCC) and China Harbor Investment, alongside subcontractors China Road and Bridge Corporation and Qingdao Port International, were the only contenders to submit a final proposal for the construction and operation of the port, granting the PRC a 49% share. The choice of partners lacked transparency and some of the companies in the consortium are internationally sanctioned. CCCC was banned from World bank-financed construction projects from 2011 to 2017 for participating in fraud and bribery, and sanctioned by the US for promoting militarization in the South China Sea in 2020. And the Bangladeshi government blacklisted China Harbor Engineering Company for corruption in 2018.
incidents.title: Sanctioned Chinese companies picked to build Georgian port

incidents.content: 4U.ge site is a platform for an ostensibly Georgian multimedia group that combines JAKO FM, LIFE FM and Shokoladi. It is owned by GBTimes, an ostensibly private Chinese multimedia company registered in Finland. However, until December 2018, state-owned China Radio International (CRI) owned 60 percent of GBTimes. A 2015 Reuters investigation revealed that GBTimes ran at least nine stations, notably in Finland, Italy, and Hungary. In Georgia, an IRI report explains that JAKO FM "offers extensive Georgian-language coverage of China’s international accomplishments, along with notable adulation of Xi Jinping."
incidents.title: China's state-owned broadcaster obfuscates its ties to European multimedia group

incidents.content: The Georgian government accused Russia of a series of attacks on its cyber infrastructure perpetrated by the GRU hacker collective known a “Sandworm.” The attacks, which took place in October 2019, targeted 15,000 websites belonging to governmental, judicial, and economic institutions, banks, and the Georgian state broadcaster. Sandworm also known by the names “BlackEnergy,” “Telebots,” and “Voodoo Bear,” was implicated previously in the 2017 NotPetya attack on Ukraine’s infrastructure, which caused $10 billion in damage.
incidents.title: Russia Blamed for October Cyberattack on Georgia

incidents.content: Starting in March of 2019, the Kremlin began to use disinformation in tandem with conferences to name Turkey and Azerbaijan enemies of Georgia to direct tension away from the Kremlin. Speakers at a conference hosted by the Georgia-Russia Center suggested that the Georgian people needed to rethink "who is the real enemy of the country. Simultaneously, pro-Kremlin media including Sputnik, Saqinform, EADaily, and the Georgian opposition party, Alliance of Patriots, promoted this discourse emphasizing the threat countries like Turkey and Azerbaijan pose to Georgian security. In addition, the Kremlin's information campaign presented Russia as "a good neighbor," the governments in Abkhazia and South Ossetia as "bad regimes," the common historical and religious ties between Orthodox majority nations, the weakness of "the West," and how NATO will never admit Georgia into its ranks.
incidents.title: Kremlin interference in Georgia's elections

incidents.content: Since 2016, Russia has been supervising and financing a Georgian opposition party called the Alliance of Patriots. According to a new report from the Dossier Center, the alliance is supervised by the Moscow-based company "Politsecrets" and is allegedly guided by Kremlin Associate Vladimir Chernov, Chief of the Russian Presidential Directorate for Interregional Relations and Cultural Contacts with Foreign Countries. The directorate was established in 2005 by Vladimir Putin, with the initial objective of thwarting "colored revolutions." Additional documents released in August, 2020, allege that Russian security services crafted a $8 million election campaign for the party ahead of the October parliamentary vote. These documents also provide evidence that the Kremlin provided step-by-step instructions to the Alliance of Patriots. The Alliance of Patriots adheres to Russian foreign policy objectives by promoting anti-Western rhetoric by stoking fear of the threat that "western liberal" ideology poses to Georgian society, revitalizing ethnic and political division, emphasizing Georgian geopolitical non-alignment and demilitarization, and presenting Turkey as the true geopolitical threat in the region. The Kremlin aims to keep the country unstable and derail it from its Euro-Atlantic path. The Dossier Center also indicated that Sputnik Georgia, EurAsia Daily, REGNUM, and the political center "North-South" were assigned with providing media support for the Alliance of Patriots.
incidents.title: Investigation alleges Russian money behind political party in neighboring Georgia

incidents.content: On February 27, 2017, Georgian social media users flagged an article by Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik that framed recent legal changes in Georgia as encouraging homosexuality. In reality, Georgia had simply removed “sodomy, lesbianism” and “other perverted sexual contact” from its definition of sexual assault. Coda Story situated the incident as part of a larger narrative pushed by the Kremlin portraying the West as decadent and immoral and Russia as a “protector of traditional values.”
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet runs disinformation regarding updates to Georgian legal definition

incidents.content: On August 4, 2015, Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev issued a statement warning of possible countermeasures against Georgia for joining European sanctions against Russia. Later that same day, the Russian consumer protection agency Rospotrebnadzor issued a warning to Georgia over the "low quality" of Georgian wines. In the past, the Kremlin has used bans from Rospotrebnadzor as a tool for political influence in its near abroad.
incidents.title: Russian Prime Minister Medvedev warns about "response measures" after Georgia joins European sanctions against Russia

incidents.content: In July 2015, The Guardian reported that Russia moved its border markers in Georgia to include part of a British Petroleum (BP) owned pipeline. The Foreign Ministry of Georgia said "the move means that a one-mile (1.5km) section of the Baku-Supsa pipeline beneath this farmland is now in what it called occupied territory." Described as part of a "creeping annexation" of the territory, the move was one of at least 56 cases of creeping annexation since 2008, resulting in locals' loss of access to their farmlands and houses.
incidents.title: Russian government moves border markers in South Ossetia, effectively seizing parts of a major oil pipeline

incidents.content: On January 23, 2015, according to The Washington Post, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik launched an affiliate service in Georgia. The service eventually launched a webpage in May 2015 and began posting articles on its news portal and transmitting radio broadcasting. Since its establishment, Sputnik Georgia has promoted pro-Russian media and hosted press conferences with NGOs that support the Russian government. According a 2018 minortiy staff report by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Sputnik is one of "the Russian government's main external propaganda outlets."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik launches service in Georgia

incidents.content: In March 2011, Georgia's Computer Emergency Response Team detected a hacker distributing malware that targeted important Georgian ministries and officials. The hacker behind the attack spread the malware by infiltrating specific pages on Georgian news sites and targeting people with an interest in the Georgian military. Throughout the course of a year, the malware infected 390 computers in government ministries, parliament, and banks. Georgian officials used a honeypot sting to spread a virus to the hackers' computer. They were able to take pictures of the hackers using their webcams and eventually traced the IP address that was connected to the Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs, Department of Logistics—routed through an Indian IP address.
incidents.title: Georgia detects hackers distributing malware through Georgian news sites

incidents.content: In August 2009, according to NBC News, "Russian hackers shut down Twitter and Facebook in Georgia." The attack coincided with the one-year anniversary of Russia's invasion of the country.
incidents.title: Russian hackers shut down social media sites in Georgia

incidents.content: On May 26, 2009, de facto Economy Minister of the Abkhazia region of Georgia Kristina Ozgan and Sergei Bogdanchikov, president of Russian state-controlled oil giant Rosneft, signed an agreement that gave Rosneft the rights to prospect for oil in the Black Sea off of the coast of Abkhazia. The Georgian Foreign Ministry said that the agreement was a violation of Georgian and international laws. Georgian law forbids foreign companies “access to develop oil fields in the breakaway Georgian territories of Abkhazia and South Ossetia without the authorization of the Georgian government,” while the 1982 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea “obliges foreign companies to obtain the permission of sovereign state authorities to engage in economic activity in its marine areas.” The action was denounced as a move by Russia to assert its influence over the occupied regions and gain an economic advantage over Georgia.
incidents.title: Abkhaz de facto government and Russian state-controlled Rosneft sign energy pact

incidents.content: According to Eurasia researcher Robert Cutler, from the beginning of the Russo-Georgian war on August 7, 2008, "Russian media" participated in a "concerted Russian effort to vilify [Georgian] President Mikheil Saakashvili as a war criminal." Russian media cited a figure of 2,000 civilian casualties in Tskhinvali city and up to 40,000 refugees (out of a maximum 70,000 total population in South Ossetia), in an attempt to paint Saakashvili as guilty of ethnic cleansing. Russian government officials cited the figures as the basis for promising prosecution in the International Court of Justice. Human Rights Watch investigations and reporters covering the region during the conflict refuted the claims made by the Russian state-sponsored media outlets.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media and government officials target Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili with information operation during the Russo-Georgian war

incidents.content: From July 18 - 20, 2008, the President of Georgia's website experienced a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack that was executed by a botnet and managed to take the site down for a day, according to a 2018 minority staff report by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The type of botnet and registration for the server were connected to Russia. This attack took place almost a month before the start of the Russo-Georgian War. Russia was suspected to have been testing Georgian systems and capabilities to prepare for the conflict.
incidents.title: The website of the President of Georgia knocked offline by DDOS attack

incidents.content: An investigation by several European news agencies revealed that Latvian MEP Tatjana Ždanoka had been working for Russia’s Federal Security Service (FSB) to advance the Kremlin’s interests in the Baltic region, reporting to two different handlers from 2004 to 2017. Leaked emails between Ždanoka and those operatives comprised detailed reports describing Ždanoka’s efforts as a European legislator to foster pro-Russian sentiment, correspondence about arranging physical meetings in Moscow or Brussels, and requests for funding, notably to organize a rally commemorating the Red Army’s victory in World War II.
incidents.title: Latvian MEP worked on behalf of Russian FSB since 2004

incidents.content: According to Latvian public broadcasting network LSM, on April 20, 2018, Latvian authorities arrested pro-Russia radical Aleksandrs Gaponenko in connection to anti-Latvia criminal activities that Latvia’s Secret Police said made Gasponenko a national security risk. Bellingcat reported Gaponenko leads the unregistered organization, pro-Russia Non-Citizens' Congress, whose "work is widespread amongst the small community of pro-Russia activists in the Baltics." Mr. Gaponenko admitted to receiving money from the Russian government to Re:Baltica. In its 2016 annual report, Latvia’s Security Police accused Gaponenko of conducting an open disinformation campaign against Latvia. Previously, Latvian Security Police had arrested Gasponenko "for aiming to cause 'national, ethnic or racial hatred' in the country."
incidents.title: Russian government-supported Latvian activist arrested as national security risk

incidents.content: On April 2, 2018, Russian state-sponsored media outlets TV Zvezda and Sputnik circulated a false news story which claimed that Adolf Hitler’s Mein Kampf was more popular than Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone among Latvians, according to Polygraph.info. The stories connected the false claims to previous articles about fascist rallies taking place in Riga. Russian state-sponsored media, such as Sputnik, frequently run stories implying that Nazism is rising in popularity across the Baltics, Poland, and Ukraine.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets claim Adolf Hitler's Mein Kampf more popular than Harry Potter among Latvians

incidents.content: In October 2017, several Russian state-sponsored media outlets actively spread disinformation and amplified narratives of dissent against the Latvian Ministry of Education’s announcement that Latvian schools would begin phasing out Russian language instruction, according to the Atlantic Council's Digital Forensic Research Lab. Russian state-sponsored outlets such as Sputnik, RIA Novosti, and others exaggerated the number of ethnic Russian Latvians and the number of Latvian citizens protesting the Ministry’s announcement.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets amplify disinformation to sow dissent regarding new Latvian language law

incidents.content: On May 25, 2017, the University of Toronto's Citizen Lab published a report detailing a large phishing and information operation against over 200 targets in 39 countries, including Latvia. The operation sought to steal emails and selectively leak them to the public. Citizen Lab was able to circumstantially link the attacks to Fancy Bear, or APT28, a prominent hacker group affiliated with Russia's military intelligence agency (GRU).
incidents.title: Researchers identify phishing and information operation potentially linked to GRU-connected hackers

incidents.content: On May 23, 2017, Reuters reported that Russian state-controlled rail company Russian Railways rerouted a significant portion of cargo typically transported through Latvia via rail. Unidentified Latvian officials and Latvian transport executives said that Russian Railways likely slashed cargo transit through Latvia in response to the Latvian government’s refusal to back Russian plans for the Nord Stream 2 pipeline. Latvian rails experienced a 90 percent drop in the volume of cargo transported through Latvia from Russia in 2017; no other country experienced such a dramatic decrease in cargo transit. Russian state-controlled companies often leverage goods' flows or prices for political gains.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled company restricts rail freight deliveries through Latvia in retaliation for Latvia's refusal to support for Nord Stream 2

incidents.content: On May 7, 2016, the Russian state-sponsored TV channel ?????? 24 broadcasted a false story about May 9 Victory Day celebrations in Latvia, according to the Center for European Policy Analysis. The broadcast reportedly claimed that the Latvian government referred to WWII veterans as occupiers, banned Victory Day symbols in Riga, and that Victory Day would only be celebrated in Russophone communities in Latvia.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored TV channel broadcasts false information about Victory Day celebrations in Latvia

incidents.content: On April 9, 2015, Latvian Public Broadcasting reported that Russian state-controlled rail company Russian Railways acquired a 50 percent stake in Latvian rail carrier Liepaja Oil Transit, securing "a unified delivery chain from Russia to Latvia's ports." According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Kremlin Playbook, Russian foreign direct investment in Europe targets strategic companies in the energy sector to expand its dominance of the industry.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled company buys large stake in Latvian transport company

incidents.content: On April 2, 2014, Latvia’s National Electronic Mass Media Council (NEPLP) suspended Russian state-sponsored TV channel RTR Rossiya for three months. NEPLP announced that RTR Rossiya repeatedly violated Latvian media laws in March 2014 by broadcasting "'war propaganda'" against Ukraine. On April 7, 2016, NEPLP again banned RTR Rossiya from broadcasting in Latvia for six months for "'inciting hatred [and] calling for war.'"
incidents.title: Latvia suspends Russian state-sponsored TV channel for promoting propaganda and attempting to incite violence

incidents.content: Between 2012 and 2015, Russian government-connected organizatons Russkiy Mir, Rossotrudnichestvo, and the Fund for the Legal Protection and Support of Russian Federation Compatriots Living Abroad provided over €1.5 million to pro-Russian NGOs in Baltic countries, including Latvia, according to Re:Baltica. In 2016, Latvian special services accused Russkiy Mir, Rossotrudnichestvo, and the Foundation for the Defense of the Rights of Compatriots Abroad of "providing cover for the actions of the Russian special services," according to Bellingcat, which also describes the organizations as "acting as arms of the Russian government." “They are being used as the agents of informational influence with the task to construct in the society messages that favor Russian interests,” said the head of the Latvian security service Normunds Mezviets.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected organizations provide funding for Russian NGOs to expand influence in Latvia

incidents.content: The Confucius Institute at the University of Latvia, opened in 2011, has drawn criticism over its relationship to the Chinese government and its preferred political narratives. Confucius Institutes are language and culture centers run by the People’s Republic of China’s Ministry of Education, which are hosted in more than 500 universities globally. Critics have raised concerns about incidents of infringement upon intellectual freedom at Confucius Institutes, whose terms of agreement and financial details are often hidden. A former head of propaganda for the Chinese Communist Party has called them "an important part of China’s overseas propaganda set-up." Latvia's security service, as well as Lithuania's and other European services, have warned that the institutes can be "disseminating ideological messages favorable to China’s Communist party" to potentially unsuspecting academic or social audiences. Latvian students at the institute have reported being denied the chance to discuss Hong Kong and other sensitive topics, as well as being unnecessarily photographed by Chinese faculty "for their reports."
incidents.title: Confucius Institute in Latvia draws security scrutiny, downplays controversial subjects

incidents.content: A hacking campaign perpetrated against European foreign ministries, including Latvia's, between 2010 and 2013 is believed to have originated in China. A report from private cybersecurity firm FireEye notes Chinese linguistic traces within the malware used, as well as Mandarin Chinese set as the default language on computers that were remotely directing the penetration of European government networks. An analyst also says that the prolonged, persistent duration of the attacks, the sophisticated, evolving nature of the phishing emails used, and the choice of government ministries as targets - rather than commercial entities - combine to suggest a state-affiliated cyber campaign rather than criminals seeking to make a profit. Technical similarities also exist between the series of attacks on foreign ministries and later attacks on finance ministries in advance of a G-20 summit.
incidents.title: Hacks of Latvian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and other European governments, traced back to China

incidents.content: A major political donor to Latvia's social-democratic Harmony party, which is associated with Latvia's ethnic Russian minority, gave over $160,000 to the party using funds originating from two money laundering schemes linked to Russia. The donor, Aivars Bergers, received over $300,000 between 2010 and 2011 from accounts implicated in the Magnitsky scandal involving a massive Russian tax fraud scheme. Bergers also received funds from an account used in the Azerbaijani Laundromat, which saw Azerbaijani political elites offshore billions using a network of shell companies which were also used by Russian money laundering operations.  The non-profit investigative outlet, Re:Baltica, first to uncover the donation scheme, also alleged that Bergers funneled money in excess of the legal limit for political donations by contributing to Riga city counselor Maxim Tolstoy, who went on to donate the funds on Bergers' behalf.
incidents.title: Funds from Russian money-laundering scheme funneled to Latvian political party

incidents.content: In January 2003, Russian state-controlled pipeline company Transneft terminated crude oil supplies to Latvia's Ventspils port, the largest export terminal of Russian oil outside of Russia. Transneft attributed the decision to high tariff prices, but officials and experts believe Moscow intended to pressure Latvia to sell a stake in Ventspils port’s operator Ventspils Nafta to Russian state-owned entities. After Latvian state and private owners refused to transfer port management to Russian ownership, Transneft suspended oil deliveries, and then rerouted all oil shipments through the Russian port of Primorsk. As described by Nicholas Redman of the Economist Intelligence Unit in London, "In the year that Latvia received the NATO invitation, [we] see fairly naked economic-political pressure from Russia ... The motive is to gain control of Ventspils Nafta and with it, the pipeline running between Russia and Latvia."
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled pipeline company halts oil exports to Latvian port

incidents.content: On February 3, 2023, the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP) published an investigative report detailing the permeating influence that a subversive group of lobbyists tied to the Russian parliament had on Cypriot party politics. The ‘International Agency for Current Policy’ (IACP), led by Russian Duma staffer and advisor Sargis Mirzakhanian, collaborated with the Russian-Cypriot Sergey Kozlov in order to sway politicians in favor of pro-Russian legislation. The IACP’s leaked emails reveal that a strategy to secure votes from “35-39 deputies” in the Cypriot parliament from the Democratic Rally and the Progressive Party for Working People, to pass a motion calling for an end to EU sanctions against Russia. Not only did the motion pass on July 7, 2016, but the following year Kozlov also helped establish the pro-Russia party Ego, o Politis (I, the Citizen).
incidents.title: Duma associate shapes party politics in Cyprus to promote pro-Russian legislation

incidents.content:
