In February 2022, the Cyprus office of accounting giant PwC enabled the transfer of $1.4 billion on behalf of Alexey Mordashov, the primary shareholder of Russia’s largest steel and mining company, just as he was about to be hit by EU sanctions. The transfer wasn’t fully effective until March 2022, raising the possibility that PwC breached fresh EU sanctions against Mordashov. PwC had been working with Mordashov since the early 2000s and, according to the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, helped him administer a holding company tied to more than 65 shell companies in fiscal havens. PwC also helped move assets belonging to metals magnates Alexander Abramov and Alexander Frolov ahead of UK sanctions. According to ICIJ, the auditing firm was engaged with at least 12 of the 25 Russian oligarchs sanctioned at the time of the 2014 annexation of Crimea. But it only terminated its business activities in Russia and “ordered its affiliates to stop working for sanctioned clients” two months after the invasion of Ukraine.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian oligarchs use Cypriot corporate enablers to avoid sanctions

incidents.content: A Cypriot political party, "I the Citizen," was founded in 2017 by a group of wealthy Russians who have used the island's lax financial and citizenship laws to gain residence while obscuring funds. One founder, Alexei Voloboev, is a businessman with murky connections to Russian media and energy entities; other connected individuals come from different industries, but the leadership appears to share Russian backgrounds and significant, if not always explained, wealth. In the past, Cypriot financial institutions have been accused on multiple occasions of insufficient diligence in preventing money laundering, including cases allegedly involving Russian organized crime.
incidents.title: New Cypriot party backed by Russian oligarchs with opaque financial presence

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On May 21, 2018, the Cyprus Development Bank was fined €715,000 by Cypriot regulators for anti-money laundering violations that occurred between 2014 and 2016. In summer 2014, Russian investors gained majority ownership of the bank and gained seats on its board. Two of those investors, Alexey Kulikov and Andrey Gorbatov, allegedly helped orchestrate one of the largest money laundering operations in history, the infamous “mirror trading” scheme that moved $10 billion from Russia to Europe through offsetting securities trades booked at Deutsche Bank’s Moscow and London offices. Kulikov was sentenced in 2017 to nine years in prison. Kulikov and Gorbatov have also seen the licenses of their numerous Russian banks and broker-dealers revoked by Russian regulators.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian-owned Cyprus Development Bank fined for violating anti-money laundering regulations

incidents.content: On November 29, 2017, Cyprus’s Russian Commercial Bank was fined €800,000 by Cypriot regulators for anti-money laundering violations that occurred through 2014. From approximately 2009-2012, the Russian Commercial Bank allegedly provided a shell company called Sandalwood Continental Limited with unsecured loans worth at least $650 million. Sandalwood was owned by Sergei Roldugin, a cellist, a childhood friend of Vladimir Putin, and the godfather to Putin’s daughter. These loans to Sandalwood were allegedly part of a larger scheme involving the sanctioned Bank Rossiya that was used to enrich individuals in Putin’s inner circle.
incidents.title: Russian Commercial Bank fined for violating AML regulations

incidents.content: The September 10, 2013 “bail-in” converted a portion of uninsured deposits into equity in the Bank of Cyprus, making several Russian depositors some of the bank’s largest shareholders overnight. Those shareholders worked to appoint six new members to the bank’s Board of Directors. One of the new board members was Vladimir Strzhalkovsky, a former KGB official alleged to be close to Vladimir Putin, who also served as the former CEO of Norilsk Nickel (and received a $100 million severance). As of June 2018, the largest shareholder in the bank is Viktor Vekselberg, whom the U.S. Treasury Department designated under the Russia sanctions program in April 2018.
incidents.title: Wealthy Russians appoint new directors of Bank of Cyprus after "bail-in"

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On February 3, 2023, the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP) released an investigative report unveiling a coordinated operation by the ‘International Agency for Current Policy’ (IACP), led by Russian parliament insider Sargis Mirzakhanian, to influence European politics and civil society and garner support for the annexation of Crimea. In the Italian regional councils of Veneto, Lombardy and Liguaria, politicians like the far-right Stefano Valdegamberi were paid to promote IACP-drafted motions calling for an end to European sanctions against Russia. Additionally, IACP leveraged its connections to publish articles in local tabloids that legitimized the annexation of Crimea. IACP also organized a luxury trip for Italian politicians and businesspeople to Crimea, paid for by the Kremlin-linked construction company Granel, that facilitated talks to bring Russian money to Italy in industries like construction, steel, and wine – violating European sanctions imposed after the annexation of Crimea.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Duma staffer undermines supports for EU sanctions in Italy

incidents.content: In 2017, Chinese state backed company CRRC, acquired Blue Engineering, an Italian aerospace engineering firm. The U.S. Department of Defense listed CRRC as a company contributing to the Chinese military’s modernization until June 2021. The 2017 CRRC takeover was never disclosed to the Italian Parliament but Italian MPs have not yet ruled whether it breached foreign investment screening rules. CRRC, through its numerous branches, has acquired other European industrial companies such as Dine, a British semiconductor group. When reporting on the acquisition, Italian investigative outlet Decode 39 quoted a U.S. Department of Defense brief to explain that Blue Engineering’s acquisition fits in the broader trend of strategic acquisitions by PRC entities to strengthen China’s technological, industrial, and military capabilities.
incidents.title: Chinese state backed company acquires Italian aerospace firm

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

China’s embassy in Italy requested that the government of Italian city Brescia close an art exhibit critical of the PRC. The artist is a Chinese dissident named Badiucao or “Chinese banking” and their exhibit was expected to represent repression censorship and information manipulation that occurs within China. The Chinese Embassy Cultural Center issued a public statement calling out Badiucao’s work as “full of anti-Chinese lies” and warning that the exhibit would harm diplomatic relations between China and Italy. According to local news sources, mayor of Brescia Emilio Del Bono stated that the art exhibit would continue as planned.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese embassy pressures Italian city over critical art exhibit

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On March 10, 2022, the Italian government annulled the sale of military drones company Alpi Aviation to Chinese investors. In September 2021, the Guardia di Finanza, the Italian financial crimes police, had placed six managers of the drones manufacturer under investigation over the planned sale of their company to two Chinese state-owned enterprises. The BBC reports that Alpi Aviation produces military grade drones for NATO. The six managers oversaw the sale of 75% of the shares in Alpi Aviation to a Hong Kong-based firm that acted as a front for a complex web of corporations that ultimately led to the Management Committee of Wuxi Liyuan Economic Development Zone and to the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council (SASAC), the body responsible for managing Chinese state-owned enterprises. The sale was in breach of Italian investment screening and arms control legislation. Following the sale, Alpi Aviation had plans to move its drone production to a technology hub in Wuxi, 135km west of Shanghai.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Italian state steps in to stop Chinese state-owned companies' covert acquisition of Italian drone maker

incidents.content: From May to November 2020, several Catholic institutions were hacked, including ones located in Hong Kong and Italy. Recorded Future, a U.S. cybersecurity firm, attributed the attacks to RedDelta, a state-affiliated Chinese hacking group. The Holy See’s Study Mission to China, which is run by representatives of the Vatican, is based in Hong Kong-based. Beijing and the Vatican cut diplomatic ties in 1951. For the next 67 years, Chinese Catholics were divided into those who followed a state-recognized church and those who followed an underground Vatican-recognized church. In 2018, the Vatican and Beijing came to a temporary agreement, set to expire in September 2020. The details of the agreement are murky, but its goal was to unify the two Catholic churches by negotiating for control over the election of bishops in China. Reportedly, Beijing would select bishops and the Vatican would approve them. Critics urged the Vatican not to accept this deal, which gave Beijing control over Catholic citizens. It is unclear whether the hackers were attempting to obtain information to use in the negotiation or were monitoring the groups to determine their involvement in the pro-democracy unrest in Hong Kong. The attacks have intensified since the official extension of the agreement in October, with fake emails impersonating journalists from the Union of Catholic Asia News and a new kind of malware deployed by the Chinese state-linked hackers.
incidents.title: Chinese state-backed group allegedly hacks Vatican

incidents.content: Italian Professor Giuseppe Remuzzi, the director of the Mario Negri Institute for Pharmacological Research, said in an interview in March 2020, that there had been strange cases of pneumonia in Italy as far back as November and December 2019. He believed that COVID-19 may have reached Europe even earlier than experts believed at the time. However, Chinese state-owned media took his comments out of context and used them to say that the pandemic originated in Italy rather than China, and rapidly spread this story across the internet.
incidents.title: Chinese state-owned media misquote Italian professor to imply coronavirus started in Italy

incidents.content: When the COVID-19 pandemic struck Italy and lockdown laws forced people to stay inside, some people went out on their balconies to socialize with their street and sing uplifting songs. In mid-March, Chinese state media and official Twitter accounts claimed that Italians were cheering for China and singing the Chinese national anthem in gratitude for Chinese aid. The claim was accompanied by a video, which showed Italians cheering with the Chinese national anthem in the background. However, Italian fact-checking and manipulation experts examined the video and determined that while the first fifteen seconds may be unaltered, it is likely that the majority of the video was doctored by taking footage of Italians cheering for medical staff and playing the Chinese national anthem under it.
incidents.title: Chinese state media and diplomats spread misleading video online

incidents.content: On March 11, 2020 the Chinese embassy in Rome promoted Chinese coronavirus aid shipments sent to Italy using the hashtag #forzaCinaeItalia. Between March 11 and 23 2020, investigative news outlet Formiche reported that 46.3% of the tweets reusing the hashtag #forzaCinaeItalia ("Go China! Go Italy!") were posted by bots. Formiche also reported that 37.1% of the tweets with the hashtag #grazieCina ("Thank you China") published over the same period were posted by bots. At the same time, Chinese diplomats and state media were actively highlighting the Italian people's purported thankfulness towards China. Beside the narrative convergence, many of the accounts amplifying these pro-Chinese narratives on Twitter bore the same hallmarks of inauthenticity observed by experts in others cases of Chinese information manipulation campaigns. Particularly egregious was the fact that the same bots also included EU-related hashtags in their tweets, shaming the organization for its inaction on coronavirus. At the end of March 2020, the parliamentary committee in charge of Italian intelligence publicly announced that an infodemic that could be traced back to "external state actors" was targeting Italy.
incidents.title: Chinese state narratives on medical shipments to Italy promoted online via inauthentic means

incidents.content: In 2020, the Ferretti Group took the first steps in investing in Taranto, a strategically important Italian port city. The Ferretti Group was an Italian yacht business until 2012, when the Chinese state-owned Weichai Group acquired an 86% stake in the financially unstable company. Taranto is an essential port for both NATO and the EU. The city hosts a NATO military naval base and supports the organization’s Standing Naval Force in the Mediterranean Sea, which conducts counterterrorism, fights against migrant trafficking, and participates in joint exercises. The EU’s counter migrant trafficking operation, also relies on Taranto. Adolfo Urso, vice-President of the Italian oversight body for state intelligence agencies, and Italian MEP Anna Bonfrisco have expressed concern over the possible sale and Bonfrisco has asked the EU to investigate. The Ferretti Group hoped to establish a production center and a research center in Taranto, but the deal was slowed by the COVID-19 pandemic. In April, Senator Mario Turco, undersecretary to the presidency of the Council of Ministers, expressed support for the deal, emphasizing the economic benefits for the region.
incidents.title: Italian government approves deal for Chinese state-owned Ferretti Group to develop NATO strategic port

incidents.content: The partnership between Italy’s largest news agency, Ansa, and China’s largest multimedia company, Xinhua, began in 2017 with a deal to encourage cooperation between the two companies, allowing them both to expand their global outreach. On 22 March 2019, an accord was signed to build on this agreement. According to Ansa, the accord was signed, "for the diffusion in Italy of an Italian-language Xinhua news service." A journalist for Italian newspaper Repubblica observed that on a given day in September 2020, ten out of eleven China-related articles on Ansa's website were written by, or in collaboration with, Xinhua. Xinhua is controlled by the CCP and has been called "the largest propaganda agency in the world" by Reporters Sans Frontières.
incidents.title: ANSA-Xinhua media partnership deepens, exposing Italy to pro-CCP bias

incidents.content: In March 2019, a major Italian broadcasting company, Radiotelevisione Italia (RAI), signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with China Media Group. China Media Group is a state-owned company which incorporates China National Radio and China Radio International. In March 2020, RAI coverage of coronavirus and Chinese aid supported Chinese efforts to portray the Chinese authorities as Italy's main ally in the fight against the virus. RAI coverage of Chinese aid was disproportionate to the coverage of aid from other countries. According to a DataStampa study, Chinese aid was given more than three times as much coverage as that given to U.S. aid and two and a half times as much as coverage as that given to Russian aid.
incidents.title: Italian media group RAI signs a Memorandum of Understanding with China Media Group

incidents.content: On October 18, 2018, a "close aide" to Italian Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini negotiated a deal with unidentified Russians for clandestine funding of Salvini's nationalist Lega party, according to BuzzFeed News. In a secret recording of the meeting, the aide, Gianluca Savoini, discusses a scheme whereby a Russian oil company would sell fuel at a discount to the Italian Eni company through intermediaries. These middlemen would then transfer the discount - valued at around $65 million - to Lega. While it is uncertain whether the transaction took place, it would have been illegal under Italian law. The discussion, conducted in Moscow by Savoini, two other Italians, and three Russians with apparent government ties, was first revealed in February 2019 by L'Espresso.
incidents.title: Unidentified Russians and Italian government aide discuss covert funding of far-right Italian party

incidents.content: From May 27-28, 2018, at least 20 Russian-government connected Twitter accounts launched an information operation pressuring Italian President Sergio Mattarella to resign using the hashtag #Mattarelladimettiti. The campaign was initiated after the President refused to appoint anti-EU Paolo Savona as Minister of Economy, according to Corriere.it. Researchers at Clemson University initially discovered the Russian accounts' connection to the resign movement, and Twitter later confirmed the accounts connection to the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA). According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is “a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.” Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin,” provides funding and support for the IRA.
incidents.title: Social media accounts linked to the Russian Internet Research Agency pressure Italian president to resign

incidents.content: In March 2018, Alto Data Analytics released a report on how social media accounts in Italy commented on the topic of immigration ahead of the March 4, 2018 Italian general election. The company's analysis ranked Russian state-sponsored media outlets RT and Sputnik within the top 3 percent of the most influential sites contributing to the anti-immigration debate. The report also noted that anti-immigration communities were responsible for sharing the vast majority, 90.4 percent, of RT and Sputnik content.
incidents.title: Report reveals Russian state-sponsored media's influence on immigration debate preceding Italy's general elections

incidents.content: On February 17, 2018, Italian newspaper La Stampa reported that anonymous experts had discovered five active Italian Twitter accounts with potential links to the Russian government. Analysis of the accounts found highly irregular activity, including numerous tweets per day (averaging 125 in early 2017) and a strong reliance on pro-Russian news sources, such as Sputnik and RT. The accounts also appeared to be using a virtual private network to obscure their location. According to La Stampa, the accounts, which resemble trolls from the Russian Internet Research Agency, may part of an attempt to influence elections in Italy.
incidents.title: Italian newspaper alleges Russian government-linked trolls may be attempting to influence Italian election

incidents.content: In April 2017, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik and Italian news agency Agenzia Nova signed a cooperation agreement. Under the agreement, both companies agreed to an information exchange, support for journalists, and the development of an “information dialogue” between the two countries. Sputnik Senior Deputy Editor-in-Chief Sergei Kochetkov issued a statement saying, “this cooperation will allow our countries build closer ties and develop Sputnik resources in Italy.” According to the Center for European Policy Analysis, the Russian government uses Sputnik "to promote the Kremlin’s chosen messages of disinformation."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik begins cooperation with Italy's Agenzia Nova

incidents.content: From October to December 2016, Russian state-sponsored media outlets RT and Sputnik promoted disinformation ahead of Italy’s referendum on constitutional reform, which was held on December 4, 2016, according to La Stampa. Voters in Italy ultimately rejected the referendum, which was backed by Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and his coalition government. On October 29, the day of a pro-Yes rally, Kremlin-sponsored media network RT falsely reported that protesters were demonstrating against PM Renzi and not in support of the referendum. According to La Stampa, RT’s false narrative reached at least one million and a half people directly, and was amplified by the Eurosceptic Five Star Movement’s (M5S) popular blog TzeTze, which frequently reposts RT and Sputnik content.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets unleash information campaign to influence Italian constitutional referendum

incidents.content: Antonio Morabito, a former Italian Ambassador, was the Directorate General for Promoting the Country System at the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs when a corruption investigation was opened into his actions in 2019. He was bribed by Chinese intermediaries with gifts, money, and favors to share confidential information on high-level Italian companies and assist Chinese investors in determining which Italian companies were strategic investments. Using his position, he created a network of insider knowledge. The confidential information shared included the trade secrets of Italian state-owned and strategic companies like Enel, an energy company, and information on strategic infrastructure in Italy, Spain, and France. He notably gave information on the telecommunications sector to Chinese intermediaries investing on behalf of Huawei. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Italian official Antonio Morabito sells strategic trade secrets to Chinese investors

incidents.content: Former Italian politician, Irene Pivetti, was appointed President of the Italian-Chinese Friendship Association (ICFA). Pivetti, once President of the Italian Chamber of Deputies, is also the founder and president of trade consortium Only Italia; Pivetti has promoted components of Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) through her firm by seeking investors to support the construction of a direct rail between Italy and China. In an interview, Pivetti stated that she works with local members of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in advancing the BRI. The ICFA is part of a global network of non-diplomatic friendship groups between foreign nations and the Chinese state that aim to advance PRC interests abroad. According to the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments (CSBA), "friendship groups are often disguised as homegrown organizations run by the host country's own citizens", and are one facet of Beijing's foreign influence campaign abroad.
incidents.title: Former President of the Italian Chamber of Deputies appointed head of PRC Friendship Association

incidents.content: An official foreign affairs organization, the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries (CPAFFC), has been tied to the creation of the Italian-Chinese Friendship Association (ICFA). Irene Pivetti, a former Italian lawmaker, was appointed ICFA President at CPAFFC headquarters in Beijing before travelling to Rome where she signed a partnership agreement with CPAFFC vice president Li Jianping. ICFA is the Italian variation of a global network of PRC friendship groups, non-diplomatic organizations which seek to promote bilateral relations between foreign nations and the Chinese state. According to U.S. policy research institute the Center for Strategic Budgetary Assessments, "friendship groups are often disguised as homegrown organizations run by the host country's own citizens." However, the research institute also explains that the groups then act as fronts to promote Beijing's domestic and foreign policy agendas. CPAFFC's involvement in the founding of ICFA suggests that the latter organization's work might extend beyond the local-level concerns typical of partnership agreements.
incidents.title: PRC foreign affairs organization involved in creation of the Italy-China Friendship Association

incidents.content: In 2015, Former Italian ambassador to China Alberto Bradanini accused former Italian Environment Minister Corrado Clini of awarding green energy projects to Chinese companies from 2011 to 2013 in exchange for money or other favors from the CCP. Italian investigators reported that some of the projects were completed in a substandard way while others were priced far above market value. Nevertheless, Clini called one of these poorly executed projects, "intelligent, ecological, and energy efficient," and pointed to a report commissioned by the Chinese Ministry of Environmental Protection, which received more than 70 million euros from the grants Clini oversaw, which judged the projects to be in "excellent" condition. Bradanini is now on the board of directors and steering committee of the Silk Road Cities Alliances, a Beijing-based organization which works to coordinate social resources to implement the BRI. Bradanini is also president of the Centre for Contemporary China Studies (CSCC), an Italian China studies think tank.
incidents.title: Former Ambassador to China Alberto Bradanini reveals pro-CCP ties and corruption

incidents.content: In April 2017, the PRC government-controlled Xinhua News Agency signed a cooperation agreement with one of the largest daily newspapers in Greece, Kathimerini. Although the exact terms of the agreement remain unknown, a study conducted by the Institute of International Economic Relations revealed that, in 2020 alone, Kathimerini republished at least one Xinhua report per week, for a total of 66 publications. According to the study, the reports defended the PRC over criticisms for the spread of COVID-19, applauded the Belt and Road Initiative, and painted a “rosy picture of Sino-Greek relations”. In 2019, Kathimerini released an article signed by President Xi prior to an official state visit to Greece, where he addressed the Greek people and called for the “continued success” of the Confucius Institute and China Cultural Center in Athens.
incidents.title: Xinhua publishes content in major Greek newspaper

incidents.content: On March 24, 2024, pro-Kremlin hackers conducted cyber operations against Greek institutions. The hackers, known as NoName057(16), started operating in March 2022 and target states that counter Russian aggression against Ukraine. The group obstructs governmental bodies by using distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks that overwhelm their websites and effectively take them offline. The March 2024 attack affected 9 Greek institutions: the metro, port, and international airport of Thessaloniki; the Ministry of Infrastructure and Transportation; the Center for European Constitutional Law; the Registry of Shipping Companies of Greece; the Hellenic Banking Association; the intercity bus service of Halkidiki; the Hellenic Railways Organization. It is uncertain whether NoName stole any data from any of the affected entities.
incidents.title: Pro-Russian hackers claim responsibility for attacking Greek institutions

incidents.content: On July 6, 2018, Greece expelled two Russian diplomats for political interference. Two other Russian diplomats were barred from entering Greece. According to BBC News, the Russian officials attempted to "obtain and distribute sensitive information" and to bribe Greek officials. The diplomats apparently encouraged rallies opposing the June 17 Greek-Macedonian deal regarding the latter's name. The Financial Times reported that the Russian officials used local businessmen as intermediaries "to bribe local government officials, Orthodox clergymen, and members of cultural associations and far-right groups" in northern Greece to oppose the deal. At least one Greek soldier was also approached. Ekathimerini reported that, according to high-level Greek diplomatic sources, the political efforts followed sustained Russian attempts to gain influence in the Greek Orthodox Church.
incidents.title: Greece expels two Russian diplomats for alleged political interference

incidents.content: On January 28, 2018, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik reported that the Turkish navy had prevented the Greek Defense Chief from approaching the islet of Imia, a disputed area between Greece and Turkey, impeding the Defense Chief from placing a wreath at the place where a Greek military helicopter was shot down in 1996. Video evidence quickly proved the story false.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet seeks to harm Greece-Turkey relations

incidents.content: In December 2016, China's State Grid utility acquired a 24% share in Greek power grid operator ADMIE, which was previously owned in its entirety by Greece's state utility Public Power Corp. The 320 million euro sale comes as part of Greece's international bailout agreement between the country, the International Monetary Fund, and eurozone nations. In May 2017, the European Commission issued an assessment asking the Greek regulatory authority to more closely analyze the risks tied to the partial ownership of ADMIE by a company ultimately owned by the Chinese state. In particular, the Commission seemed concerned about actions by Beijing that would harm security of supply in the EU. A Reuters article from May 2017 also reports that, through its stake in ADMIE, State Grid has been looking for ways to get involved in "the 1.5 billion-euro EuroAsia Interconnector project which aims to link up via subsea cables the power transmission systems of Israel, Cyprus and Greece."
incidents.title: EU concerned about Beijing's acquisition of minority share in Greece's power grid operator

incidents.content: In January 2016, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik, according to its own reporting, established a partnership with the Athens News Agency-Macedonian Press Agency (ANA-MPA) as part of what both parties dubbed "The Year of Russia in Greece." ANA-MPA and Sputnik news launched two new websites, www.greece-russia2016.gr and www.russia-greece2016.ru, which offered news and information in Greek and Russian. Sputnik also launched a one-hour program in Greek on Radio Praktoreio FM. According to the Center for European Policy Analysis, the Russian government uses Sputnik "to promote the Kremlin’s chosen messages of disinformation."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik partners with Greek ANA-MPA news agency

incidents.content: On October 10, 2008, the Greek authorities and China Ocean Shipping Company Limited (COSCO), then known as COSCO Pacific, entered into an agreement to lease two of Piraeus port's terminals to COSCO for a period of 35 years, in a deal worth $5.90 billion. The Greek government received $647 million upfront in 2010, with the rest meant to be received out of future earnings. In his book "Adults in the Room," former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis reports that the Chinese ambassador to Greece told him in 2015 that: "from Beijing’s perspective, Cosco is the dragon’s jaw. First, we must ensure that its teeth bite hard so that the dragon gets in. Once it is in, have no concerns or doubt: the rest of the dragon will follow.’ COSCO became the majority owner of Piraeus in 2016 and the Chinese state committed to spending an additional $660 million to continue the port's development in 2019.
incidents.title: Chinese state-owned company COSCO leases two thirds of Greek port of Piraeus for 35 years

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In February 2023, a Russia-based hacking group calling itself “Anonymous Sudan” took responsibility for a series of distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks on Swedish airports, hospitals, and banks. These cyberattacks disrupted online programming at Sweden’s national public broadcaster and the websites of Scandinavian Airlines, the state-owned power company Vattenfall, and the defense firm Saab AB. Truesec, one of Sweden’s biggest cybersecurity firms, provided evidence that the group is not Islamist but a well-organized unit of Russian hackers. Truesec was unable to determine whether the group consisted of Russian government employees or pro-Russia hackers. Katarzyna Zysk, a professor of international relations at the Norwegian Institute for Defence Studies, said that the hackers’ timing, targets, and in-depth knowledge of Swedish politics points to Russian intelligence service involvement. Anonymous Sudan continues to claim to be a Sudanese hacktivist group and assert that its attacks on Sweden were prompted by the burning of a Koran in Stockholm. 

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian hackers posing as Islamic activists target Sweden

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On April 9, 2021, the Chinese embassy in Stockholm sent Swedish journalist Jojje Olsson an email accusing him of “moral corruption” and threatening him to stop his critical coverage of the Chinese government or “face the consequences of your own actions.” The email also accused Olsson of “colluding with Taiwan separatists, fabricating fake news to smear China, making extreme anti-China comments, spreading disinformation to provoke anti-China sentiments and sabotaging China-Sweden friendship.” Olsson had previously received three increasingly strongly worded emails from the Chinese embassy. The Swedish foreign minister described the threat as “completely unacceptable” but stopped short of expelling the Chinese ambassador. The Swedish Foreign Ministry had already summoned the Chinese ambassador in January 2021 over perceived threatening statement addressed at Swedish media.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese Embassy in Stockholm threatens Swedish journalist

incidents.content: In the second half of March 2021, Chinese netizens resurfaced old statements by several clothing companies, including H&M, Nike, and Burberry, expressing concern about allegations of forced labor in Xinjiang's cotton industry. The online outrage was notably fanned by groups like the Communist Youth League, the CCP's youth arm. On March 26, a spokesperson for Xinjiang's local government declared that "Can H&M continue to make money in the Chinese market? Not anymore." Chinese diplomats and state media closely covered the boycott, repeatedly showing empty H&M shops and interviewing indignant Chinese consumers. H&M's listings were wiped off popular Chinese shopping apps and the geo-locations of the Swedish brand's stores were also deleted, making it impossible for users to search them. Since the incident, some brands, like Zara's parent company, have pre-emptively taken down statements about Xinjiang from their websites.
incidents.title: Chinese diplomats and state media promote "spontaneous" boycott of H&M and other clothing brands over Xinjiang

incidents.content: In late January 2021, a spokesperson for the Chinese ministry of commerce urged Sweden to "correct [its] mistake" over Stockholm's decision to exclude Huawei and ZTE from the country's 5G infrastructure. The Chinese official went on to add that China would "take all necessary measures" in response to Sweden's actions. The Chinese ambassador to Stockholm had already told the Swedish press in October 2020 that banning Huawei was an "incorrect decision" and that "it could have negative consequences for Swedish companies working in China." In early January 2021, media reported that Ericssson's CEO was pressuring Swedish authorities to reverse the ban out of concerns that Ericsson might be excluded from the Chinese market in retaliation for the Huawei ban. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Chinese ministry of commerce threatens Sweden over Huawei ban

incidents.content: Chinese-born Swedish publisher Gui Minhai, who has been repeatedly detained since 2015, was honored with an award from a Swedish literary group, Svenska PEN. Chinese government officials, however, criticized the ceremony and warned Sweden's government not to have anyone attend. After Sweden's Culture Minister presented the award, China's ambassador said his government would take "counter measures," without immediately specifying the actions. He notably said during a media interview that "we treat our friends with fine wine, but we have shotguns for our enemies." Subsequently, the ambassador mentioned restricting cultural, trade, and economic exchanges, and at least two China-Sweden business delegations were canceled. There was also talk of Swedish officials being banned from entering China in the future.
incidents.title: Chinese government retaliates over Swedish literary award to detained publisher Gui Minhai

incidents.content: In April 2017, as Coda Story later reported, the NGO “Swedish Professors and Doctors for Human Rights” (SWEDHR) released a video which claimed to discredit reports of chemical weapons use by the Syrian government. The video, which SWEDHR claimed depicted actors staging the aftermath of a fake chemical weapons attack, was actually footage of ‘White Helmet’ volunteers responding to a 2015 chemical attack. SWEDHR failed to reference the fact that the video was two years old at the time of its release. The Guardian reports that Russian state-sponsored media outlets RT and Sputnik seized on and deliberately circulated this disinformation in order to cast doubt on the work done by the White Helmets and the reality of the 2017 chemical attacks. Syria's UN ambassador also cited SWEDHR's claims at an April 12, 2017 Security Council meeting. Additionally, research commissioned by the human rights group the Syria Campaign, revealed that the network of Twitter users who discussed the White Helmets "included many known pro-Kremlin troll accounts, some of which were closed down as part of the investigation into Russian interference in the US election."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets seize on disinformation from a Swedish NGO to discredit reports of a chemical attack in Syria

incidents.content: In February 2017, a Russian TV crew reportedly attempted to bribe a group of Swedish teens to riot on camera in the Stockholm suburb of Rinkeby. The group of Rinkeby teens told journalists that the Russian film crew refused to say what station they worked for and repeatedly offered the boys money in return for staging a riot in front of the camera. According to Foreign Policy magazine, the coverage "falls in line with a wider pattern of Russian state-funded media portraying Europe as falling apart due to immigration."
incidents.title: Russian TV crew from unidentified outlet offers money to Swedish teens to riot on camera

incidents.content: Over the summer of 2016, Sweden experienced a barrage of anti-NATO disinformation amid domestic political debate over the potential for military cooperation with NATO. False rumors circulated on social media regarding the Alliance’s plans to stockpile nuclear weapons in Sweden, NATO soldiers raping Swedish women, and NATO’s ability to launch an attack on Russia from Sweden. According to The New York Times, "numerous analysts and experts in American and European intelligence point to Russia as the prime suspect."
incidents.title: Western intelligence assesses Russian government behind anti-NATO information operation in Sweden

incidents.content: On March 19, 2016, a coordinated cyberattack disabled the online editions of several Swedish news outlets. The hackers used prolonged Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks to crash the websites. The attack took place just two days after the Swedish Security Service published its annual assessment of threats, which dedicated a chapter to Russian disinformation campaigns. A U.S. State Department cable noted that the Russian government is suspected of carrying out these attacks. According to Newsweek, "Sweden’s national police cyber crime unit said the network of computers used in the attacks was located in Russia."
incidents.title: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack disrupts Swedish media websites in a suspected warning from Russia

incidents.content: On September 2, 2015, according to researchers Martin Kragh and Sebastian Asberg writing for the Journal of Strategic Studies, Russian state actors created a forged letter from Tora Holst, head of the International Public Prosecution Office in Stockholm, addressed to the head of Ukraine’s Department of National Security and Defense Affairs, Oleksiy Pokotylo and uploaded it to CNN’s Istory webpage. The letter communicated Holst's alleged willingness to overlook purported Ukrainian war crimes in the interest of preserving Ukraine’s international reputation as a democratic state. The forgery was later broadcasted by Russian state-sponsored media outlets and pro-Russian channels.
incidents.title: Forged letter alleges that Swedish government agreed to overlook Ukrainian war crimes

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In May 2015, both Sweden and Lithuania accused Russia of using its navy to disrupt the construction of the NordBalt power cable. The power cable would connect the electricity markets of the Baltics to Scandinavia through Lithuania and Sweden and decrease both regions' energy dependence on Russia. Russia is reported to have disrupted the cable's construction on multiple occasions. In one instance, a Russian naval ship ordered a Swedish construction vessel to change course and in another, ships were ordered to stay away from the construction site as Russia would be conducting military exercises there.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia disrupts the construction of NordBalt power cable

incidents.content: On February 21, 2015, a forged letter from Swedish Defense Minister Peter Hultqvist addressed to the CEO of BEA Systems Bofors AB Magnus Ingesson appeared on Swedish social media. The debunked letter contains an exchange between Hultqvist and Ingesson, in which Hultqvist signals Sweden’s intent to export an advanced Archer artillery system to Ukraine. The letter purportedly surfaced on a German news site, then appeared in Sweden and Russia on several pro-Russian websites. The Swedish Institute of International Affairs attributed the information operation to the Russian government.
incidents.title: Forged letter potentially tied to the Russian government falsely indicates Swedish weapons sales to Ukraine

incidents.content: Swedish universities and local school districts' last partnership with a Confucius Institute ended in 2020. Confucius Institutes are language and culture centers run by the People’s Republic of China’s Ministry of Education, which are hosted in more than 500 universities around the world. Critics have raised concerns about incidents of infringement upon intellectual freedom at some Confucius Institutes, whose terms of agreement are often hidden. A former head of propaganda for the Chinese Communist Party has called them "an important part of China’s overseas propaganda set-up." The Confucius Institute of the University of Stockholm was the first to open in Sweden, in 2005, and closed in 2015. University officials expressed opposition to foreign state funding of educational programs, as well as broader concerns over China's repression of Uighur minorities, restrictions on freedoms of speech and press, and treatment of dissidents such as arrested publisher Gui Minhai.
incidents.title: Confucius Institutes in Sweden closed over worsening relations, state influence on curriculum

incidents.content:

On March 3, 2022, the US Treasury Department sanctioned 26 individuals and seven entities for spreading disinformation ahead of the war in Ukraine and around a series of other geopolitical flashpoints on behalf of the Russian government. The sanctions targeted employees of the Strategic Culture Foundation, InfoRos, NewsFront, and SouthFront—all of which are Russian intelligence-linked sites that were sanctioned in April 2021. Treasury also designated new sites for being affiliated with the Strategic Culture Foundation, including Odna Rodyna, Rhythm of Eurasia, and Journal Kamerton. The outlets New Eastern Outlook and Oriental Review were sanctioned for being linked to Russia’s foreign intelligence agency. Sanctions also targeted the sites United World International and Geopolitica, which are connected to the Russian nationalists Darya Dugina and Alexander Dugin.

Russian forces have taken over, impersonated, and shutdown local news stations in Ukraine to spread Kremlin-approved content and prevent accurate information from being shared. In April, Ukraine’s State Special Communications Service said eight stations were being used by Russian forces to target local populations in southern Ukraine with disinformation and propaganda. The Kremlin’s strategy involves capturing transmitter towers and switching off access to Ukrainian national programs as well as violently forcing Ukrainian journalists to spread pro-Russian views. If violence doesn’t work, Russian forces have taken over and impersonated media outlets. Without a satellite, citizens in occupied areas only have access to Russian state TV channels. 

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian forces take over Ukrainian media to spread wartime disinformation

In May 2022, Russian officials and state media outlets amplified efforts to frame the United States, the European Union, and other Western allies for global food shortages caused by the war in Ukraine. Kremlin-linked social media accounts argued that Western sanctions and macroeconomic blunders sparked the food crisis, not Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Russian diplomats said that the West “artificially created” the food shortage as a “media stunt.” In June, the Foreign Ministry tweeted a link to an 11-page document, which purported to debunk eight myths pushed by the West about Russia’s role in triggering the food crisis. Moscow-affiliated messengers also blamed Ukraine for blocking food shipments by mining ports and claimed that Ukrainian soldiers had “torched 50,000 tons of grain.” Russia’s Ministry of Defense accused Kyiv of “food terrorism.” On July 22, Russia and Ukraine reached a deal to ensure the safe export of Ukrainian agricultural products, forcing Russia’s propaganda campaign around the issue to shift its focus.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia blames the West for food shortages in disinformation campaign

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Kremlin-linked accounts issued a barrage of denials and unfounded counteraccusations after Ukrainian officials said Russian forces had killed dozens of civilians with a missile that targeted a train station in Kramatorsk. Russian diplomatic accounts claimed a Tochka-U missile was used in the attack and that only Ukrainian forces use that type of weapon. Investigators later found evidence of Russian forces using those missiles. Russian diplomats also argued that “any [social media] user with a basic understanding of physics” could see that the missile came from Ukrainian territory, and they asserted that the serial number on the missile proved it belonged to the Ukrainian army. The Russian Embassy in Canada said the “Kiev junta” had ordered “neo-Nazis” to carry out the “heinous crime.” That same post argued that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was “controlled by the Western intelligence services to destroy the people of Ukraine.” Other diplomatic accounts argued that Ukraine wanted to “maximize the number of civilian victims” to prevent and deter people from fleeing the country because Ukrainian forces intend to use civilians as “human shields.”

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia blames Ukraine for Kramatorsk railway station attack

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Russian diplomats and state media pushed a high-volume disinformation campaign to discredit reports that Russian troops had murdered citizens in the Ukrainian city of Bucha in April 2022. Kremlin-linked accounts tweeted about “Bucha” in more than 1,200 posts between April 3 and April 10, 2022. State media claimed that the Bucha massacre was a “fake attack” staged by actors. Diplomats suggested that the United States and NATO “ordered” the false flag operation to sabotage peace talks and to justify additional sanctions against Russia. Russia’s foreign intelligence service said the head of the U.K.’s MI6 spy agency, Richard Moore, might have planned the Bucha incident. Moscow-affiliated accounts also insisted that the Western media was an “accomplice” to the fake attack. At the same time, Russian propagandists claimed that the dead bodies were real but that the people had been killed by Ukrainian forces for supporting Russia. One diplomatic account put out a 16-tweet-long thread, which asserted that the chronology of events proved Russia’s innocence and that a Ukrainian neo-Nazi had ordered the killings in Bucha. Officials and state-backed outlets predicted that “Ukraine and its Western propaganda-tutors” were planning to stage another attack to blame Russia. The U.S. State Department and independent investigators have disproven Russia’s narratives around Bucha. 

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia pushes disinformation about the Bucha massacre

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Russian hackers tried to bring down a Ukrainian power grid, which would have caused blackouts for over 2 million people, Ukrainian government officials and the Slovakian cybersecurity firm ESET said on April 12. The hacking group, known as Sandworm, successfully infiltrated and disrupted the industrial control system of one power station, but defenders were able to prevent electrical outages, Ukrainian officials said. Leaked Ukrainian government documents, though, say that Russian hackers had temporarily shut down nine electric substations. Sandworm initially compromised the Ukrainian power station in February, around the time of Russia’s invasion, according to reports. The group used a malware variant called Industroyer2 that sought to damage high-voltage power substations. A destructive wiper malware known as CaddyWiper was also planted on systems to erase evidence of the attack. Sandworm was behind two pervious hacks that disrupted power supplies in Ukraine.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia attempts to hack Ukrainian energy provider

Russia carried out a cyberattack that took down satellite communications in Ukraine only hours before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine began in late February, U.S. and European officials determined. The cyberattack hit ViaSat’s KA-SAT system, which provides high-speed satellite communications to Ukraine, disconnecting thousands of Ukrainians from the internet. The hack disrupted Ukraine’s ability to communicate with troops during the invasion, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated. The effects of the cyberattack spilled over into the broader region, interrupting satellite communications in the EU and affecting 5,800 wind turbines in Germany. U.S. officials suspect that Russia’s military intelligence agency, the GRU, carried out the cyberattack by hacking and sabotaging ground-based modems, which disrupted communication with the satellites.    

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian cyberattack takes down satellite communications in Ukraine

The Security Service of Ukraine (SSU) identified five members of Russia’s Federal Security Service (FSB) as a part of the Armagedon hacking group, which is known to have conducted more than 5,000 cyberattacks against Ukrainian public officials and critical infrastructure entities since 2014. The SSU said Armagedon’s goals were to gain control of critical infrastructure facilities, collect intelligence, block information systems, and conduct influence operations. Ukrainian intelligence services utilized FSB software to maintain anonymity while intercepting communications between and gathering evidence against the hackers. The actors have been notified of suspicion of treason and charged in absentia.   

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Ukraine identifies Russian hackers targeting government, infrastructure

Ukrainian authorities said that Russia was responsible for a cyberattack that temporarily took down 70 government websites on January 14, 2022. “All the evidence points to Russia being behind the cyberattack,” the Ukrainian digital transformation ministry said. The hack left a message on targeted websites reading, “Be afraid and expect the worst.” The threat was written in three languages—Ukrainian, Polish, and Russian—and referred to a point of tension between Poland and Ukraine, which was likely an attempt to frame Poland for the breach. Microsoft warned that the website defacements were designed to distract from a more destructive malware, which disguised itself as ransomware but was designed to disable impacted systems.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

U.S. intelligence officials determined that Russia was “laying the groundwork” to create a pretext to further invade Ukraine, White House press secretary Jen Psaki said on January 14, 2022. Russia had launched a disinformation campaign about an imminent Ukrainian attack on Russian forces, while the Kremlin had sent operatives to sabotage Moscow-backed groups in Ukraine, Psaki said. Russia’s disinformation operation sought to blame the West for escalating tension, highlight Ukraine’s alleged humanitarian abuses, and encourage support for Russian troops. The White House reported seeing a 200 percent increase in the daily average of Russian-language content pushing those narratives from November to December of 2021.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia prepares “false flag” operation in eastern Ukraine as pretext for invasion

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Russian intelligence operatives worked with current and former Ukrainian officials to spread disinformation intended to undermine the Ukrainian government, according to U.S. sanctions announced on January 20, 2022. Russian actors coordinated with two opposition members of the Ukrainian parliament, Taras Kozak and Oleh Voloshyn, to turn public opinion against Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Kozak owns several news channels, which he used to amplify disinformation about the Zelensky administration. Kremlin-linked agents also worked with two former Ukrainian officials, Volodymyr Oliynyk and Vladimir Sivkovich, to build support for Ukraine to formally cede Crimea to Russia and to collect information on Ukraine’s critical infrastructure.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russia works with Ukrainian officials to spread disinformation

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On January 22, 2022, the United Kingdom said that Russia was organizing a plot to install a pro-Kremlin leader in Ukraine. A communiqué by the U.K. Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office alleged that Russia was considering former Ukrainian MP Yevhen Murayev as a potential candidate. The statement noted that four other former high-ranking Ukrainian officials had been linked to Russia’s intelligence services. Some of those former officials had been in contact with Russian officers planning an attack on Ukraine, according to the announcement. The United Kingdom provided little information on the intelligence that led to the accusation. U.S. officials, though, supported the charges. Russia denied being involved in the plot. The U.K. warning came as Russia was massing tens of thousands of troops near Ukraine’s border.    

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: UK accuses Russia of planning to install pro-Kremlin leader in Ukraine

[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On February 3, 2022, U.S. officials warned that Russia planned to use a fake video of a Ukrainian attack as a pretense to further invade the country. Russia had recruited people to stage the fabricated assault, which would have likely included “graphic scenes” of false explosions and shown NATO-supplied weapons being used, the Biden administration said. Russia’s military intelligence agency, known as the GRU, was involved in planning the video. The Kremlin intended to use the video to accuse Ukraine of genocide against Russian-speakers, according to U.S. officials, who did not provide much evidence to support the accusation, citing concerns about revealing the sources and methods used to collect the intelligence.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: U.S. warns Russia may use fake video as pretext to further invade Ukraine

On 24 June 2021, Ukraine decided to take its name off a joint statement urging for a detailed investigation into the human rights situation in Xinjiang, China’s westernmost territory, after Chinese authorities threatened to withhold COVID-19 vaccine shipments. The joint statement, led by Canada and signed by more than 40 countries, asked that the Chinese government allow international independent observers in Xinjiang. According to two anonymous Western diplomats, Chinese officials pressured their Ukrainian counterparts by warning they would block a scheduled shipment of over 500,000 Chinese-made COVID-19 vaccine doses. As of July 2021, Ukraine was no longer included in the list of countries supporting the joint statement. While Chinese officials denied that they had pressured Ukraine, British media subsequently reported that Beijing and Kiev agreed an investment deal just weeks after the latter removed its name from the joint statement. The Chinese authorities have committed serious human rights violations against the Uyghur ethnic group in Xinjiang, with several countries accusing the Chinese state of genocide.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: China withholds vaccines from Ukraine over UN joint statement

In early 2021, the Russian government-linked cyberespionage group Gamaredon engaged in a spear-phishing operation targeting Ukrainian government officials, according to CyberScoop. Ukraine’s main security services, the SBU, has accused Gamaredon-linked hackers of working on behalf of Russia’s Federal Security Service, or FSB. According to the cybersecurity firm Anomali, which exposed the operation targeting Ukrainian officials, the hacking group sent emails posing as trusted contacts and distributed malware through deceptive .docx attachments. The documents centered on current political and security affairs and were likely private and legitimate files illicitly obtained and weaponized by the hacking group. Anomali was unable to determine the ultimate objective of the group’s campaign.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Suspected Russian state-sponsored cyberespionage group targets Ukrainian officials

In January 2019, Ukrainian officials reported that Russian hackers were likely behind an uptick in cyberattacks targeting election servers and personal computers of election staff in the run up to Ukraine’s March elections. Officials described how hackers used virus-infected greeting cards, shopping invitations, offers for software updates, and other malicious phishing materials in an effort to steal passwords and personal information. The hackers also purchased personal details of election officials on the dark web.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian hackers behind surge in cyberattacks targeting Ukrainian election

In May 2017, Russian government-connected hackers conducted an organized cyberattack on President Petro Poroshenko's website, according to Ukrainian officials. The attack, which briefly disabled the website, was reportedly in response to Kyiv's decision to impose sanctions against a number of major Russian Internet businesses, according to Ukrainian officials.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Ukraine accuses Russia of cyberattack following sanctions
