According to Ukrainian counterintelligence and Western intelligence agencies, APT28, a Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacking group, targeted a chlorine plant in Ukraine with a malware attack in July 2018. Plant workers were able to thwart the attack, which reportedly aimed to install malware to snoop on encrypted web traffic, establish a backdoor on compromised devices, and allow for disruptions of plant operations. Some aspects of the malware code overlapped with a previously identified malware known as BlackEnergy, which was used to target a Ukrainian power distribution station.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian hackers target Ukrainian chemical plant

incidents.content: State-supported Russian actors, including Patriarch Kirill, the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, have attacked the Orthodox Church of Ukraine and the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople before and after the Ukrainian body was granted autocephaly, or religious independence. Reports suggest that Russian operatives conducted cyberattacks on Ukrainian church entities as well as those of the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, while Moscow has cut all ties with the Constantinople branch of Orthodox Christianity and any other churches, such as those in Greece and Alexandria, that supported the decision. Even Vladimir Putin himself has weighed in, criticizing the Ukrainian branch and warning of possible bloodshed if rights to worship were not properly respected.
incidents.title: Russia interferes in the affairs of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine, attacks Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople after autocephaly grant

Gamaredon, a pro-Russian Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) that has been in operation since at least 2013, has in the months of late 2019 and early 2020 seriously ramped up the scale of its operations against the Ukrainian government. It has particularly targeted Ukrainian defense establishments, such as the National Ground Forces Academy, as well as assisting separatist forces of the so-called Donetsk and Luhansk Peoples Republics. Researchers at Sentinel Labs have linked the increase in cyberattacks by Gamaredon to the curtailment of kinetic ones in response to France-led negotiations on the status of the Donbas at Normandy.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Pro-Russian Advanced Persistent Threat Gamaredon ramps up scale of operations against Ukrainian government, including major defense establishments.

incidents.content: Russian state-sponsored media outlets RT and Sputnik launched a global, multilingual information operation to deny and obfuscate the Russian government's violation of Ukrainian sovereignty and international law on November 25, 2018 when Russian border patrol boats fired upon and seized three Ukrainian vessels and 24 Ukrainian sailors in the Kerch Strait. RT and Sputnik both falsely asserted that the Ukrainian vessels were in Russian territorial waters, and articles from Sputnik's French and German language services falsely indicated that Ukraine had planned to destroy the Kerch Strait Bridge between the Russian mainland and Crimea, currently under construction by Russia in violation of international law.  Sputnik English also carried a story that claimed Ukraine's western allies had prior knowledge of Ukrainian plans to "provoke" Russia by sending Ukrainian navy vessels through the international waters. Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Maria Zakharova stated on Russia's Channel One, "This is a deliberate provocation, of  which, I have no doubt, some of  our Western partners at  least knew, or maybe even took part in  the planning. All this is not accidental." Russian state-sponsored media outlets frequently attempt to blame the Ukrainian government for what the Russian government calls "provocative" acts.
incidents.title: Russian messaging muddies facts around Russian attack on Ukrainian navy vessels in Kerch Strait

incidents.content: According to Reuters, cybersecurity firm ESET accused Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers of infecting three energy and transport companies in Ukraine and Poland with new malware, potentially with the intention of planning destructive Cyber Operations.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers infect energy and transport companies in Ukraine and Poland

incidents.content: In April 2018, Ukraine’s security service (SBU) exposed a pro-Russia hate group seeking to foment inter-ethnic hostility in the northern Ukrainian city of Chernihiv. The Kyiv Post reported that SBU operatives determined the group was connected to Russian security services when one of the organization’s leaders attempted to contact Russian security service personnel via social media. SBU agents said the group disseminated anti-Semitic and pro-Russia propaganda throughout Ukraine.
incidents.title: Ukraine's SBU reportedly exposes Russia-supported hate group in Ukraine

incidents.content: In March 2018, Russian state-sponsored media outlets and other pro-Russia outlets propagated false reports that the Ukrainian military was planning to launch a punitive campaign against the Donbas, according to StopFake. As the basis for their claims, the sites manipulated a speech by Ukraine’s Military General Staff Colonel Yuriy Bobrov on March 6, 2018 concerning Ukraine’s February 28 legislation on the re-integration of the Donbas and the de-occupation of Crimea. StopFake debunked the report, stating that Bobrov made no mention of an offensive campaign against the Donbas in his speech.
incidents.title: Russian media falsely claim Ukraine ordered a punitive campaign against Donbas

incidents.content: On October 24, 2017, a wave of Cyber Operations crippled Kyiv’s subway ticketing system, Odessa international airport’s operating systems, and three Russian media outlets. Ukraine's Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) released a statement calling the ransomware attack, identified as BadRabbit, a threat to Ukrainian national security and urged Ukrainian companies to remain on high alert. Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty reported that the Ukrainian government suspected Russian state involvement. Reuters concluded the same Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers who conducted the NotPetya ransomware attack in June 2017 also likely orchestrated the BadRabbit ransomware attack.
incidents.title: Russia military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers  suspected of launching BadRabbit cyberattack against Ukraine

incidents.content: On June 27, 2017, one day prior to Ukraine's Constitution Day, according the CIA, hackers connected to the Russian military intelligence service (GRU) targeted Ukraine’s financial sector with the NotPetya virus that evolved into the most costly and damaging malware attack to date. Experts estimate that the NotPetya virus cost the world an estimated $1.2 billion dollars, as the ransomware crippled the operating systems of international businesses and organizations in over 150 countries.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers launch NotPetya malware attack

incidents.content: The Atlantic Council’s Digital Forensic Research Lab (DFR Lab) reported that on January 4, 2017, the pro-Russia Donbas News International (DNI) agency published a false story claiming that the United States sent 3,600 tanks to Europe in preparation for war with Russia. According to official U.S. military sites and several reputable Western media sites, the American military transported 87 tanks to Europe for a routine nine month rotation. Russian state-sponsored outlets, such as RIA Novosti, and other pro-Russian media outlets reposted the story.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets amplify disinformation spread by news agency from Russia-backed separatist region

incidents.content: On December 17, 2016, Russian state-connected hacker group Sandworm again triggered a power outage in Kyiv, this time leaving 700,000 Ukrainians without electricity. The Cybersecurity firm Dragos Inc. linked the power outage to Sandworm with "high confidence." Ukrainian energy company Ukrenergo representatives said that the hackers sent phishing emails to Ukrenergo employees to harvest login credentials.
incidents.title: Russian state-connected hacker group Sandworm takes offline Ukraine's energy grid for second time

incidents.content: In July 2016, several Russian state-sponsored media outlets, including RIA Novosti, NTV, Gazeta.ru, Lenta.ru and others, ran a string of false stories claiming that ISIS operates training camps on Ukrainian territory, according to StopFake. Russian embassies in the UK and in Canada amplified the false stories on Twitter.
incidents.title: Several Russian state-sponsored media outlets spread disinformation claiming Ukraine serves as ISIS training site

incidents.content: On December 23, 2015, iSight Partners attributed an attack on Kyiv's power grid to Russian state-connected hacker group Sandworm. The hackers shut down electric substations located around Kyiv, affecting an estimated 225,000 Ukrainians.
incidents.title: Russian state-connected hacker group Sandworm takes offline Ukraine's energy grid

incidents.content: In March 2015, Russian state-sponsored news outlet TASS fabricated reports that ethnic Hungarians living in western Ukraine’s Transcarpathia region convened a congress to demand autonomy from Ukrainian. The Economist described the Russian disinformation campaign as an attempt to stir ethnic hostility with the objective of fostering a separatist movement. Pro-Russian news sites continue to circulate false reports of escalating ethnic tensions in Transcarpathia. In March 2018, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko warned Ukrainians in a tweet that Russian security services endeavored to foment anti-Western, Eurosceptic propaganda in Transcarpathia.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet fabricates reports of separatism in Transcarpathia

incidents.content: Information security service firm Secureworks indicated that Russian military intelligency agency (GRU)-connected hacker group Fancy Bear, or APT 28, attempted to gain access to the correspondence of senior Orthodox religious leaders in Turkey. The targets included top aides to Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I. Bartholomew I possesses final decision making authority to deny or grant Ukraine’s petition to separate from the Russian Orthodox Church. Russian state-sponsored media outlets, such as Sputnik and RT, frequently promote disinformation to undermine Ukraine’s petition to form its own church.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers attempt to access correspondence of senior religious leaders in Turkey

incidents.content: Between 2015 and 2017, officers from Russia's Military Intelligence Agency (GRU) targeted key infrastructure and undisclosed businesses in Ukraine with Cyber Operations according to a report by the UK Government's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC).  NCSC experts assess that GRU officers mounted a ransomware attack against the Kyiv metro network and the Odessa airport using a version of ransomware called "Bad Rabbit." Ransomware encrypts critical documents and coerces victims to pay for the decryption of their own sensitive materials. According to technology magazine the Verge, the attack even affected the safety control systems of the Chernobyl power station, forcing the facility to shift to manual operations. The attackers simultaneously stole confidential information from several unnamed Ukrainian businesses. The NCSC believes with "high confidence" that GRU officers were behind the attacks, and that the actors likely belonged to the same group as the suspects in the March 2018 Salisbury chemical attack. The NCSC report also provided evidence of three other Russian government Cyber Operations against targets in the United States, United Kingdom, and Canada between 2015 and 2017.
incidents.title: Russian Military Intelligence Agency (GRU) targets Ukrainian businesses and infrastructure with cyberattack

incidents.content: During U.S. Vice President Joe Biden’s official visit to Ukraine on November 20-21, 2014, Russia-backed hacktivist group CyberBerkut hacked several Ukrainian government websites and programmed them to display messages representing Biden as a fascist. BBC News reported that CyberBerkut claimed it obtained confidential U.S.-Ukraine military documents in the cyber breach; however, neither Ukrainian nor American officials confirmed that CyberBerkut accessed any sensitive military information.
incidents.title: Russian-backed hackers breach Ukrainian government websites to spread disinformation about U.S. Vice President Biden

incidents.content: In March 2017, Ukrainian hackers exposed Alyaksandr Usovsky, who according to The New York Times is "a Belarus-born writer, Russian-nationalist agitator and ideological hired gun," as the curator of a wide-reaching network of pro-Russia nationalists and radicals in Eastern Europe laboring to escalate tensions between Ukraine and neighboring Poland. In fall 2014, Usovsky transferred more than $100,000 to pro-Kremlin activists in Poland for the purpose of organizing rallies to protest the government of Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko. The New York Times reported that Usovsky directed projects to target fringe political groups in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Moldova, Poland, Slovakia and Ukraine with the financial assistance of Russian government-connected oligarch Konstantin Malofeyev. Malofeyev is sanctioned by the EU and the U.S. Treasury Department for “fund[ing] separatist activities in eastern Ukraine.”
incidents.title: Emails reveal Russian government-connected oligarch funded network of pro-Russia fringe political groups in Eastern Europe

incidents.content: Since the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17) on July 17, 2014 over eastern Ukraine, Russian state-sponsored media outlets have consistently spread false information and conspiracy theories concering the downing. According to Australian and Dutch investigators, Russia is responsible for downing the passenger jet. EU vs. Disinfo reported that Russian state-sponsored media outlets, such as Lifenews, Rossiya, RT, and many more, continue to falsely claim that Dutch investigators tasked by the international community with investigating the MH17 wreckage found evidence suggesting Ukrainian and EU involvement. The Russian state-sponsored media outlets often falsely allege that Dutch investigators found no evidence implicating Russia or Russian-backed forces in the downing.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets blame the West for the downing of MH17

incidents.content: On July 12, 2014, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Channel One aired an inflammatory story claiming that the Ukrainian military crucified a three year old child in the Ukrainian city of Slovyansk. An individual interviewed by Channel One claimed that the Ukrainian military dragged the child’s mother through the center of town on a tank. Pro-Russian ideologue Victor Dugin and others later posted similar stories on pro-Russian media platforms. The Moscow Times reported that a journalist from the independent Russian periodical Novaya Gazeta later travelled to Slovyansk and debunked the Channel One broadcast. The Novaya Gazeta journalist reportedly interviewed dozens of Slovyansk locals, none of whom confirmed the events.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet airs false story of Ukrainian military crucifying a child

incidents.content: On May 22, 2014, Russian government-connected hacktivist group CyberBerkut successfully penetrated the Ukrainian Central Election Commission’s (CEC) voting system three days prior to the May 25 presidential election. According to Ukraine’s security service (SBU), the hackers manipulated election data in favor of a far-right candidate. SBU agents determined that a CEC administrator planted a virus within internal CEC systems that permitted CyberBerkut to access the CEC’s digital infrastructure and disable the CEC’s election analytics system. Ukrainian officials also noted the presence of malware developed by Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, on CEC systems. Despite the data breach, CyberBerkut and Fancy Bear did not succeed in changing the ultimate outcome of the election. The Wall Street Journal and the University of Toronto’s Citizen Lab have linked CyberBerkut, a self-proclaimed independent pro-Russian hacktivist group, to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacking group Fancy Bear, or APT 28.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected hacktivist group CyberBerkut breaches Ukraine's Election Commission

incidents.content: In May 2014, according to The Moscow Times, Russian government-connected hacktivist group CyberBerkut successfully breached the costumer database of Ukrainian lender Privatbank and posted Privatbank clients’ personal information online. CyberBerkut posted a statement on its VKontakte page calling the data breach retribution for the bank’s decision to close its branches in Donetsk and Luhansk. The Wall Street Journal and the University of Toronto’s Citizen Lab have linked CyberBerkut, a self-proclaimed independent pro-Russian hacktivist group, to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacking group Fancy Bear, or APT 28.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected hacktivist group CyberBerkut targets Ukrainian bank

incidents.content: On March 18, 2014, according to a report from Zurich's Center for Security Studies, Russian government-connected hacktivist group CyberBerkut targeted Rivne TV channel in Western Ukraine with a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) cyberattack. The attack coincided with President Putin's signing of the bill to annex Crimea. The Wall Street Journal and the University of Toronto’s Citizen Lab have linked CyberBerkut, a self-proclaimed independent pro-Russian hacktivist group, to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacking group Fancy Bear, or APT 28.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected hacktivist group CyberBerkut targets Ukrainian TV channel

incidents.content: In spring 2014, Ukrainian soldiers started to receive malicious text messages via fake cell towers. For three years, soldiers frequently received demoralizing messages urging them to desert their posts or informing soldiers that their commanders had betrayed them. The Associated Press reported that the sophisticated equipment required to send the messages suggested Russian state involvement.
incidents.title: Russian-backed actors send Ukrainian soldiers false text messages

incidents.content: Since the fall of pro-Russian Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych in February 2014, Russian government officials and state-sponsored media outlets have executed a sustained, concerted disinformation campaign to undermine Ukrainian sovereignty, prevent Ukrainian integration into Euro-Atlantic institutions, and to support Russian efforts to annex Crimea and back separatists in eastern Ukraine. Disinformation narratives have targeted a variety of subjects and include a wide range of narratives, from claims of Ukrainian corruption to assertions that the Ukrainian military shot-down Malaysian Airlines Flight 17. According to The Atlantic, these claims are often contradictory and implausible.
incidents.title: Russian officials and state-sponsored media outlets target Ukraine in long-term disinformation campaign

incidents.content: Since 2014, Russia has provided extensive, wide-ranging support to Eastern Ukrainian separatists. As the Institute for the Study of War (ISW) notes, Moscow uses “[private military company] Wagner, nationalist or extreme leftist groups, and public and online recruiting campaigns” to recruit manpower for the separtists, while providing the separatists with funding, weapons and military equipment, training, and advisors. Russian troops have even fought on the frontlines in support of the separatists. As ISW writes, “The Kremlin is the guarantor of the survival of its separatist proxies… [who] could not continue to fight without the support of the Kremlin.”
incidents.title: Russia sponsors separatist proxies in Eastern Ukraine

incidents.content: In April 2010, Ukraine's pro-Russia president Viktor Yanukovych signed the Kharkiv Accords, which provided Ukraine with a significant discount on natural gas supplies in exchange for the extension of Russia’s lease on a naval base located on the Crimean peninsula. The Kharkhiv Accords exemplified Russia's use of gas as a foreign policy bargaining chip, which The Guardian described as "yet another example of Russia endeavoring to ensure its continued hold on Ukraine."
incidents.title: Pro-Russia Ukrainian President Yanukovych signs the Kharkiv Accords

incidents.content: In March 2010, according to the New Jersey Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Cell, Russian-state connected hacker group Sandworm launched a two-pronged cyberattack using BlackEnergy 2 code to simultaneously suspend Ukrainian banks’ web services and steal bank customers’ information. BlackEnergy gained notoriety when Russian cyber criminals used the malicious code to target Georgia in 2008 during the Russia-Georgia conflict.
incidents.title: Russian-state connected hacker group Sandworm targets Ukrainian banks

incidents.content: According to Reuters, between 2010 and 2014, the Russian government offered Ukrainian oligarch Dmytro Firtash lucrative business deals in exchange for Firtash’s political support in Ukraine. Firtash and his companies received large loans and lucrative gas contracts from Russian state-owned energy giant Gazprom at significantly discounted prices. Firtash's companies would then sell gas to the Ukrainian government at a high price and pocket the difference. Firtash used his domestic political influence in Ukraine to support Russian government-backed presidential candidate Viktor Yanukovych's successful bid for the 2010 presidency. According to Reuters, the Russian government instructed Firtash to ensure Ukraine’s position in Russia’s sphere of influence.
incidents.title: Russian government supports Ukrainian oligarch for political leverage

incidents.content: On January 1, 2009, Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom halted gas deliveries to Ukraine citing a pricing dispute as the primary reason. In an interview with the Council on Foreign Relations, Russia expert Jeffrey Mankoff stated, "The dispute that led Russia to cut off natural gas to Ukraine and other European states has its origins in differences over pricing as well as Ukraine’s interest in closer ties with the West, including membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)." According to Rice University's Baker Institute, “Ostensibly commercial factors are used to legitimize gas price and/or supply manipulations that, in many instances, are motivated more by geopolitics than by concerns about corporate profitability.”
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Gazprom cuts Ukraine's natural gas supply

incidents.content: On January 1, 2006, Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom halted gas deliveries to Ukraine after talks over pricing and transit terms broke down. Gazprom sought to increase the price Ukraine paid for natural gas from $50 per 1,000 cubic meters to around $220 per 1,000 cubic meters. According to The New York Times, though the "dispute involves complex arguments by Gazprom ... not far below the surface, there is the embarrassing loss of a Kremlin-backed candidate in last winter's Orange Revolution" that brought a pro-Western government to power in Kyiv.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Gazprom cuts Ukraine's natural gas supply

incidents.content:

In March 2022, The Guardian reported that a former Chinese spy who escaped to Norway is receiving constant voice-message threats from members of the Chinese state. Memettursun Omer, a member of the Uyghur minority group, was trained to be a “loyal Chinese citizen” and gather information on Uyghur activists around the world. After defecting he fled to Turkey and later Norway, however his Chinese handlers found him and continued the harassment, allegedly telling him, “Wherever you can see the moon, we can find you.”

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: China harasses former Uyghur spy in Norway

incidents.content: In December 2020, Norway's Police Security Service assessed Russian hackers as the culprits behind a cyberattack and data breach of parliamentary accounts. Multiple email accounts were compromised, and investigators noted that in some cases, "sensitive" content was extracted. APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, is a Russian hacker group that is believed to be associated with Russia's GRU military intelligence agency that has been blamed for carrying out numerous cyberattacks on Western governments, think tanks, and corporations in recent years.
incidents.title: Russian hackers accused of operation targeting Norwegian parliament

incidents.content: In February 2017, the Norwegian Police Security Service (PST) announced that the Russian hacker group Cozy Bear, or APT29, which is connected to the Federal Security Service (FSB) and Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR), targeted civil servants' e-mail accounts and Norway's Labor Party in a large-scale cyberattack launched in fall 2016. Cozy Bear employed spearphishing techniques in an effort to compromise nine webmail accounts belonging to Norwegian civil servants. Labor party spokesman Martin Bernsen told reporters that an unidentified foreign intelligence service alerted the Norwegian government to the ongoing Russian cyberattack.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored hacking group Cozy Bear targets Norway's Labor Party

incidents.content: In January 2017, the Norwegian Police Security Service (PST) accused the Russian intelligence agency SVR of attempting to prevent the Nobel Prize Committee from awarding the 2015 Nobel Peace prize to Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko. PST stated that on June 10, two SVR employees operating under the cover of Russian Embassy staff met with Olav Njølstad, the director of the Norwegian Nobel Institute, to discuss collusion between Ukraine and the United States to influence the prize committee's decision. Oslo labeled the meeting an effort by the Russian government to discredit Poroshenko and Ukraine. Russia denies the allegations.
incidents.title: Norwegian intelligence agency accuses Russian intelligence officers (SVR) of spreading disinformation targeting Ukrainian President

incidents.content: In August 2017, popular Norwegian tabloid Dagbladet reported several instances of Russian state-sponsored media outlets alleging that the sexual abuse of children is rampant in Norway and sanctioned by the authorities. Rumors of widespread, state-condoned pedophilia in Norway began in March 2012 when a Russian woman named Irina Bergset claimed that her Norwegian ex-husband sexually assaulted their son. These stories are circulated by Russian state-sponsored media outlets, according to EU vs Disinfo.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets allege systemic child abuse and pedophilia in Norway

incidents.content: After the Nobel committee, based in Oslo, Norway, awarded the 2010 prize to Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo (imprisoned on nominal charges of "inciting subversion of state power"), China broke off negotiations for a free trade agreement. The negotiations did not resume until 2016, when the two countries restored diplomatic relations. Norway's fishing, energy, and telecommunications industries had the most to lose in the suspended trade negotiations. In addition, China blocked Norwegian officials, including a former prime minister, from getting visas for travel to China. The Chinese government also kept Norway off a list of countries whose citizens could travel to and stay in Beijing for up to 72 hours without a visa. All other European countries had been put on the approved list. Diplomatic contacts were not restored until December 2016, when Norway issued a statement effectively apologizing for not supporting Chinese sovereignty over its internal affairs. In the intervening period, the Norwegian government had declined a potential 2014 meeting with the Dalai Lama, who China's government considers a separatist.
incidents.title: Norway visas to China blocked over Nobel award to dissident

incidents.content: Norwegian salmon exports to China faced an effective ban after Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo was awarded the 2010 Nobel prize. Though bilateral trade increased nearly 50% in 2011, salmon sales declined 62% in the same period, damaging a key Norwegian industry. Norway's government reported the dispute to the World Trade Organization in 2011.
incidents.title: Norwegian salmon banned in retaliation for Nobel award to Chinese dissident

incidents.content: OCCRP reported in October 2021 that Huawei had paid former Serbian state telecom executive Igor Jecl more than USD1 million through an offshore company in the British Virgin Islands. The investigation into the Pandora Papers revealed several well-remunerated contracts between Huawei and Jecl via offshore companies based in Panama and the British Virgin Islands. For instance, in 2014 the Chinese tech giant agreed to pay Jecl 359,000 euros (over USD493,000) to organize meetings between Huawei executives and Serbian telecom officials, as well as to help the Chinese giant “obtain approvals and licenses”. The last leaked contract dated to early 2014, but Jecl continued to file invoices through offshore companies into 2016. In 2016, Huawei received a 150-million-euro contract to overhaul Serbian telecommunication infrastructure. In 2017, Huawei became a strategic partner of the Serbian government, notably tasked with helping establish “smart cities” through the “Safe City” project. As of 2021, the Serbian Interior Ministry planned to install 8,100 Huawei facial recognition cameras throughout the country.
incidents.title: Huawei used offshore company to fund introduction to Serbian officials

incidents.content: In 2019, Chinese and Serbian police officers began to participate in joint patrols in areas of Belgrade, Novi Sad, and Smederevo. Serbian Interior Minister Nebojsa Stephanovic justified the new role of Chinese police officers by pointing to the increase in Chinese tourists in Serbia since a 2017 agreement to not require visas for travel between Serbia and China. Stephanovic explained that Chinese officers made communication between tourists and the police easier, ensuring the security of tourists. In addition to joint patrols, the Chinese officers operate a Chinese-language emergency phone service and visit the areas in which Chinese businesses and citizens are located. However, though the move was justified as protecting tourists, Smederevo and Novi Sad are not tourist cities. A steel mill bought by a Chinese company in 2016 is the largest direct and indirect employer in Smederevo, and the Budapest-Belgrade railway, commissioned as a part of the Belt and Road Initiative, uses Novi Sad as the key base before the Hungarian border.
incidents.title: Chinese-Serbian joint police patrols in key Serbian cities

incidents.content: Recent concerns over the vulnerabilities that 5G will create and the potential for breaches in data privacy have caused many democratic countries to reduce their dependence on Huawei. On 4 September 2020, Belgrade committed to an American agreement not to use 5G equipment from untrusted vendors, largely interpreted to mean the Chinese tech giant. However, a week later, a Huawei Tech Centre opened in Serbia. Belgrade justified the continued partnership by interpreting "untrusted vendors" to mean shoddy craftsmanship, making the partnership between Huawei and the state-owned Telecom Serbia a reasonable step to take to ensure the development and implementation of 5G in Serbia. According to Chinese law, Huawei could be required to provide private data to the Chinese government.
incidents.title: Huawei Tech Centre opens in Serbia a week after a US-Serbia agreement on 5G

incidents.content: On March 20, 2020 the Chinese ambassador to Serbia posted pictures of a new donation of medical equipment on Twitter, showing the brand name He Steel, a Chinese state-owned company and praising Beijing. However, the message omitted to mention that the EU and UNDP has financed and arranged for the flight. Furthermore, the donated equipment was only a small part of the plane's cargo, with the rest being medical supplies purchased from Chinese manufacturers.
incidents.title: Chinese ambassador to Serbia minimizes EU's role in aid delivery

incidents.content: On 22 March, 2020 a Chinese medical team arrived in Serbia as a part of Beijing’s attempt to shift the narrative around COVID-19. By distributing aid during the pandemic, Beijing wanted to shift the blame for the crisis from its own early, opaque policies, in 2019, to Western governments struggling with the virus. The Serbian President, Aleksandar Vucic, was at the airport to greet the medical team. He said that, "Chinese experts are the first to have defeated the virus. From now on, we will do everything they say." He greeted the doctors with elbow bumps, thanked them, and kissed the Chinese flag. Chinese state media and official Twitter accounts actively spread the image of the Vucic kissing the flag and portrayed China as a well-intentioned benefactor.
incidents.title: Chinese state media capitalize on Serbia's need for medical supplies to fight COVID-19

incidents.content: In late February 2020, Serbia's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Ivica Dacic visited China. Upon his return, he told Pink TV, a private broadcaster, "China is the second-largest economy in the world today, so it's not out of the question that [the coronavirus crisis] is part of a special war against China." On March 1, he told the Serbian public broadcaster that China was testing the virus and believed it had been manufactured and brought to China, implying that the outbreak in China which began the pandemic was an attack by a foreign power. The EEAS special report on COVID-19 Disinformation highlights a number of articles published by Chinese state-run media encouraging the spread of this conspiracy theory.
incidents.title: Chinese diplomats inspire conspiracy theories surrounding COVID-19 origin in Serbia

incidents.content: In July 2019, Serbia announced that the Belgrade metro would be built by French companies and the Chinese state-owned company China’s Power Construction Corporation (Powerchina). Since 2014, the project had been discussed and studies carried out in cooperation with the French company Alstom. Two French companies, Powerchina, and members of the Serbian government entered negotiations on the contracts, but the final deal was kept from the public. When Transparency Serbia, the Serbian branch of an NGO that fights corruption, asked for details from the government, the deal was protected as a business secret at the request of Powerchina. Transparency Serbia has accused the deal of being shaped around the needs of the companies involved rather than the needs of the people of Belgrade and of breaking the Law on Public Procurements and the Public-Private Partnership Law. While 80 million euros will be borrowed from France to fund the project, the budget classifies the remaining 500 million as "project loans with foreign investment corporations, funds and banks."
incidents.title: State-owned Powerchina encourages opacity surrounding the construction of Belgrade's metro

incidents.content: In 2017, Huawei entered into an agreement with the Serbian government to develop the "Safe City" project, in which Huawei worked with Serbia to upgrade police technology. Under terms that were not made public, Huawei installed cameras with facial and license plate recognition technology in Belgrade. At the end of 2018, 100 cameras were installed at 60 sites. At the beginning of 2019, Serbia made the project public as Huawei added 1000 cameras in 800 sites within Belgrade. Serbian authorities turned down civil society organizations’ information requests on the project. In August 2019, the Personal Data Protection Law, a national law developed to comply with EU standards on data protection, came into effect. This mandated the release of an impact assessment of the project’s data processing. Both the Serbian Commissioner for personal data, as well as local NGOs found that the impact assessment that was eventually completed in September 2019 did not fulfill the Personal Data Protection Law’s requirements. According to Italian think-tank ISPI, Serbian civil society is concerned that the surveillance system is used "to control and monitor the participants of the anti-government [protests]." According to Chinese law, Huawei could be required to provide private data to the Chinese government.
incidents.title: Huawei deploys facial recognition technology in Serbia in opaque circumstances

incidents.content: According to EUobserver, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik conducted a disinformation campaign in late 2015 during a time of protests in Kosovo and Montenegro aimed at stopping an EU accord on better relations with Serbia and NATO accession. Sputnik published multiple stories accusing the West of promoting instability in the region and planning the overthrow of pro-Kremlin President Milorad Dodik. According to EUobserver, Sputnik became a leading source of information in Serbia following the shut-down of the independent Tanjug news agency in November 2015.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik launches disinformation campaign during tumultuous period in the Balkans

incidents.content: In 2014, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development dismissed a Serbian project to build a coal power plant for its detrimental effects on the environment. As a result, China EximBank  stepped in and granted Serbia the loans to build the plant. Several Chinese companies, including state-owned Power Construction Corp of China (PowerChina) and China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) were hired for the construction, which began before the Environmental Impact Survey had been completed in 2015. Moreover, experts who eventually examined the completed Environmental Impact Survey and the Feasibility Assessment determined that they had likely been manipulated as their conclusions were suspect. Despite statements from PowerChina that the plant would be in line with EU environmental impact standards, experts believe that the new plant will cause excessive pollution both within Serbia and in neighboring EU countries. Furthermore, the plant is not financially viable when the EU Emissions Trading Scheme is taken into account. The official Feasibility Assessment assumes both a lower cost of coal than is currently available and a lower cost of carbon allowances than experts believe possible. And while the government announced the completion of the desulphurization unit, meant to reduce pollution, in 2017, there is no evidence that the unit was ever operational. In 2019, the Serbian Ministry of Environmental Protection opened a public consultation on an environmental impact study for the construction of a desulphurization unit, despite the fact that the government had announced its completion two years prior.
incidents.title: Chinese-funded and -built coal plant in Serbia lacks transparency

incidents.content: In 2013, former Serbian Foreign Minister Vuk Jeremi? left his position at the UN, became a consultant for CEFC China Energy, a company with links to the United Front. With the help of CEFC funding and influence, Jeremi? established a think tank, the Center for International Relations and Sustainable Development (CIRSD), in Belgrade. Over the next few years, CEFC continued to fund both Jeremi? and the CIRSD, and the think tank held events and published papers extolling the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and explaining how a strong relationship with China benefits Serbia. Multiple scandals broke around Jeremi? ‘s associates' involvement in corruption and bribery. China uses "United Front" work to co-opt and neutralize sources of potential opposition to the policies and authority of its ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP). The CCP’s United Front Work Department (UFWD)—the agency responsible for coordinating these kinds of influence operations—mostly focuses on the management of potential opposition groups inside China, but it also has an important foreign influence mission.
incidents.title: CEFC help Vuk Jeremic establish a pro-Beijing think-tank in Serbia

incidents.content: In November 2013, Beijing, Belgrade, and Budapest agreed to construct the Budapest-Belgrade railway as a part of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), a Chinese project aimed at rebalancing global trade around China. The original idea was to build a high speed railway reaching all the way to the Greek port Piraeus, which state-owned Chinese company COSCO operates. Though there was little demand for trade along the route from Belgrade to Budapest, it was expected that other BRI infrastructure projects would complement this one and generate revenue for the three states. However, rising European distrust of BRI and clashes with European Union regulations have slowed the project and doused European enthusiasm for further contracts. In addition, Serbian concerns over the high price have downgraded the project from a high speed train to a 200 km/hr train. These setbacks are of little concern to Beijing, which profits from the project no matter what. The Export-Import Bank of China is financing 85% of the infrastructure project through loans to Serbia and Hungary. Projections estimate that it will take Serbia thousands of years to pay back the $1.3 billion loan. Furthermore, two Chinese railway companies have been contracted to build the railway, China Railway International and China Communications Construction Company, as well as the Russian RDZ International. In 2020, Hungary classified the documents detailing the project's financing by a Chinese state bank for ten years.
incidents.title: Financially unsustainable Budapest-Belgrade railway proceeds thanks to Chinese state bank loan

incidents.content:

Vuk Jeremic was the Serbian Minister of Foreign Affairs until he became a president of the U.N. General Assembly in 2012. CEFC China Energy, a company with links to the United Front, allegedly donated to Jeremic and two other U.N. General Assembly presidents. CEFC helped Jeremic increase his influence, benefiting both parties as Jeremic used this influence to help CEFC establish contacts and make deals. CEFC also arranged speeches and meetings with world leaders, often including both Jeremic and Patrick Ho, a Chinese politician arrested for bribery in November 2017. Having influence inside the U.N. allows Beijing to push for human rights norms which reflect Communist Party values and frame its government's actions in a better light. China uses "United Front" work to co-opt and neutralize sources of potential opposition to the policies and authority of its ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP). The CCP’s United Front Work Department (UFWD)—the agency responsible for coordinating these kinds of influence operations—mostly focuses on the management of potential opposition groups inside China, but it also has an important foreign influence mission.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: CEFC donates to UN General Assembly President Vuk Jeremic, Jeremic spreads CEFC influence

incidents.content: On April 25, 2012, in accordance with a 2009 deal between Serbia’s pro-Russian Foreign Minister Ivica Dacic and Russian Defense Minister Sergey Shoigu, the Russian-Serbian Humanitarian Center (RSHC) opened in Nis, Serbia. Western analysts have since described the center as a military and intelligence outpost for Russia in the Balkans. In May 2017, Russia began to pressure the Serbian government to grant diplomatic status to the Russian staff working at the RSHC. In January 2018, Bosnian news site Zurnal reported that elements of Republika Srpska (RS) President Milorad Dodik’s personal paramilitary force trained at the center.
incidents.title: Russian government establishes so-called Russian-Serbian Humanitarian Center (RSHC) in Nis, Serbia

incidents.content: On January 29, 2012, Russian Orthodox Church Patriarch Kirill stated that Kosovo Serbs "live just like in concentration camps" and "are not even given a basic right to life." Kirill also accused the "western media" of "publishing intentionally twisted information about the Miloševi? regime’s atrocities against Kosovo Albanians by exaggerating the number of victims of ethnic cleansing carried out by the Serbian police in the province." According to The New York Times, the Russian government maintains a close alliance with the Orthodox Church, which has proved to be a "powerful tool" for expanding Russian influence.
incidents.title: Russian Orthodox Church Patriarch spreads disinformation about Kosovo Serbs and Western media coverage of Yugoslav wars

incidents.content: On December 21, 2011, Serbian gas monopoly Srbijagas agreed to a ten-year deal with Russian energy giant Gazprom to import Russian natural gas at a discounted price. Under the deal, Gazprom would send five billion cubic meters of gas to Serbia per year. According to a European Parliament study, long-term supply contracts between Russian energy companies, in particular Gazprom, and European importers increase the purchasing country's dependence on Russian energy supplies by locking in energy purchases for the duration of the contract.
incidents.title: Serbian gas monopoly signs 10-year deal with Gazprom

incidents.content: On February 3, 2009, Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom finalized the acquisition of a 51 percent stake in Serbia’s state-owned oil monopoly NIS for 400 million euros. The acquisition was in accordance with a purchase agreement signed between Gazprom Neft (a Gazprom subsidiary) and the Serbian government on December 24, 2008. According to Reuters, analysts argued that Gazprom's 400 million euro offer was well below market value for the company. According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Kremlin Playbook, Russian foreign direct investment in Europe targets strategic companies in the energy sector to expand its dominance of the industry.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom acquires controlling stake of Serbia's state owned oil monopoly

incidents.content: In October 2008, Russian state-owned energy giant Gazprom pressured its Serbian counterpart Srbijagas into a contract with the Gazprom-owned company YugoRosGas in order to expand Russian leverage over Serbia's energy market. A former Serbian official alleged that Gazprom had presented the Serbs with an ultimatum to either sign a deal with YugoRosGas or Gazprom would not sell gas to Serbia. According to Roman Kupchinsky of the Jamestown Foundation, the officials involved in the deal "were apparently signing contracts with themselves in order to help secure a Gazprom takeover of Serbia's energy market." Russian newspaper Kommersant reported that YugoRosGas was 75 percent owned by Gazprom at the time, and the chairman of Srbijagas also held stock in the company. Other stockholders in YugoRosGas had links to Gazprom, Gazprombank, and other affiliates.
incidents.title: Gazprom implicated in self-dealing with middleman and Serbian client

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On October 26, 2021 Reuters reported that the Chinese embassy in Copenhagen took down posters critical of the Chinese government, which included the Tibetan flag, hung up by Thomas Rhoden, a candidate in local Danish elections. Hung out outside of the Chinese embassy, at least then of the posters were taken down a few hours afterward, ostensibly by embassy employees. Rhoden is the chairman of the Danish China-Critical Society, and the posters were meant to protest a 2012 partnership accord between Danish health authorities and the Chinese province of Jiangsu. Rhoden has since stated that he asked the Danish Foreign Minister to speak with the Chinese embassy to ensure freedom of speech is respected by all in Denmark.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Tibetan flag posters removed from the Chinese Embassy in Denmark

incidents.content: Russia's Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline plans to partially traverse Danish waters in the Baltic Sea, demonstrating another instance of exploiting western European energy needs to pursue geopolitical ambitions. The proposed pipeline would undermine Ukraine's prior contracts to supply gas to European states, and the company behind the pipeline, Gazprom, has been sanctioned on multiple occasions. The United States government and numerous energy experts have spoken out against new Russian gas pipelines to Europe, as they threaten Europe's energy security by making it more dependent on Russian gas imports. Russian actors also appear to have spread disinformation regarding the pipeline, its effects, and U.S. opposition.
incidents.title: Russian Nord Stream 2 pipeline seeks to divide Denmark, European U.S. allies

incidents.content: In March 2018, Greenlandic authorities chose Chinese state-owned enterprise China Communications Construction Company (CCCC) as one of the finalists for a contract to build a major expansion of Greenland's airports. Given the island's GDP is only about $3 billion, Danish and American officials raised concerns that Chinese completion of the roughly $550 million project would grant Beijing an outsized influence. Chinese investments in the neglected infrastructure of the island could also potentially jeopardize a U.S. military installation at Thule, an air base which houses systems for space monitoring and early warning of ballistic missiles. A foreign affairs spokesman for one of Denmark's governing parties commented that "we don't want a communist dictatorship in our own backyard." As a result of this pressure, CCCC withdrew its bid in June 2019.
incidents.title: Chinese state-owned company bids in airport construction contract that would grant it significant influence in Greenland

incidents.content: The Chinese government threatened to cancel a potential trade agreement with Denmark's Faroe Islands if 5G company Huawei did not receive access to the Danish telecommunications market. While the semi-autonomous islands were exploring a contract for a 5G network, the Chinese ambassador allegedly told its representatives that China would sign a trade deal if Huawei got the contract. The small islands, which rely heavily on salmon and other fish exports, including to China, initially attempted to downplay any links between trade and the 5G negotiations.
incidents.title: China threatens to halt Danish trade deal unless Huawei access assured

incidents.content: In early August 2017, Russian online media outlet Kolokol Rossii circulated a fictional report quoting the former Danish agriculture and fisheries minister, Dan Jorgensen, as confirming Denmark’s legalization of the sexual abuse of animals. According to a 2018 minority staff report by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, "one of Russia’s largest TV stations" amplified the story, quickly spreading it to outlets in neighboring Belarus and Georgia. Kolokol Rossii's story follows a similar narrative to previous reporting by Russian state-sponsored media outlets on the prevalence of animal sex abuse and general moral decline in western Europe.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets amplify disinformation claiming that the Danish government legalized the sexual abuse of animals

incidents.content: In January 2018 the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) attributed the massive cyberattack NotPetya that struck Ukraine in summer 2017 to Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers. NotPetya spread to the Danish headquarters of the world’s largest container shipping conglomerate A.P. Moller Maersk Group, affecting the loading and unloading systems of 76 A.P. Moller Maersk Group ports worldwide. The attack cost A.P. Moller Maersk Group an estimated 1.3 to 1.9 billion Danish Krone and created one of the biggest disruptions to ever hit the global shipping industry.
incidents.title: Danish shipping giant hit by Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected NotPetya malware

incidents.content: On January 12, 2017, Danish Defense Minister Claus Hjort Frederiksen warned the Danish public that "state-supported Russian hacker groups" were targeting Danish medical centers and power grids in an ongoing cyber operation and would continue to do so.
incidents.title: Danish Defense Minister warns public of ongoing cyber campaigns by "state-supported Russian hacker groups"

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

In August 2021, the Lithuanian National Security Center, part of the Defense Ministry, released a report warning about "cybersecurity risks" in phones made by Chinese firms Huawei and Xiaomi. Most notably, the center said Xiaomi phones were able to identify and censor phrases, including "Free Tibet" and "Long Live Taiwan Independence," which were against the official stances of the Chinese government. While the ties between Huawei and Chinese authorities are well-documented, this was the first time Xiaomi was explicitly accused of carrying out the CCP's agenda. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Lithuania's cybersecurity body warns against Chinese-made phones

incidents.content:
