At the end of August 2021, Chinese authorities took several measures to restrict trade flows between China and Lithuania over the Baltic nation's decision to seek closer ties with Taiwan. Earlier that month, Lithuania had allowed Taiwan to set up a "Taiwanese" representative office in Vilnius, deviating from Beijing's preferred designation of "Taipei" to name the island. In response, a Chinese state-owned railway operator put the freight link between China and Lithuania "on hold" indefinitely. And on August 22, the Baltic Times reported that Chinese authorities had stopped approving new export permits for Lithuanian food exports to China.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese government disrupts trade with Lithuania over its closer ties with Taiwan

incidents.content: FSB agent Pyotr Chagin, also known by his Lithuanian cover name Petras Taraskevicius, was expelled by Lithuanian authorities after it was discovered he was using a fictitious cover organization called Fond Pobedy, supposedly headquartered in the Russian exclave of Kaliningrad, to develop contacts with Russian compatriot organizations and hold multiple events meant to advance Russia’s narrative concerning the Soviet invasion and occupation of Lithuania post-World War II. These events included “Immortal Regiment” marches and Victory Day concerts in Lithuanian cities. Chagin also collected intelligence for the FSB on Russian compatriot organizations and the ethnic-Russian community in Lithuania.
incidents.title: Russian FSB agent under assumed Lithuanian identity caught running cover organization by Lithuanian authorities.

incidents.content: In March 2020, a new EU report detailed a Russian attributed disinformation campaign working to spread coronavirus-related disinformation to exacerbate the impact of coronavirus, particularly in the West. The report listed Ukraine and Lithuania as two of the main targets of the campaign that is pushing fake news in English, Spanish, Italian, German, and French. In Ukraine, coronavirus-related disinformation led to unruly protests in which police and citizens were injured. These disinformation efforts advance a narrative that coronavirus is weaponized by the West, stoke societal divisions, and undermine the EU's ability to successfully respond to the crisis.
incidents.title: Russia Pushing Coronavirus Lies As Part of Anti-NATO Influence Ops in Europe

incidents.content: Since losing market share dominance over Lithuania’s natural gas market in 2019, Russian state-owned natural gas company Gazprom has sought to strengthen its activities through loyal intermediaries involved in gas trading schemes via companies registered in Lithuania and abroad. Novatek, one such Russian intermediary part owned by Gazprom and by Gennady Tymchenko, a Russian oligarch under U.S. sanctions, has made use of favorable prices from Gazprom to increase its turnover at the terminal in Klapeida, Lithuania, as part of a larger scheme to restore Russian natural gas’ previously dominant position.
incidents.title: Russian state-owned gas companies seek to reassert their dominance of the Lithuanian market through non-transparent means

incidents.content: Starting in 2018, the Russian Investigative Committee held pre-trial investigations and other proceedings against Lithuanian jurists who oversaw the trials of 67 former Soviet officers for crimes against humanity. These crimes took place in the context of the “January Events” of January 11-13, 1991, when Soviet forces killed 14 Lithuanian civilians and injured 702 following Lithuania’s reaffirmation of its independence in March 1990. Russia used these judicial proceedings, and concomitant media campaigns, to legitimize the Soviet Union’s half-century occupation of Lithuania and the actions of the Soviet military in the country as the USSR fell apart, as part of a wider narrative war over the Soviet Union’s actions both generally and in the Baltic after World War II.
incidents.title: Russia uses its judiciary to harass Lithuanian jurists

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

During the August 23, 2019 rally in Vilnius to support Hong Kong's protests, a group of Chinese counterdemonstrators showed up and disrupted the event, with at least two individuals charged by police. Reports suggest that the counter protestors' leader also heads the Chinese Chamber of Commerce in Lithuania, an organization established the same day as the rally. A Lithuanian MP in attendance claims to have seen the Chinese ambassador "personally observing from the side-lines." As a result of Chinese authorities' involvement in the counterprotest, the Lithuanian foreign minister summoned the Chinese ambassador and said that the Chinese diplomats had "crossed the line." A Lithuanian intelligence report in February 2019 added China to the list of intelligence threats to the country, and noted that "China’s domestic policy issues drive Chinese intelligence activities in Lithuania," expressly mentioning Tibet and Taiwan as flashpoints.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese counterdemonstrators disrupt Vilnius rally supporting Hong Kong; official backing suspected

incidents.content: Chinese telecommunications firm Huawei has sought to guarantee access to Baltic states' 5G infrastructure by whatever means available. The Lithuanian intelligence service's 2019 threat assessment did not name Huawei in its unclassified publication, but alluded instead to "Chinese companies" as vectors for intelligence operations. The report mentions tactics targeting influential officials by "giving gifts, paying for trips to China, covering expenses of training and courses," and other inducements to support Chinese positions. In February 2019, Huawei sent its VP of cybersecurity to the region to meet with unnamed government officials, but did not release details of who he contacted or what proposals and incentives were discussed. Although Lithuanian law stipulates that only firms from NATO member states or allied countries are permitted to bid for projects classified as important to national security, two of Lithuania's three main telecom companies, as well as the public broadcaster, already use some Huawei components, and the state-owned energy company is exploring Huawei involvement in its refurbished electrical meters. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Huawei efforts to secure Lithuania 5G access employ methods carrying risks of hidden influence

incidents.content: On January 18, 2018, hackers broke into a Lithuanian news portal and posted a fake story claiming that Lithuania’s Minister of Defense Raimundas Karoblis sexually harassed a journalist and several diplomats, and admitted to being a homosexual. Immediately after the story was posted, the hackers sent the story to Lithuanian government institutions and foreign embassies in Lithuania. According to the Atlantic Council's Digital Forensic Research Lab, "The story was a result of a cyber attack on TV3’s website and was removed within five minutes. The attacker’s IP address was from St. Petersburg, Russia." EU vs. Disinfo found further evidence that the attack originated in Russia, stating "the malicious code was injected into a hidden data field, description of which also shows an error message in Cyrillic (Russian) alphabet allowing investigators to assume that a Russian version of Microsoft Word software was used for the creation of the document." According to the Center for European Policy Analysis, the attack "took place two days after Lithuania released the Magnitsky List, which names 49 Russian citizens banned from entering Lithuania for violating human rights." Russian state-sponsored media outlets had previously targeted the Lithuanian Magnitsky Act with an information operation.
incidents.title: Suspected Russian hackers break into a Lithuanian news portal and spread false stories about the Lithuanian Minister of Defense

incidents.content: In October and November of 2017, the weeks leading up to the passage of the “Lithuanian Magnitsky Act,” Russian state-sponsored media outlets and aligned pro-Russian domestic outlets conducted an information operation to misrepresent the legislation, according to the Atlantic Council's Digital Forensic Research Lab. Russian state-sponsored outlets depicted the legislation, which was intended to “prevent foreigners connected to large-scale money laundering, corruption, or human rights abuses from entering Lithuania,” as the “result of calculative realpolitik, in times of the collapsing trans-Atlantic alliance and growing Russophobia. The DFR Lab reported that several Russian state-sponsored outlets participated in the campaign, including News Front, which "is reportedly funded and controlled by the Russian secret services," as well as Sputnik, and Ria Novosti.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets spread disinformation regarding the Lithuanian "Magnitsky Act"

incidents.content: On February 16, 2017, emails alleging the rape of an underage Lithuanian girl by German NATO soldiers were sent to Lithuanian politicians and media outlets ahead of an upcoming NATO military exercise, according a 2018 minority staff report by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lithuanian authorities found no evidence of the alleged rape, though "pro-Kremlin media outlets" quickly seized on the story, according to the report. NATO officials stated that the Russian government likely perpetrated the information operation.
incidents.title: Emails sent to Lithuanian media and parliament falsely accuse German NATO soldiers stationed in Lithuania of rape

incidents.content: According to the Lithuanian State Security Department's 2018 National Threat Report, Russian state-sponsored media outlets "attempted to portray minor protests [in Lithuania] organized by marginal political movements as large-scale events." The minor protests occured in response to the deployment of NATO enhanced Forward Presence (eFP) forces in Lithuania in 2017, and according to the report, the outlets attempted to use the misrepresentation of the protests to establish a negative image of Lithuania "and to demonstrate ostensible Lithuanian society’s disapproval of domestic and foreign policy."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets exaggerate the scale of protests in Lithuania

incidents.content: On December 9, 2014, unidentified persons distributed a book titled “Red Dalia” to the mailboxes of all 761 members of the European Parliament. The book criticized Lithuanian President Dalia Grybauskait?, who had previously made statements critical of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and President Putin. The EU parliamentary security service eventually stated that their investigation had found that Ellul Bonici – a staffer for the euroskeptic Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy group (EFDD) – and three other men had distributed the books. Bonici's colleagues reported that he made regular visits to the Russian embassy in Brussels and often returned with Russian propaganda, according to The Guardian. Lithuanian officials alleged that the Russian government directed the stunt.
incidents.title: EU staffer with links to Russian embassy distributes propaganda to Parliament members

incidents.content: On March 21, 2014, a Lithuanian court upheld the the suspension of NTV Mir, a TV channel owned by Russian state-owned energy giant Gazprom. The TV station had recently shown a movie that "intentionally spread lies about events in Lithuania on January 13, 1991 ... mocking the Lithuanian people and scorning the memory of the fighters for Lithuanian freedom,” according to Lithuania's media watchdog.
incidents.title: Lithuanian court upholds the ban of Russian state-sponsored TV station for spreading disinformation about the 1991 Soviet invasion of Lithuania

incidents.content: On October 7, 2013, Russia partially banned Lithuanian dairy imports, claiming that its consumer protection agency Rospotrebnadzor had found ‘numerous violations’ of quality and sanitary standards in Lithuanian products. The EU Commission contradicted these claims, stating that it has "complete confidence in the quality of Lithuanian dairy products." The ban came a few weeks before an EU Eastern Partnership Summit in Vilnius where the EU was scheduled to sign a free trade accord with Ukraine and take further steps toward adopting similar agreements with Moldova and Georgia. According to the Latvian Institute of International Affairs, Rospotrebnadzor's decision was designed to intimidate Lithuanian politicians and steer them toward policies friendlier toward Russia, and also to demonstrate to Ukraine, Moldova, and Georgia that closer relations with Europe would have negative economic consequences.
incidents.title: Russia halts Lithuanian dairy imports before EU summit

incidents.content: Between 2012 and 2015, the Russian government Fund for the Legal Protection and Support of Russian Federation Compatriots Living Abroad contributed funding to pro-Russia NGOs in Lithuania. Lithuania's State Security Department described the Fund's activity as a national security threat, as it supports organizations which coordinate with the Russian embassy to "discredit the Baltic states internationally and encourage ethnic disharmony at home," according to Re:Baltica. The fund also reportedly provided support to local affiliates of the "World Without Nazism" (WWN), an organization that Latvian intelligence services describe as "subversive 'Russia influence organization,'" according to the Daily Beast.
incidents.title: Russian government fund provide support for "subversive" Russian NGOs to expand influence in Lithuania

incidents.content: Discussions of possible Chinese investment to expand the port of Klaipeda have been halted in 2019 after the Lithuanian government expressed opposition. President Gitanas Nauseda noted that "we still don’t have specific (…) investors who would be acceptable in terms of all national security criteria," during a 2019 visit to the port. Lithuanian Defense Minister Raimundas Karoblis more explicitly added that "[Lithuania] can't afford that China controls Klaipeda port," especially in the context of any threat to NATO military access in a crisis. Chinese interest in the project, specifically from China Merchants Group, a state-linked shipping conglomerate, extends as far back as 2011, when the first Chinese cargo trains began transiting the country. The expansion project - estimated to cost roughly 800 million euros - would have formed part of Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative to link trade and investment across Eurasia with political dependence on China.
incidents.title: Lithuanian government rejects Chinese investment bid to expand Klaipeda port over security concerns

incidents.content: In November 2010, South Korean company KEPCO unexpectedly withdrew its proposal to invest in a nuclear power plant construction project in Lithuania. The withdrawal came two weeks after Russian President Dmitry Medvedev visited South Korea and signed multiple economic and energy deals. In the wake of the withdrawal, several Lithuanian officials expressed concern that Russian officials may have actively discouraged KEPCO from investing in the nuclear plant in order to maintain Lithuanian dependence on Russian electricity.
incidents.title: Lithuanian officials express concern that the Russian government may have pressured foreign investors to withdraw from a potential energy project in Lithuania

incidents.content: In summer 2010, money from Rosneft share sales was transferred to and from accounts in Lithuanian Ukio Bank in operations that indicated money laundering. The accounts were owned by Putin's associate Sergei Roldugin. The largest shareholder of Ukio Bank was Lithuanian citizen Vladimir Romanov, who was accused of embezzling 25 million euros from the bank and in 2014 was granted asylum in Russia in order to avoid extradition to Lithuania on embezzlement charges. Another shareholder, Vladimir Antonov, is a Russian national who also held a stake in Lithuania's Snoras Bank. Ukio Bank was placed in administration due to financial troubles, and is alleged to have been used for suspicious transactions by an associate of Vladimir Putin as part of the Panama Papers investigation. The case demonstrated that corrupt businessmen in Lithuania could be used to assist Kremlin in moving money outside of Russia and that they could later count on receiving Moscow's backing so that they would not have to face punishment for their illicit financial activities.
incidents.title: Money from Rosneft share sales transferred to and from Roldugin-owned accounts in Lithuanian Ukio Bank

incidents.content: On January 21, 2009, Belarusian President Aleksandr Lukashenko signed a deal with Russian state-controlled nuclear power equipment and service exporter Atomstroyexport to build a contentious nuclear plant along the Lithuanian border. France’s Areva CEPFi.PA and Westinghouse-Toshiba also bid on the project; however, Atomstroyexport was the only company that offered Belarus financing for the project – a credit line of up to $10 billion to build the plant. This deal further increased Moscow’s leverage over Belarus, a country that is almost entirely dependent on Russian energy. Additionally, it allowed Russia to supply Lithuania, which had recently stopped importing Russian gas, with low-cost energy, further increasing its dependence on Russia. As described by Lithuania's Energy Minister Zygimantas Vaiciunas, “Our reliance on Gazprom has ended, now it’s Rosatom. When you stop one weapon, Russia tries another one.” According to the Atlantic Council, Russian-made nuclear power plants rely on imports of specialized parts and fuel from Russian state-owned companies, thereby making the host country entirely dependent on the Russian government for the plant's continued functionality.
incidents.title: Belarusian President Lukashenko announces the decision to move forward with Russia-led construction of a nuclear plant near Lithuanian capital

incidents.content: In July 2006, Russian state-controlled oil pipeline company Transneft closed down the section of the Druzhba pipeline supplying the Mazeikiu oil refinery in Lithuania. The closure was allegedly due to repairs, but Lithuanian officials accused the Russian government of closing the pipeline to punish the Lithuanian and Latvian governments for refusing to sell their stakes in the refinery to a Russian state-controlled company. As a result, the refinery was forced to import crude oil supplies by ship and rail, significantly hurting profitability. The Russian government often cites commercial reasons, such as repairs or unpaid debt, when disrupting energy or goods flows for political purposes. Energy security expert Agnia Grigas described the shutdown as a part of Russia's "political vendetta against Vilnius."
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Transneft closes oil pipeline for "repairs" after Lithuania rejects Russian bid to purchase oil refinery

incidents.content: In April 2021, a Hungarian investigative outlet revealed that the $1.5 billion construction of a new Budapest campus for Shanghai's Fudan university was to be funded via a 10-15 year loan from a Chinese state-bank to the Hungarian government. By way of reference, Hungary's entire budget for higher education was $1.3 billion in 2019. Hungarian authorities intend to use the loan to hire the state-owned Chinese State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSES), despite its sub-market value bid for the project and a track record of fraud and corruption. CSES was most notably sanctioned and blacklisted by the World Bank in 2009. Fudan University is a public university in Shanghai. In December 2019, it amended its charter to remove mentions to "academic independence and freedom of thought" and add a pledge to follow the Communist party's leadership. It also opened an intelligence college in 2011.
incidents.title: Hungary to take out $1.5 billion loan from Chinese state bank to finance Budapest campus for Fudan university

incidents.content: Hungarian Finance Minister Mihály Varga announced in April 2020 that the Chinese government had agreed to provide a loan for Hungary's portion of the proposed Budapest-Belgrade high-speed rail project, estimated to be at least $2 billion. However, the Hungarian government also classified documents describing the precise contents of the loan agreement as a state secret for a 10-year period. The 20-year loan will be provided by the Export–Import Bank of China, one of the Chinese institutional banks in charge of implementing state policy. The loan should cover roughly 85% of the funding for the rail project, with the Hungarian government funding the remaining 15% and paying annual interest of at least 2.5%. The investment represents a significant portion of the Chinese state's One Belt, One Road initiative, and may eventually link up with other Chinese projects, such as the refurbished Greek port of Piraeus, that aim to secure greater Chinese economic and geostrategic leverage in EU markets.
incidents.title: Hungarian government conceals details of Chinese loan backing Budapest-Belgrade rail project

incidents.content: Executives from Chinese telecommunications firm Huawei were granted a meeting with Hungarian Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó after the company donated medical supplies to Hungary's efforts to combat COVID-19. Hungarian media suggested that the meeting, nominally to thank the company for the donation, actually concerned Huawei's continued access to the Hungarian market. In November 2019, the Hungarian government had announced that Huawei would take part in the country's 5G network. In addition, Huawei's largest plant outside of China is located in Komarom, Hungary. U.S. and European officials have raised concerns about potential Chinese Communist Party access to data via technical and legal "backdoors" embedded in Huawei's infrastructure. Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: Huawei uses medical donation to secure meeting with Hungarian officials

incidents.content: On December 16, 2019, the Hungarian Minister for Innovation and Technology of Hungary and the rector of Fudan University signed an agreement in Shanghai to establish the first foreign Fudan campus in Budapest. The campus is slated to open in 2024 and the agreement raised concerns that Beijing's economic leverage and political influence could harm academic freedom for future students at the institution. Comments from Levente Horváth, a top advisor to Hungary's central bank and a vocal backer of the agreement, that Chinese faculty would train new professors, and that some Chinese professors serve as members of "state economy advisory boards," suggest that the CCP's ideology may be spread further into Hungary's civil society discourse. Lastly, Horváth noted that Chinese companies might pursue research collaboration with the Fudan campus in Budapest, meaning the new campus will be a platform for increased ties between the Chinese and Hungarian economies.
incidents.title: New Chinese university campus in Budapest looks to leverage economic, political influence

incidents.content: In 2019, Hungarian and Chinese partners in Opus Global, a holding company under the control of Viktor Orban ally Lorinc Meszaros, won the contract for construction of Hungary's portion of the proposed Budapest-Belgrade rail project. The deal is worth at least $2.1 billion, though the Hungarian government approved a measure classifying details of the project. An Opus Global subsidiary, RM International Zrt., maintains a 50% stake in CRE Consortium, which was granted the tender. Meszaros himself has a 37% share in Opus and remains the largest shareholder. State-backed entities China Tiejiuju Engineering & Construction Kft. and China Railway Electrification Engineering Group Kft own the other half of CRE Consortium, and Beijing has partnered with both Hungary and Serbia on the project's financing. The project has already been delayed for years, and EU authorities had opened an infringement procedure against Hungary back in 2016 over alleged noncompliance with procurement regulations, though no formal penalty was imposed.
incidents.title: Chinese money flows to friend of Hungarian PM Orban in contract for Budapest-Belgrade railway

incidents.content: On December 6, 2017, Hungarian law enforcement charged Bela Kovacs, a member of the European Parliament from the far-right Jobbik party and an observer at the illegitimate Crimean referendum, with spying on the EU for Russia. The evidence against Kovacs reportedly includes the use of forged private documents, secret meetings with Russian diplomats through frequent trips to Moscow, inconsistent financial reporting, and the potential defrauding of the European Parliament of as much as 25,000 USD, according to Reuters.
incidents.title: Hungarian member of the European Parliament and far-right Jobbik party is charged with spying for Russia

incidents.content: In February 2017, Ukrainian hacktivists leaked emails revealing that Russian-government connected oligarch Konstantin Malofeyev was funding the efforts of Belarusian pro-Kremlin activist Alexander Usovsky to organize protests and support pro-Kremlin political groups in Central and Eastern Europe. Usovsky allegedly transferred funds to the Hungarian right-wing party, Jobbik, as well as to the paramilitary organization "Magyar Gárda." Malofeyev, who is under EU and U.S. sanctions for support of pro-Russian separatists in Ukraine, allegedly demanded that Usovsky supply “a clear, concrete and realistic plan for the coming to power of pro-Russian forces” to secure further funding.
incidents.title: Russian-connected oligarch passes funds to far-right Hungarian party and paramilitary organization through middleman

incidents.content: In 2017, the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, a Beijing-based research entity with state backing, opened a China-Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) Institute in Budapest. The institute studies perceptions of the Belt and Road Initiative and China's wider engagement with the region. However, the institute's offers of grants for joint research projects note that "one Chinese institution shall serve as the leading party," and a secretariat based in the Chinese Foreign Ministry oversees the grant program for European scholars. A report by European experts suggest that the Hungarian Academy of Science backed away from a fully joint venture, and the Chinese side ended up operating the institute alone, as a nonprofit.
incidents.title: State-backed Chinese think tank opens in Budapest

incidents.content: A China-backed think tank in Budapest, the China-Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) Institute, appears to emphasize events and content favorable to the Chinese Communist Party, potentially functioning as a vector to launder propaganda. Despite European concerns over ongoing human rights violations in Xinjiang (where minority Muslim Uighurs face mass detentions) and elsewhere, the institute's 2019 forum celebrated bilateral relations between the Chinese state and European counterparts. Moreover, the event was co-hosted by the Pallas Athene Innovation and Geopolitical Foundation, an organization under the Central Bank of Hungary, which has sought financing from Chinese sources via Belt and Road Initiative infrastructure projects. On the academic side, China-CEE Institute research findings reportedly need to be translated to Chinese, grants for joint research projects note that "one Chinese institution shall serve as the leading party," and a secretariat based in the Chinese Foreign Ministry oversees the grant program for European scholars. In 2017, the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, a Beijing-based research entity with state backing, opened the institute after the Hungarian Academy of Science backed away from a joint venture.
incidents.title: Outputs of China-backed think tank in Budapest seek to soften Beijing's image to Europe

incidents.content: According to Politico, Russian Embassy officials enlisted the help of a Chechen named Magomed Dasajev to pressure a Hungarian activist into publicly apologizing for throwing paint on a Soviet memorial. The Chechen posted a video of himself in a Budapest café with the activist, who later claimed that the Russian-backed Chechen threatened him and his family. The Russian Embassy denied any knowledge of Dasajev’s actions, although an embassy spokesman did mention that the embassy called on members of a Facebook group that included the Chechen and discussions of his plans asking them not to engage in unlawful activities.
incidents.title: Russian embassy official reportedly pressures Hungarian activist to publicly apologize for vandalizing Soviet memorial

incidents.content: In fall 2016, Hungary's national security committee revealed that Hungarian neo-nazi Istvan Gyorkos “openly trained with Russian diplomats and men dressed in Russian military intelligence uniforms.” Gyorkos was also the founder of the Russian-domain website Hidfo.ru, which distributed pro-Russia disinformation across the Hungarian media landscape. Gyorkos was the leader of the Hungarian neo-Nazi National Front movement (MNA) and in October 2016, engaged in a shootout with the Hungarian police and was taken into custody due to his connections to Russian military intelligence (GRU) officials.
incidents.title: Hungarian officials reveal ties between Hungarian neo-Nazi group and Russian military intelligence officers (GRU)

incidents.content: In February 2015, Russia offered Hungary a heavily discounted and lenient payment deferment plan for natural gas deliveries following a visit from President Vladimir Putin and repeated praise from Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban. According to Western media, the visit was symbolically important for Putin, as it demonstrated Moscow's continued influence within the EU despite sanctions and conflict in Ukraine. In regards to Hungary's increasingly close relations with Russia, Orban stated that the EU has "shot itself in the foot" by sanctioning Russia and cutting trade, and that "security in the region cannot be created against Russia. Europe's unity can and must be created alongside Russia."
incidents.title: Russia offers Hungary lenient payment deferment plan for natural gas following President Putin's visit to the country

incidents.content: In December 2014, Chinese, Hungarian, and Serbian officials reached an initial agreement to fund a rail project linking Budapest and Belgrade. After preliminary discussions the previous year, the signing ceremony took place at the China-Central and Eastern Europe (China-CEE) Summit in Belgrade, and details of the design were agreed on in 2015. Originally touted as ready for operation by 2017, the project has instead run into numerous logistical, financial, and political delays, and remained incomplete in 2020. The investment, with precise figures fluctuating but assessed in the billions of euros, represents an early and ambitious portion of the Chinese state's One Belt, One Road initiative, and was expected to eventually link up with other Chinese projects, such as the refurbished Greek port of Piraeus, that aim to secure greater Chinese economic and geostrategic leverage in the European market. European Union authorities opened an infringement procedure against Hungary regarding the project's noncompliance with procurement regulations, but no formal penalty was imposed. In 2020, Hungary classified the documents detailing the project's financing by a Chinese state bank for ten years.
incidents.title: Hungary and China reach initial agreement on Budapest-Belgrade rail project

incidents.content: In December 2014, the Hungarian government under Prime Minister Viktor Orban confirmed a deal with a subsidiary of Russian state-controlled nuclear power company Rosatom to significantly expand the Paks nuclear power plant in December 2014. The deal included a $10.8 billion loan from Russia to help finance the project. Prior to the deal being finalized, the Hungarian parliament passed a new bill that removed the requirement for public competition for such projects and extended the official secrecy of the project terms to 15 years. Opposition officials criticized the bill and the deal and accused Orban of making “secret deals” with Russia that compromise Hungary’s sovereignty and cede influence to Russian energy. According to Reuters, Zoltan Illes, a former lawmaker in Orban's Fidesz party, stated that the deal was merely "camouflage," and that "for the Russians this is buying influence." According to the Atlantic Council, Russian-made nuclear power plants rely on imports of specialized parts and fuel from Russian state-owned companies, thereby making the host country entirely dependent on the Russian government for the plant's continued functionality.
incidents.title: Hungary signs non-transparent nuclear deal with Russian state-controlled firm

incidents.content: In September 2014, following a meeting with Alexey Miller, the CEO of Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom, Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban cut off the flow of gas from Hungary to Ukraine. Orban stated shortly after the meeting that "Hungary cannot get into a situation in which, due to the Russian-Ukrainian conflict, it cannot access its required supply of energy." Russia previously imposed energy sanctions on Ukraine and threatened to cut off gas to any European country that re-exported gas supplies to Ukraine to help it cope with the sanctions.
incidents.title: Hungary suspends gas supplies to Ukraine under pressure from Moscow

incidents.content: Russian government-linked disinformation site, Hidfo.net, published an article claiming that Hungary was transferring T-72 tanks to Ukraine. Officials from the Russian Foreign Ministry used the article as evidence that Hungary was providing lethal military aid to Ukraine. Hidfo.net was founded by Istvan Gyorkos, the leader of the Neo-Nazi National Front Movement (MNA). Gyorkos maintained close ties to Russian intelligence operatives, according to Hungarian intelligence officials.
incidents.title: Russian government-linked website spreads false information regarding Hungarian tanks in Ukraine

incidents.content: In May 2014, Alexey Miller, the CEO of the Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom, met with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban and called for a shortened timeline for the construction of the South Stream gas pipeline due to the conflict in Ukraine. The South Stream pipeline would deliver Russian gas to Europe via the Black Sea, isolating Ukraine and further expanding Russian energy influence over Europe. The U.S. government and numerous energy experts have spoken out against new Russian gas pipelines to Europe, as they threaten Europe's energy security by making it more dependent on Russian gas imports.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Gazprom CEO encourages development of South Stream pipeline to isolate Ukraine and increase European energy dependence on Russia

incidents.content: In March 2009, Russian government-connected oil company Surgutneftegaz bought a 21 percent stake in Hungarian energy company MOL. In the past, MOL had repelled attempts by foreign competitors to gain control over the company. Surgutneftegaz was Russia's 4th largest oil producer in 2015, according to Investopedia. The Guardian reports that Surgutneftegaz maintains close ties to the Russian government, with some experts claiming that Russian President Vladimir Putin owns as much as 37 percent of the company. According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Kremlin Playbook, Russian foreign direct investment in Europe targets strategic companies in the energy sector to expand its dominance of the industry, specifically referring to this purchase of a large stake in MOL.
incidents.title: Russian government-connected oil producer purchases large stake in Hungarian energy company

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right="" type="legacy"][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

An interview with one of the Hungarian founders of Budapest's largest Confucius Institute suggests that the entity's Chinese government support does affect decisions and content. Confucius Institutes are language and culture centers run by the People’s Republic of China’s Ministry of Education, which are hosted in more than 500 universities globally. Critics have raised concerns about incidents of infringement upon intellectual freedom at some Confucius Institutes, whose terms of agreement are often hidden. A former head of propaganda for the Chinese Communist Party has called them "an important part of China’s overseas propaganda set-up." Gergely Salat, who helped open the Confucius Institute in Budapest's Eötvös Loránd University in 2006, admitted when discussing the Chinese vice-directors that they "do infuence them and inform Hanban [Confucius Institute governing body] what goes on." He also said that "official meetings were just one part of the process. I believe the key was personal contacts and background talks," potentially raising concerns that the already opaque language in Confucius Institute governing documents may provide even less protection than anticipated for academic freedom.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Co-founder of Confucius Institute in Budapest admits Chinese officials influence decision-making

incidents.content: In September 2000, Hungarian energy company MOL bought an increased stake in Hungarian chemical producer TVK in order to block Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom from gaining a controlling stake in TVK. Gazprom had recently acquired a 24.7 percent stake of TVK's largest shareholder BorsodChem. Gazprom executives acquired the shares through a cutout, the Irish-registered offshore company "Milford Holdings." The Independent reports that Gazprom was seeking to gain control over TVK's extensive pipeline network.
incidents.title: Hungarian oil and gas company blocks Russian state-controlled company's attempt to control Hungarian pipelines

incidents.content: On March 18, 2021, the Finnish intelligence services (Supo) publicly announced that the APT31 group was behind a 2020 cyber espionage operation aimed at the Finnish Parliament. The cyber intrusion had been reported in December 2020 but had been spotted several weeks earlier. As a result of the attack, the security of a number of parliamentary email accounts was compromised, some of which belonged to MPs. In its March 2021 announcement, Supo stated that the cyber attack had been "state-run." While Finnish intelligence did not mention China by name, several cybersecurity firms have linked APT31 to the Chinese government.
incidents.title: Finnish security service attributes cyberattack against the Parliament to a Chinese state-affiliated group

incidents.content: According to Markku Mantila, then-Head of the Finnish government's communications department, in mid-2016 the Russian government led a targeted disinformation campaign at the Finnish public. Mantila stated that false news stories, misleading statements, and pro-Russian online activity took aim at Finnish independence and sought to warn the country against joining NATO. Some of the narratives questioned the historical legitimacy of Finland's independence from the Soviet Union and represented Finnish independence leaders as Nazi collaborators.
incidents.title: Finland faces anti-NATO information operation

incidents.content: In September 2015, Finland recorded an unprecedented influx of migrants entering the country via two border crossings located on the Finnish-Russian border. EU and Finnish officials expressed concern that Moscow orchestrated the migrant crisis by directing migrant flows into Finland to extract concessions from Helsinki and to apply pressure on Helsinki to normalize the two countries’ bilateral relationship. Experts argue that migrants could not cross into Finland through Russia without the assistance of Russian security services, as migrant routes traverse zones of military interest in Russia’s northwestern corridor and therefore remain under constant state supervision. Finland reinstated ministerial-level meetings with Russia in 2016 after a multi-year hiatus to resolve the migrant crisis.
incidents.title: Russian government directs unprecedented number of migrants into Finland

incidents.content: In August 2015, cybersecurity firm Trend Micro attributed a cyberattack on the communication servers of Finland's largest media group Sanoma to the Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hacking group known as Fancy Bear, or APT28. The same attack attempted to compromise the email account of Finnish investigative journalist Veli-Pekka Kivimäki, a member of Bellingcat who was investigating the conflict in Ukraine.
incidents.title: Russian GRU-connected hackers launch attack on Finland's largest data communications group

incidents.content: In 2014, after publishing an investigative report concerning the Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency (IRA), Finnish journalist Jessikka Aro became the subject of a Russian media campaign that attacked her character and mental stability. Johan Backman of the Moscow-based Russian Institute for Strategic Studies (RISS) served as the source for much of the content about Aro that circulated in the Russian media. According to The New York Times, RISS is "a state-funded research group led by a Soviet-era intelligence officer." According to the U.S. Department of Justice, the IRA is "a Russian organization engaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes." Evgeniy Prigozhin, "a Russian oligarch who is closely identified with Russian President Vladimir Putin," provides funding and support for the IRA
incidents.title: Finnish journalist who reported on Russian government-connected Internet Research Agency targeted by information operation

incidents.content: "In 2014, the government of Montenergo entered into a contract with Chinese state-owned company China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) for the construction of a 169 km highway connecting Bar on the Adriatic in Montenegro to Bojare in Serbia. 85 percent of the project's estimated $1.1 billion cost is covered by a loan from the state-run Exim Bank of China. This represents approximately 21 percent of Montenegro national GDP. Two feasibility studies conducted by a French and an American company determined that the highway’s traffic would not be enough to justify its costs. The Financial Times reported in April 2019 that the loan agreement allowed Exim bank to potentially seize Montenegrin land should the country fail to service its debt in time. In addition, any dispute arising from the loan is to be settled in an arbitration court in Beijing, placing Montenegro at a clear disadvantage. The Montenegrin government has most of the documents associated with the highway’s construction as secret."
incidents.title: Chinese state-financed highway endangers Montenegro's sovereignty

incidents.content: In April 2017, Bellingcat reported that "Russian State-backed leadership" had taken over the Montenegro Organisation of Russian Speakers, creating the “Balkan Federation of Russian Speaking Organizations” (BaFro). According to Bellingcat, “BaFRO now operates as a pro-Kremlin organisation and is partnered with bodies including Rossotrudnitchestvo, RISI and Russkiy Mir.” According to Bellingcat, BaFro leaders Aleksey Galitsky and Veniamin Striga are representatives of Deputy Chairman of the Russian State Duma Sergey Zheleznyak. In a Meduza article, Striga claimed that his organization has the approval of the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Aleksey Galitsky is also the top ranking member of the Russian government-connected Night Wolves biker gang in Montenegro. In 2014, the U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned the Night Wolves, which it describes as "closely connected to the Russian special services", due to their support for Russia-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine.
incidents.title: "Russian State-backed leadership" converts group for Russian speakers into pro-Russia instrument

incidents.content: In March 2017, three months before Montenegro officially joined NATO, the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and a state-sponsored media outlet spread disinformation painting the country as dangerous and Russophobic, according to RFE/RL. On March 25, Russian state-sponsored meda outlet Zvezda ran a story about Montenegro under the headline “Crime, minefields and tetanus: why Montenegro has become a danger for tourists.” The following month, Russian Foreign Ministry’s spokeswoman Maria Zakharova accused Montenegro of inflaming “anti-Russian hysteria” and warned that Russians "may expect provocations and detentions” in the country. According to RFE/RL, tourism is a major industry in Montenegro, and Russian tourists typically account for one-third of all summer-holiday visitors to the country. The Montenegrin Foreign Ministry responded by pointing out the absence of reports of harassment and classified the efforts as “nothing but manipulation and the continuation of a media war that Moscow has been waging against Montenegro, aimed at blocking its accession to NATO."
incidents.title: Russian government and state-sponsored media spread disinformation about Montenegro ahead of NATO accession

incidents.content: Cybersecurity firms Fire Eye, Trend Micro, and ESET found that Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, launched at least three separate Cyber Operations in January, February, and June 2017 against Montenegro’s Ministry of Defense, other government and state institutions, and pro-government media outlets. According to Pierluigi Paganini, member of the European Union’s Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA), the information gathered “points directly to the Russian APT28 group … In June 2017, after Montenegro officially joined NATO, the attacks continued; experts at the security firm Fire Eye who analyzed them collected evidence that confirmed the involvement of Russia’s APT.”
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear targets Montenegro's government and media outlets with cyber attacks

incidents.content: On October 16, 2016, the day of Montenegro’s parliamentary elections that returned to office pro-EU and pro–NATO Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic of the Democratic Party of Socialists, a series of Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks targeted several media and government websites, including those of the Democratic Party of Socialists of Montenegro, elections watchdog the Centre for Democratic Transition, and mobile carrier T-kom. According to Business Insider, “the pattern of attacks - news media, party websites, and NGOs - would suggest an attempt to stifle the flow of information in the run-up to the election.” While the Montenegrin government stopped short of formerly implicating the Russian government in the attack, security firms such as FireEye and Trend Micro have stated that they possess evidence linking Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected Fancy Bear, or APT28, to ongoing Cyber Operations in the country.
incidents.title: DDoS attacks halt Montenegrin institutions during parliamentary elections

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Before Montenegro acceded to NATO in June 2017, the Russian government perpetrated a failed coup and assassination attempt against then-Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic on the eve of Montenegro’s parliamentary elections on October 16, 2016. Bratislav Dikic, a former Serbian gendarmerie commander working under the direction of Russian military intelligence agency (GRU), and in concert with leaders of the pro-Russian Montenegrin opposition alliance (Democratic Front), “was to lead a group of around 20 insurgents, disguised as Montenegrin police officers, to occupy Montenegro’s parliament and open fire on protesters on election night.” Russian intelligence officers hoped that the violence would allow the Democratic Front to take control of the government and bring Montenegro’s NATO membership bid to a halt. According to the Montenegrin government’s indictment, Russian GRU officers covertly funneled $200,000 to the operation to purchase weapons and encrypted telephones to carry out the coup.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian operatives plan an unsuccessful coup in Montenegro

incidents.content: According a 2018 minority staff report by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and NBC News, leading up to the October 2016 Montenegrin parliamentary election, the Russian government secretly funded opposition parties and aligned media outlets and “influencers” to undermine the pro-NATO party. The Russian government also "launched a coordinated disinformation campaign using traditional and social media to allege widespread voting irregularities." Social media networks were inundated with complaints, leading the Montegrin government to temporarily shut down WhatsApp, Viper and similar messaging apps, furthering election-day confusion.
incidents.title: Russian government secretly funds anti-NATO parties and aligned media outlets to influence Montenegrin elections

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

Between September 1-12, 2015, the Russian government-connected Night Wolves biker gang visited the Russian embassy in Podgorica, Montenegro and met with Russian Ambassador to Montenegro Sergey Gritsai as part of the “Russian Road” bike tour. According to the Night Wolves’ website, the group considered creating a pilgrimage center alongside the Russian cultural-information center in Podgorica. According to Bellingcat, “Rather than simply being commemorations or benign events, (these processions) are partly about spreading ideas of a Russian historical claim to territories based on religion and ethnicity.” In 2014, the U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned the Night Wolves due to their support for Russia-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. The Treasury Department described the group as "closely connected to the Russian special services."

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian government-connected Night Wolves visit Montenegro as part of "Russian Road" tour

incidents.content: Ukraine-based hacking group CyberJunta published emails that expose efforts from known Kremlin false-flag operation planner Alena Sharoykina to order novelist and Russian operative living in Belarus Alexandr Usovsky to "leak" information about the visit between Kremlin officials and Republika Srpska Serbian seperatist candidate Milorad Dodik. According to Bellingcat, Sharoykina ordered Usovsky to leak to Polish sources the news that Konstantin Malofeyev, a Russian oligarch and Putin associate active in Russian interference measuers abroad, and Milorad Dodik met secretly, implying that the Malofeyev's visit was to oversee the Russian Cossack troupe. He was to hypothesize that the Cossack dancers were actually Russian Special Forces ("Spetznaz") present in RS to conduct a Crimea-like scenario in case Dodik lost the election.
incidents.title: Kremlin operatives ordered a disinformation campaign in Republika Srpska on its 2014 election day

incidents.content: Ukraine-based hacking group CyberJunta published emails between Russian officials detailing the Kremlin's outline for its influence campaign in Republika Srpska. The emails prioritize Milorad Dodik's victory and his promises for a secession referendum for the ethnic Serbian entity from Bosnia. According to Bellingcat, the emails predicted that a secession would destabilize Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia, which would lead other predominantly Orthodox countries like Bulgaria, Romania, Macedonia, and Greece to a re-orient themselves toward Russia.
incidents.title: Hacked emails outline Russia's national interest in interfering in Republika Srpska elections

incidents.content: In September 2014, outspokenly pro-Russian Republika Srpska President Milorad Dodik, who supports RS independence from Bosnia, met with Kremlin officials a month ahead of the election. The Kremlin published a meeting summary detailing that Putin announced support for RS presidential candidate Milorad Dodik, and that Gazprom signed an agreement with RS to link the republic to the South Stream pipeline. The agreement bypassed official channels of the central government of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
incidents.title: Gazprom signed an agreement with the Republika Srpska (RS), bypassing the central government of Bosnia and Herzegovina

incidents.content: On October 2, 2014, a memo released by the Border Police of Bosnia and Herzegovina announced the entry of 144 Russian men dressed in Cossack uniform in Republika Srpska (RS). Photographs revealed that among the Russian nationals was Nikolai Djakonov, who led a paramilitary Cossack unit in Crimea a few months prior. The troupe arrived during a tense period, just weeks before a Bosnian election in which nationalist, pro-Russian RS leader Milorad Dodik declared his intent to hold a secession referendum for territorial independence from Bosnia if elected. Bellingcat notes that the behavior of the Cossack troupe reflected that of the "polite people" who arrived in Crimea weeks before the annexation.
incidents.title: Over 100 Cossacks are sent to Republika Srpska (RS) ahead of the Bosnian elections

incidents.content:
[fusion_builder_container type="flex" hundred_percent="no" equal_height_columns="no" menu_anchor="" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" class="" id="" background_color="" background_image="" background_position="center center" background_repeat="no-repeat" fade="no" background_parallax="none" parallax_speed="0.3" video_mp4="" video_webm="" video_ogv="" video_url="" video_aspect_ratio="16:9" video_loop="yes" video_mute="yes" overlay_color="" video_preview_image="" border_color="" border_style="solid" padding_top="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" padding_right=""][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type="1_1" layout="1_1" background_position="left top" background_color="" border_color="" border_style="solid" border_position="all" spacing="yes" background_image="" background_repeat="no-repeat" padding_top="" padding_right="" padding_bottom="" padding_left="" margin_top="0px" margin_bottom="0px" class="" id="" animation_type="" animation_speed="0.3" animation_direction="left" hide_on_mobile="small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility" center_content="no" last="true" min_height="" hover_type="none" link="" border_sizes_top="" border_sizes_bottom="" border_sizes_left="" border_sizes_right="" first="true"][fusion_text]

On March 20, 2018, members of the Russian government-connected Night Wolves biker gang entered Republika Srpska (RS), a semi-autonomous region within Bosnia and Herzegovina that has previously called for secession from the country. The Night Wolves traveled to the region "funded with a grant from the Kremlin," according to The New York Times. The bikers visited several churches in Banja Luka, the administrative center of RS. About a week prior, Bosnia's central government banned Night Wolves' leaders Aleksandar Zaldostanov and Sasa Savic from entering the country citing them as threats to national security. Bosnian officials alleged the tour aimed to intimidate non-Serbs in the country. In 2014, the U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned the Night Wolves due to their support for Russia-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. The Treasury Department described the group as "closely connected to the Russian special services."

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Russian government-connected biker gang visits Republika Srpska on Kremlin-funded tour

incidents.content: On December 16, 2017, Republika Srpska-based gas company Gas-Res signed a deal with Russian state-controlled Gazprom to build a liquefied natural gas plant in the town of Zvornik in Republika Srpska. The project, financed by Gazprom, was estimated to cost around $82 million. According to Reuters, the project was an assertion of Republika Srpska's ability to pursue an energy policy independent of the rest of Bosnia. The political leadership of the Republika Srpska entity is pro-Russian and resists Bosnia and Herzegovina's Euro-Atlantic integration.
incidents.title: Bosnian gas company forms joint venture with Russian state-controlled Gazprom to build an LNG plant

incidents.content: According to Balkan Insight, in October 2015, Republika Srpska’s (RS) Alliance for Change opposition bloc accused RS Prime Minister Zeljka Cvijanovic and Finance Minister Zoran Telgetija of accepting a $300 million loan from Florida-based Global Bancorp Commodities & Investment Inc. without National Assembly approval. That company had only been around for a year and had no other business dealings. The company’s manager, a Russian citizen named Alexander Vasiliev, negotiated the loan with Dodik in October 2015 at an international investment forum in Moscow where Vladimir Putin was a keynote speaker. RS is a semi-autonomous region with an anti-NATO platform that has repeatedly called for its secession from Bosnia.
incidents.title: Republika Srpska officials accused of accepting $300 million loan from opaque Russian source

incidents.content: On November 27, 2008, Bosnia and Herzegovina's sole oil refinery reopened under Russian ownership in Bosanski Brod, a town in Republika Srpska. Russian state-controlled oil company Zarubezhneft purchased the refinery, which shut down in 2005 due to damage sustained in the Yugoslav Wars, and the Russian Development Bank funded its reconstruction. According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Kremlin Playbook, Russian foreign direct investment in Europe targets strategic companies in the energy sector to expand its dominance of the industry.
incidents.title: Bosnia and Herzegovina's sole oil refinery reopens under Russian ownership

incidents.content: Vitaly Milonov, a vehemently anti-LGBT Russian legislator, opened a "Russian human rights center" in Mitrovica without registering it. Milonov explained that the purpose of the organization is to aid the city's ethnic Serbian population. Milonov does not recognize Kosovo's statehood, and claims that ethnic Serbians living in Kosovo are subjected to a "real genocide" under the rule of "Islamic-Albanian occupiers and Turkish fascists."
incidents.title: A Russian legislator illegally opened a "Russian human rights center" in Mitrovica

incidents.content: Police arrested a Russian employee of the UN Mission in Kosovo for attempting to block a police operation against a Serbian-run crime syndicate. The Russian Foreign Ministry defended the employee, accused his counterparts of attacking him, and denounced the incident as a "provocation." Kosovo's President Hashim Thaçi said the Russian UN employee was "camouflaged under a diplomatic veil to hamper the police operation."
incidents.title: A Russian UN employee in Kosovo was arrested for attempting to foil a police operation

incidents.content: In October 2017, the Kosovar Centre for Security Studies (KCSS) released a report revealing that Russian state-sponsored media outlets RT and Sputnik had attempted to deteriorate French-speakers’ opinion of Kosovo, perhaps due to the location of UNESCO’s headquarters in Paris. Kosovo began weighing a second UNESCO bid in February 2017 after a 2015 attempt failed partially due to concerns over Kosovo’s inability to protect Serbian religious and cultural heritage sites in its territory. According to The Guardian, a successful UNESCO bid would have marked a significant step in Kosovo’s campaign for international recognition. Additionally, the KCSS study reported that both the Russian and Serbian Orthodox Church (SOC) believed that UNESCO membership for Kosovo would have represented a “transfer of the SOC monuments in Kosovo to those that destroyed them,” referring to the destruction of UNESCO heritage sites in the 1999 NATO bombing campaign and in further 2004 unrest involving Kosovo Albanians. According to the report, the French language line of effort was part of a much larger disinformation campaign targeted at the predominantly Serbian northern population of Kosovo that aimed to turn Kosovo Serbs against the state.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media attempt to influence international perceptions of Kosovo

incidents.content: In April 2017 in an interview with Radio Free Europe, Deputy Foreign Minister of Kosovo Valon Murtezaj accused the Russian Government of attempting to influence Kosovo through biased and inaccurate media coverage. Burim Ramadani of the Research Center for Security Policies reaffirmed the claims, asserting that the Russia government spreads disinformation in an attempt to undermine Kosovo's favorable view of the West. Ramadani said that the strongest Russian influence efforts were aimed at Kosovo's Serb community.
incidents.title: Kosovar Deputy Foreign Minister reveals Russian disinformation campaign in Kosovo

incidents.content: Following coverage of the COVID-19 outbreak critical of the CCP in the Romanian press, the Chinese embassy in Bucharest published two scathing statements on its website. The first one named Romanian media such as Kanal D television and Republica.ro and accused them of "misleading people." The second, explicitly titled "Stop the slander of China immediately," was even more forceful and condemned Romanian articles where it deemed that "facts have been replaced by rumors, and science by imagination, full of mistakes and confusions, seriously violating the principle of objectivity of the press and professional ethics of the media." Romanian media were taken aback by the tone, accusing the embassy of asking them "to behave like the [media] in communist China: loyal to Beijing, critical of Europe and the U.S."
incidents.title: The Chinese Embassy in Bucharest criticizes the Romanian press on COVID-19 coverage.

incidents.content: In 2013, Wang Yan had his Romanian citizenship withdrawn on national security grounds following a recommendation from the Romanian Intelligence Service (SRI). But in October 2017, supported by the Chinese embassy in Bucharest, Hong Kong-based company Merlion Resources was represented by Wang Yan and granted the entire production of copper concentrate from Cupru Min, a Romanian state-owned company running Romania's only operational copper mine. Under the terms of the contract, 100% of Romania’s current copper production is now sent to China. According to investigative journalists, the Chinese Embassy supported Merlion Resources, accompanying a company delegation to the Romanian Economy Ministry. Subsequent investigations revealed that Wang and a Chinese diplomat paid a working visit to Cupru Min ahead of the October 2017 deal without proper approval from Romanian authorities.
incidents.title: Company represented by Chinese businessman whose Romanian citizenship was withdrawn on national security grounds wins tender for the production of a Romanian state-owned copper mine

incidents.content: On June 27, 2017, at least three large companies in Romania were affected by the NotPetya cyberattack that struck companies and institutions all across Europe and the United States. Ukraine's security service reported on July 1, 2017 that Russian security services were involved in the attacks. In June 2018, the U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned five Russian firms and three of their executives in response to the NotPetya Cyber Operations and other campaigns.
incidents.title: Romanian companies hit by costly GRU-conducted NotPetya cyberattack

incidents.content: On April 19, 2017, the Russian government-funded Russian Center for Culture and Science in Bucharest opened a photo exhibition on the war in Syria. According to Corina Rebegea from the Center for European Policy Analysis, the exhibition offered a “chronicle of war” in Syria, presenting a pro-Russian perspective of the conflict just weeks after a devastating chemical weapons attack by the Russian-supported Syrian government.
incidents.title: Russian government-funded cultural center launches photo exhibition promoting Russian narrative of war in Syria

incidents.content: During anti-government protests in Romania in February 2017, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik spread disinformation regarding the nature of the protests, referring to them as the "Euromaidanization of Romania" and alleging that they were organized by Hungarian-American philanthropist George Soros, according to the Center for European Policy Analysis. Pro-Russian Romanian media outlets adopted similar rhetoric and conspiracy theories.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet spreads disinformation regarding anti-government protests in Romania

incidents.content: On September 15, 2014, Russian state-controlled enery giant Gazprom threatened to cut gas deliveries to Romania by ten percent. On September 16, Romanian Energy Minister Razvan Nicolescu accused Gazprom of threatening to manipulate its supply of gas to Romania in the event that Romania supported proposed sanctions on Russia over the annexation of Crimea. Gazprom gave no reason for the planned reduction.
incidents.title: Romanian energy minister accuses Russia of manipulating gas supplies for political ends

incidents.content:

Several Romanian officials, including Prime Minister Victor Ponta, alleged that protests against Chevron’s purchase of land in Pungesti, Romania in December 2013 were organized and funded by the Kremlin. Vlasa Mircia, the mayor who approved the deal and sold the land, was shocked by the protests that ran him temporarily out of town, saying, “we never had protests here and suddenly they were everywhere.” The Romanian officials who accused Russia of involvement pointed to Russia’s interest in maintaining its energy monopoly over Europe. According to The Financial Times, advocates of shale gas suggested that Russia was using the Orthodox Church in Romania to shape public opinion, stating that priests led some of the protests.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Romanian officials accuse Russia of funding protests against shale gas

incidents.content: On January 17, 2019, Facebook announced that it removed several hundred accounts and pages from Facebook and Instagram that originated in Russia for "coordinated inauthentic behavior" targeting citizens in post-Soviet states and Central and Eastern Europe. According to the Atlantic Council's Digital Forensic Research Lab, the activity, which began in 2013, "represented a systematic, covert attempt to improve  Rossiya Segodnya's online audience across more than a dozen countries €¦ Sputnik was the main beneficiary." The activity was designed to build relationships with social media users based on their special interests in order to develop audiences for Russian government-linked disinformation. The network included Sputnik employees who amplified Sputnik content but hid their affiliation. The first operation, which targeted Ukraine, involved 26 pages, 77 accounts, 4 Groups, and 41 Instagram accounts that shared local news stories to hundreds of thousands of followers. The second operation, which targeted the Baltics, Central Asia, the Caucasus, and Central and Eastern Europe, involved a network of 289 pages and 75 accounts that included numerous pages focused on general interest topics such as tourism, sports and politics. According to CNN, the accounts and pages spent around $135,000 on ads on Facebook between October 2013 and January 2019. Facebook's head of cybersecurity policy, Nathaniel Gleicher, stated in a post "We identified some technical overlap with Russia-based activity we saw prior to the US midterm elections, including behavior that shared characteristics with previous Internet Research Agency activity."
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media use inauthentic social media network to target Baltics, Central Asia, the Caucasus, and Central and Eastern Europe

incidents.content:
