In February 2022, after the Irish Department of Foreign Affairs hosted an Uyghur leader at a meeting, the Chinese embassy in Dublin urged Irish politicians to stop spreading “lies on Xinjiang and support for terrorist and separatist activities.” The action follows Irish media reports that Irish media reports, the Chinese diaspora in Ireland is not safe from CCP surveillance and persecution, where people face attacks upon their freedom of speech. Chinese supporters of the Hong Kong democracy movement, as well as people from places like Xinjiang or Tibet, and their families are at risk if they draw the CCP’s attention. If their advocacy is discovered, Chinese activists may be fired from jobs at Chinese companies. Even if they are no longer Chinese citizens, they may struggle to get a visa to re-enter the country to see their families, who have to sign a statement that their relatives abroad will not "destabilize the motherland and disturb social harmony." If they are still Chinese citizens, returning home can be even more dangerous. In addition, for Irish residents from Xinjiang or Tibet, catching the attention of the CCP comes with particular risks. A computerized surveillance system in Chinese consulates and embassies flags Uighurs and Tibetans for scrutiny upon entrance. Just the fact that they left can be taken as a signal that their family is not loyal to China, and they may be sent to re-education camps.

[/fusion_text][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
incidents.title: Chinese authorities monitor and threaten Chinese diaspora in Ireland

incidents.content: Chinese state-run Tsinghua and Southeast Universities have entered into research partnerships with Trinity College Dublin, University College Cork, and University College Dublin. The research partnerships are in drone technology and artificial intelligence. Experts fear that this research could be used to further monitor and oppress political opponents and the ethnic minorities in China. Both of these subjects are dual use and, with the Chinese partner institutions being state-run, any new intellectual property produced by the partnerships can be commandeered by the PLA. Furthermore, both the Chinese universities have a history of cybercrime and espionage. In 2015, software from Southeast University was tied back to Chinese state-affiliated hacking group AFT17. In addition, a 2018 report by cybersecurity company Recorded Future accused Tsinghua university of cyber-attacks on governments, international organizations, and NGOs after the IP addresses of the attackers linked back to the university.
incidents.title: State-run Chinese universities accused of cybercrimes partner with Irish universities to conduct dual-use research

incidents.content: The partially state-owned Chinese companies Hikvision and Dahua provide surveillance equipment used throughout Ireland, including sensitive political and security locations, such as the Irish parliamentary building, Leinster House, and police stations. Both companies were banned in the 2019 NDAA over concerns about backdoor vulnerabilities, as well as for their role in supplying surveillance equipment used to oppress Uighurs in Xinjiang.
incidents.title: Chinese companies involved in Xinjiang repression provide cameras for sensitive locations in Ireland

incidents.content: During May 2016, British energy companies and other critical infrastructure were targeted, reportedly by hackers connected to Russia’s military intelligence agency (GRU). The attack targeted energy networks running the national grid in the Republic of Ireland, which also covers Northern Ireland. Security analysts believe the hackers intended to access control systems using a massive spear phishing operation. Emails disguised as job applications and complaints were sent to engineers who had access to the control systems. While no disruption was caused, according to British media, "a number of Industrial Control System engineering and services organisations are likely to have been compromised."
incidents.title: Russian GRU-connected hackers target the Republic of Ireland's national energy grid, which also covers Northern Ireland

incidents.content: On July 11, 2017, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik falsely reported that Ireland was considering leaving the European Union because of the EU's new tax harmonization plan, which would standardize corporate and income tax policies in European Union countries. Ireland worried the policy would damage competition and therefore vowed to oppose the initiative, but never claimed to consider leaving the European Union over the issue. According to EU vs Disinfo, the Sputnik article failed to provide any evidence of this claim beyond citing the spokesman of the group "Ireland Exit," a group that EU vs Disinfo was unable to locate and thus substantiate its existence.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet falsely reports that Ireland is considering leaving the European Union

incidents.content: Chinese state security has pressured members of the Uighur community abroad to spy on dissident groups, threatening them with the prospect of having their families in Xinjiang sent to reeducation camps should they not comply. Buzzfeed News interviewed a Uighur man based in Turkey whose son was detained by police in China; PRC operatives asked that he provide information on Uighurs in Turkey, and in return he would receive news about his son. Tamir Imin, a member of the Uighur community living in the United States, told Buzzfeed that he had been contacted several times by state officials, refused to cooperate, and has been consequently unable to reach his family in Xinjiang. Those interviewed by Buzzfeed said that the surveillance campaign "aimed not only to gather details about Uighurs' activities abroad, but also to sow discord within exile communities in the West and intimidate people in the hopes of preventing them from speaking out against the Chinese state".
incidents.title: PRC intelligence threatens overseas Uighurs' families if they don't spy on dissidents

incidents.content: On April 3, 2018, construction began on the $20 billion Akkuyu nuclear power plant in southern Turkey. Rosatom, the Russian state-controlled nuclear power company, owns a 51 percent stake in the project. According to researchers, the power plant is a means of deepening Russia's energy links with Turkey, which already imports more than half of its natural gas from Russia. According to the Atlantic Council, Russian-made nuclear power plants rely on imports of specialized parts and fuel from Russian state-owned companies, thereby making the host country entirely dependent on the Russian government for the plant's continued functionality.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled company begins construction of nuclear power plant in Turkey

incidents.content: On May 7, 2017, Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom began construction of the TurkStream pipeline to bring Russian gas to Turkish and European consumers, replacing the failed South Stream pipeline project. The pipeline would allow Russia to become less reliant on Ukraine as a transit country when exporting gas to Europe. Turkey views the pipeline as a chance to become a regional oil and gas hub. The United States government and numerous energy experts have spoken out against new Russian gas pipelines to Europe, as they threaten Europe's energy security by making it more dependent on Russian gas imports.
incidents.title: Russia begins construction of TurkStream pipeline

incidents.content: Over the weekend of July 30, 2016, Russian state-sponsored media outlets RT and Sputnik reported "false stories of the U.S. airbase at Incirlik being overrun by terrorists," according to the Daily Beast. Pro-Russian trolls and bots on social media, along with other news outlets, quickly picked up and amplified the stories with conspiracy theories spreading about U.S. nuclear missiles at the base. In reality, the articles misreported "a small protest gathered outside the Incirlik gate," of which American authorities had previously been notified.
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlets falsely reports that Turkish police are surrounding the U.S. airbase in Incirlik

incidents.content: On July 25, 2016, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik published a story titled "Massive Fire Near NATO Base in Turkey, Possible Anti-American Sabotage." Other Russian state-sponsored outlets, such as RT, picked up on the story. However, as NATO spokeswoman Oana Lungescu explained, "there was a forest fire at some distance from the base, but with no connection to it.” She noted that “NATO has been dealing with a significant increase in Russian propaganda and disinformation since Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014.”
incidents.title: Russian state-sponsored media outlet spreads disinformation regarding a fire near a NATO base in Izmir

incidents.content: On December 14, 2015, at least 400,000 Turkish websites were hit by a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) cyberattack that many believe was sponsored by the Russian government due to its timing, degree, and method. The attack came less than a month after a Turkish fighter jet shot down a Russian warplane on November 24. The attack lasted several days and brought significant financial losses to Turkish businesses and delayed official business. Only ten days later on December 24, a number of Turkish banks were hit by the attacks, preventing customers from accessing online banking.
incidents.title: Cyberattack attributed to Russia impacts Turkish websites and financial institutions

incidents.content: Between late-July 2015 and mid-November 2016, researchers from Secure Works investigated an operation by Bronze Union, a Chinese cyber-attack group "likely located in the People's Republic of China." The hacker group compromised a website to deliver a malicious executable to potential victims. According to the Secure Works, the primary target was the Turkish government, five Turkish banks and two academic networks. Secure Works researchers consider that the PRC-based cyber group Bronze Union "is likely to view Turkey as a potential target for political and defense intelligence gathering" especially because the country is a NATO member and U.S. ally. CTU experts said that, since 2016, the cyber group are continuously using extensive tools and intrusion methods to achieve their aims.
incidents.title: Chinese cyber-attack targets several institutions in NATO ally Turkey

incidents.content: Information security service firm Secureworks indicated that Russian military intelligency agency (GRU)-connected hacker group Fancy Bear, or APT 28, attempted to gain access to the correspondence of senior Orthodox religious leaders in Turkey. The targets included top aides to Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I. Bartholomew I possesses final decision making authority to deny or grant Ukraine’s petition to separate from the Russian Orthodox Church. Russian state-sponsored media outlets, such as Sputnik and RT, frequently promote disinformation to undermine Ukraine’s petition to form its own church.
incidents.title: Russian military intelligence agency (GRU)-connected hackers attempt to access correspondence of senior religious leaders in Turkey

incidents.content: In June 2018, Chinese state-owned company Hisense acquired 95% of the shares in Slovenian household appliance maker Gorenje. In April 2019, Hisense acquired the company for 339 million USD, the largest Chinese acquisition in the country to date. Since then, the deal has been consistently referred to by all advocates for closer ties between China and Slovenia. For instance, in June 2020, the Chinese ambassador mentioned the acquisition at the very beginning of an interview he gave Slovenian media about the excellent ties between both countries. In October 2020, a business group advocating for Huawei's continued participation in Slovenia's 5G roll-out similarly alluded to the Hisense acquisition as one of the "strategically important investments in Slovenia." Under PRC law, Huawei is obligated to participate in national intelligence work, has been credibly accused of cooperation with PRC intelligence agencies, and is owned ultimately by a trade union entity likely controlled by the CCP.
incidents.title: China uses state-owned Hisense's purchase of appliance giant Gorenje to exert influence in Slovenia

incidents.content: On July 16, 2018, the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP) reported that Russian businessman Ivan Savvidi funneled at least €300,000 to various groups in Macedonia that opposed the referendum to change the country's official name to "North Macedonia." The move would have opened the door to NATO and EU membership for Macedonia. Savvidi, based in Greece, sent the money to Macedonian politicians, members of nationalist organizations, and soccer hooligans who participated in riots against the agreement. According to The New York Times, U.S. officials “intercepted communications” in June 2018 that proved that Savvidi was working against the referendum on Russia’s behalf.
incidents.title: Russian businessman funds opponents of Macedonia's name change

incidents.content: On March 1, 2017, pro-Russian Macedonian President Gjorge Ivanov, a member of the nationalist VMRO-DPMNE party, stated that he would not give his backing to a majority coalition government formed by social democrat leader Zoran Zaev and parties from the country’s ethnic Albanian minority. A day later, EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini visited Macedonia’s capital, Skopje, to prevent a political crisis. Russia’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs then accused the West of forcing Macedonians to accept an “Albanian platform,” which would help Albania take over “vast regions” in the Balkans. Simultaneously, Russian state-sponsored media outlet Sputnik published inflammatory headlines such as “NATO Willing to See ‘Blood in Streets of Macedonia’ for Greater Albania Project.”
incidents.title: Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and state-sponsored media outlet spread disinformation to undermine Macedonian government

incidents.content: In June 2017, a leak of classified reports by Macedonian counterintelligence revealed that Serbian and Russian intelligence had orchestrated "a nearly decade-long effort" to spread propaganda and destabilize the country "as part of a region-wide endeavor to stop Balkan countries from joining NATO." According to the report, these activities began in April 2008, when Greece blocked Macedonia’s efforts to join NATO due to the long-running dispute over the country’s name. Macedonian counterintelligence accused Russian agents of attempting to "influence and offer funds to Macedonian media outlets... in order to spread 'information and disinformation.'" The documents showed that operations were directed from the Russian embassy in Skopje by three SVR agents, as well as four GRU agents based out of the Russian embassy in Skopje, whose activities were coordinated from a GRU base in Sofia, Bulgaria. Others implicated included local representatives from Russia’s state-sponsored media outlet TASS, and Rossotrudnichestvo. Rossotrudnichestvo is a government-organized non-governmental organization (GONGO) founded in 2008 by President Medvedev as a means to advance Russia’s political and economic interests. According to the Marten’s Centre, it “officially propagandizes the Russian political position.”
incidents.title: Leaked documents reveal Russian intelligence agencies (SVR and GRU) orchestrated a 9-year propaganda campaign in Macedonia

incidents.content: According to The Guardian, between 2008-2017 Rossotrudnichestvo, a Russian government-organized non-governmental organization (GONGO), worked with state-sponsored media outlet TASS and Russian intelligence agencies as part of a nearly decade-long influence effort that sought to distance Macedonia from the EU and NATO and to prevent the success of the Macedonian name change referendum.
incidents.title: Rossotrudnichestvo collaborates with Russian intelligence in Macedonian influence campaign

incidents.content: According to Mother Jones, in March 2017, Albania’s right-wing Democratic Party of Albania (DPA) hired American lobbyist Nick Muzin to promote the DPA in the United States and globally. Biniatta Trade, a Scottish firm that was formed by two Russian-owned shell companies based in Belize, paid Muzin for his work with the DPA. At the time of the agreement, the DPA was challenging the ruling pro-EU government in parliamentary elections. Although it could not confirm who directed the payments, Mother Jones expressed concern that "a Russia-connected source" funneled funds through a shell company "to help the Democratic Party of Albania and to fuel the ongoing political discord in Albania."
incidents.title: Mother Jones alleges unidentified Russian source supported right-wing Albanian party through shell companies

incidents.content: In February 2017, Russia's domestic intelligence service (FSB) introduced a new security zone along the Russia-Belarus border. The Russian government framed the move as necessary to guard Russia from terrorists who could potentially enter the country through Belarus after Belarus instated a visa-free regime with more than 80 countries, including EU members. Belarusian President Lukashenko said the move looked like a "political attack," stating “Russia has become wary that Belarus could turn to the West.”
incidents.title: In response to Belarus' visa liberalization policy, Russia introduces new border security zone

incidents.content: In the fall of 2016, according to Coda Story, Russian state-sponsored media, such as "government-run entities like the First Channel and Regnum news agency," engaged in an aggressive propaganda campaign against Belarus and its president Aleksandr Lukashenko. The campaign started after Lukashenko attempted to improve the country's relations with the EU, implement a visa-free regime for citizens of European countries, and rebutted Russia's attempts to establish a military base in Belarus. Some of the narratives included claims that Belarus was becoming a fascist state like Ukraine, that the Belarusian language was inferior to Russian, and that Lukashenko was ready to betray Russia.
incidents.title: Russia wages aggressive propaganda campaign against Belarusian president Lukashenko

incidents.content: In July 2016, Russia's state-controlled pipeline company Transneft reduced oil flows to Belarus ostensibly because of a dispute over mounting debts for gas payments. However, according to Reuters, the real reason for the decrease of the supply was Belarusian president Aleksandr Lukashenko's attempts to mend the country's relations with Europe and reluctance to participate in the Eurasian Economic Union, which Russia has pushed as its alternative to the European Union. Lukashenko's pivot to the West was prompted by fears that the Ukrainian situation could repeat itself in Belarus. Transneft’s actions were an attempt to coerce Lukashenko to change his position. Russian state-owned companies, in particular Gazprom, have often allowed their customers to accumulate debt without objection, only to leverage that debt subsequently for political purposes.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Transneft reduces oil flows to Belarus

incidents.content: Between 2015 and 2017, the Russian private military company ENOT Corp established paramilitary training centers for young Belarusians. The attendees of the camps were indoctrinated with pro-Russian, nationalistic, and xenophobic ideas. ENOT Corp has operated these camps for several years and recruited young people from separatist regions like Transnistria and South Ossetia. According to the Jamestown Foundation: "Moscow could use the graduates of these training centers to destabilize the situation in Belarus while maintaining some level of plausible deniability." While ENOT Corp claims to be an independent organization, Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty reports that they are an ultranationalist group whose members have fought alongside separatists in the Donbass region of Ukraine. ENOT was reportedly founded by former Russian special operations officers.
incidents.title: Russian private military company trains Eastern European youths in paramilitary camps

incidents.content: In June 2010, Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom slashed gas flows to Belarus, nominally for unpaid debts amounting to nearly $200 million. The Christian Science Monitor contends that the move stemmed from the Russian government's dissatisfaction with Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko's reluctance to join the Russian-led Eurasian Economic Union. Although unpaid debts were used as justification for the cuts, Gazprom has regularly allowed its customers to accumulate debt without objection, only to later leverage that debt for political purposes.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Gazprom decreases gas supplies to Belarus

incidents.content: In July 2009, Belarusian news site Charter97.org experienced Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. The Register reports that "the attacks follow increased political tension between Belarus and Russia... Alexander Lukashenko, the president of Belarus, has accused the Russians of punishing his country for failing to recognize the independence of rebel-held regions of Georgia." According to the report by Arbor Networks, Jose Nazario, manager of security, said the attacks were similar to the ones used against Georgian government websites during the Russo-Georgian war in 2008.
incidents.title: Belarusian media websites experience Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks similar to those perpetrated by the Russian government in Georgia

incidents.content: On March 23, 2017, The Wall Street Journal reported that former Russian spy Leonid Reshetnikov delivered a document in 2016 detailing a strategy for Bulgaria’s presidential campaign to Korneliya Ninova, leader of the pro-Russian Bulgarian Socialist Party. The document allegedly instructed the party to plant disinformation, claim that the polls were rigged, call for an end to the Russia sanctions, talk up Brexit, and criticize NATO.
incidents.title: Former Russian spy delivers document to Bulgarian officials advocating for the use of disinformation to discredit election

incidents.content: On February 23, 2015, Voice of America reported that Russian state-controlled Gazprom was accused of successfully blocking shale gas exploration in Bulgaria through a shadowy but well-funded Russian campaign to protect its regional energy dominance. According to The New York Times, Bulgaria banned fracking in 2012 and canceled a shale gas license that had been issued to Chevron. Former U.S. and European officials and energy experts outlined an effort by which Russian officials, working with foreign consultancies in Brussels, financially supported anti-fracking activities in several European countries. According to Margarita Assenova, an analyst at the Jamestown Foundation, “at least two Brussels-based consultancies allegedly transferred funds to several Bulgarian environmental groups through local corporate structures connected with Russia. The assets initially went through Overgas, Gazprom’s Bulgarian subsidiary, and the lobby supporting Russian nuclear energy projects. Both have been used in the past to promote Gazprom’s interests.”
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Gazprom accused of blocking shale gas exploration in Bulgaria

incidents.content: In May 2014, Bulgarian media reported that declassified documents indicated officials from Russian state-controlled energy giant Gazprom sent a letter to the state-owned Bulgarian Energy Holding company advising the company on how to amend laws to benefit Gazprom's interests in Bulgaria. Gazprom supplies nearly 97 percent of Bulgaria's gas demand, according to a report by the Center for Strategic and International Studies.
incidents.title: Russian state-controlled Gazprom advises Bulgarian state-owned energy company on amending energy laws

incidents.content: In 2013, pro-Russian Bulgarian political party Ataka increased its influence in the Bulgarian parliament by joining the governing coalition for the first time. Ataka maintained close ties to the Russian government, with the party's leader Volen Siderov accepting a medal from the Russian Duma for fostering cooperation between the two countries. A leaked diplomatic cable also revealed that the Russian Embassy in Bulgaria maintains close links with Ataka, even steadily funding the party's activites. According to the Financial Times, former Bulgarian government officials have alleged that the Russian government also supplies funds to Ataka through the Sofia branch of Russkiy Mir, a Russian cultural foundation.
incidents.title: Pro-Russian Ataka party reportedly receives funding from the Russian Embassy

incidents.content: In April 2015, the Russian Foreign Ministry released an extensive report on what it called the rise of neo-Nazism in Europe, the United States, and Canada. The report falsely accused the Croatian government of persecuting Serbs in Croatia by forcing Orthodox Christians to convert to Catholicism on a large scale. According to BalkanInsight, the idea of forced religious conversion to Catholicism is a highly sensitive issue and calls to mind the fascist regime of Ante Pavelic during World War II, which forced thousands of Serbs to convert to Catholicism. The Serbian Orthodox Church in Croatia denied Russia’s claims about mass forced conversion.
incidents.title: Russian Foreign Ministry falsely accuses the Croatian government of persecuting Serbs and forcing them to convert to Catholicism

incidents.content: A donation of $425,000 to the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) was masked through two loopholes. First, rather than paying money directly to the party, it was sent to the German Ifo Institute as payment for their preparation of the party's economic program used in a 2015 election. Second, it flowed through several foundations, including one tied to energy companies that are themselves connected to a woman who is a close friend of the head of the party and whose money came from an endowment headed by Russian citizen of Ukrainian origin Oksana Dvynskikh, who according to Finnish authorities has close ties to Russian state bank Sberbank through various energy companies she represents.
incidents.title: Croatian political party's campaign expenses are funded through foundations by Russian sources of unclear origin in 2015
